A striking example of the ever-present violence black Americans face are the reports that police violence leads to the death of a black man once every 28 hours in cities all across the US. ‚ÄúWe as a nation do not like to talk about slavery in the north, our 12 presidents who owned slaves, or our legal system that continues to legitimate racial disparities,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIn the American imaginary, the south is a backwards place, consumed by its bigoted ways.‚Äù According to Barron, we need to understand that racism isn‚Äôt only slavery or Jim Crow laws, but it‚Äôs more systemic than these instances. And we need to understand that the entire foundation of the US is built on a racial hierarchy that has always said that white is better than black ‚Äì not just in the south. Once we understand this, we can then begin to do the work to stop racism as a whole without trying to lay blame to an area of the country, which she thinks is just a form of complicity. However, in light of the recent mass shooting in Charleston, South Carolina, it‚Äôs fair to not be able to shake the idea that the south is more violent in its racism. A larger number of hate groups are also active there.
‚ÄúThe density of hate groups in the south has typically been thicker than other parts of the country,‚Äù Heidi Beirich, director of the Intelligence Project at the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC) told the Guardian. ‚Äú[But] it‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs just a ‚Äòsouth thing‚Äô ‚Äì there are a lot of hate groups on the coasts as well.‚Äù The SPLC is the leading organization in the US that represents victims of hate crimes. The organization also tracks all hate groups through their Hate Map, which noted 784 active groups in 2014. According to Beirich, when it comes to the most violent hate in America, there is no southern or northern divide ‚Äì rather it‚Äôs a national problem that is typically being led by what she calls ‚Äúlone wolves‚Äù. ‚ÄúFor the most part, nowadays the violent acts that have taken place ‚Äì including the shooting that took place in Charleston ‚Äì are mostly locals. Sometimes they‚Äôve been involved in hate groups, sometimes they haven‚Äôt. [But] they mostly are people getting radicalized on the internet and choosing to do this stuff on their own.‚Äù Beirich says such crimes are the result of people digging deep and being influenced by forums and websites such as StormFront.org, which has over 300,000 registered white nationalists. In other words, the internet is now the problem. While she acknowledged that people on sites like StormFront.org should have their first amendment rights supported, she also feels that it‚Äôs the responsibility of businesses to not make money off messages that could influence others like Dylan Roof, for ‚Äúhate propaganda leads to hate violence‚Äù. Roof exemplified this in his online manifesto, where he wrote: ‚ÄúWe have no skinheads, no real KKK, no one doing anything but talking on the Internet. Well someone has to have bravery to take it to the real world, and I guess that has to be me.‚Äù In his interview with Marc Maron, Obama said: Racism, we are not cured of it. And it‚Äôs not just a matter of it not being polite to say ‚Äònigger‚Äô in public ‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs not just a matter of overt discrimination. Societies don‚Äôt overnight completely erase everything that happened 200-300 years prior. As the US hopefully begins to work to realize what the president points to, and Confederate flags begin to come down in Columbia, South Carolina, and maybe Mississippi, many of us will all begin to realize, like I did in 2008, that no matter where you live in the US, racism remains ‚Äì even if the flags come down.

column4: French police clash with migrants as ferry strike causes chaos in Calais
column5:
Migrants and police were engaged in an uneasy standoff on the motorways around Calais on Wednesday, as groups of young men tried to exploit the continuing disruption to climb on trucks bound for the UK. Several hundred lorries were still queueing on the main roads leading to the ferry port and Eurotunnel, following Tuesday‚Äôs strike by French ferry workers. On the motorway above the main migrant camp ‚Äì home to 3,000 people ‚Äì there were regular skirmishes in the afternoon. Each time a queue of lorries formed, the migrants ‚Äì many of whom have fled war and persecution in the Middle East and east Africa ‚Äì abandoned what they were doing and ran up the bank to try and break into them.
French police tried to stop them and at one point officers drew their batons and hit out at a group of young men before using pepper spray on them. Watching from the edge of the camp, Teddy, 20, from Eritrea said it had been a very difficult 24 hours. ‚ÄúLots and lots of people have been trying because of the lorry queues and some of them have made it, but it is very dangerous. The police have been very aggressive and many people have been injured trying to jump on the underside of lorries.‚Äù An Afghan man nearby held out his injured hand and said a police dog bit him last night. ‚ÄúAre there any doctors?‚Äù he asked. ‚Äú Many people have been hurt but what else to do? We have to keep trying because this is no place to stay.‚Äù
In the UK, the home secretary, Theresa May, said British and French authorities had stopped ‚Äúsignificant numbers‚Äù of migrants climbing aboard lorries in Calais and entering the UK in the last two days. She said the UK border force had put in place ‚Äútried and tested‚Äù contingency plans to deal with chaotic scenes that led to the Channel tunnel being closed. David Cameron moved to ease tensions with France over the migrant crisis in Calais, calling for an end to the finger pointing over who is to blame and signalling that Britain is prepared to contribute more resources if necessary. The prime minister described ‚Äútotally unacceptable scenes‚Äù in Calais.
Asked what Britain was planning to do about the crisis, Cameron said it must work more closely with the French, tackle the people-smuggling gangs in north Africa and do more to make the UK a less attractive place for migrants. The mayor of Calais, Natacha Bouchart, told French radio on Tuesday that Britain had ‚Äúnot offered a penny‚Äù to help the authorities in Calais ease the pressure caused by the increasing number of migrants arriving in the town, as they attempt to travel to Britain. But Cameron, speaking in the House of Commons on Wednesday, struck a conciliatory tone. ‚ÄúThis is a strong partnership that we have in place and we should keep it that way.‚Äù He said the UK would provide more security assistance to French authorities if necessary, including sending more personnel and sniffer dog teams. He also said more needed to be done with other EU countries to prevent migrants from attempting the journey to Europe in the first place. ‚ÄúThirdly, we‚Äôve got to do more to make sure Britain is a less easy place for illegal migrants to come to and work in. That‚Äôs what our immigration bill is all about.‚Äù
The heightened diplomatic tension came amid disruption caused by striking employees of the French firm MyFerryLink, whose industrial action forced the closure of the Channel tunnel and led to the cancellation of train and ferry services. Travel chaos was subsiding on Wednesday as cross-Channel services resumed but authorities in Calais continued to grapple with desperate migrants seeking to take advantage of the disruption. One group of young men ‚Äì some as young as 15 ‚Äì were chased away by a lorry driver as they tried to break into hisvehicle. ‚ÄúThis is terrible, worse than it‚Äôs ever been,‚Äù said the driver from Poland, as the queue inched forward. ‚ÄúIt has been like this all night, it has been very difficult.‚Äù Another migrant managed to break the cord on the back of a nearby truck and was trying to clamber on board before he was confronted by the French driver. Neither man wanted to talk. A 17-year-old Eritrean man sitting by the side of the motorway slip road said he and his friends had been up all night trying to get into lorries bound for the UK. ‚ÄúMany people have been trying, but it is very difficult. We are very tired now.‚Äù Emmanuel Agius, a deputy at Calais town hall, claimed that the British PM was in danger of sparking a diplomatic incident. ‚ÄúDavid Cameron says he does not want these migrants, he doesn‚Äôt want to take responsibility but the UK is part of the EU and it cannot continue to try and play two roles. ‚ÄúIt is not acceptable to say: we are insular, we are an island and we will only be part of Europe how and when we want ‚Äì you Europeans just deal with it. That is too easy. If he continues to speak in that way then he is in danger of creating a diplomatic incident.‚Äù
For there to be a lasting solution to the crisis Europe had to work together, and that included the UK, Agius added. ‚ÄúIf the UK and Mr Cameron want to leave Europe, then at least the situation would be clear and precise and in that case the British could have their border back in the UK instead of here in Calais,‚Äù he said. Agius said migrants have ‚Äúone idea in their heads and that is to cross the 30km to Dover for a better life in the UK‚Äù. He said the UK ‚Äúneeds to stop ignoring that reality and take responsibility‚Äù. Additional reporting by Kim Willsher in Paris

column4: Spanish victims of thalidomide meet Pope Francis
column5: As they push forward in their struggle to obtain the kind of compensation given to other victims across Europe, Spanish victims of thalidomide have a powerful new ally: Pope Francis. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre really happy,‚Äù said Alejandro Romero, one of the 100 or so Spanish victims who travelled to the Vatican on Wednesday to meet the pope. ‚ÄúHe promised he would try to help. He‚Äôs the most important diplomat in the world, so maybe he can ring people that won‚Äôt speak to us on the phone.‚Äù An estimated 3,000 Spaniards are believed to have suffered severe birth defects after their mothers took thalidomide, prescribed by Spanish doctors five decades ago to combat morning sickness during pregnancy. Unlike victims in many other countries in Europe, only two dozen victims in Spain have ever received any kind of compensation. Many of them were unable to meet the stringent criteria set out by the drug‚Äôs manufacturer, Gr√ºnenthal, which asks for the bottle of medication taken by their mother decades ago and, at times, the doctor‚Äôs prescription, in order to offer compensation. And unlike other governments in Europe, successive Spanish governments have refused to create a fund for victims. The issue is further complicated by the fact that the use of thalidomide in Spain took place during the dictatorship of General Francisco Franco. It was not until 2007 that the government confirmed that the drug had been sold in the country. Campaigners point to official documents and doctors‚Äô prescriptions to argue that the drug was sold under a variety of names until the mid-1970s ‚Äì some 15 years after doctors in Germany began linking the drug to severe birth defects. It was this story that victims shared with the pope in their brief meeting on Wednesday. ‚ÄúThe pope was really surprised about the lack of protections for victims in Spain,‚Äù said Romero. ‚ÄúHe promised that he would try to intervene and speak with the Spanish government.‚Äù The victims presented him with gifts; a football kit sporting the logo of the group that represents Spanish victims of thalidomide and a copy of the book Dark Remedy, which explores the history of thalidomide. As he prepared to embark on a plane back to Spain, Romero hoped the pope‚Äôs support would mark a turning point in the decades-long struggle of Spanish thalidomide victims for recognition and compensation ‚Äì one that has taken so long, campaigners note, that a third of the victims have already died. ‚ÄúAfter nearly 50 years of near-silence on our case, I think we‚Äôre closer to achieving change.‚Äù

column4: Two Irish students killed in Berkeley balcony collapse buried in Dublin
column5:
The father of an Irish student who died in the Berkeley balcony tragedy has urged the US authorities to ensure a similar tragedy could never happen again. As the burials took place on Wednesday in Dublin of two more victims, it emerged that the Californian town‚Äôs district attorney was considering a fresh investigation into the accident. The district attorney‚Äôs office in Berkeley said it ‚Äúwill begin looking at the matter‚Äù of its own inquiry but stressed that no formal investigation had been launched. Berkeley authorities confirmed that their investigation found the number of people on the balcony during the party was not a factor in its collapse. Dry rot was the only contributing factor, according to Eric Angstadt, director of the city‚Äôs planning and development department.
However, Berkeley‚Äôs mayor confirmed that the police would not be carrying out a criminal investigation into how the balcony supports collapsed, killing six students ‚Äì five from Ireland and one from the US. The families of those who died now only have the option of taking civil action in relation to the tragic incident, which took place last Tuesday during a 21st birthday party at the flat complex. At the funeral of Niccolai Schuster in Dublin‚Äôs Rathgar district on Wednesday, the 21-year-old‚Äôs coffin was flanked by friends wearing the colours of Bayern Munich, the student‚Äôs favourite football team. In a message during the requiem mass, his father, John Schuster, said: ‚ÄúWe have lost our magical son and we are devastated ... Leave no stone unturned in this investigation. This cannot happen again.‚ÄùHe also appealed to other parents not to hold back their children‚Äôs dreams of travelling. ‚ÄúLet your kids go, do not let this deter you. Let them have freedom, it will give them life experience,‚Äù he said. Schuster added that his son had planned to move from California to South America, and had he survived, Niccolai would have travelled ‚Äúon one leg‚Äù to get to that continent. The history and politics student at University College Dublin was a grand-nephew of the writer and playwright John B Keane, and his father said Niccolai loved to read the author‚Äôs stories from County Kerry.
Meanwhile, in Foxrock, South Country Dublin, Grammy-nominated Irish musician Hozier performed an acoustic version of Work Song, one of Olivia Burke‚Äôs favourite songs, at her funeral in the Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Succour on Wednesday afternoon. In his tribute to his daughter, Paul Burke mentioned her cousin, Ashley Donohoe, 22, who was also killed in the accident. ‚ÄúSeparated by over 6,000 miles, they were incredibly close,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúFrom around 18 months old, all the way to recent years when they continued to trade trips to Ireland and San Francisco, none more exciting than the surprise arrival of Ashley to Olivia‚Äôs 18th birthday party. You two guys departed this world side by side, together in God‚Äôs place and may you look down on the rest of us.‚Äù Mass-goers burst into applause when he delivered this final message to his daughter and niece. He said: ‚ÄúYou are not forgotten, loved one, nor will you ever be, as long as life and memories last, we will remember thee. We miss you now, our hearts are sore, as time goes by we miss you more. Your loving smile, your gentle face, no one can fill your vacant place. Olivia Burke, my darling, may you rest in peace.‚Äù The last of the six students killed in the accident, Lorc√°n Miller, 21, will be laid to rest on Thursday, following a funeral service at Rathmichael parish church in Shankill.

column4: The secret world of Isis brides: 'U dnt hav 2 pay 4 ANYTHING if u r wife of a martyr'
column5:
Karen sat in a hotel room in Istanbul, grappling with a difficult decision. She had spent about $3,500 (¬£2,220) on the round trip to Turkey from her home in the US but, when she had bought the ticket, she had had no intention of flying home. The return bookings were for appearance‚Äôs sake. Her SMS mailbox was filled with promises for the future: messages from an Islamic State fighter who had promised to marry her. But as she sat in that Istanbul hotel room, something didn‚Äôt feel quite right. Her prospective groom‚Äôs insistence on absolute secrecy had not seemed strange at first. Karen had met him through the swarm of Isis-friendly social media. They started by chatting on Twitter and Ask.fm, then moved to encrypted messaging apps such as Kik, Surespot and Telegram. Paranoia runs through most of the online interactions ‚Äì no one‚Äôs identity is clear, and anyone could be bluffing. But the hint of danger was part of the glamour and Karen thought she was being careful. She was in her late teens and had recently graduated from high school, where she had been a lonely girl interested in Star Trek and computer programming. She converted to Islam less than a year before her journey, after watching the news and deciding to learn more about the religion. She had been inspired by Isis‚Äôs apparent authenticity ‚Äì they were as far removed from the west as it seemed possible to be. Her Christian parents worried whether she would be safe walking down the street wearing a hijab. She kept her real plans well hidden from them. Online, she disguised her identity by using a kunya ‚Äì a traditional Arab title. Karen had created several of these, but mostly she went by Umm Khalid ‚Äì ‚Äúmother of Khalid‚Äù. The name derived from Khalid bin Walid, a military commander known as the ‚ÄúSword of God‚Äù in the early days of Islam. Umm Khalid was also the name of a Palestinian village that was evacuated in 1948 and swallowed up by the Israeli city of Netanya. The name has its roots in violence inflicted and violence suffered.
When she met the Isis fighter Abu Muhammad online [not his real name; all names in this article have been changed], she took the chance to bring her new identity to life.
As she planned her trip, she asked him to put her in touch with some of the women who had already joined Isis from the west. She wanted to know that she could trust him. He promised that he would, but made an excuse the next time she asked, and the time after that. This made her uneasy, but so did the prospect of delaying the trip. All the other Isis supporters she had met online said that it would only become more difficult and dangerous to get to Syria as time passed. Things weren‚Äôt easy at home: her parents ‚Äúhad a fit‚Äù when she tried to wear a niqab. And so she boarded the plane to Istanbul, hoping for the best. Later, Karen did not like to talk about all the promises Abu Muhammad had made to her: it was embarrassing to think about how naive she had been. He had told her to board the bus from Istanbul to Urfa and make the 18-hour journey alone, as many others before her had done. At the other end he, or one of his friends, would be waiting to hear from her. They would come at once, and would help her to cross into Isis territory immediately. But to her, the plan seemed risky and rushed. He had told her so little. Things came to a head on the final day, when the tone of his texts became more sexual. When she confronted him, he argued that there was nothing wrong with doing, as she later called it, ‚Äúthings‚Äù. They were, he pointed out, just 24 hours from being married. This was not, to Karen‚Äôs mind, how pious and devoted jihadis were supposed to behave. Unlike some girls, who flirted with fighters online, she never obsessed about true love. Marriage was a practical consideration ‚Äì a means to a life with Isis. But she would talk, from time to time, about wanting to be a good wife to a good husband ‚Äì one who behaved like a perfect Muslim. Sexting was not part of the picture.
I later contacted Karen in private on encrypted apps, and eventually she opened up. She had flown home to the US after two days in Turkey (‚Äúwith great photos of Istanbul‚Äù, she added, ‚Äúlol.‚Äù). One final piece of information had clinched her decision to call off the Isis marriage. She had heard about a woman similar to herself being kidnapped in Urfa by the PKK, the Kurdish nationalist group, then arrested. The PKK is listed as a terrorist organisation by the US and the EU, but is also at the forefront of the fight against Isis on the ground. She began to wonder if Abu Muhammad was really who he claimed to be. ‚ÄúTalking to him, I realised that things weren‚Äôt right,‚Äù she said. She became convinced that Abu Muhammad was not from Isis but the PKK. It was by the grace of God, she told me, that she was still alive and free. She had broken no laws, and no longer intended to do so. Others in Isis have since offered to help her to come over, but she trusted no one enough to take the risk. She issued some sharp advice. ‚ÄúBrothers lie to get a wife.‚Äù Like the three schoolgirls from Bethnal Green, Karen was from a lower-middle-class background and had a decent education. Almost all the women I came across looked and sounded not unlike myself at 16. They were conservative Muslim girls, whether they were recent converts or the daughters of Muslims, who took their faith seriously. Although their interpretation of Islam rarely agreed with mine, the women I spoke to were driven in part by religious ideals. But few of these women were willing to engage thoughtfully with a variety of Islamic religious texts, traditions and interpretations. They hated disorder and ambiguity; the clear-cut doctrines issued by jihadist ideologues appealed to their political sensibilities. Opposing the west was their measure of religious authenticity.
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs time for action‚Äô ‚ÄúThe sickest thing I‚Äôve ever done in my life is cross that Turkish border,‚Äù said Umm Umar on Twitter. She was using ‚Äúsick‚Äù to mean ‚Äúgood‚Äù. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never forget that night.‚Äù She was already in Syria and was the widow of an Isis fighter. In our private conversations, she tried to influence me with her single-minded energy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time for action,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúYour EemƒÅn [faith] will get sooo high during the border crossing,‚Äù she promised. ‚ÄúBig adrenaline rush.‚Äù After some thought, she added: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sinful for u to be staying in UK whilst there is a khilƒÅfah [a caliphate].‚Äù Umm Umar was just 16 when we started talking. She was born in Britain but her parents were Bangladeshi. She walked out of her parents‚Äô home in the middle of the night, leaving a letter on her bed explaining her actions. She seemed pleased to be able to share her experiences. ‚ÄúCreep out,‚Äù she told me. ‚ÄúIf u can take out a student loan pls do so.‚Äù What about our religious duty to repay loans? ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she said, without missing a beat. ‚ÄúThe kuffar [non-Muslim] wealth is halƒÅl [permitted] for us.‚Äù
Umm Umar did not enjoy her childhood in Britain. ‚ÄúMan I hated UK so much,‚Äù she told me the first time we spoke. She grew up in a part of the country where there were few migrants, and even fewer Muslims. Other kids often beat her up at school when she was small, she said, and spat at her on the bus when she was older. She was desperately lonely and alienated. Her strongest bond was with her mother. ‚ÄúGive my mother happiness,‚Äù read a prayer she retweeted. ‚ÄúIf sadness still lingers in her eyes, give her whatever happiness is left of mine.‚Äù But Umm Umar‚Äôs sentimentality was shadowed by a violent streak. When I asked her about hurting her parents, she reassured me that it was ‚ÄúhalƒÅl‚Äù. ‚ÄúI did it and I‚Äôm sure everyone else did it,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúRight now we are in a state of war.‚Äù Like most of the girls I spoke to, Umm Umar‚Äôs marriage to an Isis fighter in Syria had largely been a pragmatic affair. ‚ÄúLife without a mahram [close male relative] here can get quite difficult,‚Äù she told me. She had been matched with a fighter who was British Bangladeshi, just like her. His family were even from the same village in Bangladesh, she told me, relishing the coincidence of fate that had brought them together. He had been ‚Äúso so sweet and caring‚Äù, but had been killed just a couple of months earlier. She was now the wife of a shaheed [martyr] and was being honoured. She seemed proud of her husband‚Äôs success, and never spoke a word of grief or sadness. Another western woman in Syria I spoke to ‚Äì Umm Zahra ‚Äì was almost envious when she discussed Umm Umar‚Äôs status. ‚ÄúU dnt hav 2 pay 4 ANYTHING if u r wife of a shaheed,‚Äù she told me. But she was careful not to seem discontented. All women, she promised me, were looked after. ‚ÄúU will still get money each month.‚Äù
Umm Umar had travelled to Syria because she wanted to join a perfect Islamic state. Like the other women, she painted a picture of an Islamic utopia. This was for the sake of propaganda and, I suspected, to reassure themselves that they had made the right decision in going over. To all these women, Isis was simply dawla [state], as if no other country existed or mattered. ‚ÄúU can come here and study btw,‚Äù Umm Umar wrote to me once. ‚ÄúStudy fiqh [Islamic legal interpretations], hadeeth [sayings of the Prophet], medicine, etc.‚Äù I once asked Umm Umar about al-Khansaa ‚Äì the rumoured women‚Äôs brigade that enforces Isis‚Äôs harsh interpretation of sharia law on the women living there. ‚ÄúYes u can do hisbah [join the religious police],‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut if ur married your husband will want u to stay at home lol.‚Äù She added: ‚Äúlots of ajar [reward for good deeds].‚Äù She had taken part in the hisbah patrols after being married, while her husband was away fighting. After he was killed, she had entered the traditional three-month mourning period. She had just a few days remaining when we last spoke, and planned to ‚Äúresume my job inshaAllƒÅh [God willing]‚Äù at the end of it. I asked her, that last time, if she had a happier life in Syria than she had in the UK. ‚ÄúYep I do,‚Äù she answered, adding a smiley face. Karen, the American, also reflected from time to time about a ‚Äúperfect‚Äù Islamic state ‚Äì although she had become more jaded since her decision to return to the US. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm an 18-year-old cynic who still dreams of an Islamic utopia,‚Äù she wrote once, ‚Äúwhich won‚Äôt ever exist on this planet.‚Äù She argued that no ‚Äúgovernment with humans in charge‚Äù could ever avoid corruption and ‚Äútruly implement shari‚Äôah‚Äù. Karen‚Äôs newfound cynicism was rare among the women I talked to, most of whom really believed that they were going to help create an Islamic utopia. ‚ÄúShariah is a perfect system who protects all,‚Äù wrote one female supporter on Twitter, ‚Äúnot just about cutting hands and stoning fornicators ‚Ä¶ like Saudi.‚Äù Dr Katherine Brown of King‚Äôs College London compares the women who have travelled to Syria to join Isis to ‚Äúindividuals who went out to join the Soviet Union in the 1950s and 60s, who weren‚Äôt looking to fight, but were looking to become new citizens of the Soviet state. What‚Äôs interesting is that they believe it‚Äôs possible ‚Ä¶ Islamic State is saying: ‚ÄòYou can have this perfect world ‚Äì you just need to try a little bit harder.‚Äô‚Äù There is a totalitarian impulse behind this. By joining the state, these women think they will become, in Brown‚Äôs words, ‚Äúperfect people‚Äù. Melanie Smith of the Institute for Strategic Dialogue calls the ‚Äúcaliphate utopian ideal‚Äù one of the common ‚Äúkey pull factors‚Äù that draw women over. They imagine a world in which there is little poverty and inequality, governed with perfect fairness under clear-cut, divine laws that work to the advantage of all. It is a vision that makes no allowances for the ambiguity and variety of traditional Islamic legal interpretations, or for the disorder of real life. But there are also ‚Äúpush factors‚Äù, says Smith, that drive women away from their homes in the west: often loneliness and alienation. Isis propaganda is designed to appeal to people who feel like outsiders in their own homes. ‚ÄúIslam began as something strange and it will revert to being strange,‚Äù reads a hadith [teaching] that is popular among Isis supporters online, ‚Äúso give glad tidings to the strangers.‚Äù ‚ÄòI miss my mum‚Äô Umm Abbas came to my attention when she retweeted some popular advice: ‚ÄúFeeling alone and alienated? Stop sinning.‚Äù When I asked her how she had found life in the UK, her answer was terse: ‚ÄúStress depression‚Äù. She was a British woman in her 20s with Pakistani parents. Where Umm Umar was open and easy to talk to, Umm Abbas was brisk and wary. On Twitter, she talked enthusiastically about her journey to Isis. ‚ÄúThe most amazing ‚Ä¶ experience of my life,‚Äù she wrote, ‚Äúwas crossing with a family of over 10 members who had a newborn baby with them! :)‚Äù Like Umm Umar, Umm Abbas was relentlessly positive about life with Isis. I asked her what happened to girls who found themselves with abusive husbands: ‚ÄúDawla has the best of men,‚Äù she promised, ‚Äúand the shariah court here protects you from all types of violence.‚Äù There was a process, she and Umm Umar explained, for unmarried women to be matched with a husband. After being placed in a maqar [a shared house for ‚Äúsisters‚Äù], a woman writes down what sort of ‚Äúbrother‚Äù she wants to marry. The emir of the area matches her with someone and sets up a brief meeting, after which, if both parties are agreeable, the marriage quickly takes place. ‚ÄúThey will still contact ur dad,‚Äù Umm Abbas told me. But if the woman‚Äôs father refused, the emir would go ahead and marry them anyway.
Chinks of unhappiness sometimes appeared. Umm Abbas‚Äôs marriage was much more difficult than Umm Umar‚Äôs had been. ‚ÄúLife throws all types of trials,‚Äù she wrote to me. ‚ÄúThe biggest is listening n obeying to your husband.‚Äù She wouldn‚Äôt say anything more except that her marriage was ‚Äúsometimes tough‚Äù. She saw this as a test, requiring sabr [patience] on her part. She wasn‚Äôt alone in her unhappiness. Umm Umar would occasionally issue quiet pleas for comfort and reassurance. ‚ÄúI miss my mum ‚Ä¶‚Äù she tweeted once. Umm Zahra shared her jealousy of a possible co-wife, and even of hooris [the famous ‚Äú72 virgins‚Äù that martyrs are said, in jihadist propaganda, to receive in heaven]. I pointed out that the Qur‚Äôan does not actually specify the gender of hooris or of those who receive them, nor restrict them to martyrs. She stopped answering my messages. Complaints about difficulties in daily life were often couched in positivity. ‚ÄúCandlelight dinner with the akhawƒÅt [sisters],‚Äù tweeted Umm Umar, ‚Äú#CozTheElectricityWent #ItsAllPartOfTheStruggle.‚Äù Sometimes complaints were hidden in advice. ‚ÄúNo good makeup,‚Äù Umm Abbas told me, ‚Äún clothes too. I brought 2 suitcases.‚Äù A recent issue of Dabiq, the Isis magazine, addressed itself specifically to the concerns of western women within Isis. The article urged those who had lost their husbands to ‚Äúbe patient‚Äù, and to ‚Äúbe wary of thinking of going back‚Äù. Dawla is not without its doubters, and utopian dreams are not easy to sustain, but few will be able to return home any time soon. ‚ÄúPeople risk their lives to bring you in,‚Äù Karen said to me once. She was still suffering from guilt at being a ‚Äúcoward‚Äù for not going through with her journey to Syria. But she knew that, once there, no Isis fighter would risk his life to get her out again. ‚ÄòDo we not have the right to defend ourselves?‚Äô For each of the estimated more than 500 western women who have travelled to Syria to join Isis, there are more sitting at their computers at home, voicing their support online. Most won‚Äôt make the journey, but they will go about their lives with the quiet fantasy of one day being citizens of dawla. There is a code that Isis supporters use to communicate online. Going to Syria is ‚Äútaking a holiday‚Äù; ‚Äúgreen birds‚Äù and ‚Äúdusty feet‚Äù are references to hadiths about martyrs. A single finger pointing upwards represents the Isis brand of monotheism and a commitment to death and victory. But Umm Kulthum disapproved of all this. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve turned [jihad] into a kind of fad,‚Äù complained a post she shared on Tumblr, warning against ‚Äútrivilising‚Äù violent jihad. ‚ÄúWe hold up our index fingers ‚Ä¶ like we‚Äôre all part of some √ºber-cool club.‚Äù She had other things in common with the various women I spoke to. Many spoke of being constrained by everyday life, and of longing to be part of something bigger. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just live life waiting for the next weekend to come,‚Äù Umm Kulthum wrote once. ‚ÄúYour aspiration should be greater than that.‚Äù She shared one important trait with the bulk of online Isis supporters: a belief that a global war between ‚Äútrue Islam‚Äù and ‚Äúthe kuffar‚Äù was taking place, and that Muslims had to choose a side. Umm Kulthum knew that Isis was associated with brutality. Some of the women I spoke to argued that the violence was exaggerated by the western media. Others defended it by arguing that the kuffar did worse, while a few, including Umm Kulthum, actively relished it. She shared pictures of Isis fighters with guns. In private, she was remarkably sweet and tender. She called me her ‚Äúbeloved sister‚Äù.
She was Libyan but had spent much of her life in England, and received her secondary education in a state school. She had been lonely there, and spent some time on antidepressants. By the time we spoke, she was back in Libya with her parents and siblings, hoping to have the chance to travel to Syria herself. But Britain still loomed large in her mind. It was there that she had been converted from the ‚Äújaahiliyyah‚Äù [ignorance] that she saw in her Muslim parents to ‚Äútrue Islam‚Äù. Umm Kulthum was fixated on stories of Muslim oppression. Her social media accounts were a montage of Muslim suffering ‚Äì Syrian children killed by Bashar al-Assad; Palestinian youths burned alive by Israelis. For Umm Kulthum, this justified almost any brutality in return. She felt all Muslims had a duty to ‚Äúprotect their siblings in Islam‚Äù; she was convinced that only violent jihadists took this seriously. ‚ÄúJihad is our right even as just human beings, not Muslims,‚Äù she said once. ‚ÄúDo we not have the right to defend ourselves?‚Äù For all her hostility to the west, her western education had helped to shape her. Like the other women, she used the language of ‚Äúhuman rights‚Äù and ‚Äúgirl power‚Äù. She shared stories of women in niqabs, with weapons, charging into battle. Special contempt was reserved for Muslims who she thought were colluding with the west by failing to support violent jihad. Such people are known in Isis circles as ‚Äúcoconuts‚Äù ‚Äì brown on the outside, white on the inside. The word has its roots in the anti-colonial movements of the 20th century. When I mentioned I had non-Muslim friends, Umm Kulthum was stern. ‚ÄúHabibti,‚Äù she wrote, ‚Äúdo not take kafir as your friend.‚Äù Umm Umar was pitying: ‚ÄúU have to understand that these kuffar are our enemies,‚Äù she wrote to me. ‚ÄúAnd they will never stop fighting us until we follow their ‚Ä¶ way.‚Äù Others were harsher. After the shootings of three Muslim students in Chapel Hill, North Carolina, Umm Abbas retweeted: ‚Äúand muslims think that the west cares about them. you are a joke by Allah.‚Äù For these women, there is no room for an ambiguous multicultural identity. No Muslim, a recent issue of Dabiq argued, has ‚Äúany excuse to be independent‚Äù of Isis, which is waging ‚Äúwar on their behalf‚Äù. All Muslims in the west must make their choice to either live as ‚Äúinauthentic‚Äù coconuts or to redeem themselves in death. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre a muslim and love democracy???‚Äô Theological ambiguity was also difficult for these women. They believed that Islam was defined more by opposition to today‚Äôs western world than by any religious ideal. After the Chapel Hill shootings, one female Isis supporter argued that candlelight vigils for the victims were un-Islamic because they involved ‚Äúimitating the kuffar‚Äù. All believed that ‚Äúpure Islam‚Äù lay in whatever was as anti-western as possible. Umm Kulthum presented democracy as the binary opposite of a utopian caliphate. ‚ÄúThe law of AllƒÅh should not be voted over,‚Äù she said, quoting Anwar al-Awlaki, the jihadist propagandist who was killed in 2011. I tried, occasionally, to argue that there are many different interpretations of sharia law, and that Islam has contained some democratic ideas ‚Äì the first four Sunni caliphs did not inherit their positions, and the idea of community consensus in legal interpretation has a long tradition. The response was usually confused or hostile. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a muslim and love democracy???‚Äù one of Karen‚Äôs online friends said, ‚Äúhmm.‚Äù What troubled me most was not that these women didn‚Äôt agree with my interpretation of Islam. It was that none of them seemed willing to form independent religious opinions at all. Brown of King‚Äôs College pointed out that few of the women seemed ‚Äúempowered to find faith on their own terms‚Äù. When I asked each of the women about their beliefs, they told me to read Anwar al-Awlaki, or to watch popular jihadist ideologues on YouTube. Whenever I tried to ask Karen why, on religious grounds, she supported Isis‚Äôs interpretation of sharia law, she avoided answering the question. She was busy, or had a headache. ‚ÄúIt hurts to think right now so I won‚Äôt,‚Äù she wrote.
Each of these women struggled with ambiguity or disorder ‚Äì in theology, in identity and in life. Each was convinced that there could be only one valid interpretation of Islam and of sharia law, and that it lay in whatever appeared to be as anti-western as possible. To find it, they had to erase their western identities. Joining Isis offered them an opportunity to do so. ‚ÄòWe don‚Äôt fit in here or there‚Äô For some women, erasing the western part of them was a struggle. Converts ‚Äúhave different battles to born Muslims‚Äù, Umm Raeesa said once. ‚ÄúMuslims thinking u r a fake Muslim.‚Äù She was one of Karen‚Äôs closest online friends. They had bonded over their shared difficulties: both women had been accused by other online Isis supporters of being spies. Their only recourse was to emphasise their religiosity on social media. Umm Raeesa was vicious towards critics of Isis, affectionate towards her online friends and professional in her daily life. She was 25 and worked in finance in Australia. She had converted to Islam two years earlier, but she wore just a headscarf and left her face uncovered. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd prefer to wear niqab at work,‚Äù she told me once, ‚Äúbut would have zero chance of a job lol.‚Äù She had been raised a Catholic, but didn‚Äôt connect with the faith. She supported Isis vehemently online, but had no imminent plans to make the journey. ‚ÄúThis area is unstable,‚Äù she told me. ‚ÄúI think it needs to settle down.‚Äù For the time being, she was content to fight for Isis online without having to give up her life in Australia. More than anything else, Umm Raeesa craved human connection. She had a deep yearning to belong. I woke up to fresh messages from her almost every morning. ‚ÄúAsalaam Alaikum dear sister,‚Äù she always wrote. ‚ÄúHow r u?‚Äù Sometimes she wanted to talk about Isis or about Islamophobia; sometimes she just wanted to chat about her day or to ask me about mine. Many of the women I contacted sought affection and praise in the arms of the Isis sisterhood. Smith and Brown describe this as another ‚Äúpull factor‚Äù that can draw women away from their homes and towards a greater sense of belonging. To Umm Kulthum, I was always ‚Äúhabibti‚Äù. Karen often tweeted about the ‚Äúbaqiyah sisterhood‚Äù: ‚ÄúMuslimah‚Äôs of the Ummah make sure you got each other‚Äôs backs!‚Äù All these women knew what to expect of life under Isis. They warned me that their days would revolve around being a wife and a mother, and would be spent largely indoors. One of Karen‚Äôs online friends was once asked, on Twitter, why she didn‚Äôt just go back to her home country if she didn‚Äôt like the west. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt fit in here nor there lol,‚Äù she replied. When I last spoke to Karen, she had decided to remain at home, in the US, for the time being. But she worries that she is being a ‚Äúcoward‚Äù, and still considers a possible future with Isis. ‚ÄúSometimes I wish I could just leave this place,‚Äù she tweeted once. She still might. All names have been changed

column4: Saudi comedian laughs off threats over Isis satire
column5:
A Saudi comedian threatened with beheading by Islamic State sympathisers and accused of apostasy by a preacher says he is not deterred and will continue to laugh off his opponents√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ rage. Nasser al-Qasabi, 53, has caused a stir with his satirical sketch series Selfie, which is being aired by MBC, a pan-Arab broadcaster, during Ramadan, the Muslim holy month.
Islamic State is caricatured in an episode in which Qasabi plays a father who travels to Syria in search of his son who has joined the group. In one scene, a group of fighters at a √¢‚Ç¨≈ìgirl market√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ pick concubines from a line of chained women abducted from the battlefield. A fighter picks a slave √¢‚Ç¨≈ìwife√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ who is actually a mustachioed man in a woman√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s black robe, only for a comrade point out the apparent mistake. √¢‚Ç¨≈ìNo problem!√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ the first fighter says. √¢‚Ç¨≈ìIf he√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s an infidel, he deserves this.√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ
One tweet sent to Qasabi since the show went out said: √¢‚Ç¨≈ìThe holy warriors will not rest until they cut your head from your body, in just a few days hopefully.√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ Qasabi responded to the threats: √¢‚Ç¨≈ìMy Twitter is overflowing with people cursing at me, threatening me and hating on me. I√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢d like for them to calm down a little. Come on, Ramadan is just beginning!√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ Fahd Deghaither, a writer at al-Hayat newspaper, tweeted in Arabic: √¢‚Ç¨≈ìTwo episodes have shaken Daesh [Isis] feelings. What would have happened if we had a whole production city with complete cinematic events? Who will stand against that?√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ
Qasabi has received supportive tweets gathering around the hashtag #√ò¬≥√ô≈†√ô‚Äû√ôÔøΩ√ô≈† (#selfie). Clips from the episode that mocked Isis were shared online:
Users tweeted their solidarity with the phrase √ò¬ß√ô‚Ä†√ò¬ß √ô‚Ä¶√ò¬π √ô‚Ä†√ò¬ß√ò¬µ√ò¬± √ò¬ß√ô‚Äû√ô‚Äö√ò¬µ√ò¬®√ô≈† (I am with Nasser al-Qasabi).
In remarks posted on MBC√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s website, Qasabi said: √¢‚Ç¨≈ìAllah will protect us. It is the job of the artist to say the truth, even if that is at his own expense. This is the price we have to pay.√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ He said in an interview with al-Arabiya: √¢‚Ç¨≈ìWarning the people about Isis is the true jihad [struggle], because we√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢re fighting them with art not war.√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ In his first episode of Selfie, Qasabi mocks ultra-conservatives in Saudi Arabia by playing the role of a musician who repents and smashes a lute on stage.
