Here the business of navigating Iraq through its latest crisis, the battle against Islamic State (Isis), is directed from a safe, insular enclave of Saddam-era palaces and embassies. The rest of the city gets by on its wits.
Iraq‚Äôs officials claim that the war is existential and that to win it will preserve the very boundaries that Bell advocated in 1921 after the demise of the Ottoman empire. From his vantage point across the river though, Hamid, 37, believes that much of what has happened in Iraq since ‚Äì and particularly the current tumult ‚Äì suggeststhe country Bell envisaged doesn‚Äôt exist any more. And if it does, it may no longer be worth fighting for. ‚ÄúWe can blame empire, occupation, the Americans, Miss Bell, Iran, anyone we want,‚Äù Hamid said, standing on a thin crust of dirt surrounded by tombstones that teeter into collapsed graves. ‚ÄúBut the reality is that people here don‚Äôt want to live together. Why else would we all behave like animals? ‚ÄúLook around. No electricity, no security, no future. If I want water for the ground here, I have to beg the British embassy for it. The country is finished.‚Äù A year into the war against Isis, and more than 12 years since the toppling of Saddam Hussein, other Iraqis are facing personal reckonings about their place within a nation in a perpetual search for identity. Across the country, apparently endless dysfunction has led many to retreat to groupings that they feel more confident in ‚Äì tribes, clan and sects.
‚ÄúIt was OK when there was security,‚Äù said Khalil al-Khater, a refugee from the northern town of Tal Afar, who has spent more than a year in a shack near the Shia city of Najaf. ‚ÄúAs long as we were safe, we could forget about the rest of the country not working. Now the army has scattered like leaves on the wind, and Iraq has split into three parts.‚Äù Since the time of Bell and her colleague TE Lawrence, who also played a defining role in shaping contemporary Arabia, Iraq has lived through colonialism, monarchy, totalitarianism, war, occupation and chaos. Throughout all its modern eras, ancient Mesopotamia‚Äôs role as a cradle of civilisation has loomed large, but many of its people say its latest incarnation, from the end of the first world war until now, has produced next to nothing in the way of nation-building that can unify its disparate groups.
‚ÄúIf all we have are winged horses from the Sumerian period to say we are Iraqis, then that is not a foundation for a state,‚Äù said Ahmed Rubaie, a guard at the Iraqi National Museum, which houses most of the country‚Äôs surviving priceless antiquities. ‚ÄúOutside these walls, you‚Äôll find nothing that has been built since British rule that commemorates the country like all of the things within these walls.‚Äù
Not far from the museum, Muhammed Amin Izzat has conducted Iraq‚Äôs national orchestra since Baghdad fell in 2003. It was one of the main institutions under Saddam, and has endured since while other citadels of state have withered. ‚ÄúWe are an institution which represents all Iraqis and we have never been a trumpet for anyone,‚Äù Izzat said. In 2012, a year of relative calm, he decided to assemble the orchestra in a public square in Baghdad. The symphony it played attracted expatriates from all over the world and was hailed as a moment when culture and unity transcended Iraq‚Äôs woes. ‚ÄúPeople wanted to come to us and enjoy the music and forget about what is happening in the street,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe Iraqis are people who love to live and want peace but our problems are caused by politicians who want to create division in order to rule.‚Äù Izzat said he too rued the lack of other symbols of Baghdad‚Äôs recent past. Occasionally he makes his way to the Shahbander cafe near the river‚Äôs edge, which has been a sanctuary for writers, poets, singers and painters for at least 70 years. For 51 of them, Haj Mohammed has run the cafe, which stands next to the site of a book fair that has been held most Fridays for all that time. The cafe‚Äôs walls are covered with photographs chronicling Iraq‚Äôs modern history ‚Äì a faded shot of Bell alongside an image of the coronation of Iraq‚Äôs last monarch, King Faisal. There are politicians at sports carnivals, tribesmen from the southern marshes and proud graduate classes.
Next to the entrance are five more contemporary photographs, of Haj Mohammed‚Äôs sons who were killed by a huge car bomb that targeted the book market eight years ago. ‚ÄúThis is all we have left. All around us is history,‚Äù he said, pointing at the framed memories as customers queue to pay for their tea. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just about our [family] history. This is about society. ‚ÄúAll that we knew has been overwhelmed since we were occupied by the Americans. We have felt like we were undressed. We don‚Äôt see people buying books or even textiles anymore. We no longer know what is coming for us, or when. Back in the 50s, we weren‚Äôt just living, we were competing with the rest of the world.‚Äù The book fair on Montanabe Street is not as popular as it was. Once a place where all manner of fiction classics could be picked up for small change, religious texts and comic books now seem more prolific, especially mid-week in summer on the eve of Ramadan. ‚ÄúBut you still won‚Äôt find anything else like it,‚Äù Haj Mohammed said. ‚ÄúIt needs to be protected.‚Äù In a palace on the edge of the Green Zone, General Abdul Amir al-Sammari, the man in charge of protecting Baghdad, was upbeat. There had been no major explosions in the capital for 10 days and the battle over the horizon had been going better lately. State security forces had played a role in the improvement, the general said, but the main contributors had been militia that work alongside the military and often take primacy over it.
Iraq‚Äôs security tsars largely endorse the role of the militias, known as the Popular Mobilisation Forces or locally as Hashd al-Shaabi. They are thought to number as many as 200,000 fighters, and nominally come under the authority of the prime minister‚Äôs office. Most of the groups are Shia. They are directly supported by Iran, and their authority is rooted in a call to arms from Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, Iraq‚Äôs top Shia cleric, last June. ‚ÄúFrom January to June last year, we were isolated and alone,‚Äù Sammari said of army units in Baghdad, which at the time were besieged by increasingly muscular Isis forces on Baghdad‚Äôs western outskirts. ‚ÄúThen came the fatwa of the marja [Iraq‚Äôs highest Shia religious authority]. As soon as that happened, the street was with us.‚Äù Last month, when Iraq‚Äôs military withdrew from Ramadi and allowed Isis to take full control of the city, the militias were sent to surround it. The pattern had already been set in smaller battles elsewhere in the country earlier this year. When the state fails, a parallel force steps into the fray. Sammari acknowledged that Iraq‚Äôs military has rarely had the upper hand against Isis, but claim ed cooperation was improving. ‚ÄúIt is true that lots of splits have happened that have weakened the morale of the military. We are trying to avoid the forces working as separate units and to unify. It is starting to happen.‚Äù The tussle for power between the ailing state forces and the ascendant irregulars clearly rankles security chiefs, as it does many of Iraq‚Äôs politicians.
‚ÄúAny nationalist must believe that the military is the strongest part of the state‚Äôs security,‚Äù said Sammari. ‚ÄúAnyone who says otherwise is delusional.‚Äù Asked about regular complaints from Iraq‚Äôs Sunnis, who lost power when Saddam was ousted, that the militias have consolidated the hold of their rival sect on the country, Sammari responded: ‚ÄúWhen will they accept that they lost?‚Äù On the other side of Baghdad in the district of Ghazaliya, the leader of the country‚Äôs largest Sunni institution has regularly warned of the dangers of the state being subjugated. Kutaiba al-Falahi, a spokesman for the Sunni waqf, said a failing political process was keeping Iraq‚Äôs disenfranchised Sunnis on the sidelines, allowing Isis to claim a role as their de facto representatives.
‚ÄúAnbar is outside state control and the Kurds aren‚Äôt interested in Iraq as it was drawn a century ago,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAlmost everyone we speak to wants a form of federalism. They want their basic needs met. The solution lies in real autonomy and authority for the provinces.‚Äù In Falluja , 20 miles west of Baghdad and the closest city to the capital held by the jihadis , a local doctor who uses the name Abu Saleh said hope of the state resuming control had evaporated. ‚ÄúI have no faith in the government, Sunni or Shia,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey are the ones who put us in the situation we are in now. The majority of people in Falluja aren‚Äôt with Isis, but some are tired and scared of the army. At least they have their homes now and their kids can go to school. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want to be begging in the streets or begging the government to let them into Baghdad. If we had Sunni tribes who will come inside the city and fight Isis, we would feel safer.‚Äù Al-Falahi said the plight of refugees from Anbar showed the standing of the broader Sunni community in the eyes of the state. ‚ÄúWe are all being labelled [as Isis supporters ]. We need the government to look at us like humans. There are refugees [from Ramadi ] sitting at the gates of Baghdad and they are not allowed in - the old the young and the sick living in tents in this heat because they don‚Äôt trust us. It would be better if the Americans came back. We can‚Äôt run the country ourselves.‚Äù

column4: Living in Greece: how would you feel about a third Greek bailout?
column5: EU leaders have reached an agreement that paves the way to a third Greek bailout, if Athens parliament approves tough austerity measures. If you live in Greece, how do you feel about this? For Greeks uncertainty is a way of life. Five years of recession and austerity have left 26% of the workforce without a job and has seen the GDP shrink by a quarter. For the last six months Greece has been locked in talks with the EU aimed at securing a sustainable future. During the last few weeks the crisis has reached breaking point ‚Äì will Greece exit Europe or can a last minute deal be negotatiated? column4: Lamb with jellyfish gene 'may have been deliberately sent to abattoir'
column5: A lamb born with a jellyfish gene was mistakenly sold for human consumption and probably ended up on someone‚Äôs plate, French authorities have said. A dispute between researchers at a highly respected national institute may have been the cause of the animal being deliberately sent to the abattoir last year. Police have now been called in and an inquiry launched into how the lamb could have been passed as fit for human consumption. Le Parisien newspaper reported that the animal‚Äôs mother was a sheep called Emeraude whose DNA had been modified to include a jellyfish gene called Green Fluorescent Protein by researchers at the National Institute for Agronomic Research (INRA) in Paris. Her lamb, Rubis, was born with the gene in the spring of 2014. Although produced for research purposes, Rubis was allegedly deliberately mixed with several other lambs that had not been genetically modified and sent to an abattoir. The president of the INRA, Beno√Æt Malpaux, described the apparently ‚Äúmalicious act‚Äù as unacceptable, but was quick to reassure the public that there was no risk to humans. ‚ÄúThe consumption of this meat presents no risk for the health for the consumer,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe are sure that individual acts that are unacceptable were committed ‚Ä¶ followed by a chain of errors and responsibilities within the hierarchy.‚Äù In what could have been the plot of a science fiction film, Emeraude and Rubis were reportedly part of a programme called Green Sheep launched in 2009, aimed at carrying out experiments on mammals for ‚Äútherapeutic research‚Äù. The jellyfish protein was reportedly introduced into the sheep to make their skin transparent and enable researchers to ‚Äúvisualise and study heart transplants‚Äù. Investigators suspect a researcher may have tricked his superior into signing a document sending the animal to the abattoir where it was sold to an unknown individual in November 2014. When the the team leader discovered the deception, he failed to report the missing animal to his bosses. Working relations between the two men were said to have been tense. Malpaux said a laboratory technician had been provisionally suspended and will face a disciplinary hearing in July. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know his motive or aim precisely, but the atmosphere within the team could be behind this behaviour,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe facts are unacceptable and call for the greatest severity. We are a world-renowned institute and we cannot tolerate such actions.‚Äù

column4: Japan's PM Shinzo Abe heckled at Okinawa battle anniversary event
column5:
Japan‚Äôs prime minister, Shinzo Abe, has been heckled at an event marking the anniversary of the end of the bloodiest battle of the Pacific during the second world war, as criticism mounts over his attempts to allow Japanese troops to fight overseas for the first time in seven decades. Shouts of ‚ÄúGo home!‚Äù and ‚ÄúWarmonger!‚Äù could be heard as Abe, a nationalist whose attempts to reinterpret Japan‚Äôs pacifist constitution have sent his approval ratings to record lows, arrived at a ceremony on Tuesday to mark the end of the battle of Okinawa in which more than 200,000 civilians and soldiers died. On a day when 5,000 people, including the US ambassador to Japan, Caroline Kennedy, gathered in the town of Itoman on Okinawa‚Äôs southern tip to remember those who died in the 82-day battle, a poll revealed strong public opposition to Abe‚Äôs plans to strengthen the role of the country‚Äôs military. Criticism of Abe in Okinawa is running high over his support for the construction of a new US marine corps airbase on a pristine stretch of Okinawa‚Äôs coastline to replace an existing base located in the middle of a densely populated city. Okinawa‚Äôs governor, Takeshi Onaga, has vowed to block the plan, which would also involve the relocation of about 8,000 US troops and their families from the island to Guam and other US Pacific territories.
Abe, who appeared shaken by the rare display of public anger, acknowledged Okinawa‚Äôs role in maintaining Japan‚Äôs security since the end of the second world war. The island, located about 1,000 miles south of Tokyo, hosts more than half the 47,000 US troops in Japan and three-quarters of US bases, despite accounting for just 0.6% of Japan‚Äôs territory. ‚ÄúPeople in Okinawa have long been asked to carry a big burden for our security,‚Äù Abe said. ‚ÄúWe will continue to do our best to reduce it.‚Äù He added: ‚ÄúWe must take pride in the path of peace we have single-mindedly walked in the last 70 years and make ceaseless efforts to establish world peace.‚Äù Abe was speaking near the spot where Japanese troops who had been ordered never to surrender forced terrified local people to throw themselves off cliffs rather than risk being captured by the Americans who, they were told, would rape and kill them. Survivors said that Japanese troops gave civilians two grenades each: the first was to be hurled at the invading enemy, and the second to be detonated in group suicides. The island is still littered with human remains and unexploded ordnance, said Naeko Teruya, a representative of the bereaved families. ‚ÄúSeventy years since the war has ended, we still feel that the war hasn‚Äôt truly ended,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe continue to find the scars of war in Okinawa today.‚Äù By the time the fighting ended, about 100,000 Okinawan civilians were dead, as well as 80,000 Japanese troops. At least 12,000 US soldiers also died in a battle that many believed offered a bloody foretaste of what could happen if the US attempted an invasion of the Japanese mainland.
Japan surrendered almost two months later, days after the US dropped atomic bombs on the cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Onaga received a warmer welcome when he referred to the unfair military burden he and many islanders believe they have shouldered since Okinawa was handed back to Japanese control in 1972. He urged Abe to reconsider a 20-year-old agreement between Tokyo and Washington to build a new offshore runway on the island, saying his election as governor last year demonstrated the strength of public feeling against the move. ‚ÄúWe strongly demand that the government cancel construction ‚Ä¶ and review its policies of reducing Okinawa‚Äôs base burden once again,‚Äù he said. Okinawa‚Äôs strategically important role as a host to US military bases has taken on renewed importance amid anxiety over increasingly assertive Chinese claims to islands in the South and East China Seas. Some local people fear their island could once again be dragged into war if Abe pushes ahead with plans to reinterpret the US-authored pacifist constitution and allow Japanese troops to engage in collective self-defence ‚Äì or coming to the aid of an ally under attack.
Article 9 of the constitution prohibits Japan from threatening or using force as a means of settling international disputes. Successive administrations in Tokyo have interpreted that to mean that troops can only go into battle in defence of direct threats to Japanese territory. Abe‚Äôs quest to end that strictly defensive posture recently suffered a setback after three respected scholars said the changes were unconstitutional. Voters also appear to doubt Abe‚Äôs reassurances that the change would not increase the likelihood of Japanese troops becoming embroiled in US-led conflicts. A poll by the liberal Asahi Shimbun released on Tuesday showed support for the Abe cabinet at 39%, the lowest since he took office in late 2012. The newspaper attributed the slump to growing public opposition to Abe‚Äôs security bills. According to the poll, 53% of respondents oppose the new legislation, while 29% support it. The end of the Okinawan battle was marked as South Korean women who were forced to work as sex slaves for the Japanese army before and during the war said they would file a $20m (¬£12.7m) lawsuit next month at a US court to seek financial compensation from Tokyo. Ten surviving ‚Äúcomfort women‚Äù, led by 89-year-old Kim Bok-dong, will lodge the suit at a California district court on 1 July, according to their attorney. ‚ÄúThe Japanese government should offer an official and sincere apology for wrongdoings by their ancestors and restore our honour,‚Äù Kim told reporters outside the Japanese embassy in Seoul. Mainstream historians say up to 200,000 women, mainly from Korea, were forced into sexual slavery during the war. Japan insists all compensation claims were settled when the two countries normalised bilateral ties in 1965.

column4: Queen's choice of Germany for state visit seen as diplomatic coup
column5:
For several days, Germans have been fed a daily stream of instructions on what to do should they happen to meet the Queen. ‚ÄúIn the first instance, she is to be addressed as ‚ÄòYour Majesty‚Äô,‚Äù wrote the liberal daily the S√ºddeutsche Zeitung, ‚Äúand thereafter with ‚ÄòMa‚Äôam‚Äô, to rhyme with ‚Äògram‚Äô.‚Äù And ‚Äúum Gottes willen, keine Selfies!‚Äù [for God‚Äôs sake, no selfies]. If such newspaper guides are anything to go by, Germany is taking Queen Elizabeth‚Äôs seventh official visit to Germany, which begins on Tuesday, extremely seriously. ‚ÄúLilac is a safe colour to wear if you meet her,‚Äù was another more specific crumb of advice in the tabloid Bild, which pointed out that it is also, appropriately, the tone that ‚Äúresults from mixing together the colours of the union jack‚Äù. Angela Merkel welcomed news of Her Majesty‚Äôs visit. ‚ÄúQueen Elizabeth is witness to the development of the relationship between Germany and Britain which is very friendly today,‚Äù the German chancellor said this week. And when she visits, ‚Äúit‚Äôs always a big event‚Äù. But as this is expected to be one of the 89-year-old monarch‚Äôs last state visits, the interest is more heightened than usual. That their country should be the choice of her final foreign port of call is seen as immensely flattering to the majority of Germans.
There has been much speculation in Germany as to the reasons, including her husband the Duke of Edinburgh‚Äôs German roots ‚Äì he was born into the House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Gl√ºcksburg and went to school in southern Germany ‚Äì and not least, her own strong German ancestry. Only during the first world war was the family name changed by her grandfather, George V, from Saxe-Coburg-Gotha to Windsor.
But as the German socialite and most prominent royal watcher, Alexander, Count of Sch√∂nburg-Glauchau, pointed out to readers of Bild in a five-part series, Die Queen und die Deutschen: ‚ÄúIt is not the Queen who decides when and where she travels, but the British government ‚Ä¶ and Downing Street has very concrete reasons why it should want to send the Queen ‚Äì the secret weapon of British diplomacy ‚Äì to Germany.‚Äù Historians have been wheeled out in their droves to explain how her first, 11-day, 18-city visit in 1965 was seen as a major contribution to healing the wounds caused by the second world war. In Britain some critical voices called it an insult to Britain‚Äôs war dead. ‚ÄúIt was highly symbolic ‚Ä¶ a sign that Germany was once again being viewed as a normal country,‚Äù said historian Simone Derix, who has researched the topic in depth. At the same time there were fears among officials ‚Äúthat some Germans in their enthusiasm to see her would let slip a ‚Äòheil‚Äô,‚Äù she said. In the end, they shouted: ‚ÄúE-li-sa-beth!‚Äù In the following years, the cold war made her visits just as necessary, not least after prime minister Margaret Thatcher was quoted in 1987, two years before the fall of the Berlin Wall, as saying: ‚ÄúI love Germany so much, that I‚Äôm glad there are two of them.‚Äù Those wars may be over, and Germany long since reunited, but nowadays, said Sch√∂nburg, ‚Äúthe anxieties are quite similar‚Äù, namely ‚ÄúLondon‚Äôs fear of ‚Ä¶ an EU which fuses into a super-state, in which the individual states lose their independence.‚Äù
David Cameron‚Äôs decision to ‚Äúpiggy-back‚Äù on the visit, when he attends a state banquet with the Queen and the German president, Joachim Gauck, on Wednesday evening, has certainly raised eyebrows. Downing Street insists his trip follows an invitation from the German government. But observers in London and Berlin view it as a deliberate exercise to reinforce the countries‚Äô commonalities ahead of crucial EU talks Cameron is due to hold with Merkel over Britain‚Äôs future relationship with Brussels, before an in/out referendum on the UK‚Äôs membership in the EU.
Certainly, when the Queen is greeted by Merkel on the steps of her cuboid chancellery on Wednesday morning, the pictures will, hope diplomats on both sides, speak volumes about the British-German relationship. Merkel has said she will do all she can to try to keep Britain in the EU. Sch√∂nburg said: ‚ÄúThe Queen, simply through her very presence, is supposed to remind us Germans just how poor Europe would be without Britain.‚Äù One commentator from the leftwing paper Taz suggested that another effect of the encounter might be to finally put Merkel, often referred to as the ‚ÄúQueen of Europe‚Äù, in her place, because ‚Äúafter all, when Elizabeth became Queen, Merkel was not even born yet‚Äù. The packed schedule of the three-day visit will on Wednesday see the Queen and Prince Philip greeted with military honours by Gauck at his residence, Schloss Bellevue, before they take a boat up the river Spree to the chancellery, where the Queen will hold talks with Merkel, before laying a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. At the Technical University she will listen to the annual Queen‚Äôs lecture, this year delivered by the outgoing director of the British Museum, Neil MacGregor ‚Äì one of the most popular Britons in Germany since his curation last year of an exhibition on 600 years of German history, and the recent announcement that he will take over as a chief adviser on the contents of the new cultural palace in Berlin, the Humboldt Forum.
On Thursday, she will travel to Frankfurt, the country‚Äôs financial centre, where the underlying message will be the strong business ties between Britain and Germany, which many say would be threatened by a Brexit. But the most poignant item on the Queen‚Äôs schedule will undoubtedly be her first ever visit to a former concentration camp when she goes to Bergen-Belsen on Friday. The camp was liberated by British troops in April 1945.
The visit ‚Äì taking place at the Queen‚Äôs request, according to the British embassy ‚Äì will see her meet survivors and liberators of the camp. It is being kept deliberately low-key but again will usefully serve to reinforce the bond. Details of everything ‚Äì from what she and Philip will eat (guinea fowl and venison), where she‚Äôll sleep (the fact that his room is reportedly at the other end of the corridor from hers in Hotel Adlon), to the colour of her Bentley, which was transported to Berlin at the weekend ‚Äì are being pored over. One celebrity magazine claims to have seen the protocol note that says the Queen did not respond to the German query as to whether she preferred to take the lift rather than using the stairs. And her personal cook in the Adlon said, on being asked if there was any food she wished to avoid: ‚ÄúI was told anything goes, which I think is quite charming.‚Äù Everyone, from porcelain manufacturers to toy makers, is exploiting the event for all its worth. The Berlin branch of Lego has even produced a limited edition Queen figure. The fascination is easily explained, say German royal watchers, by the fact that the country does not have its own royal family to admire. From the butler who will serve her tea on her arrival at the Adlon, where the royal entourage will move into 70 rooms on two floors, to the organ grinders outside on Pariser Platz, everyone has their own memories of her last visit in 2004. And few have forgotten how she briefly fell asleep during a lecture on medicine and magnets in D√ºsseldorf, an incident which did nothing to lessen the love.

column4: Rwanda complains after spy chief is held in London over alleged war crimes
column5:
Rwanda has angrily condemned the arrest of the country‚Äôs intelligence chief, Karenzi Karake, by British authorities acting on a Spanish indictment. Louise Mushikiwabo, the Rwandan foreign minister, tweeted: ‚ÄúWestern solidarity in demeaning Africans is unacceptable!!‚Äù She suggested the arrest was a conspiracy by those who deny the 1994 genocide. ‚ÄúIt is an outrage to arrest Rwandan official based on pro-genocidaires lunacy!‚Äù Mushikiwabo also described the arrest warrant as preposterous. Karake, 54, known as ‚ÄúKK‚Äù, has for two decades been a senior intelligence and military officer in the Rwandan Patriotic Front. The RPF brought an end to the genocide by Hutu extremists that left an estimated 800,000 Tutsis dead. Karake and 39 others are accused of ordering revenge massacres of Hutus and the murder of three Spanish aid workers, according to a European arrest warrant issued by Spain in 2008, understood to be the basis for his detention by the Metropolitan police at Heathrow on Saturday. Johnston Busingye, Rwanda‚Äôs justice minister, told the country‚Äôs New Times newspaper: ‚ÄúWe are handling the matter with the UK government. They have better details on this evolving situation.‚Äù Karake had been on official duty in London for a week, the report added. Busingye dismissed the Spanish indictment as politically motivated. ‚ÄúI would be surprised if it is one the UK is acting on. We will contest in the courts. We have sought explanation from the UK on this matter as well.‚Äù
Williams Nkurunziza, the Rwandan high commissioner to the UK, told the BBC World Service: ‚ÄúWe take strong exception to the suggestion that he‚Äôs being arrested on war crimes. Any suggestion that any of our 40 leaders are guilty of crimes against humanity is an insult to our collective conscience.‚Äù Jordi Palou-Loverdos, however, a lawyer representing the Spanish victims, told the BBC‚Äôs Newsnight on Monday: ‚ÄúWe hope in the name of the victims that this time justice will be provided and Karenzi Karake will soon be delivered to the Spanish court to have a fair trial, where he can defend himself. ‚ÄúWe hope that political or other interests will not neutralise the place for justice, truth and reparation.‚Äù The arrest was also welcomed by Rwanda‚Äôs opposition FDU-Inkingi party. Its vice-president, Boniface Twagirimana, said: ‚ÄúIt is a sign of equal justice for those who have killed innocent people. If someone has been involved in crimes against humanity, it is good if he is brought before the law to explain himself. ‚ÄúIt is very difficult for us to have reconciliation without this ‚Ä¶ We cannot confirm if people are guilty or innocent. That is the job of the judge to confirm.‚Äù Andrew Mitchell, who worked closely with the Rwandan government while serving as Britain‚Äôs international development secretary, said the European arrest warrant system was being abused. He told BBC Radio 4‚Äôs Today programme: ‚ÄúThese are politically motivated. They are not about justice, they are about politics.
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs be very clear, they are being pursued by supporters of the genocidal regime which murdered up to one million people in Rwanda. It is one of the great tragedies and disgraces of our time, only 21 years ago. ‚ÄúI think it is reprehensible that the European arrest warrant system should be abused in this way by a junior Spanish judge.‚Äù A 2008 diplomatic cable sent from the US embassy in Kigali and released by WikiLeaks dismissed the Spanish indictments as ‚Äúoutrageous and inaccurate‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe Spanish indictment of 40 Rwandan military officers offers an unrecognisable version of some of the most painful and violent episodes in Rwanda‚Äôs history,‚Äù said the cable, which described the allegations as ‚Äúa bloated political tract, sloppily organised and endlessly repetitive‚Äù. Karake is a former deputy chief of the UN-African Union peacekeeping force in Sudan‚Äôs Darfur region. Human Rights Watch criticised his appointment to the peacekeeping mission, alleging that he was responsible for the killing of civilians in the town of Kisangan in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in June 2000.
Karake has had mixed fortunes under president Paul Kagame‚Äôs rule. In 2010 he was placed under house arrest for misconduct, but was later released. He was a close friend of Patrick Karegeya, a former spy chief who became a dissident and was murdered in a South African hotel in late 2013. Karake, the director-general of Rwanda‚Äôs national intelligence and security services, appeared at Westminster magistrates court in London and was remanded in custody until Thursday. Madrid‚Äôs ability to prosecute him may be hampered by a law passed last year that severely limits judges‚Äô ability to prosecute crimes that occur outside Spain. Carina Tertsakian, Rwanda researcher at Human Rights Watch, said: ‚ÄúHis arrest is significant because he‚Äôs been a key senior member of Rwanda‚Äôs intelligence and military for the past 20 years. Victims of human rights violations in Rwanda have often cited his name. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to follow it closely. It could be a really important in terms of accountability. Many senior officials in Rwanda have never been held to account.‚Äù The Spanish link Karake stands accused of ordering the killing of three Spaniards ‚Äì Flors Sirera, Manuel Madrazo and Luis Valtue√±a ‚Äì in 1997. All three were members of the NGO M√©dicos del Mundo, and were allegedly murdered by four Tutsi soldiers after they had been taken to see the mass graves of murdered Hutus. A former member of Karake‚Äôs intelligence unit testified to the Spanish judge Fernando Andreu that Karake had ordered the killings because ‚Äúthese whites had sensitive information about the Rwandan Patriotic Front‚Äôs recent massacres‚Äù. In 2008 Andreu brought a case against Karake and 39 other military officials. Madrid‚Äôs ability to pursue Karake may be impeded by a law passed by the country‚Äôs conservative government last year that severely limits judges‚Äô ability to prosecute crimes that occur outside Spain under a system known as universal justice. The concept is rooted in the 1949 Geneva conventions and compels any signatory to provide effective sanctions against those accused of breaching the convention. Spain took the lead in applying universal justice after the concept was integrated into the Spanish judicial system in 1985, most famously with the arrest and attempted extradition of the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet from London in 1988. The government introduced reforms to the system last year, apparently to avoid conflict with China, which had been indicted over human rights abuses in Tibet. A government spokesman said universal jurisdiction had to be abolished because ‚Äúit only causes conflict‚Äù. A spokesman for Amnesty International in Spain described the reform as ‚Äúa backward step‚Äù for human rights. Not long after the new law was introduced, a number of international drug barons jailed in Spain successfully sued for their release, claiming that Spain had broken its own laws by acting outside its jurisdiction. The chances of prosecuting Karake would be much greater were he extradited and made to stand trial on Spanish soil, legal experts say. Four other Spaniards ‚Äì Joaquim Valmaj√≥, Servando Garc√≠a, Fernando de la Fuente and Isidro Uzkudun, all priests ‚Äì were also tortured and murdered by RPF members. The dismembered bodies of Valmaj√≥ and Garc√≠a were thrown into a well. Stephen Burgen in Barcelona

column4: Muslim human rights group accuses Kenyan government of harassment
column5: A Kenyan human rights group has accused the government of using anti-terror measures to crack down on its work, suggesting it has been targeted for exposing abuses by the security services. Muslim Human Rights (Muhuri) is to apply to the courts to unfreeze its bank accounts as part of an ongoing legal battle after it was placed it on a state list of ‚Äúterror suspects‚Äù in the wake of the recent al-Shabaab attack at Garissa university. The government lost the first round when a high court ruled earlier this month that Muhuri and another human rights group, Haki Africa, should be removed from the list. The two groups have criticised the country‚Äôs anti-terror policies, accusing the government of making arbitrary arrests and conducting extra-judicial killings. ‚ÄúWe are currently working with the Independent Policing Oversight Authority to follow up cases of extrajudicial killings and forced disappearances, and we think that has triggered the government‚Äôs heavy handed response,‚Äù a spokeswoman said. Following the death of 147 people in the attack on Garissa in April, 86 organisations and individuals were listed as terrorist organisations. The government says their finances are to be investigated. The list included Al Qaida, Boko Haram and Islamic state - alongside the NGOs and several money transfer organisations, Hawalas, which predominantly serve the Somali community. Thirteen of the hawalas are set to be reopened after Kenya‚Äôs president, Uhuru Kenyatta, ordered the Central Bank to lift their suspension because an investigation had cleared them of involvement in terror. However the bank accounts belonging to Muhuri and Haki Africa, both based in Mombasa, remain frozen. The judge who ordered that they be taken off the terror list dismissed an application to unfreeze them because the Central Bank of Kenya, which regulates banks, was not part of the case. In response, Muhuri will this week file an amended petition suing the Central Bank of Kenya and the Kenya Financial Reporting Centre for freezing its accounts. The spokeswoman said not being able to access its bank accounts had put Muhuri in dire financial straits. ‚ÄúWe have not paid salaries since April and we have had to negotiate with our suppliers to give us a grace period considering the unique circumstances and most have obliged. However, if our accounts remain frozen longer than this month, we will not be able to keep the lights on or the phones connected,‚Äù she saidd. ‚ÄúAll our donors have been very supportive although we haven‚Äôt been able to receive any funding from them due to the fact that the accounts are frozen. We expect everything to go back to normal once we are allowed access to our accounts,‚Äù she added. Human Rights Watch condemned the ‚Äúharassment and intimidation‚Äù of the ngos. ‚ÄúHaki Africa and Muhuri are working to protect human rights in Kenya under difficult circumstances,‚Äù said Leslie Lefkow, Human Rights Watch‚Äôs deputy Africa director, in a statement. ‚ÄúHaki Africa and Muhuri should be supported for their human rights work, not harassed and intimidated.‚Äù

column4: China finds an eager South American stablemate in Suriname
column5:
It would be hard to imagine a more striking contrast. On the one hand, there is the massive Suriname Aluminium works, a subsidiary of the US giant Alcoa. It employs some 5,000 people. On the other hand, less than a kilometre down a tarmacked road in the industrial suburbs of Paramaribo, the capital of Suriname, Broad, a Chinese construction company housed in a corrugated iron shed, specialises in turnkey homes and offices. Two different worlds, almost face-to-face but travelling in opposite directions. On 1 July, after almost a century of operations, the management of the Suralco plant will be handing over the reins to a group of state-appointed managers. Broad started trading five months ago and Suriname‚Äôs President Desi Bouterse attended the official opening. His National Democratic party triumphed in the general election on 25 May, winning a comfortable majority. These entirely separate events are emblematic of the scale of the changes at work in this former Dutch colony, once seen as Uncle Sam‚Äôs backyard.
In less than 10 years the Chinese have set up hundreds of companies, shops, casinos and restaurants in this small South American state, which reaches deep into the Amazon jungle. They have widened and asphalted roads, and built social housing. A television channel, with staff of about 20, now broadcasts in Mandarin Chinese on Suriname networks. In 2011 the Southern Commercial Bank opened in Paramaribo. A group of Chinese businessmen has just bought out another one, the Fina Bank. Chinese nationals are now estimated to control around 90% of the country‚Äôs supermarkets, small grocery stores and food shops. All the main parties in the recent election fielded a prominently placed candidate of Chinese heritage. As in Africa, Beijing has unobtrusively but methodically established a foothold in this country of barely half a million people. Immigration has substantially increased since the late-1990s, adding (according to official sources) about 10,000 people to the existing Chinese community. Some observers see this presence as a rear base or testbed for Chinese ambitions in South America. ‚ÄúSuriname is a lucky country, such [a] small population, so much land,‚Äù the New York Times quoted Yuan Nansheng, a former Chinese ambassador to Suriname, as saying in 2011. The close ties his country enjoys with Bouterse, who 16 years ago was sentenced by a Dutch court in absentia to 11 years in prison for drug trafficking, were sealed with an official visit to Beijing in 2013. In the meantime China has gifted dozens of coaches to the Suriname military. A group of Chinese contractors clubbed together to build a magnificent office block, about 500 metres from the president‚Äôs palace. It now houses the foreign ministry. ‚ÄúThe Dutch government‚Äôs relationship with the Bouterse clan was turbulent, particularly when it suspended development aid. This prompted the regime‚Äôs top brass to look for other solutions,‚Äù says Winston Ramautarsing, a lecturer in economics at Anton de Kom University of Suriname. ‚ÄúCloser links with China, which is keen to find its place in the Amazon basin for obvious reasons, came about almost naturally. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs much the same trend everywhere, but given the size of our country and the way the authorities here have welcomed them with open arms, the Chinese presence is more visible,‚Äù he adds. Heading out of Paramaribo and into the country, you soon see the scale of this presence. On either side of the road are dozens of small timber-processing plants, factories producing roofing or sheet aluminium, with signs sporting Chinese ideograms or the owner‚Äôs name. In some places this influx of cheap labour has caused resentment, a cause taken up by Ronnie Brunswijk, leader of the General Liberation and Development party ABOP, now allied with Bouterse. ‚Äú[Chinese migrants] buy up all the street corners, help grow our economy, offering a range of competitively priced products, with a variety and quality of service we‚Äôve not seen before,‚Äù Ramautarsing explains. ‚ÄúBut their very low salaries and their visible or supposed success sometimes upset people.‚Äù In the centre of the capital, small food shops are mostly operated by families who have recently arrived from China. ‚ÄúThey call us ‚Äòsaltwater Chinese‚Äô, unlike the others who arrived here in the 19th century and have settled on farms further inland, close to freshwater rivers,‚Äù says one such shop worker named Lia. Sitting at her till, behind an array of iron bars, ‚Äúbecause attacks are frequent‚Äù, this young student helps her parents keep the shop open ‚Äúas long as possible‚Äù. ‚ÄúLife isn‚Äôt easy here,‚Äù she adds. ‚ÄúWe had to learn Dutch and Sranan Tongo [Suriname creole], cope with the violence, the climate too. But we‚Äôd never leave now.‚Äù This article appeared in Guardian Weekly, which incorporates material from Le Monde

column4: Germany frees Al-Jazeera journalist Ahmed Mansour
column5:
German authorities have released al-Jazeera journalist Ahmed Mansour without charge, after he was detained on Saturday by police at Berlin‚Äôs Tegel airport on an Egyptian arrest warrant. A spokesman for the state prosecutor said there were ‚Äúpolitical and diplomatic concerns that could not be ignored‚Äù in addition to the legal aspects of the case. These concerns, he said, were discussed with the Berlin state justice minister and the appropriate federal authorities. A lawyer for Mansour, who has dual Egyptian and British citizenship, told al-Jazeera that while his client was happy about the court‚Äôs decision, he was also sad that he had been detained. Questions remain as to why the German authorities arrested Mansour at the behest of Egypt‚Äôs military regime in the first place, and why they waited until he was at the point of leaving Germany to do so. There was considerable confusion over the warrant, which a German government spokesman said on Monday came via Interpol‚Äôs ‚Äúred notice‚Äù system, though both Mansour and Interpol said no such red notice exists against his name.
According to police spokesman Meik Gauer, the arresting officers at Tegel airport were answerable only to the federal police headquarters, not to Interpol. There also remains a question mark over why the police officers felt obliged to detain Mansour, given that Germany does not have an extradition agreement with Egypt. Cologne-based lawyer Nikolaos Gazeas told Zeit Online: ‚ÄúGermany is not under a legal obligation to extradite to Egypt. That is ultimately a political decision.‚Äù For that reason, legal commentators have suggested the warrant could not have been executed without consultation with the government. Last year, an Egyptian court convicted Mansour in absentia of torturing a lawyer in Tahrir Square in 2011 and sentenced him to 15 years in prison. Mansour rejected the charges, calling them ‚Äúa flimsy attempt at character assassination‚Äù. On Monday morning, a group calling itself the German-Egyptian Union for Democracy gathered about 100 protesters outside the Berlin jail where Mansour was being detained. They held signs that read: ‚ÄúFreedom for Ahmed Mansour. Freedom for Egypt. Freedom for journalists.‚Äù MPs across Germany‚Äôs main political parties had voiced concern over his detention. Among the most outspoken was the opposition Green party‚Äôs Franziska Brantner, who said in a statement on her website: ‚ÄúThe Berlin judiciary should under no circumstances allow itself to become a willing tool of the capricious regime in Cairo.‚Äù Egypt accuses both Qatar and al-Jazeera of supporting the Muslim Brotherhood, which was branded a terrorist organisation after the military deposed Mohamed Morsi as president in 2013. Three journalists with al-Jazeera English spent more than 400 days in prison following their arrest in Cairo in late 2013. Their trial was regarded internationally as a farce. Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, was criticised by opposition parties and rights groups for hosting the Egyptian president, Abdel Fatah al-Sisi, on a state visit this month. During the visit, the German industrial group Siemens signed an ‚Ç¨8bn deal with Egypt to supply gas and wind power plants. Since Sisi took power in 2013 and won a presidential election the following year, courts in Egypt have issued scores of death sentences against Muslim Brotherhood members including the group‚Äôs leadership.

column4: Up for adventure: the ascent of rock climbing in the West Bank
column5:
Rubaa Bledi, 16, is being lowered to the ground having completed her first rock climb. ‚ÄúI was trembling!‚Äù the Palestinian schoolgirl says breathlessly as she rests her head on her knees. Her face is hidden for a moment by her headscarf and helmet. ‚ÄúI wanted to know if I could do something risky,‚Äù she says when she recovers. ‚ÄúI wanted to know if I was up to the adventure.‚Äù It is Saturday and we‚Äôre on the cliffs of Ein Qiniya, a band of bulging orange limestone that fringes a valley full of thorn scrub and olive groves outside Ramallah, the de facto Palestinian capital of the West Bank. Rubaa is one of a group of about 20 Palestinians, including students and telecoms workers, attending a course run by Wadi Climbing, an initiative set up by two young Americans.
The participants have travelled from across the West Bank ‚Äì from nearby Ramallah, Jenin and Nablus ‚Äì to attempt a sport in its infancy in the occupied territories. Rubaa says her parents were anxious about her new pastime. ‚ÄúMy father didn‚Äôt want me to come,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHe told me: ‚ÄòNext year you‚Äôll be in the 12th grade. It‚Äôs too important to be injured.‚Äô‚Äù But Rubaa was determined. ‚ÄúI kept asking and told him: ‚ÄòDaddy, I really want to come.‚Äô‚Äù In almost a year, about 500 people have attended Wadi Climbing‚Äôs courses, most Palestinian and 40% of them women. ‚ÄúSummer‚Äù Rushdi is older and more experienced. ‚ÄúA friend of my sister posted a link on Facebook and I knew I wanted to try it. And this is something people do in the rest of the world. That‚Äôs another reason why it is inviting,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAnd we are so involved with the reality of the [Israeli] occupation. It is all about the struggle. And it becomes part of our mentality. It is good to do what other people are doing elsewhere in the world, where people have the time and the opportunity to do different activities. That is why it is so good that this is also available to us now.‚Äù Most of those on the Wadi Climbing course are well-educated and speak fluent English. But later in the afternoon three Bedouin youths arrive. They are not part of the course, which costs about ¬£12 for a weekend of instruction, but borrow harnesses and shoes and get on to the rock.
One of the two founders of Wadi Climbing, Will Harris, explains its genesis. ‚ÄúMy partner Tim and I were living in Amman in Jordan and studying Arabic.‚Äù He says during a visit to the occupied Palestinian territories the pair were struck by the lack of recreational facilities. Much of the equipment provided on the course, including climbing shoes and harnesses, was sourced from the lost-and-found cupboards at two climbing walls in Colorado, where Wadi Climbing‚Äôs founders went to college. ‚ÄúWe came last July ‚Äì we had done a feasibility trip last January. People were overwhelmingly positive in their response so we moved here.‚Äù Wadi Climbing has developed two cliffs close to Ramallah and plans for the city‚Äôs first climbing wall are in the pipeline. The reality of the occupation is difficult to avoid, even in this quiet and pretty corner of the West Bank. In the distance a settlement and Israeli military tower are visible ‚Äì both factors have limited the development of climbing.
‚ÄúMost of climbing on the West Bank has been developed by Israeli climbers,‚Äù says Harris. ‚ÄúWhen we first came we only met one Palestinian climber. In comparison with the Palestinian territories, Israeli climbing is very active. The Israeli climbing club alone has some 3000 members. Most of that climbing on the West Bank is in Area C [ie under Israeli security control and administration]. And it is close to settlements. ‚ÄúIf you go to Ein Fara [a major climbing area for Israelis in an Israeli-controlled nature reserve in the occupied Palestinian territories between Jerusalem and Jericho] you either have to go through the neighbouring settlement and pay or you have a 40-minute walk. ‚ÄúWe recently took our first group of Palestinians into that Wadi by the walk-in access Palestinians are allowed to use. While we were on the trail two [Israeli] security guards approached us to ask where we had come from. We told them we were going to climb and they said it was OK.‚Äù They have received support from high-profile climbers, including Nina Caprez, from Switzerland, who was visiting on a sponsored trip and had inquired about the possibility of climbing in the Palestinian territories.
Harris tells the story of the young Bedouins who come to climb when he is running his courses. ‚ÄúFriday is their only day off and all they want to do is climb. Some of them work in construction in Rehan [a new Palestinian town being built on the ridge opposite the Ein Qiniya cliffs],‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThey can look over towards the cliff and if they see us they run across the valley to come climbing. These guys will be the future of Palestinian climbing.‚Äù Fifteen minutes after her first climb Rubaa is ready to try another. She asks if she can use the Guardian‚Äôs rope. This time she runs up the climb. When she returns to the ground all nervousness has gone. ‚ÄúThis is so much fun,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI want to come again.‚Äù

column4: New Zealand grounds all flights after national radar outage
column5: All scheduled flights were prevented briefly from taking off in New Zealand on Tuesday after a radar fault struck. Airways New Zealand, which manages air traffic control, grounded all commercial airlines at airports across the country. The fault struck at 2.48pm and led to delays, with passengers sitting on planes on the tarmac. A spokesman for the aviation authority said the fault was eventually rectified and services resumed about 4.20pm. A statement from Airways New Zealand said: ‚ÄúAt no point was the safety of any airport operations compromised.‚Äù Delays were expected to continue throughout the afternoon. Earlier, after the grounding order was put out, a spokesman said: ‚ÄúThere has been a radar failure that has occurred at 2.48pm [02.48 GMT] this afternoon; we are working on the issue at the moment. ‚ÄúThe impact is that all aircraft have been held on the ground. There are no aircraft taking off across the country. The aircraft that are in the air have been cleared to land.‚Äù

column4: Killing Season: Labor's collapse was the worst I've ever seen, says British adviser
column5:
Former British cabinet minister Alan Milburn, who advised Australian Labor in the 2010 and 2013 election campaigns, delivers the final blunt verdict on Labor‚Äôs term in office in the ABC‚Äôs documentary series The Killing Season. ‚ÄúThe hard question that the Australian Labor party has to ask itself is this: how is it possible that you win an election in November 2007, on the scale that you do, with the goodwill that you have, with the permission that you are gifted by the public, and you manage to lose all that goodwill, to trash the permission and to find yourself out of office within just six years. ‚ÄúI have never seen anything quite like it in any country, anywhere, anytime in any part of the world. No one can escape blame for that in my view,‚Äù he said. But in a new chapter for her autobiography My Story, Julia Gillard rejects the idea that Labor‚Äôs constant leadership turmoil during its six years in office was particularly about her and Kevin Rudd, although she argues Australia‚Äôs concentrated media ownership might exacerbate Australia‚Äôs apparent preoccupation with leadership change.
She claims the fact Tony Abbott faced a leadership spill motion last February, at a time when he was under political pressure ‚Äúas near to zero as you can get‚Äù showed instability was caused by a range of new pressures on governments of all political persuasions in modern democracies. ‚ÄúUp until that point, those who are paid for their political commentary and expertise had largely concluded that the leadership changes between Kevin Rudd and me were best explained as being something to do with the nature of the Labor party and its factions and something to do with the characters of two individuals,‚Äù she writes. ‚ÄúI have sought to explain how this kind of analysis was always simplistic and slipshod. How it deliberately ignored internal turmoil in conservative governments, including the replacement of Ted Baillieu as premier of Victoria. The changing pattern of political incumbency had also been underscored by Queensland‚Äôs hugely dramatic repudiation of its one-term conservative government led by Campbell Newman and Victoria‚Äôs return to Labor, also after just one term. ‚ÄúNow, after the events of 9 February 2015, whatever one concludes about my story, the theory that this was all about Kevin, me and the Labor party cannot stand. This view has passed its use-by date. Contemporary reality has rendered it absurd.‚Äù She points to the changing nature of the media and the difficulties it poses for politicians, and Australia‚Äôs history of leadership rivalry. ‚ÄúLooking nationally, the dominant media narrative about leadership is that now we tend to instability, whereas earlier we did not. Yet history seems to be telling us otherwise. In reality, a metanarrative of Australian national politics for more than 30 years has been leadership tensions: Hawke and Keating; Howard and Abbott and his undeclared contenders. ‚ÄúWhat seems to be changing is not the underlying cycle but the speed at which it goes around. While we share so much in media and political culture with other democracies, it seems that in this area, we are at the head of the pack. Neither the United Kingdom nor Canada, despite having the Westminster system, has seen leadership become such a dominant narrative, prime minister after prime minister, government after government. No easy explanation presents itself as to why we should be so fixated. But the nature of our media market may offer some clues. Put simply, we live in one of the most concentrated media markets in the world.‚Äù At the conclusion of the third episode of The Killing season, Rudd suggests things could have been different. Asked whether he and Gillard were better as a team, he replies: ‚ÄúOf course we were, and we were a very effective team and I wanted her to succeed me, I really did.‚Äù But Gillard disagrees. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see what alternative reality was possible other than the ones we lived through. I think people are really wistfully hoping for something that was never going to be.‚Äù

column4: Julia Gillard exclusive interview: the timid ABC is rewarding Tony Abbott
column5:
Julia Gillard has delivered a biting critique of the modern media for shallow, policy-light reporting, bias, inaccuracy and succumbing to ‚Äúbullying‚Äù, accusing the Daily Telegraph of ‚Äúintegrated bias‚Äù and the ABC of ‚Äúpulling its punches‚Äù for fear of more attacks by the Abbott government.
In a new chapter of her autobiography, My Story, and an exclusive interview with Guardian Australia, the former Labor prime minister contends that the media and Australia‚Äôs preoccupation with leadership destabilisation contribute to politicians‚Äô difficulties in arguing for increasingly necessary policy changes. The leader who in 2010 vowed to start showing Australian voters ‚Äúthe real Julia‚Äù describes what she calls a ‚Äúvicious cycle‚Äù of media preoccupation with gaffes or peripheral stumbles, leading to ever more tightly staged public appearances and even deeper voter disillusion. ‚ÄúThe very thing the public would most like to see ‚Äì spontaneity, deep ideas, a focus on the longer term ‚Äì is often the stuff least easy to portray in modern politics due to the nature of the media cycle,‚Äù she told Guardian Australia.
‚ÄúSo the public ends up feeling deprived, the media chides the politician for spin and hollowness, but the media is very rarely self-reflective about how its own practice may well be drawing out the spin and hollowness as opposed to the alternatives.‚Äù The new media cycle also rewards political negativity, she claims, benefiting Tony Abbott‚Äôs calculation in opposition to ‚Äúgo hard negative‚Äù. ‚ÄúThat kind of political calibration could have been easily made in an earlier age, but the political rewards for going simple and negative are greater in an accelerated media age that likes schlock and horror ... I think Tony Abbott‚Äôs style profits more easily in this time.‚Äù Freed from concerns about the ‚Äúindignant harrumphing‚Äù of her media targets, Gillard is also open in her opinions about different media outlets.
She writes that the Coalition‚Äôs ‚Äúbullying‚Äù of the ABC has ‚Äúpaid off‚Äù and the broadcaster frequently ‚Äúpussyfoots around potential criticism of the government‚Äù. In an interview from London, she told Guardian Australia she believed the Coalition‚Äôs early fierce attacks on the ABC‚Äôs news gathering had changed its approach. ‚ÄúI think there is such a sensitivity at the ABC to becoming the subject of more hard-hitting criticism from the government that there is a pulling of punches and I do think you can see that on the news ‚Ä¶ I watch it from time to time and I think there are clear occasions where there is not the sort of hard-hitting analysis that would have happened in different circumstances,‚Äù she says. Without passing judgment on the facts behind reports that asylum seekers had been burned while on a boat being turned back to Indonesia in 2014, Gillard says ‚Äúthe way in which the government hit hard at the ABC at that point, the way in which the ABC felt cowed enough to apologise effectively to the government, I thought that was telling you a story about the psychology in the ABC‚Äù. The former prime minister was also scathing about how quickly the radio broadcaster Alan Jones had been able to recover from the widespread condemnation of his remark that her father had ‚Äúdied of shame‚Äù ‚Äì for which Jones was forced to apologise ‚Äì saying it sent a message to young journalists that there were no limits to what could be said. ‚ÄúAlan Jones‚Äô comments did get a huge reaction, as they should, and it created a crisis for him and his show and the radio network, as it should, but here we are precious few years later and he is still on the radio, still earning considerable money to be on the radio, and the most senior politicians in the country regularly appear on his radio program, so it‚Äôs telling you there really is no line that you can‚Äôt cross and still be there in the media. ‚ÄúAnd so for any young cub reporter looking at that, what‚Äôs the lesson to be learned ‚Äì you might get a sharp reaction in the first instance but it will all be all right in the long term.‚Äù
She cites the Daily Telegraph‚Äôs front-page headline on the first day of the 2013 election campaign, ‚ÄúKick This Mob Out‚Äù, and the paper‚Äôs subsequent reporting, as an example of ‚Äúthe preparedness to integrate bias so fully into a newspaper that it ceases to play in any meaningful way the role of objectively bringing facts and balanced coverage to the attention of voters. Rather the paper is a vehicle for pushing a pre-established view.‚Äù And she writes that in Australia‚Äôs heavily concentrated media market, ‚Äúbias matters more, simply because there is less capacity to contest arguments and less diversity of commentary‚Äù. Gillard applauds comedy and the ‚Äúlarrikinism‚Äù that allows Australians to laugh at themselves, but questions whether constant ridicule invites voters not to take politicians seriously and asks why some types of ridicule appeared reserved for her ‚Äì like the ABC comedy series At Home with Julia in which actors playing her and her partner, Tim Mathieson, were portrayed having sex under an Australian flag. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve said I think the ABC crossed the line with that comedy series about me. I tried to take that as one that should be laughed through, but I thought where it got itself to was gratuitous and disrespectful and interestingly there has been no suggestion that the ABC would be producing such a comedy about the current prime minister so people might want to muse on that, why it was a Labor prime minister and the first woman and why it‚Äôs not the current prime minister.‚Äù Gillard also warned that the Abbott government‚Äôs pattern of holding royal commissions to inquire into their political opponents ‚Äì the royal commission into trade unions that called her to give evidence and has now called the Labor leader, Bill Shorten, and the royal commission into the pink batts program before which Kevin Rudd appeared ‚Äì set a dangerous precedent that could be used against the Coalition in the future.
‚ÄúThis is a shift in our political culture that‚Äôs been brought by the Abbott government, it‚Äôs an Americanisation ‚Äì intertwining judicial processes and political processes ‚Äì and, as is the way of politics, new weaponry does end up being adopted by all sides, so I suspect these won‚Äôt be the only royal commissions we see that look back at past government policy.‚Äù She says the development could deter people from becoming political advisers, given the cost of buying legal defence. ‚ÄúI think it would be a very bad circumstance in our politics if going to serve as a political staffer meant you were at risk of getting ensnared in various royal commissions and other processes and come out bankrupt. The government would say there is some legal aid support for people who are required to go before these commissions, but I know from my own experience that it is insufficient. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt complain for myself, I am a person of means. But I am concerned what it might mean for others.‚Äù Gillard cites the former Victorian premier Ted Baillieu as a ‚Äúreal-world example‚Äù of a politician who tried to ignore the demands of the media cycle. ‚ÄúHe deliberately decided to try to slow it down and ended up being chastised for not doing anything ... ultimately what happened to Premier Baillieu had a set of other explanations. It wasn‚Äôt solely a result of that, but I think the fact he ended up with a reputation as a do-nothing premier because he deliberately tried to slow down the cycle fed into issues about his leadership.‚Äù In her new chapter, 2015: Reflections on reform, she also: Points to a global loss of faith in democracy, citing the pace of economic change as one of the reasons, the ‚Äúshrieking‚Äù nature of the media and a tendency for readers to ‚Äúturn inward‚Äù in response.
Attacks journalists for criticising politicians‚Äô inability to mount a case for policy reform without assessing their own role in the process. ‚ÄúAmid all this bellowing comes the unedifying spectacle of newspaper columnists pontificating on the opinion page about the flaws of visionless, reform-shy politicians while the front page splashes gory headlines and drama-filled articles that degrade the ability of governments to reform. The ultimate irony presents when the same person, a reporter who also writes opinion pieces, smashes a reform conversation in a news piece and then, in their column, smashes politicians for not reforming. Overall it seems columnists are obsessed by the speck in a politician‚Äôs eye, ignoring the log in their own.‚Äù Criticises conservative commentators for ‚Äúcynically‚Äù misrepresenting the legacy of the Hawke and Keating governments to justify their own ideological preferences about future change, especially the deregulation of labour laws and ‚Äúto sneer at contemporary Labor being the enemy of reform‚Äù. Yearns for the day when ‚Äúa publication only extends the benefits of off-the-record quotes or views appearing in print to sources that genuinely would otherwise face some persecution or payback, not people who are using a cloak of anonymity for their own reasons‚Äù, for example backbenchers trying to stir leadership tensions. ‚ÄúOne ill-tempered comment from an anonymous backbencher is the easiest and quickest of content,‚Äù she says.
But despite all her criticism, Gillard said in her interview she was ‚Äúlong-term positive‚Äù about the capacity of the political system to achieve policy change, because of the ‚Äúpent up‚Äù need for reform and because she believes media consumers will emerge from the current era of ‚Äúclick freneticism ‚Ä¶ and say, ‚ÄòI am over the quick click now. I might do that for reports on Kim Kardashian or celebrity culture but, for things that really matter in the political culture I am going to look for more authoritative news sources.‚Äô ‚Äù ‚ÄúI think there will be a demand build up for deeper analysis, I think it will take some time for the market to sort itself out that way, but that will help us to bust out and find places to have deeper debate.‚Äù Gillard claims not to have watched the ABC‚Äôs The Killing Season series, which has included claims she could have done more to dissuade those plotting against Kevin Rudd and in favour of her before the leadership coup in 2010. She says she agreed to be interviewed for the series because she believed it would have been made with or without her participation. ‚ÄúI think for everyone who took part it was a difficult decision. I didn‚Äôt want the issues about leadership in the last Labor government to distract from my current colleagues‚Äô efforts ‚Ä¶ I thought about that very deeply, but the ABC was crystal clear that it would be made whether I participated or not. ‚ÄúOnce it‚Äôs crystal clear there is going to be that kind of show on air it becomes a question of whether you have your voice in it or not, on balance and in some ways with a bit of a heavy heart because I knew it would cause a distraction to the current colleagues, I thought it was better to have my voice in it than not, but it was a very difficult judgment.‚Äù

column4: Rwandan military general arrested in London in connection with war crimes
column5: One of Rwanda‚Äôs top military figures has been arrested in London in relation to alleged war crimes against civilians, police have said. Karenzi Karake, director general of Rwanda‚Äôs national intelligence and security services, was prevented from leaving the country on Saturday morning by the Metropolitan police extradition unit on behalf of authorities in Spain. ‚ÄúKarenzi Karake, 54, a Rwandan national appeared before Westminster magistrates‚Äô court on Saturday 20 June after being arrested on a European arrest warrant on behalf of the authorities in Spain, where he is wanted in connection with war crimes against civilians,‚Äù a Met spokesman said. Karake was remanded in custody and will reappear in court on Thursday. A Spanish judge indicted Karake in 2008 for alleged retributory war crimes in the years after the 1994 Rwandan genocide. He is accused of ordering massacres while head of Rwanda‚Äôs military intelligence between 1994 and 1997, and ordering the killing of three Spanish nationals working for the NGO M√©dicos del Mundo, the BBC reports. He is one of 40 current or former Rwandan military officials named on the indictment. Karake is a leading member of the Rwandan Patriotic Front, the current ruling party of Rwanda, and fought in the civil war that preceded the genocide in which 800,000 Tutsi and politically moderate Hutus were killed. He was previously the deputy commander of the UN peacekeeping mission in Darfur, Sudan, a role which he left in 2009. Humanitarian campaigners Human Rights Watch had protested against his appointment, accusing him of orchestrating deadly attacks against civilians when Rwandan forces were fighting Uganda in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 2000. It is thought Gen Karake had travelled to the UK on business earlier this month, and is said to have visited the country on previous occasions. Jordi Palou-Loverdos, a lawyer representing nine Spanish massacre victims, told BBC‚Äôs Newsnight: ‚ÄúWe hope in the name of the victims that this time justice will be provided and Karenzi Karake will soon be delivered to the Spanish court to have a fair trial, where he can defend himself. And we hope that political or other interests will not neutralise the place for justice, truth and reparation.‚Äù

column4: Former ambassador's bizarre attack on Obama lays bare strains in US-Israeli ties
column5:
It‚Äôs a peculiar feature of American relations with Israel that more than a few senior diplomats posted from Jerusalem to Washington were once US citizens. The present Israeli ambassador, Ron Dermer, was born in Miami Beach and carried an American passport until he renounced it in 2005 in order to serve as the Jewish state‚Äôs economic envoy in DC. When Dermer lived in the US, before moving to Israel two decades ago, he was a Republican party operative. There is a view in the White House that he remains one as ambassador after Dermer colluded with Republican leaders to embarrass Barack Obama, most notably by engineering an extraordinary foreign intervention in American politics with the Israeli prime minister‚Äôs controversial speech to Congress to denounce the president‚Äôs Iran policy. Dermer‚Äôs predecessor as envoy in Washington, Michael Oren, has now created his own diplomatic uproar with a remarkable attack on Obama that appears at least partly rooted in his disillusionment with the president as leader of the land of Oren‚Äôs birth.
Oren, a New Yorker and US citizen until 2009 when he became ambassador, has stirred outrage by suggesting that the president is not a loyal American. He has also drawn accusations of ‚Äúpsychobabble‚Äù for arguing that Obama‚Äôs alleged hostility to Israel is because abandonment by his Muslim father has driven a craving to be accepted by his father‚Äôs ‚Äúco-religionists‚Äù. In extracts from a book to be published on Tuesday, Ally: My Journey Across the American-Israeli Divide, Oren accuses the president of policies that ‚Äúimperilled Israel‚Äù not least over Iran. He told an audience in New York on Sunday that the book is intended to mobilise American opinion ahead of the deadline next week for an ‚Äúemphatically bad‚Äù US nuclear deal with Iran reached over the objections of Israel. Oren wrote in the book of how disturbed he was that Israel‚Äôs ‚Äúclosest ally had entreated with our deadliest enemy on an existential issue without so much as informing us‚Äù. Oren, who is now a member of Israel‚Äôs parliament, writes that Obama is soft on terrorism, a claim open to challenge from those on the end of US drone attacks. He also paints the president‚Äôs advisers as infected with ‚Äúneo-Marxist ideas‚Äù from studies at American universities. Oren, who was ambassador to the US until 2013, has promoted the book with a blitz of opinion pieces and interviews, including one in the Wall Street Journal under the headline, How Obama Abandoned Israel. He describes relations between the US and Israel as ‚Äúin tatters‚Äù in part after the president dared to demand Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu halt the inexorable expansion of Jewish settlements in the occupied territories which has done so much to undermine the prospects of peace and a Palestinian state. Tellingly, Oren says in an interview about the book with the Times of Israel that the creation of a Palestinian state is ‚Äúunrealistic‚Äù but that Israel should keep up the diplomatic pretence of supporting one. That is widely considered to be the true position of Netanyahu who promised voters before this year‚Äôs Israeli election that he would not permit the creation of a Palestinian state but, under US criticism, claimed to have altered his position after he was re-elected. Oren writes that he has tried to understand why the president acts as he does and came to the conclusion that it is because Obama does not believe in American exceptionalism. That leads the former Israeli ambassador to perhaps his most incendiary charge, that the president is somehow disloyal to the US. ‚ÄúMore alarming for me still were Obama‚Äôs attitudes towards America. Vainly, I scoured Dreams from My Father (Obama‚Äôs first book) for some expression of reverence, even respect, for the country its author would someday lead. Instead, the book criticizes Americans for their capitalism and consumer culture, for despoiling their environment and maintaining antiquated power structures. Traveling abroad, they exhibited ‚Äòignorance and arrogance‚Äô‚Äì the very shortcomings the president‚Äôs critics assigned to him,‚Äù writes Oren, according to an excerpt released to the rightwing Breitbart.
Oren drew more fire over an article in Foreign Policy on Friday which said that Obama has been hard on Israel and more sympathetic to the Arab world in part because his father and stepfather were Muslim. ‚ÄúI could imagine how a child raised by a Christian mother might see himself as a natural bridge between her two Muslim husbands. I could also speculate how that child‚Äôs abandonment by those men could lead him, many years later, to seek acceptance by their co-religionists,‚Äù he wrote. Yair Lapid, former finance minister and leader of the Yesh Atid party, told Israel radio that Oren‚Äôs claim of Muslim influence on the US president was ‚Äúutter nonsense‚Äù and ‚Äúpseudo-psychological analysis not based on anything‚Äù. The head of the strongly pro-Israel Anti Defamation League, Abe Foxman, accused Oren of veering ‚Äúinto the realm of conspiracy theories‚Äù. ‚ÄúWith an element of amateur psychoanalysis he links US policies in the Middle East to the president‚Äôs personal history of having a Muslim father. Then, taking it a step further by suggesting this ‚Äúworldview‚Äù of Muslims and Islam has driven the president to embrace the Muslim world at the expense of both Israel and US national security interests. This results in borderline stereotyping and insensitivity,‚Äù said Foxman. Oren offers an insight into how deep the tensions between Obama and Netanyahu were, and also how powerless the White House was to influence the Israeli leader. The former ambassador reveals an incident in which the then US ambassador to the UN, Susan Rice, threatened to withdraw Washington‚Äôs unswerving support for Israel in the security council unless Netanyahu stopped the relentless construction of Jewish settlements which is a major factor in preventing a peace agreement. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt appreciate the fact that we defend you night and day, tell us,‚Äù admonished Rice. The Israeli government has sought to distance itself from Oren even though there is little doubt that his book reflects the betrayal some of its leaders feel toward Obama. It has said that the former ambassador largely played a ‚Äúpublic diplomacy‚Äù role in Washington and was out of the loop on many of the more important negotiations with the US. The deputy foreign minister, Tzipi Hotovely, said that Oren only represents himself, not the government. ‚ÄúThe United States is a true friend of Israel and every attempt to harm the relationship between the two countries by resorting to personal attacks will not succeed,‚Äù she told the Israeli website Walla News. Haaretz reported that the US ambassador in Tel Aviv, Dan Shapiro, took him to task over the book and subsequent articles. The newspaper said Shapiro appealed to Netanyahu to issue a public statement repudiating Oren‚Äôs claims but that the Israeli prime minister refused. Oren defended the book to the Times of Israel as ‚Äúa cri de coeur ‚Ä¶ for an alliance that should be in a much better place than it is‚Äù. Perhaps hoping to avoid giving more publicity to Oren‚Äôs book, the White House has so far declined to comment.

column4: UK police need 24/7 counter-terror 'hotline' with Turkey, says Keith Vaz
column5:
British police must urgently set up round-the-clock communications with their counterparts in Turkey to stop Britons crossing into territory controlled by Islamic State, a prominent MP has said. Keith Vaz, chair of the home affairs select committee, made the demands after meeting the husbands of two of three sisters who are feared to have travelled to Syria with their children to join the terror group. Bradford-born sisters Khadija Dawood, 30, Sugra Dawood, 34, and Zohra Dawood, 33, and their nine children, aged between three and 15, are feared to have travelled via Istanbul after visiting Saudi Arabia for a religious pilgrimage.
Vaz, Labour MP for Leicester East, met Sugra‚Äôs husband, Akhtar Iqbal, and Mohammad Shoaib, husband of Khadija, to discuss the situation on Monday. A lawyer acting for the men wrote to Vaz over the weekend accusing UK police of beingcomplicit in the alleged ‚Äúgrooming and radicalising‚Äù of the three Bradford sisters, saying the husbands were ‚Äúextremely disappointed with the manner in which this matter is being investigated by West Yorkshire police‚Äù. Following the meeting on Monday Vaz said in a statement: ‚ÄúI met today with the fathers and their legal representatives for one and a quarter hours. They were clearly heartbroken, and want to be reunited with their wives and children as soon as possible. ‚ÄúThey expressed serious concerns about how the police have dealt with their wives over a number of months. I will be meeting with the Counter Terror Unit from the region tomorrow.‚Äù Vaz said there were a number of urgent measures that should be put in place.
‚ÄúFirstly, we need a hotline between the UK and Istanbul. Isis work on a 24/7 basis and our Consulate in Istanbul must also work continuously. We cannot continue to rely on emails. Rather like the Bethnal Green case, the system needs to cope better with these urgent cases,‚Äù he said, referring to the Bethnal Green teenagers who ran away together to Turkey and are believed to have joined Isis. ‚ÄúSecondly,‚Äù wrote Vaz, ‚Äúthe police need to meet with the fathers at a senior level urgently to clear the lines of communication. ‚ÄúThirdly, the prime minister is right that we must bring an end to the ‚Äòfinger pointing‚Äô. This is a fight for hearts and minds of British citizens being groomed by Isis. Our efforts need to be led by the families and communities.‚Äù Last week the men‚Äôs lawyer told the Guardian that the Met police had just one counter-terror officer in Turkey.
