Carr says he is fed up with talks of an American dream, and of black martyrs like those young girls in Birmingham, Alabama, of calls by a president for gun control, a culture of which was conceived precisely to keep black Americans down. ‚ÄúThose words ring hollow to African Americans who do not seem to enjoy protection from state violence, or from private paramilitary acts of violence,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThis speaks to the structural failure of America to protect its black citizens.‚Äù

column4: Greece to make improved offer to international creditors
column5:
Greece is to improve its offer to its international creditors in a new attempt to find agreement before a deadline at the end of June which could force the country into default and out of the eurozone.
Athens has been locked in negotiations with European leaders for weeks, but has been unable to reach a compromise on the reforms demanded by its creditors in return for a fresh tranche of cash. The European Central Bank provided ‚Ç¨1.8bn in emergency funding for the Greek banking system on Friday to keep it afloat over the weekend, after Greeks withdrew more than ‚Ç¨1bn in a single day, prompted by fears that their country was about to slip deeper into economic crisis. The minister of state, Alekos Flabouraris, told a Greek television show on Saturday morning that the government was prepared to bring new reforms to the table when talks restarted. ‚ÄúWe will try to supplement our proposal so that we get closer to a solution,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe are not going there with the old proposal. Some work is being done to see where we can converge, so that we achieve a mutually beneficial solution.‚Äù If Greece does not receive a fresh bailout from its creditors by 30 June, it will be unable to meet the next repayment of ‚Ç¨1.6bn to the International Monetary Fund and could be turfed out of the single currency. The prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, and his leftwing government elected in January on an anti-austerity platform, have so far refused to give in to eurozone demands that they cut pensions and raise taxes. Flabouraris, who is close to Tsipras, said he was confident a deal would be reached soon. A teleconference between Tsipras and the head of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, will probably take place today, he said. Tsipras is on his way back to Greece from Russia, where he has been seeking support from Vladimir Putin. Speaking in St Petersburg on Friday, Tsipras expressed confidence that a deal would be done. ‚ÄúAll those who are betting on crisis and terror scenarios will be proven wrong,‚Äù he said.

column4: Charleston shooting: Confederate flag at heart of growing political storm
column5:
Pressure is mounting on South Carolina to pull down the Confederate flag that continues to fly on the grounds of the state capitol, after a Republican legislator announced plans to introduce a bill to remove the divisive symbol that has inflamed feelings in the wake of the Charleston church shootings. Norman ‚ÄúDoug‚Äù Brannon, a white legislator, said on MSNBC that he wanted to introduce the bill because of the death of his friend Clementa Pinckney, a reverend and state senator who was pastor of the Emanuel AME church and one of nine worshippers gunned down there on Wednesday night. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not political tonight, but I do have access and I will file that bill in December,‚Äù Brannon said.
The flag, which represents the region that seceded from the Union in 1861 in defense of slavery, has become the focus of rising tension in South Carolina as a result of the racist opinions expressed by the suspected shooter, Dylann Roof, 21, who was arrested a day after the rampage in a car that bore the Confederate icon. The Battle Flag of the Northern Virginia Army, as the controversial banner is also known, once flew above the state house dome, but was moved to its current location still in state grounds in 2000. President Barack Obama said pointedly on Friday that the flag belongs in a museum. Speaking after a vigil on Friday at the the TD arena in downtown Charleston, South Carolina senator and Republican presidential hopeful Lindsey Graham conceded that further debate on the matter needed to occur but declined to take a position. ‚ÄúThere are graveyards of Confederate soldiers all over the state ‚Äì what do we do? How much of revisiting one‚Äôs past is it going to take before we can move forward? To the extent this debate helps us move forward, let‚Äôs have that debate.‚Äù Asked by the Guardian what his position in that debate was, however, Graham responded: ‚ÄúThat it happens here.‚Äù During standing ovations at the vigil, as those on the podium called for the flag to come down, Graham and fellow South Carolina republican senator Tim Scott stayed seated. The growing demand for a resolution to South Carolina‚Äôs official attachment to one America‚Äôs most notorious symbols highlights the fault-line that exists to this day in a state that has consistently failed to make a clean break with its racist secessionist past. The revived dispute over the Confederate flag that has erupted in the wake of the Charleston shootings is just the sharpest expression of an age-old seeping wound. All across the state, from the urban centers of Columbia and Charleston to the conservative rural heartlands in the north, examples of the Confederacy‚Äôs stranglehold on the collective imagination, at least of many white Carolinians, abound. They vary from moderate to extreme, from whimsical to revolutionary.
At the mild end of the spectrum are the many outposts of what might be called Confederacy nostalgia, epitomized by the Confederate Museum located just a few blocks away from the Emanuel AME church. The museum has been curated in a hall that in 1861 was used to recruit and arm thousands of secessionist soldiers. It is still run by the Charleston chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, a group formed by the female descendants of the soldiers and sailors of the Confederate forces. Its exhibits include the Secession Flag, as well as a captured Union battle flag. On the more extreme end, South Carolina remains a hotbed of neo-confederacy nationalism calling for a new secession, according to the Southern Poverty Law Center which monitors hate groups and extremist organisations. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no other state that has this level of pro-confederate sympathies, of hate-group organizations or such an open public display of the Confederate battle flag,‚Äù said the SPLC‚Äôs Heidi Beirich. The law center has identified 19 active hate groups in South Carolina, some six of which have secessionist aspirations.
Debate about the prevalence of Confederate imagery in South Carolina was rekindled by photographs of Roof posing on the bonnet of his car that bore a Confederacy license plate. He also made ‚Äúracially inflammatory‚Äù comments during the shooting spree, according to local police. Though there is no evidence that Roof was directly connected to any hate groups or secessionist campaigns, there are concerns that ubiquitous cultural references to the golden past of the antebellum south may have fueled his racist obsessions. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt get those ideas from nowhere,‚Äù Beirich said. One of the most prominent secessionist groups in the state is the South Carolina League of the South. It owns a ‚ÄúSouthern Patriot Shop‚Äù and a two-acre plot of land in Abbeville, site of the first secession speeches in 1860 that triggered the civil war, which it has turned into a memorial park. The league‚Äôs chairman in South Carolina, Pat Hines, told the Guardian that the purpose of the group was the ‚Äúsurvival and wellbeing of the southern people. We feel we are under siege ‚Äì we‚Äôve been under attack for the past 150 years.‚Äù Hines said that the league‚Äôs members in South Carolina wanted to see a new secession of the southern states. He estimated that some 25% to 40% of the population of the state supported the idea.
Then he clarified to the Guardian that he was referring exclusively to white South Carolinians. ‚ÄúWe consider southern people to be whites,‚Äù he said. Hines denied that the new secessionist movement had any responsibility for the crazed violence of the Charleston mass killer. In fact, he said the league was upset by Roof‚Äôs adoption of the Confederate flag. ‚ÄúWe have negative feelings about the fact that this drug-addled young man chose to display southern symbols. We don‚Äôt advocate doing anything like he did. Ask how many southern nationalists have been involved in mass shootings ‚Äì the answer is zero.‚Äù In Columbia, the state capital, there were rumors on social media on Friday that a demonstration would take place in an effort to push lawmakers to finally remove the Confederate flag from the state house. It was first raised above the dome of the capital building in 1961, a provocative act coming at a particularly sensitive moment in the history of US civil rights. Jayne Williams, who is white, ended up being one of two people to show up for the rumored demonstration, and instead sat in the sweltering heat, next to the flags and the signs she had made demanding that the flag be taken down. ‚ÄúThe fact that a pastor and a victim served in the state house and they are basically flying a white victory flag out here is just disgusting me,‚Äù said Williams, who is a graduate of Columbine high school, the site of what was once the United States‚Äô most notorious mass shooting. She drove from North Carolina to South Carolina on a whim, having told her husband that she knew it was crazy, but she needed to see the Confederate flag flying full mast outside the state house building in Columbia, while state and American flags flew at half mast in honor of the nine of victims of the Charleston shooting. Frustrated, sad and angry, Williams placed nine American flags around the state house‚Äôs Confederate memorial, in honor of the Charleston victims. A black state trooper had to ask her to remove the flags.
Meanwhile, black children did cartwheels on the state house lawn as one of their relatives had her pictures taken in a wedding dress on top of the building‚Äôs steps. The Confederate flag flew behind the lens. Gwendolyn Neal, a black woman who was born and raised in South Carolina, said the sign is blatantly offensive: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always going to be a slap in the face, as long as it‚Äôs up there.‚Äù ‚Ä¢This story was amended on 24 June, 2015, to delete a claim that the Confederate Museum stood on the site of an old slave market.

column4: World‚Äôs most inaccessible art found in the heart of the Colombian jungle
column5:
A British wildlife film-maker has returned from one of the most inaccessible parts of the world with extraordinary footage of ancient rock art that has never been filmed or photographed before. In an area of Colombia so vast and remote that contact has still not been made with some tribes thought to live there, Mike Slee used a helicopter to film hundreds of paintings depicting hunters and animals believed to have been created thousands of years ago. He said: ‚ÄúWe had crews all over the place and helicopters filming all over Colombia. As a photographer, Francisco Forero Bonell discovered and took the pictures for my movie.‚Äù The extraordinary art includes images of jaguar, crocodiles and deer. They are painted in red, on vertical rock faces in Chiribiquete national park, a 12,000 square kilometre Unesco world heritage site that is largely unexplored. There are also paintings of warriors or hunters dancing or celebrating. ‚ÄúIt is the land that time forgot,‚Äù Slee told the Observer. There had previously been only vague reports of rock art in the area, which is known as Cerro Campana, he said: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no information, maps or communication. It‚Äôs such a massive central part of Colombia.‚Äù Though some paintings had previously been found and photographed elsewhere in Chiribiquete, this Cerro Campana art has never been filmed or photographed, Slee said: ‚ÄúIt was an absolutely stunning moment to be able to get the footage.‚Äù Slee used a helicopter to gain access to the area, as the terrain is impenetrable ‚Äì thick vegetation, forested rock peaks and valleys, sheer cliffs and giant rock towers soaring through a rainforest canopy. Professor Fernando Urbina, a rock art specialist from the National University of Colombia, was struck by the ‚Äúmagnificent naturalism‚Äù of the depictions of deer when shown the photographs. ‚ÄúThey reveal the hand of a master of painting,‚Äù he said, adding that the paintings could be up to 20,000 years old. He was particularly interested in a human figure in a seated position whose arms appear to be folded over his shoulders, a ritual position in Amazonian cultures. ‚ÄúA seated man has special significance as the sage of the tribe,‚Äù he said.
The art may have been painted by the Karijona tribe, a few of whose members still live in the region. The seated position might suggest a prisoner or slave, Urbina said.Jean Clottes, a French prehistorian, and author of Cave Art ‚Äì a book covering key sites such as Lascaux in France ‚Äì described the images as exciting and well-preserved, but said it would be hard to determine their age because radiocarbon dating could not be used, as they were painted with mineral-based materials derived from iron oxide rather than the charcoal used in European rock art. The species depicted are thought to include capybaras, snakes and anteaters. Slee described the art as a wildlife chapel. ‚ÄúThe peoples who once lived here have left in pictures testimony of their awe and respect for the wild,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhen I saw the images, I honestly felt an affinity with the artists. They were attempting to capture the power, grace, spirit and essence of the animal in pictures. Perhaps it was to make the hunt better next day, but there is clearly careful observation in their art. It‚Äôs what contemporary photographers, painters, film-makers set out to do when they create a wildlife project.‚Äù Slee made his name making natural history films and directed the movie Bugs! 3D, about two rainforest insects, narrated by Judi Dench. In 2012, the Observer reported that his Flight of the Butterflies 3D had captured butterflies in unprecedented detail, moving scientists to tears at an early screening. Over the past three years, Slee has been exploring Colombia to make Colombia: Wild Magic, which will be in cinemas next year. Through spectacular footage, it portrays ‚Äúa majestic tropical wilderness‚Äù ‚Äì but one he said was threatened by humans who are ‚Äútaking more than they are giving‚Äù. With swooping aerial footage and detailed close-ups, it reveals a landscape of canyons and caves, lakes and lagoons, rivers and rock masses with ‚Äúthe largest varieties of living things on the planet‚Äù, including unique species of hummingbird and endangered jaguar.
Drawing on the expertise of a dozen scientific advisers, the film warns of threats from the world‚Äôs ‚Äúcraving‚Äù for natural resources such as gold and emeralds. Slee said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got illegal gold-mining polluting the rivers, we‚Äôre overfishing the seas, the habitat destruction is massive. We‚Äôre taking out the rainforest, we‚Äôre losing species every week. We have the most beautiful country on Earth and we are in danger of destroying it. There are places that no Colombian has been. It‚Äôs mainly because, when you think of Colombia, you think of kidnapping and drugs.‚Äù Bonell, a Colombian conservationist and photographer, was inspired to become executive producer of the film, describing the region as ‚Äúone of the few areas on our planet that still remains unspoiled and unexplored‚Äù. The film has been produced by British company Off The Fence, and will be distributed free in schools in Colombia, as well as cinemas, ‚Äúspreading the word about what their country has and the need to protect it‚Äù, Slee said. Slee hopes to return for another large-scale expedition focusing on the rock art. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve probably only scratched the surface,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere are believed to be many hundreds of these cave paintings dotted throughout that central region.‚Äù

column4: Obama's strong words on Charleston shooting: 'I refuse to act as if this is the new normal'
column5:
Declaring that he refused to ‚Äúact as if this is the new normal‚Äù, President Barack Obama on Friday called for a national moment of soul-searching over gun violence, in his second statement in as many days on Wednesday‚Äôs mass shooting inside a church in Charleston, South Carolina. ‚ÄúMore than 11,000 Americans were killed by gun violence in 2013 alone,‚Äù Obama said in an afternoon appearance at a national conference of mayors in San Francisco. ‚ÄúIf Congress had passed some commonsense legislation after Newtown, after a group of children had been gunned down in their own classroom, reforms that 90% of the American people supported ‚Ä¶ we might still have more Americans with us.‚Äù
The words echoed a statement the president delivered at the White House on Thursday, in which he said that ‚Äúat some point, we as a country will have to reckon with the fact that this type of mass violence does not happen in other advanced countries‚Äù. Gun advocacy groups including the National Rifle Association have said a new national debate over guns was inappropriate so soon after the massacre, in which nine African Americans were shot dead inside Emanuel AME church. Dylann Roof, a 21-year-old white man said to have yelled racist taunts before he shot, was arrested on Thursday and charged with the crime.
In his statement to the mayors, the president rejected a foreclosure of the gun debate. He said repeated incidences of mass shootings made a serious national discussion about gun control more urgent. ‚ÄúAs much as we grieve this particular tragedy, it‚Äôs important to step back and recognize that these tragedies have become far too commonplace,‚Äù Obama said. Over the course of his presidency, Obama has delivered similar statements expressing shock and dismay, and calling for change, after other mass shootings. Victims have included soldiers at Fort Hood, Texas, in two separate incidents; wounded congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords in Tucson, Arizona, and six others who were killed; moviegoers in Aurora, Colorado; worshippers at a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wisconsin; first-graders in Newtown, Connecticut; and people at a Washington DC naval base. In his statement, the president said that Congress should follow the will of the people, and that the national will had shown itself capable of rapid change on issues such as same-sex marriage and, more incrementally, on climate change. The same can happen with gun control, Obama said. ‚ÄúI am not resigned,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI have faith that we will eventually do the right thing. I was simply making the point that we have to move public opinion. We have to feel a sense of urgency. ‚ÄúAt some point as a country, we have to reckon with what happens. It‚Äôs not enough to express sympathy. You don‚Äôt see this kind of murder, on this scale, with this kind of frequency in other advanced countries on earth.‚Äù

column4: Putin says Fifa's granting of World Cup to Russia 'should not be questioned'
column5: Russia fought honestly for the right to host the 2018 World Cup and the decision should not be called into question, Vladimir Putin has declared. Swiss judicial authorities are investigating the awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar as part of a far-reaching corruption scandal that has also raised questions about the 2010 event in South Africa. ‚ÄúWe fought in an honest manner [for the tournament] and we won. We do not think the decision should be questioned,‚Äù Putin told journalists on the sidelines of an investment forum in Saint Petersburg. ‚ÄúWe were ready and that‚Äôs what convinced Fifa. The stadium construction has already started. The head of Fifa‚Äôs auditing and compliance committee, Domenico Scala, this month warned Russia and Qatar could lose the right to host the the 2018 and 2022 World Cups if evidence was found of corruption in the bidding process. Putin said Russia supported the corruption inquiry currently unfolding at world football‚Äôs governing body but said it was ‚Äúup to a court to decide if someone was guilty‚Äù. The president said no evidence had been found of any corruption. ‚ÄúIf anyone has evidence, let them present it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe won in a fair fight and are going to host the World Cup.‚Äù Putin also insisted Russia wanted to co-operate with Washington and its allies in dealing with the threat posed by Islamic State and other global challenges as he tried to allay investors‚Äô fears over the country‚Äôs course. Putin blamed the United States for ignoring Russia‚Äôs interests and trying to enforce its will on others but he sent conciliatory signals, saying Moscow wanted a quick settlement to the Iranian nuclear standoff and a peaceful political transition in Syria. Russia wanted February‚Äôs Ukraine peace agreement to succeed, he said. Fighting there would stop once Ukraine provided broader rights to its eastern regions, gave amnesty to the rebels and called local elections. The annual event, intended to burnish Russia‚Äôs image before global investors, was tarnished by the freezing of Russian accounts in France and Belgium on Thursday as part of an effort to enforce a $50bn judgment to compensate shareholders of the now-defunct Yukos oil company. Putin sought to downplay the freeze and said Russia would contest it. He argued the arbitration court in The Hague, Netherlands, which issued the ruling in 2014, does not have jurisdiction over Russia. The court ruled Russia must pay damages to shareholders in the oil company, which was dismantled in a politically driven onslaught that saw its chief executive, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, sentenced to 10 years in prison. EU and US sanctions over Ukraine have helped push Russia‚Äôs economy into recession and cut investment and imports dramatically. Putin, however, argued on Friday the Russian economy was on the path to recovery and the west hurt itself by imposing the sanctions. Asked about the downing of a Malaysia Airlines plane over eastern Ukraine last July that killed all 298 people on board and triggered the toughening of western sanctions, Putin said it was necessary to wait for the conclusions of the Dutch Safety Board investigation into the crash. Controversy continues over who downed the airliner. Ukraine and the west suspect it was destroyed by a surface-to-air missile fired by Russian soldiers or Russia-backed separatist rebels fighting in the area. Russia denies this. Putin referred to an unofficial report alleging the damage to the Malaysian airliner could have been inflicted by a missile launched from the area held by Ukrainian forces at the time. Putin‚Äôs speech on the economy lacked any engagement on his part or specific proposals to turn around the economy. A large number of Russian and foreign investors in the audience were reading news or emails on their smartphones as Putin delivered a speech in which he did not address the severe crisis businesses in Russia are facing. In contrast to the economy speech, Putin was much more animated while responding to questions about foreign policy. His emphasis on foreign affairs has reflected the way the Kremlin has been running Russia since the Ukrainian conflict began. Critics have blamed Putin for sacrificing the country‚Äôs economic growth for geopolitical ends such as the 2014 annexation of Crimea. David Iakobashvili, founder of Russia‚Äôs once-largest beverage company and head of a Russia-US business council, said businessmen have got used to the fact Putin seems to prioritise foreign policy goals over domestic development. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very clear today that geopolitics is more important from his point of view,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut ... we shall adapt to whatever environment has been presented by the government and act accordingly.‚Äù Addressing the forum, Putin argued Russia wants February‚Äôs peace deal for Ukraine to succeed. He said Russia was exerting pressure on the rebels to abide by the agreement and urged the US to encourage Kiev to comply. Ukraine and the west have accused Russia of breaking the peace deal by supporting the rebels with troops and weapons. Moscow denies this. Commenting on the accusations, Putin said the rebels are defending themselves against the Ukrainian military. He added that ‚Äúonce an attempt is made to solve the problem by political means, those weapons will be gone‚Äù. In Washington, State Department spokesman John Kirby called on Russia to fully implement February‚Äôs ceasefire agreement in Ukraine and remove heavy weapons from the country. As for Putin linking the arms to a political solution, Kirby said it was ‚Äúdifficult to have a political solution when you‚Äôve still got thousands of combined Russian separatist forces inside Ukraine fomenting violence and instability, and violating the agreement that they signed up to.‚Äù Putin used the investment conference as yet another opportunity to blame the US and the European Union for triggering the Ukrainian crisis by refusing to take into account what he described as Russia‚Äôs legitimate interests. ‚ÄúThey have pushed us back to the line beyond which we can‚Äôt retreat,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúRussia isn‚Äôt seeking hegemony or some ephemeral superpower status.‚Äù Putin said Russia wants to co-operate with the west in tackling global threats and challenges ‚Äì including Islamic State, calling the extremist group an ‚Äúabsolute evil‚Äù that requires stronger joint efforts to combat. Putin also said Russia wants a deal ending the standoff over the Iranian nuclear program to be signed as planned before the end of June, but cautioned against putting ‚Äúunfulfillable‚Äù demands upon Tehran. And he also voiced readiness to encourage the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, to discuss a peaceful political transition. He explained Moscow‚Äôs backing for the Syrian ruler was to prevent the victory of radical forces who would begin a reign of terror. ‚ÄúWe are ready to work with the president to ensure political transformation, so that all Syrians have access to instruments of power,‚Äù he said. The Associated Press and Agence France-Presse contributed to this report

column4: A novel oasis: why Argentina is the bookshop capital of the world
column5:
Their country has endured military dictatorship, economic collapse and a particularly vituperative brand of politics, so perhaps it is not surprising that Argentinians should still find solace in the oldest of pleasures: curling up with a good book.
The country‚Äôs capital Buenos Aires has more bookshops per inhabitant than any other city in the world, according to a recent study by the World Cities Culture Forum. With a population of around 2.8 million, Buenos Aires has at least 734 bookstores ‚Äì roughly 25 bookshops for every 100,000 inhabitants. Worldwide, only Hong Kong comes close, with 22 bookshops per 100,000, followed by Madrid in a distant third with just 16 and compared to a mere 10 bookshops for every 100,000 for London. Gabriela Adamo, who until recently was the president of the city‚Äôs annual book fair ‚Äì an event which draws over 1 million visitors each year ‚Äì says Argentina‚Äôs love affair with the book is related to the wave of mass immigration in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. A century ago, Buenos Aires was the shining capital of one of the wealthiest countries of the world. European immigrants poured into Buenos Aires, creating a multicultural environment in which culture and the arts thrived. At one stage Buenos Aires boasted two English-language newspapers, various German-language papers (including at one stage a pro-Nazi paper, an anti-Nazi one and a Jewish newspaper) along with a plethora of Spanish-language newspapers, magazines and literary and arts publications. ‚ÄúThe book as an object became a cultural symbol back then. It‚Äôs something that persists today,‚Äù said Adamo. But contemporary economics also plays a role: books are exempt from Argentina‚Äôs standard sales tax ‚Äì a whopping 21% on most goods ‚Äì and internet sales and electronic book readers have yet to make inroads on the local publishing market. Amazon does not have an Argentinian site and import restrictions make it a bureaucratic nightmare to purchase books from international internet sellers. ‚ÄúArgentinians still prefer to come in and browse for books,‚Äù said Antonio Dalto, business manager of the Ateneo Grand Splendid bookshop. ‚ÄúWe have a website for selling books, but it only draws a small percentage of readers. As a matter of fact, they seem to use it more to select titles online, but then they come to buy the actual book here at the shop.‚Äù
That is perhaps unsurprising, considering the grandeur of the shop‚Äôs setting: opened as a theatre in 1919 and converted into a giant bookstore 15 years ago, the Grand Splendid still boasts the beautiful ceiling frescoes painted by an Italian artist almost a century ago. Around 1 million customers visit it each year to browse through its gargantuan 21,000 square feet showroom, or withdraw into one of the old theatre boxes perched for a leisurely read. ‚ÄúCulture is very important to the people of Buenos Aires. Even young kids read books, we see them here every day. Books for teenagers are one of our biggest sellers,‚Äù said Dalto. Publishers and booksellers say that the city‚Äôs book market is distinctly catholic in taste, immune to fads or fashion. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a very particular kind of reader here, with wide and varied demand,‚Äù said Adamo. Argentina is one of the most prolific book publishers in Latin America, and the number of titles published has grown steadily each year, from 16,092 in 2004 to 28,010 last year. The total number of books printed in 2014 was 123m. Publishing experts have also linked the country‚Äôs love for reading to its obsession with psychoanalysis: Argentina has more psychologists per inhabitant than any other country in the world, and according to Virginia Ungar, a member of the Buenos Aires Psychoanalytical Association, the habitual introspection of therapy makes Argentinians ideal readers. ‚ÄúPsychoanalysis, reading and the arts in general are all linked because they are all an inquiry into the depths of personality. Both literature and psychoanalysis work with the word,‚Äù said Ungar, who is president-elect of the International Psychoanalytical Association founded by Sigmund Freud in 1910. It is not only the market for new books which is thriving: Buenos Aires also has a total of 102 rare and secondhand bookshops, far outranking London with only 68 or Berlin, with only six, and only third in terms of secondhand bookshops per inhabitant after Johannesburg and Tokyo, most of them congregated along Avenida Corrientes.
The city‚Äôs unusual hours ‚Äì people often meet for dinner at 11pm, and shops stay open until after midnight ‚Äì also play a role, said Ignacio Iraola, general manager of the Argentinian branch of the Spanish publishing behemoth Planeta. ‚ÄúBuenos Aires is a city that wakes up late and the day stretches out into the early hours,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAvenida Corrientes is like a long, open bookshop that never sleeps.‚Äù Away from the city centre, local bookshops also thrive. Tucked away in the bohemian neighbourhood of Villa Crespo is La Internacional Argentina, an independent store which specialises in first editions of Latin American authors. On a recent evening, its owners Francisco Garamona and Nicol√°s Moguilevsky, both thirtysomething, were ending the day with some bottles of red Argentinian wine in the back room where they run Mansalva, a speciality press that publishes many first-time novelists and poets, as well as art books by Argentinian painters. ‚ÄúIf this was a job we would have got bored by now and quit ‚Äì our existence is a miracle,‚Äù says Garamona. Although the bookshop and Mansalva press barely scrape by, they have been in business for 15 years now, a testament to the unquenchable thirst of the city for books. ‚ÄúWe hold a fair every two months on a Saturday on the sidewalk here,‚Äù says Moguilevsky. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really surprising, sometimes up to 500 people come, many of them young kids. And they usually walk away with two or three books that they get here for the price they would pay for just one at one of the big bookshops downtown.‚Äù

column4: 'I forgive you': Charleston church victims' families confront suspect
column5:
‚ÄúI forgive you,‚Äù said the daughter of 70-year-old Ethel Lance to the 21-year-old man who allegedly murdered her mother in church and appeared at an emotionally charged video court appearance in Charleston on Friday afternoon, two days after a horrific mass shooting here.
Relatives of the Emanuel church victims stood up one by one in the courtroom, offering forgiveness to the man accused of murdering their sons, mothers and grandfathers in cold blood, as a nation continued to call for justice. Dylann Roof appeared at his bond hearing via videolink from the Charleston detention center, where he is being held in isolation. Officials later confirmed he is being detained in the same jail unit as Michael Slager, the white police officer who just 10 weeks ago stood in the same court, charged with the murder of Walter Scott, whom he shot five times from behind as the unarmed black man ran away. ‚ÄúYou took something very precious from me, but I forgive you,‚Äù Lance‚Äôs daughter said through tears. ‚ÄúIt hurts me. You hurt a lot of people, but may God forgive you.‚Äù Speaking of her son Tywanza Sanders, who was also killed on Wednesday night trying to shield his great aunt from gunfire, Felicia Sanders said to the suspect: ‚ÄúWe welcomed you Wednesday night in our Bible study with open arms. You have killed some of the most beautifullest people that I know. Every fiber in my body hurts. I will never be the same.‚Äù
She continued: ‚ÄúTywanza was my hero. But as they say in the Bible study, we enjoyed you, but may God have mercy on your soul.‚Äù Roof stood still, in an oversized black-and-gray striped inmate‚Äôs uniform, as Judge James Gosnell requested a representative from each family to declare if they wished to make a formal statement. The 21-year-old was flanked by two heavily armored officers throughout the hearing. He uttered very few words, confirming his age, employment status and address in a timid baritone. As successive relatives stood to offer him forgiveness, he expressed no emotion, staring down and occasionally into the camera inside a cell. Court officials later confirmed that Roof could see into the courtroom and heard each of the speeches, but he could not see the relatives who stood a few feet away from the judge, out of his view. Alanna Simmons, the granddaughter of 74-year-old retired pastor Daniel Simmons, stood after Sanders. ‚ÄúAlthough my grandfather and the other victims died at the hands of hate, this is proof that they lived and loved,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHate won‚Äôt win.‚Äù In all, five representatives of the nine people killed in the massacre spoke at the hearing, with President Barack Obama tweeting shortly after the hearing that the ‚Äúdecency and goodness of the American people shines through in these families‚Äù.
In an address later on Friday in San Francisco, Obama made a renewed call to action on gun control, saying he had ‚Äúfaith we will eventually do the right thing‚Äù despite political gridlock in Washington. ‚ÄúThe apparent motivations of the shooter remind us that racism remains a blight that we have to combat together,‚Äù he said. The small courthouse in Charleston was packed full of relatives and friends who had arrived earlier in the afternoon in small groups, walking through the sweltering 95-degree heat, flanked by sheriff‚Äôs deputies and taking no questions from media. In an opening statement Judge Gosnell asked that Roof‚Äôs family be acknowledged as they were also victims of his crimes. ‚ÄúWe would like you to take this opportunity to repent,‚Äù said Anthony Thompson, grandson of 59-year-old Myra Thompson as the family‚Äôs statements continued. ‚ÄúRepent. Confess. Give your life to the one who matters the most, Christ, so he can change your ways no matter what happens to you and you‚Äôll be OK. Roof‚Äôs family later issued its first public statement since the shooting: ‚ÄúWe have all been touched by the moving words from the victims‚Äô families offering God‚Äôs forgiveness and love in the face of such horrible suffering,‚Äù the family said. Immediately after the hearing, court officials released Roof‚Äôs arrest warrants, which provided chilling new details on how all nine were shot during a prayer group meeting at the historic Emanuel AME church in downtown Charleston. Roof was seen on security camera footage entering the church on Wednesday night, at 8:06pm, the warrants said. He spent an hour studying with the dozen parishioners in the Bible study room and then opened fire, striking each victim ‚Äúmultiple times‚Äù. ‚ÄúPrior to leaving the Bible study room he stood over a witness to be named later and uttered a racially inflammatory statement to the witness,‚Äù the warrant states. After a manhunt, Roof was identified to police by both his father and uncle, who recognized him and his car from photographs distributed to the public by police. Roof‚Äôs father confirmed to police that his son owned a .45 caliber handgun, which he was seen carrying out of the church shortly after 9pm on Wednesday. Investigators stated in the warrant that .45 caliber shell casings were recovered in the church. On Friday afternoon, the US justice department announced it is investigating whether the church shooting could be a hate crime or an act of domestic terror. On Thursday, the attorney general, Loretta Lynch, had described the massacre as a ‚Äúbarbaric crime‚Äù, and said it was being looked at as a hate crime. ‚ÄúActs like this have no place in our country and in a civilized society,‚Äù Lynch said in Washington. Roof‚Äôs homicide charges make him eligible for the death penalty, for which South Carolina‚Äôs Governor Nikki Haley advocated during a visit to Charleston on Friday. Earlier in the day, the NAACP national president, Cornell William Brooks, condemned the church attack as a hate crime. ‚ÄúThis was an act of racial terrorism and must be treated as such,‚Äù Brooks said in an emotional press conference of his own. Brooks, who spent time in Charleston as a child as both his grandfather and uncle owned barbershops nearby, said the state and the US as a whole needed to examine the underlying racial hatred that fuelled Roof‚Äôs crime. He made particular note of the Confederate flag flying above the South Carolina state house. ‚ÄúSome will assert that the Confederate flag is merely a symbol of years gone by, a symbol of heritage, not hate. But when we see that symbol lifted up as an emblem of hate ‚Ä¶ as an inspiration of violence, that symbol has to come down.‚Äù Tensions over the flag have been renewed since the shooting, and local politicians were preparing legislation to have it removed. On Friday morning, the Republican presidential candidate and South Carolina senator Lindsey Graham attempted to distance Roof‚Äôs actions from the flag‚Äôs prominent position in South Carolina politics. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to give this guy an excuse about a book he might have read or a movie he watched or a song he listened to or a symbol out anywhere. It‚Äôs him ‚Ä¶ not the flag,‚Äù Graham told CNN. The senator was present at a vigil, later on Friday, when hundreds of people cheered and applauded at repeated calls for the flag to be removed from state buildings. There was a loud expression of support from Nelson B Rivers, from the National Action Network civil rights group, who compared calls for the flag to be taken down for the legislation to introduce body cameras in the aftermath of Walter Scott‚Äôs death. ‚ÄúWalter Scott got killed and the paradigm shifted, and then all of a sudden what couldn‚Äôt be done became a done deal,‚Äù he said. Amid a rising a cacophony of supportive shouting, Rivers called on lawmakers in the auditorium: ‚ÄúYou will take that flag down, you will taken it down!‚Äù Graham, who sat impassively, later told the Guardian he welcomed the debate, although declined to take a firm position. ‚ÄúThere are graveyards of confederate soldiers all over the state ‚Äì what do we do? How much of revisiting ones past is going to take before we can move forward?‚Äù Graham and South Carolina‚Äôs other senator, Tim Scott ‚Äì also a Republican ‚Äì both remained seated during standing ovations following calls for a ‚Äúrational conversation‚Äù about gun rights in America. Charleston‚Äôs mayor, Joseph P Riley, said he did not want to inject any kind of politics into the situation, but added: ‚ÄúNine people died, because of this crazed man, with obviously easy access to a handgun,‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is complicated, and the right to bear arms is ingrained in the Constitution and life in America, but we can‚Äôt just forget about this and we must encourage a national discussion. There has got to be a better way.‚Äù He added: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want to live in a country where you need a security guard for Bible study.‚Äù Further vigils to mourn the nine murdered church members were planned to continue in Charleston and throughout the US through the weekend.

column4: Obama on Charleston shooting: 'I refuse to act as if this is the new normal' ‚Äì live updates
column5: Here‚Äôs a final summary for today: Dylann Roof, the 21-year-old suspect appeared at an emotional bond hearing in Charleston at 2pm ET. Though only 13 minutes long, we heard from the judge, the suspect himself and the victim‚Äôs families who offered Roof forgiveness. New details of the shooting emerged on Friday afternoon, as the arrest warrants were released to the public. NAACP national president Cornell William Brooks called the shooting an ‚Äúact of racial terrorism‚Äù in a powerful speech on Friday. He also said that the confederate flag ‚Äúmust come down‚Äù from the South Carolina state capitol. Meanwhile, Rick Perry has called the massacre a ‚Äúdrug-induced accident‚Äù. South Carolina governor Nikki Haley has voiced her support for the death penalty to be used in the case against Roof. Charleston Mayor Joe Riley however has said that he doesn‚Äôt personally support the death penalty. A portrait of Dylann Roof as an apparently committed racist has emerged throughout the day That‚Äôs it from us today on the live blog, thanks for tuning in. For more on the Charleston shooting, check out all of our stories here. For Twitter updates, follow my colleagues Ed Pilkington (@Edpilkington), Paul Lewis (@PaulLewis) and Oliver Laughland (@oliverlaughland), who are on the ground in Charleston. Amanda Holpuch (@holpuch) is in Columbia.

column4: 'He was my hero': Charleston mother hails 26-year-old killed shielding victims
column5: Tywanza Sanders, 26, the youngest victim of the deadly shooting at the Emanuel AME church in Charleston, died trying to shield the oldest victim, his great aunt Susie Jackson, 87, from the barrel of a gun. That simple act of courage has emerged as perhaps the enduring image of the victims‚Äô resilience in the face of the hatred unleashed by the shooter on Wednesday night. At about 9pm that night, as the Bible studies class attended by Sanders, Jackson, and 10 other church regulars drew to a close, a stranger who had walked into their midst about an hour previously pulled out a gun. Dylann Roof, 21, is charged with murdering nine of the congregants, each of the deceased shot multiple times. The description of Roof‚Äôs alleged offences released by the Charleston police department on Friday suggests that he stood over one of the survivors of the attack ‚Äúand uttered a racially inflammatory statement‚Äù. Sanders‚Äô actions stand in stark contrast to the alleged racial animosity of his assailant. Accounts originating from the three survivors of the attack indicate that the young man remained strikingly calm as he tried to talk the shooter out of what he was about to do. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to do this,‚Äù Sanders said. When the shooter moved to pull the trigger anyway, saying he was going to kill everyone in the room, Sanders is said to have leapt in front of the gun, putting himself between the firearm and his great aunt. He took the first bullet, but the killer reloaded and they both died. Sanders‚Äô mother, Felicia Sanders, was also at the Bible studies meeting on Wednesday. She survived by playing dead. At Roof‚Äôs bond hearing on Friday she put the loss of her child in the most simple terms. ‚ÄúTywanza is my son, but he was my hero.‚Äù To Roof, she said: ‚ÄúWe welcomed you Wednesday night in our bible study with open arms. You have killed some of the most beautifullest people that I know. Every fiber in my body hurts ‚Äì I will never be the same.‚Äù There were four members of the Sanders extended family in the basement of the Mother Emanuel church that night. In addition to Tywanza Sanders and Susie Jackson who died, and Felicia Sanders who survived, another family member Ethel Lance, 70, was also killed. By Friday a deep sense of shock had settled over the Sanders family home, a classic Charleston wooden house with porch just a few blocks away from the scene of the shooting. Most of the family was grieving behind closed doors, but Tywanza‚Äôs cousin Horace Taylor, 33, took time to recall for the Guardian the ‚Äústandup guy‚Äù that he had been. Taylor said that his cousin was ‚Äúalways speaking positive, he was always with a smile on his face. Though he was younger than me, I looked up at him as my big cousin.‚Äù He said that Sanders had an entrepreneurial bent, and was forever seeking the next venture that would allow him to better himself and support his large extended family. He worked two jobs ‚Äì cutting hair in a barber shop in North Charleston and working in a restaurant kitchen. In his spare time he wrote rap lyrics and poetry. ‚ÄúWhile other kids fall into drugs and shit, he was just trying to find another way to make a better life for all of us,‚Äù Sanders said. That same concern to do the right thing was on display on Wednesday night, Taylor added. ‚ÄúTywanza tried to save my grandma. He tried to protect everybody else from those bullets. I‚Äôm pretty sure he knew he wasn‚Äôt going to make it, but he still did his best to save others. That‚Äôs the man he was.‚Äù

column4: Police crack down on activists on eve of London austerity march
column5:
Police have launched a crackdown on activists previously linked to direct action protests before what is expected to be the largest anti-austerity demonstration of the year.
At least three activists arrested on suspicion of offences at earlier demonstrations have been handed fresh bail conditions forbidding them from attending the protest march on Saturday, sources have told the Guardian. A fourth activist was arrested on suspicion of offences at an anti-gentrification protest in Brixton in April and released on bail under similar conditions. A fifth attended a police station voluntarily and was not arrested. Officers are believed to be hunting two more. Critics have accused the police of staging a politically motivated crackdown before more than 65,000 people are expected to gather in the City for a march against the government‚Äôs austerity agenda. The moves by the Metropolitan police are being seen as an attempt to thwart direct action during the demonstration. In the past year, groups campaigning against austerity and the gentrification of London have gained widespread coverage with a number of stunts. Lisa McKenzie, an activist with Class War, an anarchist group, said: ‚ÄúThere seems to be a massive crackdown. There is some sort of political motivation behind all of this. This is not the Met police; they haven‚Äôt got the brains. I think there‚Äôs a political motivation to stop this wave of direct action going on all across the city.‚Äù
A spokesman for Liberty, the human rights group, said: ‚ÄúWe have seen bail conditions abused by the police in the past to impede the right to protest of people neither charged nor convicted of a related criminal offence. The whole question of lengthy police bail when used as a restriction on protest and even on journalism needs urgent parliamentary attention.‚Äù Police targeted activists from groups including the Brick Lane Debates, the London Black Revolutionaries and Squatters and Homeless Autonomy. The latter group have been behind a wave of occupations of empty buildings in central London. Saturday‚Äôs march, organised by the People‚Äôs Assembly Against Austerity, will begin outside the Bank of England on Threadneedle Street and end in a Parliament Square rally. This week‚Äôs arrests follow an article in the last edition of the Mail on Sunday which accused activists of planning violent disruption to the march. The paper sent two reporters to a Brick Lane Debates meeting in Dalston, east London, where it said it uncovered a ‚Äúriot plot‚Äù by activists who were planning to turn the peaceful demonstration ‚Äúinto a rampage‚Äù. One of the arrested activists told the Guardian that the MoS story was mentioned in his interview with police. He was released without charge after being arrested on suspicion of violent disorder outside Downing Street during a demonstration in May. Katya Nasim, a Brick Lane Debates activist who was named in the story, denied its allegations. She has made a complaint directly to the newspaper after it claimed she called for demonstrators to storm a stage set up for the rally. ‚ÄúNo one proposed at the meeting storming the stage,‚Äù said Nasim. ‚ÄúWe welcome Saturday‚Äôs People‚Äôs Assembly demonstration, it looks set to be a massive expression of discontent. ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs a long history of the rightwing media misreporting and misrepresenting the left and leftwing campaigns. I think it‚Äôs politically motivated. In the runup to big demonstrations, it‚Äôs quite a classic scenario: the scaremongering in the media and the intimidation of activists.‚Äù Arnie Hill, of the London Black Revolutionaries, who was mentioned in the same Mail on Sunday story, dismissed the newspaper‚Äôs implication that it had infiltrated a secret planning meeting of the far-left. ‚ÄúThe meeting itself was a public meeting. It was not a conspiratorial meeting as they say,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAll we were talking about was how to make the demonstration more effective.‚Äù Hill said the paper had recycled untrue claims about his involvement in earlier protests. He has complained directly to the paper and is preparing to take up the issue with the Independent Press Standards Organisation. Neither Nasim nor Hill were among those arrested. The Metropolitan police said it did not comment on bail arrangements.

column4: Rick Perry calls Charleston church shooting an 'accident'
column5:
Republican presidential candidate Rick Perry on Friday suggested the fatal shooting of nine black people at a church in Charleston, South Carolina, by a white male was a drug-induced ‚Äúaccident‚Äù.
The former Texas governor was asked about the mass shooting at Emanuel AME church during an interview with the conservative NewsmaxTV. A spokesman for Perry later clarified that the Republican presidential candidate meant to say ‚Äúincident,‚Äù but the soundbyte drew immediate attention and backlash. Perry, who announced this month that he is running for president again after a failed bid in 2012, said he didn‚Äôt know if the tragedy was an ‚Äúact of terror‚Äù, but acknowledged it was ‚Äúa crime of hate‚Äù. But Perry then pivoted to what he called the ‚Äúreal issue to be talked about‚Äù ‚Äì drugs. ‚ÄúIt seems to me ‚Äì again, without having all the details about this one ‚Äì that these individuals have been medicated. And there may be a real issue in this country, from the standpoint of these drugs, and how they‚Äôre used,‚Äù Perry said. Some acquaintances of Dylann Storm Roof, the 21-year-old gunman in the Charleston killings, have said he used drugs ‚Äì a detail that has been seized upon by conservative conspiracy websites such as Infowars.
But Roof, who was apprehended in North Carolina on Thursday, has confirmed that the killings were both premeditated and racially motivated. The shooting suspect told authorities he wanted to ‚Äústart a race war‚Äù, after confessing to attending Bible study with the victims and then opening fire. In addition to steering the conversation away from race and terrorism, Perry also accused Barack Obama of trying to take firearms away from the American people by pushing for stricter gun laws in the wake of mass shootings like the one in Charleston. ‚ÄúThis is the MO of this administration, any time there is an accident like this, the president is clear. He doesn‚Äôt like for Americans to have guns and so he uses every opportunity, this being another one, to basically go parrot that message,‚Äù Perry said. He added that pushing gun control was a ‚Äúknee-jerk reaction‚Äù that would do little to change gun violence ‚Äúas long as evil and cowardice is alive in the world‚Äù. Perry said he wasn‚Äôt ready to point to any policy changes that could prevent another Charleston, and said it was up to South Carolina to decide if the Confederate flag should continue to fly on the grounds of the state capitol in Columbia.
Other Republican presidential hopefuls have not explicitly discussed guns in relation to the Charleston massacre, but have cautioned that new laws are not the answer. The New Jersey governor, Chris Christie, who is weighing a presidential bid but has not officially declared himself a candidate, told a conservative gathering on Friday morning that laws would not be able to prevent what happened in Charleston. ‚ÄúThis type of conduct is something that only our display of our own love and good faith that is in our heart can change ‚Äì laws can‚Äôt change this,‚Äù Christie said during a speech at the Faith and Freedom Coalition conference in Washington, DC, an event that draws a largely evangelical audience. ‚ÄúOnly the goodwill and love of the American people can let those folks know that that act was unacceptable, disgraceful.‚Äù Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor who formally launched his presidential campaign this week, mourned the Charleston victims at the same conference but did not get into any policy implications. ‚ÄúThey were praying. They were learning and studying the word of the Lord,‚Äù Bush said on Friday. ‚ÄúIn times like these, in times of great of national mourning, people of faith, all of us must come together and at least reflect on this and fortify our strength and love of Christ, love of God to be able to continue to go forth.‚Äù Bush was also reticent to discuss race when a reporter at the Huffington Post asked him if the shooting was racially motivated. ‚ÄúIt was a horrific act and I don‚Äôt know what the background of it is, but it was an act of hatred,‚Äù Bush said, although he acknowledged the role played by race when asked again.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. Looks like to me it was, but we‚Äôll find out all the information,‚Äù Bush said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear it was an act of raw hatred, for sure. Nine people lost their lives, and they were African American. You can judge what it is.‚Äù The Charleston shooting is being investigated as a hate crime or an act of domestic terrorism.

column4: A day without Haitians as vendors stay clear of Dominican marketplace
column5:
Avenida Duarte in the Dominican capital is a busy bustling commercial street where hundreds of vendors ‚Äì both Dominican and Haitian ‚Äì normally clog the sidewalks selling everything from clothes to hot dogs. On Friday, however, a day after the window for undocumented migrants to apply for residency permits closed, the only salesmen and women working were Dominicans.
This week saw the final deadline for the Dominican government‚Äôs ‚Äúregularization plan‚Äù for residents of the country without documents ‚Äì most of whom are Haitian or Dominicans of Haitian descent. Dominican authorities are now prepared to deport those who did not register. Daniel, 33, a Haitian immigrant, usually sets up his water and soft drinks stall on Duarte early. But he‚Äôs too afraid to be seen there now after being unable to register. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm scared to go back and sell because they might pick me up and send me home. I don‚Äôt want to be separated from my family,‚Äù said Daniel, whose two children were born in the Dominican Republic. ‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt know what to do, except stay home until we know what the government‚Äôs going to do.‚Äù Others, who like Daniel, were unable to register because of bureaucratic delays, have decided not to wait for the police or military to round them up and repatriate them forcibly, with reports of buses filled with Haitians heading toward the border. ‚ÄúWe know of many people who‚Äôve decided to leave already,‚Äù says Ana Geraldo, a lawyer at Centro Bono, which works with Haitians and Dominicans of Haitian descent. An informal survey of the centre‚Äôs users showed that some 200 buses per day have been leaving Santo Domingo for the border with people going back to Haiti for the past week. But people born in the Dominican Republic to undocumented migrants say they have no reason to leave. For decades, the Dominican Republic recognized the children of Haitian migrants born in the country as Dominican citizens but they were rendered stateless by a 2013 ruling of the Dominican constitutional court and now risk being deported to a country where they have no citizenship or familial bonds. Elena Lorac, 26, is one of the lucky ones. Lorac, who is studying to become a social worker, was born in the Domincan Republic of Haitian parents, but only received her identity card on Monday. ‚ÄúI was born here and the government has been threatening to deport me,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúFor months, I‚Äôve had to live in fear that they will deport me to Haiti ‚Äì a country I don‚Äôt know and have never been to. This is my country and they want to deny it to me.‚Äù On Friday the UN High Commission for Refugees urged Dominican authorities not to deport Dominicans of Haitian descent. ‚ÄúWith a stateless population in the Dominican Republic estimated at more than 200,000 people, the consequences of expulsion could be devastating,‚Äù a UNHCR spokesman, Adrian Edwards, told a press briefing in Geneva. ‚ÄúIt is of the utmost importance that the Dominican Republic takes necessary action to prevent any expulsions of stateless Dominicans because of the human rights implications and to avoid creating a new refugee situation,‚Äù the UNHCR said in a statement. The interior and police minister, Jos√© Ram√≥n Fadul, responded that the Dominican Republic ‚Äúwould not accept interference‚Äù on the matter and denied that there were refugees in the country.

column4: ECB staves off collapse of Greek banking system with emergency funding
column5:
The European Central Bank provided just enough support on Friday to stave off the collapse of the Greek banking system as political and financial pressure was piled on Athens before a crisis summit of eurozone leaders on Monday. With more than ‚Ç¨1bn (¬£715m) leaving Greek banks on Friday alone, the ECB provided ‚Ç¨1.8bn in emergency funding to keep the system operating over the weekend and said it would meet again on Monday to decide whether to provide further help. The ECB‚Äôs tough line came as a succession of European politicians demanded the Greek government of Alexis Tsipras come up with proposals that would prevent Greece‚Äôs default and its possible exit from the single currency. European commission sources said a meeting of finance ministers ‚Äì to be held hours before the leaders‚Äô summit ‚Äì would discuss plans for managing Greece‚Äôs exit from the single currency. Far from buckling, the Greek prime minister put on a show of defiance on Friday during a visit to Russia, where he made a pitch for support from Vladimir Putin. ‚ÄúWe are ready to go to new seas to reach new safe ports,‚Äù Tsipras said. Russia‚Äôs deputy prime minister Arkady Dvorkovich had hinted that Russia would consider a loan to Greece. ‚ÄúThe most important things for us are investment projects and trade with Greece. If financial support is needed, we will consider this question,‚Äù he said in an interview on RT television. Since Tsipras became head of the leftwing Syriza-led coalition five months ago, he has said the Greek debt crisis will be solved by the eurozone‚Äôs political leaders rather than its finance ministers. Speaking in St Petersburg, he expressed confidence that a deal would be done. ‚ÄúAll those who are betting on crisis and terror scenarios will be proven wrong,‚Äù Tsipras said. Failure to end the stalemate between Greece and its creditors at a meeting of eurozone finance ministers on Thursday led to fresh Greek deposit withdrawals, bringing the total for the week to ‚Ç¨4.2bn. Greek bank shares have lost almost a third of their value since the end of May, as Athens and its creditors ‚Äì the International Monetary Fund, the ECB and the European commission ‚Äì maintain a standoff over ‚Ç¨7.2bn in bailout funds that Greece needs in order to meet a ‚Ç¨1.6bn payment to the IMF by 30 June. The support from the ECB meant no queues outside Greek banks on Friday, but a European commission vice-president said the assistance was only temporary measure. Speaking in Luxembourg at a meeting of EU finance ministers, Valdis Dombrovskis said: ‚ÄúIt is very clear that to regain financial stability a clear agreement is needed on the programme, and a credible strategy needs to be presented by the Greek authorities showing how they will regain financial stability and economic growth.‚Äù The British chancellor, George Osborne, said Tsipras should do a deal before it was too late, and that Europe should start preparing for the worst. ‚ÄúWe have entered the eleventh hour of this Greek crisis and we urge the Greek government to do a deal before it is too late. We hope for the best, but we now must be prepared for the worst,‚Äù Osborne said on Friday outside the Luxembourg gathering. Donald Tusk, Poland‚Äôs prime minister and president of the European council, said: ‚ÄúWe are close to the point where the Greek government will have to chose between accepting what I believe is a good offer of continuing support, or head towards default. At the end of the day it can only be a Greek decision and a Greek responsibility.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe game of chicken needs to end and so does the blame game,‚Äù he said. European commission sources stressed that for the Eurogroup of finance ministers or the leaders‚Äô summit to consider a compromise, Greece would first need to submit new proposals on contentious issues such as pension reform and a widening of the tax base for VAT. Tsipras has insisted that making pensions less generous or raising VAT would cross his government‚Äôs ‚Äúred line‚Äù and would push Greece even deeper into recession. Athens wants its creditors to agree to a debt swap that would help it reduce its budget deficit without any additional economic pain.
The creditors argue that without such reforms, Greece will not be able to be financially independent, but they were uncertain on Friday night as to whether Athens would table anything new at the meetings on Monday. ‚ÄúIf there are no new proposals from Greece to discuss, the ministers are likely to instead talk about how to handle Greece‚Äôs default,‚Äù one eurozone official said. The IMF‚Äôs managing director, Christine Lagarde, has insisted that Athens will be given no leeway over the 30 June deadline for the ‚Ç¨1.6bn payment. Failure at Monday‚Äôs talks would intensify the outflow from Greek banks and increase the chances of capital controls being imposed. Tsipras has also come under pressure from political opponents at home. Anna Asimakopoulou, a shadow finance minister with the New Democracy party, said: ‚ÄúThere is a bad scenario and a worst-case scenario. Either Tsipras agrees to take austerity measures worth ‚Ç¨5bn, because that is what the Europeans are asking, or he takes Greece out of the eurozone And the problem is this. He doesn‚Äôt have a mandate for either.‚Äù Jonathan Loynes, the chief European economist at the consultancy Capital Economics, said: ‚ÄúThe failure to reach a deal at last week‚Äôs Eurogroup meeting and the rapid outflow of deposits from Greek banks suggest that a near-term eurozone exit may now be more likely than not. ‚ÄúWe do not buy the view that Greece would slip out of the eurozone without a ripple. Should it become clear that a major default and exit are indeed coming soon, we will pull down our projections for growth across the rest of the eurozone this year and next, possibly to predict a renewed recession.‚Äù

column4: Berkeley student deaths: shock and heartbreak as tragedy touches Ireland
column5:
The Omniplex cinema in Rathmines, Dublin, is a long way from Berkeley, California. But this week the staff there, like so many people across Ireland, have been touched by a tragedy that unfolded in the early hours of Tuesday in the American university town. Jack Halpin, a University College Dublin (UCD) student, Gaelic football player and former part-time employee of the Omniplex, was one of a group of young people celebrating a 21st birthday party when the balcony of the flat they were on crumbled under their feet. Six students in their early 20s died after they plunged 12 metres to the pavement below and seven others were taken to hospital. The injured included Halpin, 21, and his friend Clodagh Cogley: he gripped on to her and cushioned her fall. Halpin suffered a broken back and has had several operations since Tuesday. Ireland‚Äôs minister for the diaspora who is in Berkeley said on Friday that the conditions of Jack Halpin and Conor Flynn, both injured, were improving rapidly Jimmy Deenihan told a press conference: ‚ÄúIt seems certain now that they are going to have ‚Äì and make ‚Äì a full recovery‚Äù He thanked the John Muir medical centre for the way they looked after the two young men and said they were very fortunate to get the medical treatment that they did. ‚ÄúWe have the reports that Jack may have helped save the life of one of the girls involved,‚Äù said Mark Anderson, operations director for Omniplex, who was Halpin‚Äôs boss before he left for summer in the United States. ‚ÄúThis is the ultimate act of bravery and selflessness that would be typical of a guy like Jack.‚Äù
Over at the main campus of UCD, a memorial service was held on Friday for the six people who died, including the three who attended the university. Eimear Walsh and Lorc√°n Miller were studying medicine, while Niccolai Schuster was reading history and politics. They died alongside their friends Olivia Burke, Eoghan Culligan and Irish-American student Ashley Donohoe. Her funeral is to be held on Saturday in California. The other victims‚Äô families plan to bring back the bodies to Ireland this weekend.
Before the memorial service, the taoiseach, Enda Kenny, said the Irish people‚Äôs reaction to the tragedy showed how the country united at the most challenging of times. ‚ÄúThe reaction to the tragedy showed the solidarity of Irish people when adverse events occurred,‚Äù Kenny said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve always had this in Ireland; people understand adversity, they understand death, they understand people being taken away.‚Äù That solidarity was on display on the crowdfunding site gofundme.com, which by late Friday afternoon had raised more than $150,000 (¬£95,000) for the victims. It was also in evidence in the national furore prompted by an article in the New York Times late on Tuesday that focused on the thousands of Irish students who travel with special J-1 visas to the US every summer. These students, said the article, were ‚Äúnot just a source of aspiration, but also a source of embarrassment for Ireland, marked by a series of high-profile episodes involving drunken partying and the wrecking of apartments in places like San Francisco and Santa Barbara‚Äù.
It quoted a 2014 column by Cahir O‚ÄôDoherty, the arts and culture editor of the Irish Voice, expressing distress at ‚Äúthe callous destruction unleashed by these loaded Irish students‚Äù at a rented house in San Francisco. ‚ÄúThey ripped chandeliers from the ceilings, they broke doors and they smashed windows; they even punched holes in the walls,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúThen they abandoned the place without a heads-up or a word of apology.‚Äù The perceived implication that the celebrating students may have in some way been to blame for the balcony collapse sparked hurt and fury. The New York Times public editor, Margaret Sullivan, wrote on her blog on Wednesday that her office had field hundreds of complaints about the piece from readers who were ‚Äúquite understandably‚Äù upset.
Indulging in the stereotype of drunken, feckless Irish students caused huge offence. And it could not be further from the selfless actions of Halpin, which have been credited by the 21-year-old Cogley‚Äôs family as having possibly saved her life. They said: ‚ÄúBoth of them sadly came off as badly as each other. Jack tried to grab Clodagh and helped lessen the impact of her fall. They both fell at the same time.‚Äù In the US, the focus of the inquiry into the tragedy is now on rain damage and dry rot that allegedly weakened the supports on the balcony where the Irish students were standing. Anger in the victims‚Äô home country was compounded when it emerged that the company that built the apartment in Berkeley was accused two years ago of building faulty balconies in another building, as court documents showed. The California-based Segue Construction paid $3.4m to settle litigation over alleged defects in a condominium development in Millbrae, California, after a homeowners‚Äô association sued, the residents‚Äô lawyer confirmed to the US media. Cogley, the granddaughter of an Irish rugby commentator, is now listening to Harry Potter tapes while recovering from her injuries. JK Rowling, the author of her favourite books, tweeted a get-well-soon message in which she wished her a speedy recovery.
Meanwhile,Katie Wolahan, a friend of Lorc√°n Miller, wrote on her blog of her memories of someone who was ‚Äúnothing short of a gentleman‚Äù. ‚ÄúLorc√°n had so much more to give, but his achievements in life far exceeded the time he had. He brought immeasurable happiness and joy to me and so many others, something I am eternally grateful for,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúHe will be in my heart always.‚Äù

column4: Glass ceiling in the sky: Qatar Airways√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ problem with pregnant cabin crew
column5:
Round the back of one Gulf airline‚Äôs corporate HQ, a door opens into a hall dominated by a lifesize recreation of a passenger jet‚Äôs fuselage. Inside, a multinational class of young women demonstrate their grasp of safety drills and emergency procedures. The plane‚Äôs evacuation slide drops into a swimming pool, where recruits practise how to save passengers in the event of a flight ditching into the sea. In another mocked-up cabin, the women extinguish fires flaring in seats and overhead cabins. This is the serious business of cabin crew training school. But whereas firefights, safety experts and lifesavers will stop here, female flight attendants pass down the corridor for the next chapter in their training, and one that some consider just as important: the beauty salon. Here, they will be given exact rules on mandated shades of makeup, hairstyling and uniform. For airlines, particularly at the top end of long-haul, cabin crew have long been a crucial part of the branding and marketing ‚Äì focusing on young, attractive women, projecting a seductive modernity and glamour with smiling ease, but in truth, performing arduous tasks for long hours for little pay. No wonder Qatar Airways wants to lock them up.
A judgment this week from the UN‚Äôs International Labour Organisation threw a renewed spotlight on working practices at the Gulf airline, which demands its crew live under curfew in monitored accommodation, and restricts their movements, relationships and family life. In particular, the ILO demanded the end of a lingering contractual clause allowing the airline to fire ‚Äì or ‚Äúterminate‚Äù, in Qatar‚Äôs peculiar parlance ‚Äì crew in the event of pregnancy. Past contracts had also stipulated a ban on marriage without express company permission; since pressure was first put on the airline by the ITF, the international transport workers‚Äô federation, new contracts have been amended on both counts. One startling provision remains: that female crew cannot be driven to or from work by a man other than a family member. This, the airline says, is for ‚Äúcompliance with a particular cultural norm in Qatar‚Äù. When the news broke of the ILO judgment, many outsiders responded with incredulity that a modern multinational could treat its employees in such a way. But within the industry, there was little surprise. For Qatar Airways is less unusual than it might seem ‚Äì within the airline industry, or Qatar. And whether as a representative of its industry or country, its working practices point to a troubling anomaly in the culture of modern aviation that has deep roots in the past.
The Gulf carrier‚Äôs practices are not dissimilar from the grand tradition of earlier international aviation, when flying was associated with glamour and luxury, and a married, ageing or pregnant woman had no future at American airlines either. Some argue that airlines such as Qatar have built award-winning commercial success and a reputation for service that western airlines now find hard to emulate. Kathleen Barry, author of a history of flight attendants, Femininity in Flight, says: ‚ÄúWhen you start looking at the Middle Eastern and Asian carriers, they are upholding a tradition of flight service standards, and uniforms, that aren‚Äôt sustainable in an American and western European labour context.‚Äù Yet Qatar‚Äôs contractual issues only tell part of the story: the ITF compiled testimony from employees describing a culture where minor lapses earned dismissal ‚Äì with swift deportation from the Gulf following. One serving crew member claimed: ‚ÄúPeople get sacked daily for many stupid reasons, such as posting a picture in uniform, from a flight, your accommodation, having tattoos ... The biggest problem is there are no workers‚Äô rights in this country, so there‚Äôs nowhere to complain. If you don‚Äôt like anything you simply get sacked and if that happens before completing two years with the company, you have to pay a bond that many cannot afford.‚Äù Accounts from past and serving crew who spoke to the Guardian ‚Äì usually on condition of anonymity, having signed stringent confidentiality clauses in their contracts ‚Äì confirm that breaches of formal and unspoken codes of conduct have led to careers being curtailed. Sherin Galal, a flight attendant, said she briefly found herself imprisoned after the airline ‚Äúterminated‚Äù her and revoked her visa: medical staff had reported her to the airline‚Äôs grooming centre after spotting a small tattoo. Like other staff, she claims to have been left in limbo after suspension from the airline. Crew are hired from abroad, and Qatar‚Äôs ‚Äúkafala‚Äù sponsorship system means workers cannot find other employment, but also cannot leave the country without the company authorising an exit permit. One long-serving cabin attendant living in Qatar kept his marriage secret, claiming that airline staff made clear that if he applied for permission he would be sacked. He said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm from the Middle East. This has nothing to do with culture or religion. It is all to do with control. We all need a job ‚Äì that‚Äôs why we are here, that‚Äôs why we joined. But this isn‚Äôt what we signed up for.‚Äù
Qatar Airways says that there are only a handful of allegations, and points to the tens of thousands of crew it employs, and the numerous awards it has won. Even so, the stories remain startling ‚Äì and do not only feature women. Ahmed Khalil, a cabin attendant who had been commended for good service, says he ended up imprisoned without charge for two nights and deported after briefly sticking chewing gum over the CCTV lens in the accommodation building. One European attendant claims she was sacked and deported and told she was a ‚Äúdisgrace‚Äù after innocuous photos of crew in everyday clothes attending a private party were emailed to the airline‚Äôs boss. Before her experience, she said, she didn‚Äôt believe people when they said why they had been fired: ‚ÄúWe thought they were lying and had done something bad ‚Äì you think it must only be rumours ‚Äì but here it‚Äôs happening to me. You‚Äôre living in a grey zone, you don‚Äôt know what is allowed.‚Äù Gabriel Mocho Rodr√≠guez, civil aviation secretary at the ITF, said: ‚ÄúCrew have told me their stories in tears. The fear they experienced they retain even after leaving the country.‚Äù Qatar Airways has accused the ITF of a ‚Äúvendetta‚Äù; in previous responses emailed to the Guardian it said the ITF was ‚Äúvery frustrated at not being able to operate in Qatar and is making inaccurate allegations‚Äù. But others back the ITF‚Äôs claims. Some say they have been blacklisted from travel through the Gulf state after being sacked or resigning. The ILO‚Äôs ruling called on the Qatari government to push the airline to give foreign employees ‚Äúappropriate complaint mechanisms to ensure that they can obtain redress without being exposed to stigmatisation or reprisals, and without the fear of being deported‚Äù. It observed that ‚Äúaccess to such procedures and remedies by cabin crew members, who are migrant workers, may be difficult because of the fear of victimisation or reprisals, including dismissal and deportation from the country‚Äù. It is hard to be sure where these draconian measures originate. But in Qatar and beyond, the airline‚Äôs chief executive, Akbar Al Baker, is a man who wields considerable power. And some recruits say that an encounter with his exacting standards can spell the end. Jacques Nell, an ex-cabin attendant from South Africa, also ‚Äúterminated‚Äù for having a tattoo on his arm (visible tattoos are forbidden at many airlines, but Nell‚Äôs were under his uniform) claims that after confronting Al Baker about unpaid wages, he ended up imprisoned for five nights to be ‚Äútaught a lesson‚Äù. Nell said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a scary thought that this is happening to many people in Qatar and that they have such power to do this to the workforce.‚Äù Qatar Airways has refused to comment on specific claims, although an airline spokesman said: ‚ÄúQatar Airways does not arrest people, nor have any powers to do so.‚Äù Al Baker recently refused to answer direct questions at the global airlines annual summit in Miami, saying only: ‚ÄúI will not speak to the Guardian, you write negative things about Qatar.‚Äù A spokesman for the airline said: ‚ÄúCandidates applying to work at Qatar Airways are fully aware of the rules and regulations prior to joining, and it is entirely their choice whether to join our five-star airline or not.‚Äù
As Qatar Airways points out, its employment conditions are not dissimilar to other airlines in the Gulf. Sympathetic sources argue that it is exercising, to some extent, a duty of care for thousands of young foreigners, predominantly women, who emigrate to work in the alien, conservative culture of the Gulf; that employees need to keep their nose clean and head down and work hard.
