That leaves little scope for human frailty among young recruits. One who was sacked after being arrested for holding hands in a cafe said: ‚ÄúI accept I made a mistake, but ... You have to quit your job, leave everything behind ‚Äì I invested quite a bit of money to get there.‚Äù Instead of a career, she found herself penniless in Qatar, waiting in the airline dormitories before finally being sent home. There are signs Qatar Airways is changing: the contracts are rewritten, and the government insists that the airline company is working diligently to improve its policies, practices and benefits for cabin crew staff. But a glimpse of the mentality in Qatar Airways‚Äô management was revealed by an email that found its way to the press earlier this year: a photo circulated to all crew of a senior flight attendant, apparently the worse for wear, crashed on the floor outside the staff HQ. A manager lamented: ‚ÄúHow can we change rules when we do not behave as mature individuals?‚Äù Onerous and unfavourable crew working conditions are not unique to the region though. Salaries are low throughout the industry ‚Äì barely taxable at some UK airlines. Virgin Atlantic crew typically earn ¬£11k basic, before earning extra for their flying hours. Ryanair claims its crew can earn up to ‚Ç¨35,000 (¬£25,000), topped up by selling scratchcards, but other studies suggest a far lower average. Its crew are employed via a third party agency, Crewlink, which makes applicants pay ‚Ç¨500 to register and then deducts a substantial training fee from new recruits‚Äô wages. And yet, of course, the allure of the skies remains. Airlines find recruits a plentiful commodity, and ‚Äì when insured by training bonds and freed from international labour standards ‚Äì a relatively disposable one.
In the big international airlines, the continued glamour and opportunity for long-haul flying is a major draw: one Virgin Atlantic stewardess, on wages below the UK poverty threshold, said she had absolutely no regrets at leaving a well-paid City job for the Branson stardust and global travel. For others, the job has become more prosaic. Youth unemployment levels in Europe has led to highly qualified graduates searching out crew jobs. One Spanish Ryanair crew member told me he valued being able to get back home to bed in Luton each night after a series of rapid short hops around the continent. But the catch-all term ‚Äúcabin crew‚Äù masks a long-evolving role. According to historian Barry, the first attendants were exclusively men, on the small aircraft of the 1920s, when air travel was pioneering and adventurous; from the 1930s, when it was seen as less of a risky business, women were hired, eventually creating a sexual division of labour on the plane. ‚ÄúMen became pursers, or senior crew ‚Äì but increasingly invisible to the public in terms of the cultural glamourisation. The image of the job became very feminised: looking after people, serving, looking great.‚Äù By the 1960s, almost no one was hiring men. ‚ÄúPan Am flipped towards women for the perceived psychological benefits: an ability to charm and make people feel at home ‚Äì and then to become the hostesses for this very lavish party in the sky,‚Äù she adds.
Only, in fact, in the decade after the Civil Rights Act was passed in the US did many of their airlines stop the kind of practices for which Qatar has been reprimanded. Women would be expected to retire once married; when some remained unmarried, United Airlines and others introduced policies that crew should be forcibly retired at 32, or sometimes 35. Until the 1970s, American crew could equally expect to get the sack if pregnant. Flight attendants became the branding, says Barry. ‚ÄúIt became a question of who had the prettiest with the most stylish uniforms. They hired designers: Pucci Braniff uniforms was the start of this more obviously sexualised image, all hotpants and boots.‚Äù While Ryanair has only recently ditched its unclad crew calendar, generally life has moved on, albeit sometimes slower than on the ground. Gone are the official weight-versus-height charts that some airlines used ‚Äì although some physical prescription remains under the guise of fitness, or the ability to wear the uniform. But the role of glamorous attendants to project the brand is strong as ever: when, for example, Emirates announced a deal with Rolls-Royce at a recent London press conference, the grey-haired CEOs were flanked by female uniformed crew standing on stage immobile, smiles fixed, throughout.
That obsession with the body and grooming persists, adding to what Barry calls the ‚Äúlabour of femininity‚Äù. Maintaining the look, particularly in a heavily stylised, close-fitting crew outfit, with hair and makeup, can be a particularly time-consuming business for attendants ‚Äì mandatory but off the clock for shift rates. Some airlines charge the crew for their uniform. And yet for all that the airlines might project a Stepford Wife-style passivity, the job has always been more: Barry says the expertise and the safety role was made clearer to the flying public through the efforts of unions and feminists in court cases ‚Äì and underlined by the wave of skyjackings of the 1970s. ‚ÄúBut deregulation and feminism are distinct to the US and the west.‚Äù In aviation‚Äôs global market, social progress starts to represent a competitive disadvantage ‚Äì one reason why unions have backed a controversial campaign by three US airlines to limit the rights of Gulf carriers to fly to the US. Crew in Britain and beyond have been forced to accept swingeing pay cuts in recent years, and more than one airline boss may secretly envy the lack of rights afforded to hapless staff abroad. When Qantas was slashing crew and other jobs, its chief executive, Alan Joyce, explained his problems at the Australian flag carrier to a global airline summit, and nodded to the Qatar Airways boss beside him on the stage: ‚ÄúAkbar told me I should put the union leaders in jail.‚Äù

column4: Governor of South Carolina calls for death penalty for Dylann Roof
column5:
The governor of South Carolina called for the death penalty on Friday, for the 21-year-old man accused of shooting and killing nine black churchgoers on Wednesday in Charleston. ‚ÄúWe will absolutely want him to have the death penalty,‚Äù Nikki Haley said of Dylann Roof, who has been charged with nine counts of murder and possessing a weapon during the commission of a violent crime. He was due to appear for a bond hearing in Charleston on Friday afternoon, probably by video link from the county jail where he is being held. No one answered the door on Friday at the home in Eastover, North Carolina, where Roof lived as recently as March. Lush plants, a stately American flag and a private property warning sign stood outside the property, which stands about 100 miles away from the site of the mass killing at the historic Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal church.
‚ÄúHe just seemed real quiet and kept to himself,‚Äù said Kim Fleming, manager of Mr Bunkys, the general store across the street on Garner‚Äôs Ferry Road, a two-lane highway that is a popular route to South Carolina‚Äôs coast. Fleming said she had met Roof several times. ‚ÄúI just couldn‚Äôt believe it was someone walking around here,‚Äù she said of the shooting. ‚ÄúThis is not the norm.‚Äù Yet according to a roommate, Roof had been ‚Äúplanning something like that for six months‚Äù. Other friends recalled racist tirades against African Americans ‚Äútaking over the world‚Äù and Roof‚Äôs desire to ignite ‚Äúa civil war‚Äù. ‚ÄúHe was big into segregation and other stuff,‚Äù Dalton Tyler told ABC News. ‚ÄúHe said he wanted to start a civil war. He said he was going to do something like that and then kill himself.‚Äù Joseph Meek Jr, a childhood friend who saw Roof the morning before the shooting, said that, a few weeks ago, Roof told him that he had used birthday money from his parents to buy a .45-caliber Glock pistol and that he had ‚Äúa plan‚Äù. He didn‚Äôt say what the plan was, but Meek said it scared him enough that he took the gun out of Roof‚Äôs car and hid it in his house until the next day. (Roof‚Äôs uncle Carson Cowles said this gun had been a 21st birthday gift from Roof‚Äôs parents.) Meek said he and Roof had never discussed race growing up. But when they recently reconnected and got drunk on vodka, Roof told him ‚Äúblacks were taking over the world [and] someone needed to do something about it for the white race‚Äù, he told the Associated Press.
‚ÄúHe said he wanted segregation between whites and blacks. I said, ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs not the way it should be.‚Äô But he kept talking about it,‚Äù Meek said. The comments resonate horribly with reported remarks Roof allegedly made to victims of the shooting. Sylvia Johnson, a cousin of Clementa Pinckney, a pastor killed in the attack, relayed a harrowing account she said was provided to her by a female survivor. The survivor‚Äôs son, who was also at the meeting, ‚Äúwas trying to talk him out of doing that act of killing people‚Äù, Johnson said. She added that Roof replied: ‚ÄúI have to do it. You rape our women and you‚Äôre taking over our country. And you have to go.‚Äù Meek said that when he woke up on the morning of the mass killing Roof was at his house, sleeping in his car outside ‚Äì its license plate bearing the flag of the slave-owning Confederate South, which fought an unsuccessful civil war to secede from the United States in the 1860s. Later that day, Meek said he and some friends had gone to a nearby lake but Roof stayed behind, saying he would rather see a movie. The next time Meek saw Roof was in surveillance-camera photos distributed by police in the aftermath of the killing. ‚ÄúI knew it was him,‚Äù Meek said. A high school contemporary, John Mullins, told the Daily Beast: ‚ÄúHe made a lot of racist jokes, but you don‚Äôt really take them seriously like that. You don‚Äôt really think of it like that.‚Äù
But now, he said, it seemed that ‚Äúthe things he said were kind of not joking‚Äù. Richard Cohen, the president of the Southern Poverty Law Center, said Roof was not known to his organization, which tracks hate crimes across the US, but based on his Facebook page he appeared to be a ‚Äúdisaffected white supremacist‚Äù. The Facebook page showed him wearing a black jacket adorned with two flags associated with white supremacy: that of apartheid-era South Africa, and that of Rhodesia, the white-ruled country that later became Zimbabwe. There was little personally identifying information on the page, which has not been independently verified by the Guardian, but it is notable that a number of his Facebook friends are black. ‚ÄúHe had black friends,‚Äù a high school friend, Antonio Metze, told AP. ‚ÄúI never thought he‚Äôd do something like this.‚Äù Meek‚Äôs mother, Kimberly Konzny, described Roof as a ‚Äúsweet kid‚Äù. ‚ÄúHe was quiet. He only had a few friends,‚Äù she said. His uncle described him as introverted. Carson Cowles told his sister, Roof‚Äôs mother, that the young man was overly withdrawn, Reuters reported. ‚ÄúI said he was like 19 years old, he still didn‚Äôt have a job, a driver‚Äôs license or anything like that and he just stayed in his room a lot of the time,‚Äù Cowles said. But Mullins told the Daily Beast that the young Roof had been ‚Äúkind of wild‚Äù. ‚ÄúHe used drugs heavily a lot,‚Äù Mullins said. ‚ÄúIt was obviously harder than marijuana. He was like a pill popper, from what I understood. Like Xanax, and stuff like that.‚Äù Though police say Roof lived in Columbia, North Carolina, he apparently had ties to the nearby Lexington area. Roof had a mixed educational record in the Lexington school district, attending White Knoll high school in both the 2008-09 and 2009-10 school years. He repeated ninth grade both years, but was pulled and re-enrolled more than once. He also attended White Knoll elementary school for fourth grade in 2003-04. The Lexington school district said it was unable to find annual photos of Roof, and that it has no records of other schools he might have attended. Roof previously had at least two run-ins with the law. The Lexington county district attorney‚Äôs office confirmed that Roof had been charged with possession of a controlled substance in March but the circumstances surrounding that arrest remain unclear. He was also arrested in April for misdemeanour trespassing in Lexington county. Additional reporting by Michael Safi

column4: Greek crisis standoff: five possible outcomes
column5:
The standoff between the EU commission and Greece must be resolved by the end of the month. Either Brussels releases the last ‚Ç¨7.2bn (¬£5.14bn) of bailout cash due to Athens under its existing rescue deal or Greece goes bust. Here are the possible scenarios to how this may play out: 1 The creditors blink It is possible the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, will persuade her fellow EU leaders on Monday that the European commission and the other creditors ‚Äì the European Central Bank and International Monetary Fund ‚Äì must keep the single currency together by agreeing a debt swap. This would trade in in old loans for new longer term ones and has been proposed by Athens because it would cut the interest rate on payments due over the next year. Athens says this would be worth ‚Ç¨2bn and bring the budget into line with creditor demands. 2 Greece blinks Athens could ditch its debt swap proposal and agree further spending cuts ‚Äì but spread over a wider area of government expenditure. At the moment creditors are demanding big cuts to pensions, but Athens says that‚Äôs a no go. The Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, could offer stricter limits on early retirement, trim other state budgets or extend VAT to new areas to find a further ‚Ç¨2bn of savings. This would be a retreat for him but not a complete surrender.
3 Greece leaves the euro If both sides refuse to move there is likely to be a run on the Greek banks. The ECB would likely stop supporting the banks, or threaten to do so. Athens would have to introduce capital controls to halt the flow of funds out of the country. At this stage, Greek departure from the single currency would not be inevitable. Athens would have a choice: fall into line and hope to scrap the capital controls, as Cyprus has done, or make plans for a new currency. Tsipras would probably hold a referendum before taking the big step of leaving the euro. This would take a minimum of two weeks. If the vote backs quitting the euro rather than more austerity ‚Äì divorce proceedings begin. 4 The Greek government collapses With the banking system paralysed, Greece grinds to a halt. Capital controls prove economically damaging and politically toxic. The government struggles to produce an alternative currency to the euro. Employers are forced to close, creating more unemployment. Riots on the streets split the ruling Syriza party and parliament, forcing new elections and a new government, that accepts all the austerity measures demanded by Brussels in return for the ‚Ç¨7.2bn. 5 The can is kicked down the road EU leaders agree to temporarily supply Greece the funds needed to repay ‚Ç¨1.6bn of debt to the IMF at the end of this month and other debt payments due later in the summer. Athens promises to embark on further economic reforms, to be monitored by the lenders. The delay allows time for talks to continue into the autumn in the hope that a compromise deal is agreed, but does not reduce Greece‚Äôs debt burden. Financial markets assume the crisis will reappear later in the year. They are right.

column4: Tourists in Greece: 'Everybody should come and spend money here'
column5:
Tourists arriving pale and stressed at Athens airport on Friday came doubly prepared ‚Äì as well as sunscreen and flipflops many were carrying wads of extra cash just in case there is a Greek banking collapse. Kees van den Berg, from Utrecht, who was catching a taxi into town with his girlfriend, Martje, flashed an envelope containing ‚Ç¨1,500. ‚ÄúShould do us for a week,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure the risk is exaggerated, though. I can‚Äôt see it coming to that ‚Äì a huge holiday destination with no cash, at the beginning of the summer?‚Äù
Greek customers withdrew more than ‚Ç¨3bn from the country‚Äôs banks between Monday and Thursday, leading to fears of serious liquidity problems and an urgent appeal by the Greek national bank for emergency funds from the European Central Bank. The country‚Äôs government is in a standoff with its European and international creditors over the terms of an aid-for-reforms deal the lenders have said must be agreed before they will release a final ‚Ç¨7.2bn in bailout funds. Athens needs that money before the end of the month if it is to avoid defaulting on a ‚Ç¨1.6bn International Monetary Fund loan and find itself unable to pay pensions and public sector wages. Adrian Lewis, from New York state, who was heading to Crete with his partner and young daughter after a few days in Athens, said he had brought $500 with him ‚Äúbecause I was aware of what was happening and I didn‚Äôt know what currency was going to be fluid. Dollars generally work.‚Äù The family had also withdrawn the maximum amount of euros they could on Friday morning. ‚ÄúThe possbility of a bank run and maybe capital controls was on my mind,‚Äù Lewis said, ‚Äúbut everything seems remarkably calm. There was a bit of a queue at the ATM and a few people taking photographs, but nothing to worry about. And the Greek people we‚Äôve met have been relaxed and amazingly generous.‚Äù
Their view chimed with those of others in departures, bronzed and ‚Äì in the main ‚Äì relaxed, who said they had experienced no difficulties despite the looming crisis. ‚ÄúNot the slightest problem,‚Äù said Andy Birbeck, from west London, who was returning home with his wife and two daughters after a week on Rhodes and a few days in Athens. ‚ÄúWe did anticipate problems, but we probably needn‚Äôt have.‚Äù Birbeck said the family had brought enough euros with them for their stay so used cash almost the whole time, resorting to a credit card only once. ‚ÄúBut from what we saw it wasn‚Äôt really necessary,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEverything looked like it was working fine.‚ÄùJohanna Meyer, originally from Hamburg but currently studying in London, said she felt guilty. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs way too many really mean and ignorant things said about Greece in my home country,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve brought ‚Ç¨500 with me just in case of problems, and I will absolutely spend them.‚Äù
Kirsi Koskinen, from Tampere in Finland, who was about to go island-hopping with her husband, Arttu, and infant daughter, said she too was concerned ‚Äì but not by a possible shortage of euros. ‚ÄúWe come each year at this time,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI love this country, I love the Greeks, and think it‚Äôs really terrible what‚Äôs happening here. Everybody should come and spend money here, everybody. They need it, really.‚Äù

column4: Attack on 11-year-old in Rio highlights fears of rising religious intolerance
column5:
Dressed in the traditional white robes of the Afro-Brazilian Candombl√© religion, 11-year-old Kailane Campos, her grandmother and some friends were walking home from their temple in Rio de Janeiro, when they heard shouts from across the street. ‚ÄúThere were two guys holding Bibles, jumping up and down and shouting that we had abandoned God and that we were going to burn in hell,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThen one of them picked up a stone, threw it at us, and it hit me on the head.‚Äù Bleeding heavily, Kailane passed out, while the two men jumped on a bus. The others in her group helped her back to their temple before taking her to the nearest hospital.
The attack has highlighted fears of rising religious intolerance among the more militant members of Brazil‚Äôs rapidly growing evangelical movement. With new churches aggressively competing for souls and space in the country‚Äôs poorer urban peripheries, many Afro-Brazilian worshippers have felt threatened by the extreme hostility of some of their pastors. ‚ÄúI hope that what happened to me can serve as some kind of warning,‚Äù Kailane said. Followers of Candombl√©, which blends ancestor worship, spiritualism and Catholic cosmology, have long faced discrimination from an officially secular state. But over recent years, reports of abuse, beatings and forced evictions from Afro-Brazilian places of worship have increased, according to Ivanir dos Santos, the president of the Commission to Combat Religious Intolerance. Dos Santos argues that certain evangelical pastors are attacking these religions and their followers, partly as a way of boosting their own congregations.
‚ÄúThey want to make people ashamed to practise Candombl√©, so they feel they have to turn to the church,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut how can you be a Christian with such hate in your heart?‚Äù The latest incident was covered widely in the Brazilian media. Kailane‚Äôs grandmother, K√°tia Marinho, 53, a Candombl√© priestess, launched a social media campaign with an image of herself holding a sign reading: ‚ÄúI dress in white. White of peace. I am Candombl√©. And you?‚Äù A few days after the attack, Kailane was abused again while giving an interview to a local TV station outside the police medical institute where she had gone to register the crime. ‚ÄúThe media only care about gays and witches,‚Äù a passerby shouted at her. Speaking at her temple in the working-class district of Vila da Penha, Marinho said that it had become more difficult to be a Candombl√© devotee over recent years. ‚ÄúThere are people who tell their followers that our faith is a way of worshipping the devil,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey insult our religion all the time and people with weak minds absorb these things.‚Äù Marinho, whose daughter Karine ‚Äì Kailane‚Äôs mother ‚Äì is an evangelical Christian, was anxious to avoid blaming the church. ‚ÄúThe people who did this are not Christian. They are crazy people and crazy people cannot be allowed to live in the midst of society.‚Äù Silas Malafaia, a prominent evangelical pastor, warned against jumping to conclusions about the attack on Kailane. ‚ÄúTell me what kind of evangelical is in favour of violence?‚Äù he said in a video posted on his website. ‚ÄúWhen have we ever tried to stop the freedom of religious expression of anyone?‚Äù Although there is anecdotal evidence of attacks on Afro-Brazilian religions, few official statistics exist on the subject. Data compiled by the presidency‚Äôs human rights‚Äô secretariat shows that there were 39 recorded acts of religious intolerance in Rio de Janeiro in 2013 and 2014, making it the state with highest number of incidents. However, the figures are not broken down by attacks on particular faiths. Dos Santos is due to present a dossier of incidents involving Afro-Brazilian religions to the state assembly in August. According to the 2010 census, Brazil‚Äôs evangelical population grew by 61.5% over the previous 10 years. Over 22% described themselves as evangelical, up from 9% in 1991. The number of Catholics fell in the same period, from 73.6% to 64.6%. Yvonne Maggie, an anthropologist who has written extensively on Afro-Brazilian religions, said that Candombl√© has long coexisted peacefully with Catholicism. Many of their worshippers venerate the same saints, with some actively practising both religions. ‚ÄúRecent acts of aggression have happened as a result of the rise of non-traditional neo-Pentecostalist churches, some of which demonise Afro-Brazilian religions,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not an organised persecution, but a rise in individual cases, many of which are mixed up with other issues.‚Äù

column4: Israeli man killed and another injured after car shot at in West Bank
column5: One Israeli man has been killed and another wounded when their car was shot at in the occupied West Bank near the settlement of Dolev. They were found slumped by their car on a dirt road on Friday not far from the settlement. Pictures in local media show the car had been hit several times. IDF military spokesman Peter Lerner said the two men, both aged 25, had been flagged down on the dirt road by a Palestinian man apparently seeking assistance. ‚ÄúA Palestinian approached a vehicle that was in the area and asked them to stop ‚Ä¶ and shot the two from close range.‚Äù Police spokesman Micky Rosenfeld said the area near the scene of the attack was cordoned off. ‚ÄúForces are currently searching the area for suspects. This is being treated at as a terror attack,‚Äù Rosenfeld said. ‚ÄúOne of the wounded arrived with no vital signs and the medical team pronounced him dead. The other man is lightly wounded and is receiving treatment,‚Äù a spokeswoman for the Sheba medical centre said. Shootings of settlers in the West Bank have tapered off in recent years as Palestinian attackers have resorted to throwing rocks and petrol bombs at passing Israeli cars. There has been a spate of attacks in which cars have been rammed into civilians waiting for public transport in Jerusalem in the past year and a number of people have been killed. Tensions flared in Jerusalem last year, both before and after the Gaza war, but the city has been relatively calm in recent months. The attack occurred on the first Friday of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, but prayers at Jerusalem‚Äôs al-Aqsa mosque, which police said were attended by about 80,000 worshippers, passed without incident.

column4: European parliament accused of 'hiding away' proof of torture by Assad regime
column5:
The European parliament has ruled against holding a major public exhibition of photographs documenting torture and abuse in Syrian government institutions, deeming the images too provocative, ‚Äúdisturbing and offensive‚Äù, the Guardian has learned.
The MEPs have decided that the photographs, smuggled out of Syria at great risk by a defector from the Assad regime codenamed Caesar, may only be shown at an undetermined future date in a small conference room on the parliament‚Äôs grounds. However, few people are likely to see it there and will not be endorsed by the organisation, even though the exhibition and its horrifying images were officially hosted by the United Nations. A diplomatic source familiar with the discussions told the Guardian: ‚ÄúThese photos are a powerful reminder of the systematic torture and mass killings ongoing in Syria ‚Äì the very least the European parliament can do is bear witness. ‚ÄúThe suggestion that a photo exhibition should be hidden away in a committee room is unheard of, and seriously calls into question the judgment of those responsible for this decision.‚Äù The UN in March hosted an exhibition of 30 photographs out of some 55,000 smuggled by Caesar, a former military photographer who fled the country with the evidence stashed on flash drives. Though warning signs were placed around the exhibition, officials at the time said it was imperative the international community did not ‚Äúlook away‚Äù from the atrocities, documented in Syrian government prisons and hospitals. The war in Syria, now in its fifth year, has claimed more than 220,000 lives. A European parliament spokesperson confirmed that the College of Quaestors, a body of five MEPs that rules on such matters, had unanimously voted against hosting the photographs in the large exhibition space with its thousands of visitors. The spokesperson said the parliament‚Äôs public exhibition areas could only host cultural events and exhibits. But correspondence seen by the Guardian showed that MEPs rejected the planned photographs because they were deemed ‚Äúoffensive and disturbing‚Äù as well as ‚Äúprovocative‚Äù. The parliament hosts an annual commemorative event and exhibit on the Holocaust. Organisers suggested removing some of the more graphic images and to open the exhibition during limited time slots, but the College of Quaestors refused, according to the diplomatic source. The parliament has also told organisers that it would not officially endorse the exhibition, which was originally scheduled to run for five days but will now only last one day if it goes ahead, the source said. Mouaffaq Nyrabia, the opposition Syrian National Coalition‚Äôs representative to the EU, said in a statement: ‚ÄúThe series of photographs taken by the Syrian regime defector ‚ÄòCaesar‚Äô present clear and compelling evidence ‚Äì endorsed by the UN ‚Äì of Assad‚Äôs systematic campaign of murder and torture, and are important testimony to the suffering of Syrians at the hands of this brutal dictatorship.‚Äù He added: ‚ÄúThis is why I urge the European parliament to turn its words of support on the protection of human rights in Syria into action, starting with providing full access to exhibit a small number of the ‚ÄòCaesar‚Äô photographs. ‚ÄúThe situation in Syria is now a global crisis, whose impact upon Europe has repeatedly been made clear. Europe can and must play a more proactive role in achieving a political transition in Syria, and accountability must be central to these efforts.‚Äù Alyn Smith, a Scottish National party MEP and the lead sponsor of the exhibition, said hosting it at a meeting room was a ‚Äúdecent compromise‚Äù given the sensitive nature of the photographs, and the fact that it would be hosted on the European parliament‚Äôs grounds. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs really important for parliament to host that exhibition,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe must not close our eyes to the fact that this is happening.‚Äù

column4: Play unites former militiamen from two sides of Lebanese conflict
column5:
The militant stared down from the rooftop through the scope of his rifle. ‚ÄúI think I see a fighter,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a 70-year-old man,‚Äù said the young man hiding behind him. ‚ÄúWell my father was 70 when they killed him,‚Äù the militant replied. ‚ÄúBut you know,‚Äù countered the young man. ‚ÄúThey say an eye for an eye makes the whole world go blind.‚Äù That was the central message of Love and War on the Rooftop: A Tripolitan Tale, a play within a play that premiered this week in Beirut. The theatre production brought together former militiamen from Sunni and Alawite communities of the northern port city of Tripoli. It was a rare effort at reconciliation in Lebanon, a nation whose social and political fabric has been stretched to breaking point by the war in its larger neighbour Syria. Tripoli has been a frontline of the war. Two impoverished neighbourhoods in particular ‚Äì Jabal Mohsen, which supports Syria‚Äôs Alawite president, Bashar al-Assad, and the Sunni-majority Bab al-Tabbaneh, which backs the Syrian opposition ‚Äì have engaged in a series of clashes that have left hundreds dead. The two neighbourhoods are separated by a single small road, Syria Street. ‚ÄúI thought everyone in Bab al-Tabbaneh was a terrorist,‚Äù said one of the Alawite youths who took part in the play. ‚ÄúBut it wasn‚Äôt true at all. They are kids like us, poor like us, who have also been deceived, who have the same anxieties that we do.‚Äù The theatre production stars 16 young men and women from Tripoli, who play actors struggling to put on a theatre production. Its story centres on Ali and Aisha, a Alawite man and a Sunni woman who fall in love. It is based on the true story of a cast member named Ali who married a Sunni girl from Bab al-Tabbaneh despite the objections of their families and Lebanese politicians. The names have significance. Imam Ali, the prophet Muhammad‚Äôs cousin and son-in-law, is the most revered figure in Shia Islam, and the Alawite sect is named after him. Aisha is the name of the first caliph Abu Bakr‚Äôs daughter, who was married to the prophet Muhammad and later led an army that fought against Ali. More radical than the play‚Äôs structure and the fact that it relies on youth who have never stood on a stage before is that it confronts the taboo concept of reconciliation.
Lebanon‚Äôs own 15-year civil war ended only because its participants exhausted themselves. A general amnesty was issued and many of the warlords whose militias perpetrated myriad atrocities still run the country. The fate of thousands of people disappeared remains unknown. ‚ÄúThis was the worst thing that happened to Lebanon,‚Äù said Lucien Bourjeily, the play‚Äôs director and scriptwriter. ‚ÄúThe war never ended, I would say, but it got to a cold war.‚Äù March, a Lebanese NGO that has worked on conflict resolution projects among local youth, had been looking into ways to address the problems in Tripoli. The organisation was concerned at the portrayal of the clashes as ideological and sectarian, when it believed they were mostly due to endemic poverty and lack of opportunities. March approached Bourjeily to collaborate on a theatre production, and recruited the young actors from local communities, and arranged for them to take part in theatre classes under Bourjeily‚Äôs supervision, as well as workshops on conflict resolution and communication skills. Bourjeily chose not to impose a ‚Äúforeign text‚Äù on them and drew on their real-life stories for the script. ‚ÄúSome have never been to school and don‚Äôt read and write, so me coming in and talking about character and scene analysis and Moli√®re and Shakespeare and all these things wouldn‚Äôt really matter,‚Äù he said before the final rehearsal session. ‚ÄúThey would have walked out of the room.‚Äù One Sunni teenager who took part in the play threw his first bomb when he was 13. He said of working with Alawites on the play: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to take part in it. The politicians who exploited us taught us that these are our enemies, but I had never seen them or dealt with them. But all those ideas changed when I came down and met them.‚Äù Soon the actors were eating and drinking together and reading lines to each other, and had come to realise that they shared similar dreams and challenges such as finding a job and getting married. Now they say that if clashes erupt again they would not fight. ‚ÄúI knew that if I went [to Jabal Mohsen] I should prepare to die, and if one of them came down he would die,‚Äù said the Sunni actor. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how I thought before the play. But next time I go up there with [an Alawite colleague], we‚Äôll get drunk, and then he‚Äôll come over and we‚Äôll also get drunk.‚Äù He said his involvement in the fighting had not been motivated by sectarianism. ‚ÄúSomeone would come to you and give you a bomb and tell you to throw it, and here‚Äôs 50,000 liras [¬£20] for the effort. We didn‚Äôt have work, so we did it. If you didn‚Äôt have a pack of cigarettes, you‚Äôd do it and take the 50,000. They taught us criminality.‚Äù His Alawite colleague agreed: ‚ÄúIf a Muslim kills a Muslim, he isn‚Äôt a martyr,‚Äù he said. A preview in Tripoli drew a mixed Sunni and Alawite crowd and was well received. Bourjeily hopes its message will resonate not just in Lebanon but in Syria as well. ‚ÄúWe are affected by Syria so much,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI truly hope that this play and the vision and the image that these guys give when you see them on stage ‚Äì Alawites and Sunnis together doing this creation ‚Äì give a message not only to Lebanon but all participants in the war in Syria today. There is so much fear of the other in Syria today that makes it impossible for progress to happen.‚Äù That vision was summed up in a melodious couplet at the play‚Äôs end: ‚ÄúWe shall not go our separate ways, no matter how much they try / Aisha loved Ali, and sacrificed for him. We will not sully our hands, we are brethren / Sunni, Shia, Alawi, they must not fight.‚Äù ‚Ä¢ This article was amended on 23 June 2015 to clarify the the roles of the NGO and the director in the proposal for the play.

column4: 'Tsipras has a bus full of people and has to change the wheel while driving'
column5:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all right, they can go ahead and do it now,‚Äù said Vassili Michaelides, a systems analyst, turning away from the National Bank cashpoint on Syntagma Square in central Athens with a clutch of ‚Ç¨20 notes. ‚ÄúThey haven‚Äôt gone down on their knees and signed the first piece of paper they were given, like all the others. But it‚Äôs time now to bring back a deal. Because honestly, nobody here can take this for much longer.‚Äù After five years of savage recession and austerity that have left 26% of the workforce without a job and seen GDP shrink by a quarter, followed by six fraught months of talks aimed at securing some kind of sustainable future, Greeks are running out of patience. ‚ÄúWe need an agreement,‚Äù said George Efstratiadis, who owns a Patras-based family firm specialising in water pumps which ‚Äì after writing off ‚Ç¨500,000 (¬£350,000) of bad debts and laying off half its workforce back in 2011 ‚Äì has recently hired 10 new staff as business has slowly improved. ‚ÄúWe just need them to seal the deal. Business needs stability, and we could live with pretty much whatever gets decided ‚Äì but we just need a decision. They‚Äôre looking after the pensioners and the public-sector employers, that‚Äôs fine, that‚Äôs right ‚Äì but not if it means this much uncertainty.‚Äù In central Athens on Friday the banks were open, the cashpoints were dispensing notes, the cafes were busy and the sesame-seed bagel stands doing a brisk morning trade. But as rumours swirled of imminent insolvency, capital controls and even bank closures by Monday, a steady stream of people ‚Äì though never enough to call a queue ‚Äì were taking money out of the National Bank branch. ‚ÄúYes, I‚Äôm worried,‚Äù admitted Dimitris, who works for an insurance company and ‚Äì since he had just taken out ‚Ç¨1,000 in ‚Ç¨50 notes ‚Äì was reluctant to supply a surname. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm worried because this is now getting very uncertain indeed. The government is not telling us what it will do, how it intends to solve this. I‚Äôm making sure I have enough for the start of next week. Just in case.‚Äù With the headline in Friday‚Äôs Kathimerini newspaper warning that the Bank of Greece had asked the European Central Bank for ‚Ç¨3.5bn of emergency funding to offset some ‚Ç¨3.2bn that has haemorrhaged from Greece‚Äôs largest banks since Monday, some were holding back out of principle. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel 100% secure, that‚Äôs certainly true,‚Äù said Giota Georgiades, who works for a timber and paper import agency. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt want to take all I have out of the bank. If everyone did that, the whole system would go.‚Äù But like almost everyone here, Georgiades ‚Äì who had withdrawn just ‚Ç¨30, ‚Äúenough for today and maybe tomorrow‚Äù ‚Äì said she was confident a way out would be found from her country‚Äôs face-off with its creditors. ‚ÄúI am optimistic,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey will arrive at a solution, I think ‚Äì it‚Äôs in no one‚Äôs interests for Greece to fall over the edge ‚Äì but it had better be found soon now. It had really better be found soon. Now there is almost no more time left.‚Äù
Polls suggest that as the aid-for-reforms talks drag on and the country edges ever closer to debt deadlines and an eventual default, perhaps crashing out of the eurozone in the process, a clear majority of Greeks now expect the country‚Äôs leftist-led government to reach an agreement with its lenders: its eurozone partners, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Asked this week by the GPO polling firm to choose between a ‚Äúbad deal‚Äù and staying in the euro, or no deal and a return to the drachma, more than 56% said they would prefer a bad deal (70% also said they believed the standoff would end with the government climbing down.) That leaves the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, in ‚Äúa difficult position‚Äù, said Nick Malkoutzis, who runs the news and comment website MacroPolis. ‚ÄúPeople like the fact that he‚Äôs stood up to the institutions,‚Äù said Malkoutzis, ‚Äúthat he‚Äôs saying look, this austerity programme isn‚Äôt working. But the longer this goes on, the more it looks like there might not be an agreement ‚Ä¶ The more dangerous that feels.‚Äù Tsipras is holding firm against a number of key reforms demanded by the lenders in exchange for the release of a remaining ‚Ç¨7.2bn in bailout funds before the end of the month, when Greece is due to repay some ‚Ç¨1.6bn in IMF loans. He argues that implementing the proposals, which include cutting pensions and raising some taxes, would mean breaking his election promises and would deepen Greece‚Äôs economic and humanitarian crisis. But his problem, Malkoutzis said, is that: ‚ÄúEveryone, the people, the experts, the markets, is telling him to do a deal ‚Äì but no one is telling him to accept the deal that‚Äôs on the table. He‚Äôs trying to find a compromise that means people are happy because Greece stays in the euro ‚Äì but not accept measures that mean he and his government will be out of office in a few months.‚Äù Not everyone sees a deal as inevitable. Stavros Messines, who runs The Cube, a co-working space for Greek (and some foreign) tech start-ups, said he saw three possible outcomes to the standoff. ‚ÄúGreece could become sort of socialist-led country with its own currency, launched on a wave of popular passion after it pushes the EU to the limit,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúOr a deal could be struck ‚Äì maybe one that doesn‚Äôt particularly suit anyone, but a deal nonetheless. Or, nobody knows what the hell they‚Äôre doing and what happens, happens. I hope, I really hope, it‚Äôs the second. But there‚Äôs far too much passion, too much animosity, in this now. Everyone needs to step back, calm down.‚Äù Upstairs, Triantafyllos Xylouris, one of the young entrepreneurs behind Greece‚Äôs biggest ever app ‚Äì a trivia game called Quizdom that is on 1.1m smartphones in Greece ‚Äì conceded Tsipras had ‚Äúa pretty impossible task‚Äù. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs got a bus with a load of people, and he has to change the wheels and the engine while he‚Äôs driving it,‚Äù said Xylouris.
But while austerity has ‚Äúclearly been a disaster‚Äù, Xylouris felt the government, elected in January, ‚Äúdid not come in with a particularly clear plan of how, realistically, to get what they wanted‚Äù. That uncertainty was compounded, he said, by ‚Äúa simple lack of trust ‚Äì you know, I think if Germany trusted Greek politicians to be sincere, honest, disciplined, there‚Äôd be no problem with a cheque for ‚Ç¨50bn, to be spent on growth.‚Äù But Tsipras and his party are different, said Tonia Katerini, a Syriza activist who helps run a thriving solidarity grocery store in the Exarchia district of Athens: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a huge change: we have a government that cares about the situation of everyone who has been affected by austerity. They do care.‚Äù From where Katerini stands, the main problem with the talks so far has been that ‚Äúthe government has already relaxed its red lines. It‚Äôs pushing for less, on salaries, on taxes ... And it should never have tried to negotiate on their ground. ‚ÄúIt should have said, right from the start, we cannot accept Greece‚Äôs debt as it is. How can we possibly increase GDP while paying back all that debt? Those repayments should be invested in the real economy, for growth.‚Äù A clear commitment to at least discuss debt relief must be part of whatever deal Tsipras brings home, said Malkoutzis: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs still room for an agreement. If the lenders can make that commitment, and if a way can be found to minimise the impact of pension reforms on pensioners ‚Äì that‚Äôs a deal he can sell in parliament, and to Greek society.‚Äù ‚ÄúPeople are tired,‚Äù said Olga Zetou, who works three days a week in a bar. ‚ÄúPeople are just so tired. And getting disillusioned. I don‚Äôt know what I want any more. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid, and I don‚Äôt even have children or a real job to worry about. Nothing is moving. Everything is frozen. And everyone feels more and more insecure.‚Äù It might almost be better, Zetou argued, to ‚Äúdo something really ‚Ä¶ dramatic. Because this really isn‚Äôt working. It‚Äôs better to say, ‚ÄòI divorce you‚Äô, isn‚Äôt it, than to be the one who is kicked out? We have so little left to lose.‚Äù Her friend, Dione Davids, agreed that people are ‚Äúrunning out of patience. We‚Äôre in limbo. Are we in, are we out? Euro or drachma? All I want is a bit of political stability, and a normal society. Not too much to ask, is it?‚Äù

column4: Shooting suspect Dylann Roof charged with nine counts of murder
column5: The suspect in the mass shooting of nine church leaders at Bible study in one of America‚Äôs oldest black congregations has been charged with nine counts of murder and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime, police say. Dylann Storm Roof has reportedly confessed to carrying out the shootings at Emanuel AME church on Wednesday night. CNN is reporting that it has been told by two law enforcement officials that Roof has told authorities that he was the shooter. NBC reported the same. The Guardian cannot confirm this. According to the CNN account, the 21-year-old resident of Columbia, South Carolina, said that his motive had been that he wanted to start a race war. Roof is being held at the Al Cannon detention center in North Charleston. A bond hearing has been scheduled for Friday afternoon, though Roof is likely to appear by video link rather than in person. Nikki Haley, the governor of South Carolina, told NBC News on Friday that she wanted Roof to face a capital prosecution. ‚ÄúWe will absolutely want him to have the death penalty,‚Äù she said. Authorities said that Roof was being kept in isolation away from other people at the jail. He was also being kept on suicide watch for his own protection, they said. New questions were also emerging about how Roof acquired the firearm that he allegedly used in the attack at the historic African American Emanuel AME church. Relatives have indicated that he was given a Glock handgun by his father in April as a birthday present, but CNN law enforcement officials familiar with the details said that he had told officers that he bought a gun recently from a gun shop.

column4: Greek prime minister reaches out to Vladimir Putin for help in financial crisis
column5:
Alexis Tsipras, the Greek prime minister, has made a broad overture to Russia as he seeks a way out of his country‚Äôs debt and currency impasse, telling Vladimir Putin that Greece wants new partners to help it out of the crisis. In a speech delivered in front of Putin in Russia, Tsipras said Moscow was one of Greece‚Äôs most important partners, and dismissed critics who wondered why he was in St Petersburg and not in Brussels trying to secure an urgent deal with European creditors.
‚ÄúAs all of you are fully aware, we are at the moment at the centre of a storm, of a whirlpool, but we live near the sea so we‚Äôre not scared of storms. We are ready to go to new seas to reach new safe ports,‚Äù he added, in a subtle nod to his hosts. Tsipras said the world‚Äôs economic centre of gravity had shifted and that there are ‚Äúnew emerging forces‚Äù such as the Bric countries and Putin‚Äôs new Eurasian union that are playing a more important economic role. ‚ÄúRussia is one of the most important partners for us,‚Äù said the Greek prime minister, ahead of formal talks with Putin. His intervention came as Greece teetered on the brink of a banking crisis, a deal between the government in Athens and creditors owed $320bn still elusive. Greece wants significant debt relief in return for fiscal reforms; lenders are reluctant to be generous to a country that has struggled to balance the books for years. ‚ÄúThe EU should go back to its initial principles of solidarity, justice and social justice. Ensuring strict economic measures will lead us nowhere,‚Äù Tsipras said. ‚ÄúThe so-called problem of Greece is the problem of the whole European Union.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe question is whether the EU can once again be a social solidarity hub or it will continue to pursue the path that will lead to a dead-end,‚Äù he added. Putin has met Tsipras on several occasions this spring as the debt crisis has intensified, leading to suggestions that Moscow might be prepared to step in where Brussels fears to tread in order to bolster its influence in southeastern Europe. The two countries announced a deal earlier in the day to route a pipeline through Greece that would carry Russian gas to Europe. Greece can expect transit payments ‚Äì but not until the project is completed in 2019. Putin‚Äôs aides indicated that Moscow would consider lending Greece money if required, though no formal request had yet been submitted. But in his earlier speech at the St Petersburg Economic Forum, Putin was coy about Russia‚Äôs intentions towards Greece. Russia itself is weathering an economic setback triggered by low oil prices and sanctions. Putin said it had successfully negotiated the worst of the crisis and was once again ‚Äúopen to the world‚Äù.
But he too put the accent on ties with Bric countries and Latin America, noting the difficulties in relations with Europe. ‚ÄúWe are following very closely what happens in Europe because it is our major trading partner. I hope that problems will go away and we will continue to develop our relationship further.‚Äù Asked whether Russia saw its economic future more closely bound into a China-led grouping, he added: ‚ÄúWe are not creating a bloc-based approach. We are trying to create a global approach.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe are not being aggressive. We are persistent, we are consistent in pursuing our interests.‚Äù

column4: Danish rightwinger Kristian Thulesen Dahl rides high on populist tide
column5:
When Kristian Thulesen Dahl first heard that election-night exit polls were predicting a doubling of support for his populist, rightwing Danish People‚Äôs party (DPP), he burst into song. Cheered on by supporters on a stage in Copenhagen, he led the celebrations with a rendition of the Liverpool FC anthem You‚Äôll Never Walk Alone. Thulesen Dahl‚Äôs companionable choice of song was not out of place in a country that pays close attention to British politics and lifestyles. Last week the multiparty right-of-centre alliance that is now expected to take power in Denmark, led by Lars L√∏kke Rasmussen‚Äôs Venstre (Liberal) party, pledged supportfor David Cameron‚Äôs efforts to reform the European Union. And the outgoing Social Democrat prime minister, Helle Thorning-Schmidt, is married to the son of the former Labour leader Neil Kinnock.
Thulesen Dahl‚Äôs success in helping the DPP become the second-largest party in Denmark‚Äôs parliament, the Folketing, with 21% of the vote, sets a daunting precedent that Britain‚Äôs Ukip ‚Äì with which the DPP is sometimes compared ‚Äì can only dream of matching. Whatever people may say about the clean-cut, politically savvy Thulesen Dahl and his divisive anti-Muslim, anti-immigrant, anti-Brussels stance, he is no Nigel Farage. Soft-spoken and plausible, the 45-year-old Thulesen Dahl ran on a platform that appealed to anti-foreigner and nationalist sentiment while promising a range of incentives, particularly to the ‚Äúgrey vote‚Äù, including improved healthcare provision for elderly people and higher public-sector spending. Ignoring opponents‚Äô claims that his sums did not add up, he offered to finance increased welfare benefits and pensions by cutting spending on settling and housing asylum seekers, refugees and EU immigrants. Coincidentally or not, 43% of DPP voters were older than 60. It was a seductive campaign narrative that pulled rival parties, including Thorning-Schmidt‚Äôs Social Democrats, to the right while denying them a clearly separate ideological identity. A similar phenomenon is evident across Scandinavia ‚Äì and to some degree, in Britain ‚Äì where the left has lost control of the agenda and is failing to provide credible alternative answers. Thulesen Dahl has now emerged as the kingmaker of Danish politics, with the balance of power teetering on a 90/89-seat split between the blocs of right and left. ‚ÄúThis election campaign has shown that we are a party that the others just can‚Äôt avoid. We are a party to be taken seriously here in this country,‚Äù Thulesen Dahl declared on election night. The political establishment knows this is no idle boast. Some see him as Denmark‚Äôs nation-saving white knight ‚Äì he belongs to the 17th-century chivalric Order of the Dannebrog. Others suspect a more destructive agenda. In a country of 5.7 million people, of whom 9% were born abroad, immigration from within the EU and from further afield is an incendiary issue that has become mixed up with anti-Muslim, or anti-Islamic, sentiment. Denmark received almost 15,000 asylum seekers in 2014, more than double the number for 2013. Like other European countries, it is watching the unprecedented influx of migrants across the Mediterranean this year with trepidation. In an interview in 2013 Thulesen Dahl said Denmark should accept more refugees from non-Muslim countries and fewer from Muslim countries, in effect saying there was no room for more Muslims. During the election campaign he was more circumspect. But it seems clear the DPP surge fed off fears about the ‚Äúenemy within‚Äù symbolised by February‚Äôs deadly attacks in Copenhagen by a lone Islamist extremist. The incident was seen as an assault on a traditional Danish value, freedom of speech.
In an echo of the British debate on radicalisation, the DPP has threatened to prosecute imams such as Abu Bilal Ismail, a preacher at the Grimhojvej mosque in Aarhus that has sent many young Muslims to Syria. Thulesen Dahl‚Äôs specific policies comprise cuts to immigration, withdrawal from the EU‚Äôs Schengen free-movement area and reinstating border controls with Germany and Sweden, opposition to further EU integration (including a possible British-style in/out referendum), mooted cuts in foreign aid, higher pensions for the less well-off and higher business taxes. Citing what it says is widespread concern about ‚Äúbenefits tourism‚Äù and criminal gangs infiltrating Denmark from eastern Europe, the DPP will side with David Cameron against Germany‚Äôs Angela Merkel and others in an attempt to curb free movement within the EU. ‚ÄúWe want an EU where power is brought back to the member states and where the commission doesn‚Äôt rule,‚Äù S√∏ren Espersen, the DPP‚Äôs foreign affairs spokesman, told the Guardian during the campaign. ‚ÄúThat is of the utmost importance to the future of Europe, we believe. ‚ÄúWe think David Cameron is speaking on behalf of many, many states that don‚Äôt want to see the continuation of this madness. What is going on in Britain is to the advantage of the whole community.‚Äù
To maximise his chances of enacting his programme, Thulesen Dahl must decide whether or not to join a coalition led by Rasmussen‚Äôs Liberals. Most DPP supporters reportedly want him to sign up, but Thulesen Dahl is dithering, pointing to the period from 2001 to 2011 when his party exerted significant influence on a rightwing coalition on key issues that mattered to it, but stayed outside government. He is said to want to avoid the fate of Britain‚Äôs Lib Dems and Norway‚Äôs Progress party, which were tainted by time spent in office. But any government led by Rasmussen and the Liberals would be fragile given the right‚Äôs one-seat majority in parliament and the fact that the Liberals came a poor third in the poll, losing a quarter of their seats. If Dahl is perceived to be undermining a weak new administration for his own ends, or failing to turn promises into reality, the populist tide that raised him high this week could turn and sink him.

column4: Anti-austerity protest in London: are you taking part?
column5: A demonstration against the government‚Äôs ongoing embrace of austerity economics takes place in London over the weekend. Organised by The People‚Äôs Assembly and supported by various unions and campaign groups, the march aims to highlight the damage caused by government cuts and privatisation across the country, while also sparking a debate about how to protect the welfare state and develop an alternative to the current political and economic status quo. Tens of thousands are expected to attend the march. Are you one of them? Share your stories and images with us. As well as pictures from the day, we want to hear your individual story: why did you decide to march? How has austerity has affected you, your family and your community? What do you hope the demonstration will achieve? You can contribute your stories by clicking on the blue banner below. We‚Äôll feature them in our coverage of the march on the Guardian website.

column4: Children suffer worsening conditions in Calais's dismal Jungle 2 migrant camp
column5:
Growing numbers of unaccompanied children and young people are living in increasingly squalid conditions in a huge makeshift camp for migrants in Calais. More than 3,000 people ‚Äì including children as young as 12 and 13 ‚Äì who have fled war, poverty and oppression are living in a sprawling camp known locally as Jungle 2. Aid workers say living conditions for migrants in Calais have worsened in the past few months with a lack of food, blankets and shelter leading to growing tensions. ‚ÄúIt is much worse than it was before,‚Äù said Martine Devries, from M√©dicins du Monde. ‚ÄúThere are more people and they are becoming more desperate and are taking more risks. Last year people would only make attempts to get on to lorries at night, now there are so many and they are so desperate people are trying in broad daylight.‚Äù
The camp, which was set up in April after the previous ‚ÄúJungle‚Äù camp was demolished, has a day centre that provides shower facilities and one meal a day for migrants as well as overnight accommodation for 100 women and children. However, aid workers say they are being overwhelmed by the numbers of people coming, mainly from east Africa, the Middle East and Afghanistan, and conditions in the rest of the site are desperate. Among the warren of tents, Bahad, who left his home in Ethiopia when he was 16 and travelled across the Sahara and into Libya, said surviving day to day was tough. ‚ÄúIt is very difficult,‚Äù said Bahad, who arrived at the camp by himself three months ago. ‚ÄúWe get one meal a day but you have to queue for many hours for it and sometimes it finishes before you get to the front.‚Äù It was late afternoon and he said he had not eaten since the day before. ‚ÄúEveryone here is always hungry,‚Äù he said. Like many in the camp, Bahad has a chilling account of his journey to Calais. He says more than half of the 40 people who set out with him died ‚Äì either crossing the Sahara or in Libya, where he says many were shot by the police.
Now he is one of six people living in a small tent tucked between mounds of rubbish and an area used as a toilet. As he spoke, a man nearby was being treated by medical volunteers for what appeared to be a broken hand. He said he got it the day before when the police beat him. ‚ÄúThe police are very hard,‚Äù said Bahad. ‚ÄúIt is very tough here ‚Ä¶ the dirt and the lack of food, the police.‚Äù He waved his hand at the rubbish piled up outside his tent. ‚ÄúIt is not what I expected Europe to be.‚Äù Bahad says he wants to go to England because it is safe and he can get an education ‚Äì and that he loves football. ‚ÄúI am pretty good you know,‚Äù he said with a smile. He had been in Calais three months and said he would try for another month then think again. ‚ÄúBut then what? I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he said. As conditions worsen, Devries says there are growing tensions in the camp as more people stay for longer. ‚ÄúThere is pressure on everyone and there have been some big fights,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúFights for food, fights for everything. People are hungry and living like this is one thing for two or three weeks but another if you are here for three or six months, like some of these people are.‚Äù

column4: Flight stowaway in critical condition as police investigate links with fall victim
column5:
A man remains in a critical condition in hospital after surviving a 10-hour flight by clinging to the undercarriage of a British Airways flight from which another stowaway is feared to have plunged to his death. The survivor was found unconscious in the undercarriage of the plane on Thursday morning having endured freezing temperatures over the 8,000 miles (12,875km) flight from Johannesburg to London. The body of the dead man was discovered an hour later on the roof of a west London office building. It is not clear if he was killed in the fall; flight data reveals the plane would have been at an altitude of around 1,400ft (427m) when it passed over the area. Police say they believe they know the survivor‚Äôs identity and that he is 24 years old, but are awaiting confirmation. Scotland Yard said officers were looking into whether there was a connection between the survivor and the dead man, who was found under the busy flight path of planes coming into Heathrow over the Richmond area. ‚ÄúAt this time, there is no evidence to link the death to the discovery of a stowaway in the undercarriage of a plane at Heathrow airport; however, this is one line of enquiry into identifying the deceased and the circumstances of his death,‚Äù the Metropolitan police said.
There have been previous cases of stowaways plunging to their deaths in west London after smuggling themselves on to planes. They hide in the landing gear where they are exposed to the elements and endure sub-zero temperatures. Most are killed by the cold and lack of oxygen at high altitude. In September 2012, Jos√© Matada, 26, died after falling from the undercarriage of a Heathrow-bound flight from Angola on to a street in Mortlake, west London. An inquest into his death heard that the Mozambican man was likely to have survived temperatures as low as -60C (-76F) for most of the 12-hour flight. It was believed he was dead or nearly dead by the time he hit the ground. David Learmount, an aviation expert and consulting editor of Flight International magazine, said the fact that one of the two men survived the long flight suggests he may have been able to get into the baggage hold section of the aircraft, which would raise serious security questions. ‚ÄúIf these two were neither airline nor airport staff and somehow managed to get on a flight, then it becomes a serious security issue. Just how did they get [on the restricted] airside at the airport? ‚ÄúThen there‚Äôs the question of just where on the plane these two were. If a person was in the wheel well of a plane on an 11-hour flight there‚Äôs really very little chance of surviving. You are either going to be frozen to death by temperatures of -50C or you are going to die through lack of oxygen with the plane flying at 35,000ft.‚Äù
The victim fell on to the offices of the online marketplace Notonthehighstreet.com on a busy road. Charles Campbell, 59, a carpenter from Ealing in west London, left a bunch of yellow flowers at the scene, saying that he thought no one else would. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs got a family and it‚Äôs Father‚Äôs Day on Sunday. This is not first time this has happened,‚Äù he said. Worshippers at a church across the road from where the dead man‚Äôs body was found would pray for him, the vicar, the Rev Neil Summers, said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very shocking when something like this happens on your doorstep. Coupled with all the migrants coming across the high seas into Europe from north Africa, it‚Äôs just another example of how desperate people are to reach this country to try to find a better life for themselves.‚Äù Johannesburg‚Äôs OR Tambo international airport, where the flight originated, announced that security was being heightened and said the incident was the first of its nature there in 10 years. Colin Naidoo, a spokesman for Airports Company South Africa, which manages the airport, said authorities were still investigating how the stowaways made it past security. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a security breach ‚Ä¶ we need to find out how and why this happened,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very rare for this to happen in South Africa.‚Äù The British Airways flight departed for Heathrow at 7.45pm (1745 GMT) on Wednesday, Naidoo added. A British Airways spokeswoman said: ‚ÄúWe are working with the Metropolitan police and the authorities in Johannesburg to establish the facts surrounding this very rare case.‚Äù A postmortem examination of the dead man is scheduled to take place next week.

column4: Charleston church massacre: 'What happened in there was brutal'
column5:
Dylann Storm Roof walked up the 23 slate grey steps that led to the main entrance of the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal church and asked for the pastor. It was Wednesday, and that meant Bible study night. Security cameras captured the slender 21-year-old dressed in dark trousers and a grey sweatshirt, with his hair cut into a distinctive bowl, entering the church by the main door. There was no sign in the video footage of the gun that he carried, carefully hidden. His father had given him a .45-calibre handgun in April as a 21st birthday present.
No one, it seemed, thought to turn the young man away. The church in downtown Charleston had a history of opening its doors to strangers that stretched back decades. Inside, a dozen regular members of the church were gathered around a table in a basement meeting room. It was the time of the week when congregants came to gain ‚Äúa closer relationship with God‚Äù, as the church describes the sessions. ‚ÄúIs something missing from your life?‚Äù the church website says. ‚ÄúAre you doing all you can to have a closer relationship with God? If you have a desire to learn more about God, then join us.‚Äù On Wednesday at about 8pm Roof answered that call. Having asked for the pastor, he sat down right next to him.
Before the shooting began, Roof‚Äôs youngest victim, 26-year-old student Tywanza Sanders, a 2014 graduate of Allen University, released a Snapchat video to a friend. It provided a glimpse of the gathering in the moments before the carnage.
The video, obtained by CNN and Mashable, is grainy and shaky, showing only the briefest glimpse of the scene. The bible group is seen sitting around the table in a large, wood-panelled room. Books and papers were on the table, and the participants were sitting on folding chairs.
One still image from the video shows Clementa Pinckney, who also held a position as a South Carolina state senator, in a green shirt, gesturing to the others and possibly smiling. At least three other unidentified black people are in the frame. At the far side of the table was Roof, partially obscured by his soon-to-be victims.
If Sanders was the youngest of those victims, the oldest was his great-aunt Susie Jackson. At 87, she had been coming to the Emanuel her entire life. As her son, Walter, told the Guardian, she rarely missed a Sunday service, was an integral part of the church‚Äôs gospel choir, and was also a dab hand at cooking for the congregation. Not long ago, she won first prize in the annual church fair for her hot devilled crab cakes. She greatly enjoyed the prize, her son said, two days at the Charleston Hyatt. The church, and her family, were the centre of Susie Jackson‚Äôs world. ‚ÄúThis is just senseless,‚Äù he said of his mother‚Äôs death, just hours after the shooting, having travelled from his home in Cleveland to rejoin his grieving family.
‚ÄúTo kill innocent people like that. It‚Äôs hard on all of us. My mother was always there for us ‚Äì she was always the one people would turn to when they had a problem.‚Äù
Other congregants at the table were Dr Daniel L Simmons Sr, 74, and Ethel Lance, 70, a reverend and a custodian respectively of the Emanuel church, and Myra Thompson, 59, the wife of a vicar at another local church. ‚ÄúThese weren‚Äôt just ordinary people,‚Äù said William Hamilton, a local attorney who knew several victims. ‚ÄúThey were major community names who had done things for us here for years.‚Äù DePayne Middleton-Doctor, 49, worked in Charleston county as director of the federal community development block grants; Cynthia Hurd, 54, was the regional manager of the St Andrew‚Äôs library, and Sharonda Coleman-Singleton, 45, was a speech therapist at a high school north of the city. So far only Sanders‚Äô seconds-long Snapchat, supplemented by an equally sketchy indirect account given by one of the three survivors, have been able to provide clues to what happened inside that room. What is known is that Roof sat quietly among the worshippers for about an hour as they studied the Bible. Both local police and the FBI have declined to provide details about what happened next.
However Sylvia Johnson, a cousin of Pinckney, relayed a harrowing account she said was provided to her by a female survivor. Johnson told NBC that Roof sat next to Pinckney throughout the class, but then made his move as the meeting was coming to an end. ‚ÄúAt the conclusion of the Bible study, from what I understand, they just start hearing loud noises ringing out. The suspect had already wounded a couple of individuals, including my cousin.‚Äù Johnson said the survivor told her that Roof reloaded his weapon five times and engaged in conversation with his victims as they pleaded with him to stop. The survivor‚Äôs son, who was also at the meeting, ‚Äúwas trying to talk him out of doing that act of killing people‚Äù, Johnson said. She added that Roof replied: ‚ÄúI have to do it. You rape our women and you‚Äôre taking over our country. And you have to go.‚Äù It was not until hours later that news of the shooting began to spread around Charleston ‚Äì and across the country. Roof fled the scene in a black sedan with Confederate flag licence plates, and was arrested, the following day, more than 200 miles away, across the North Carolina border.
By the early hours of Thursday morning, distraught relatives of the victims had gathered at the nearby Embassy Suites hotel. ‚ÄúRaw emotion was out,‚Äù said Tamika Myers, 40, who works at Blind Justice, a local group that assists grieving relatives of shooting victims. ‚ÄúPeople were crying. Some were passing out.‚Äù The identities of only three victims were relayed to families that night, Myers said. By 5am the coroner, Rae H Wooten, had to explain why identification was proving so difficult. ‚ÄúWhat happened in there was brutal,‚Äù Myers said. ‚ÄúIt was gruesome.‚Äù

column4: Stowaway death of man who died with a single pound in his pocket
column5: The tragic death of a stowaway in London, who plunged from a plane, echoes that of Jos√© Matada, who died with a single pound in his pocket after hiding in the landing gear of a plane. Like the as-yet-unnamed man who fell to his death on Thursday, Matada was on a British Airways flight from Africa ‚Äì in his case Angola ‚Äì and his body was found close to Heathrow airport. Matada was discovered on the pavement of Portman Avenue in East Sheen shortly before 7.45am on 9 September 2012, the day after his 27th birthday. He was either dead or at the point of death due to hypothermia and lack of oxygen when he fell from the plane as its undercarriage opened for its descent into Heathrow, an inquest heard. Despite wearing only light clothes, he appeared to have survived the bulk of the 12-hour trip from the south Atlantic coast of Africa through being young and fit, though low oxygen levels and temperatures of as low as -60C in the unpressurised wheel recess of the Boeing 777 would have left him unconscious. Matada, known as Youssop, had no identity papers on him and no one had reported him missing. It was only in April 2013 that detectives said they had been able to identify him, after analysis from an Angolan mobile phone sim card found in a pocket. This showed he had been exchanging text messages with an Anglo-Swiss woman for whom he had formerly worked. The woman said Matada had worked for her family as a housekeeper and gardener when they lived in South Africa in 2010. She correctly described a distinctive tattoo on his left arm, matching that on the body found in west London. It was many months more before his family was finally traced. In January last year, the BBC reported that his family had come forward and identified themselves to the authorities in Mozambique after reading about his death in a local newspaper. His older brother, Domingos Matada, said he had last spoken to his brother in June 2012, when he believed he was in South Africa, but could not get through after that. ‚ÄúI called others who knew him there, but they said, ‚Äòhe‚Äôs disappeared‚Äô,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt expect him to go to another country, I just thought he‚Äôd suddenly appear here one day, or call.‚Äù In November 2014, Matada‚Äôs body was exhumed from an unmarked grave in Twickenham and flown home to his family in Mozambique.

column4: UN launches fresh Yemen aid appeal as WHO confirms dengue fever outbreak
column5:
The United Nations has launched a renewed appeal for $1.6bn in funds to help civilians in Yemen, as the World Health Organisation confirmed an outbreak of dengue fever in the Arab world‚Äôs poorest country, where a growing humanitarian crisis is spiralling out of control and a massive aid pledge by Saudi Arabia has failed to materialise. Yemen is reeling from the effects of a blockade imposed by a Saudi-led coalition, which launched an aerial campaign in March to stem the advance of Houthi rebels allied with Iran. The blockade has led to severe fuel, water and medicine shortages in Yemen, where the UN believes 21 million people, or 80% of the population, are in need of humanitarian assistance. Stephen O‚ÄôBrien, UN under-secretary general for humanitarian affairs, launched the revised funding appeal, telling donors a ‚Äúlooming catastrophe‚Äù was in the making.
The WHO says it has confirmed an outbreak of dengue fever in the country, with more than 3,000 cases recorded since March ‚Äì a number that is likely to rise due to the collapsing infrastructure and health system. A health ministry official in the southern port city of Aden told the Associated Press that at least 5,000 people have been diagnosed with the mosquito-borne virus. He said mountains of uncollected garbage, along with untreated sewage and heat, have contributed to its spread. Dengue causes fever, headaches and skin rashes. Potentially lethal cases, mainly in children, involve abdominal pain, vomiting and difficulty breathing, according to the WHO. The Houthis, members of the Zaydi sect of Shia Islam, took control of Sana‚Äôa last year before advancing on the country‚Äôs south, driving the president of Yemen, Abd Rabbu Mansour Hadi, into exile. They are allied with former president Ali Abdullah Saleh, who was ousted in a deal brokered by the Gulf states after Arab spring-style protests. The Saudi coalition is concerned about the growing influence of its regional rival Iran, and has responded with near-daily air strikes. More than 2,500 people have been killed and 11,000 injured so far in the war, which has had limited success in halting the Houthi advance. Amanda Pitt, the spokesperson for the UN‚Äôs Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (Ocha), told the Guardian on Thursday the organisation‚Äôs appeal would ‚Äúhighlight the significantly increased aid and protection needs across the country‚Äù.
‚ÄúAs with all the crises we are dealing with, appeals are issued on the basis of people‚Äôs needs,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey are aimed at all or any donors, be they governmental, private sector or individuals, to raise the funds needed to carry out vital aid activities.‚Äù The UN launched a ‚Äúflash appeal‚Äù in April, urgently asking for $274m in funds to deal with the crisis. Saudi Arabia said at the time that it would cover the entire cost of the appeal, ordering the disbursement of $274m towards humanitarian aid in Yemen. However, the Saudi pledge has yet to materialise. The UN says it has so far received $163m in Yemen funds in 2015, but a list of donors that was last updated on Wednesday does not include Saudi Arabia. ‚ÄúWe are continuing to work with the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia on the modalities of transferring the humanitarian funds that were pledged to help the people of Yemen,‚Äù said Pitt.
‚ÄúOf course we cannot speak on behalf of donors or determine decisions made by them with regard to timing, recipients, or other factors related to humanitarian funding.‚Äù The aid appeal comes against a backdrop of UN-brokered talks in Geneva between Yemeni factions involved in the war that has made little progress towards a resolution to the conflict. Earlier this week the UN secretary general, Ban Ki-Moon, called for an immediate halt to the fighting in Yemen at the opening of the talks: ‚ÄúYemen‚Äôs very existence hangs in the balance.‚Äù

column4: One in four plane stowaways can survive, but London case is astonishing
column5:
Given the number of desperate people attempting to reach Europe by land or sea on incredibly risky journeys, stowaways on aircraft are comparatively rare. But security at airports is usually tighter than at other borders, and the risks of an attempt are enormous, with the prospects of survival remote.
The fact that one of the two men who secreted themselves on the eight-hour BA flight from Johannesburg to London Heathrow has survived the journey, albeit in a serious condition in hospital, is astonishing. While neither the airline nor the police have yet confirmed it, the most likely scenario is that the stowaways would have hidden in the landing gear of the plane, exposing themselves to temperatures of -50C to -60C. There have been occasional previous recorded cases of people making it alive, on shorter flights at lower altitudes. A 20-year-old Romanian man made it to Heathrow from Vienna in 2010, concealed in the undercarriage of a private jet that flew comparatively low, in air still thick enough for lungs to function. But normally the combination of cold, lack of oxygen and air pressure experienced at a plane‚Äôs cruising height, outside the artificially maintained conditions of the cabin, would prove fatal. If they can withstand the flight, the stowaways need to cling on and remain conscious when the wheels come down on the approach to the airport. One of the two men on the BA flight appears to have been beyond the point of endurance by the time the plane was on its descent over Richmond, his body falling on to shops below. US Federal Aviation Authority records suggest that, at best, one in four stowaways survives. Others die or fall in transit; some are crushed when the mechanised landing gear retracts into the wheel well; most survivors suffer severe hypothermia or frostbite, often losing limbs. Thursday‚Äôs tragic incident recalls the death of Jos√© Matada, who made a similarly desperate attempt to reach the UK from Angola in 2012, His body was found on a pavement in East Sheen in south-west London and an inquest found he was either dead or at the point of death due to hypothermia and lack of oxygen when he fell from the plane. Airport security is normally extremely tight, even in places where security outside the terminal is a problem. Airline and airport staff would normally perform pre-flight checks, including inspection of the wheel well, although airlines say security is ultimately the airport‚Äôs responsibility. Passengers and workers face numerous checks. But airport perimeter fences are often surrounded by the worst poverty, such as the shanty towns in Luanda, the Angolan airport from where that last reported Heathrow-bound stowaway flew.
The Angolan capital responded to that event by tightening security to have all international flights followed by a security patrol vehicle for evening departures, keeping the plane‚Äôs undercarriage in full view.
