column4: Pope puts sex aside and declares green living central to faith
column5:
The first thing that strikes you about the pope‚Äôs latest slim volume is that there‚Äôs virtually no sex in it. And that is not to be facetious. Ever since the publication of another milestone encyclical, Paul VI‚Äôs Humanae Vitae, the Catholic leadership has become progressively more obsessed with sex: contraception, abortion, IVF, surrogate parenthood, homosexuality and, reluctantly, clerical sex abuse. The effect has been to sideline other, hugely important matters. To read 184 pages written by ‚Äì though, in reality, approved by ‚Äì a pope that deal almost solely with the fate of humanity, rather than what humans get up to in private, makes an immensely refreshing change. The part where sex does creep in will be, for many, the least convincing. It is the part where Francis addresses those who maintain that the Vatican cannot credibly deplore the desecration of the environment without recognising the effects of its aversion to birth control. In a passage that defines the term ‚ÄúJesuitical‚Äù, Francis, the first Jesuit pope, tries to convince us that the proponents of reproductive health are, unwittingly, working for the environmental bad guys. ‚ÄúTo blame population growth instead of extreme and selective consumerism on the part of some is one way of refusing to face the issues,‚Äù he writes. ‚ÄúIt is an attempt to legitimise the present model of distribution, where a minority believes that it has the right to consume in a way which can never be universalised, since the planet could not even contain the waste products of such consumption.‚Äù The International Planned Parenthood Federation as a tool of the rich? That really won‚Äôt wash, particularly since Francis goes on to acknowledge that ‚Äúattention needs to be paid to imbalances in population density, on both national and global levels‚Äù. Apparently, then, it is not a surplus of babies that is the real problem, but where they are born. The pope‚Äôs effort to sever the link between population growth and environmental deterioration should not, however, detract from the importance of what else he has to say. This is the first encyclical to be devoted entirely to environmental issues, though it is certainly not the first time a pope has spoken out on the destruction of the environment. As the encyclical notes, Paul VI first raised the issue as long ago as 1971, describing it as a ‚Äútragic consequence‚Äù of uncontrolled human activity. Saint John Paul II and his successor, Benedict XVI, inveighed against mankind‚Äôs ill-treatment of nature ‚Äì or as they viewed it, creation.
Far more explicitly than his predecessors, however, Francis heaps the blame on to the part of humanity that is rich. He accepts that the poorer nations should ‚Äúacknowledge the scandalous level of consumption in some privileged sectors of their population and ‚Ä¶ combat corruption more effectively.‚Äù They ought also to develop less polluting sources of energy. But his real target ‚Äì as in his apostolic exhortation Evangelii Gaudium two years ago ‚Äì is the rich world and the global economic order it has forged, which he argues tolerates vast differences in the wellbeing of nations and individuals ‚Äì a system characterised by ‚Äúspeculation and the pursuit of financial gain‚Äù, which ignores ‚Äúthe effects on human dignity and the natural environment‚Äù. Thus, says Francis, environmental degradation is intimately linked to an erosion of human and ethical values. That is the connection he needs to support the true originality of this encyclical. He writes that it is addressed not just to the Roman Catholic ecclesiastical hierarchy (as were the earliest encyclicals) or to the faithful as well (as more recent ones have been), but to all of mankind. ‚ÄúFaced as we are with global environmental deterioration, I wish to address every person living on this planet,‚Äù he writes.
It is in the passages addressed to his own flock that Francis really breaks new ground. Using a phrase first coined by John Paul II, he says that Catholics, if they have not already done so, need to undergo an ‚Äúecological conversion‚Äù. This is not just because ‚Äúgreen is good‚Äù but because, he declares, green is central to their faith. ‚ÄúLiving our vocation to be protectors of God‚Äôs handiwork is essential to a life of virtue; it is not an optional or a secondary aspect of our Christian experience.‚Äù It is a call ‚Äì no, an instruction ‚Äì to the world‚Äôs Catholics to work for the protection of the environment and to save the planet. The potential effect hardly needs to be spelled out. One in every six human beings is baptised a Catholic. The question that has yet to be answered is whether Francis‚Äôs flock, especially in the United States, will pay any more attention to Laudato Si than it paid to the ban on artificial methods of contraception in Humanae Vitae.

column4: South Carolina church shooting: police hunt gunman after 'hate crime' attack
column5:
At least nine people have been killed after a gunman opened fire at a historic black church in Charleston, South Carolina, in what police have described as a ‚Äúhate crime‚Äù. Police released a image of the gunman and a car from video at a press conference on Thursday. The suspect, who is still on the loose, has been described as a clean-shaved, white male aged approximately 21, with a small, slender build, wearing a grey sweatshirt with jeans and boots.
Gunfire erupted on Wednesday inside the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal church, whose pastor Clementa Pinckney, a Democratic member of the South Carolina Senate, was named as one of the dead. Eight of the victims were killed in the church. Another died on the way to hospital. Charleston police chief Greg Mullen said there were survivors, but declined to give more details. The gunman had yet to be caught hours after the attack and was considered extremely dangerous, he said.
Mullen said he believed the shooting was ‚Äúa hate crime‚Äù. He said: This is a tragedy that no community should have to experience ... It is senseless, unfathomable. We are going to do everything in our power to find this individual, to lock him [the gunman] up, to make sure he does not hurt anyone else. ‚ÄúThe primary emphasis is going to be us catching this individual before he hurts anybody else‚Äù. A reward would be announced on Thursday, he said. The city‚Äôs mayor, Joseph P Riley Jr, described the killing as an ‚Äúunspeakable tragedy‚Äù, pledging to ‚Äúbring this awful person to justice as soon as humanely possible‚Äù. ‚ÄúPeople in prayer on a Wednesday evening, a ritual coming together, praying and worshipping God. To have an awful person come in and shoot them is inexplicable, obviously the most intolerable and unbelievable act possible,‚Äù he said.
He said he had met victims‚Äô families in ‚Äúa heartbreaking scene I have never witnessed in my life before‚Äù. He added: ‚ÄúI told them that this community sends forth it love to them and we are all in this together.‚Äù Police have not named the victims but the Democratic party leader in the South Carolina state house confirmed pastor and state senator Pinckney was among the dead. ‚ÄúHe was always out doing work either for his parishioners or his constituents. He touched everybody,‚Äù minority leader Todd Rutherford told AP.
Pinckney helped lead a prayer vigil in April for Walter Scott, a black South Carolina man who was shot dead by a North Charleston police officer. He campaigned for police to be equipped with body cameras, which he said ‚Äúmay not be the golden ticket, the golden egg, the end-all-fix-all, but [would help] to paint a picture of what happens during a police stop‚Äù. Mandatory body cameras became law in the state one week ago. The Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal church traces its roots to 1816 and is one of the largest black congregations south of Baltimore. The Reverend Martin Luther King Jr addressed the church in 1962. South Carolina governor Nikki Haley said in a statement she and her family were praying for the victims. ‚ÄúWhile we do not yet know all of the details, we do know that we‚Äôll never understand what motivates anyone to enter one of our places of worship and take the life of another,‚Äù she said.
‚ÄúPlease join us in lifting up the victims and their families with our love and prayers.‚Äù Cornell William Brooks, president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) said the organisation was ‚Äúoutraged‚Äù to be faced with another mass hate crime 106 years after it was founded to fight racial hatred. ‚ÄúThe senselessly slain parishioners were in a church for Wednesday night bible study. There is no greater coward than a criminal who enters a house of God and slaughters innocent people engaged in the study of scripture,‚Äù he said in a statement. Soon after Wednesday night‚Äôs shooting, a group of pastors huddled together praying in a circle across the street. Community organiser Christopher Cason said he felt certain the shootings were racially motivated. ‚ÄúI am very tired of people telling me that I don‚Äôt have the right to be angry,‚Äù Cason said. ‚ÄúI am very angry right now.‚Äù Even before Scott‚Äôs shooting in April, Cason said he had been part of a group meeting with police and local leaders to try to shore up better relationships. Presidential candidate Jeb Bush has cancelled a planned trip to the state, and the South Carolina legislature has suspended a sitting planned for Thursday.

column4: Mothers of Isis recruits find healing and resolve through support network
column5:
Christianne Boudreau learned her son was dead when a reporter showed up at her front door with a link to a tweet announcing that he had been killed in Syria, fighting for the Islamic State. It had been more than a year since Damian Clairmont, 22, surreptitiously left his home in Canada and made his way to a jihadi training camp in Turkey. Boudreau spent the intervening months searching through militant videos online, scouring through often gruesome footage in the desperate hope of catching a glimpse of her eldest son. Eventually, Damian texted her from Syria, and Boudreau spoke to her son on the phone several times, pleading with him to come home, but she was unable to convince him. Then in January 2014, Isis supporters started sharing a tweet reporting Damian‚Äôs death. The link led to a statement attributed to Boudreau‚Äôs son, in which he rejected his family and ‚Äúworldly life‚Äù in Canada, and dedicated himself to ‚Äúan eternity in Paradise‚Äù. ‚ÄúI sat there, staring at the computer, reading it over and over,‚Äù Boudreau said.
Boudreau was unable to help her son, but she was determined that no other mother should suffer the same experience. She founded a group to help counter extremist propaganda in Canada, and earlier this month, she helped launch Mothers for Life, a network of mothers from seven European and North American countries whose children have gone to fight with jihadi groups. In an open letter, the mothers counseled youngsters contemplating joining the jihadi fight to think twice ‚Äì and pleaded for their children to come home. The group‚Äôs launch comes amid growing concerns that western countries at the forefront of the fight against Isis have failed to draw up effective strategies to stop their own young people from going to fight and die for the militant group. Over the past year, a steady stream of young Europeans and North Americans have made their way to the battlefields of Iraq and Syria. Conservative estimates put the numbers of westerners who have joined militant Islamist groups in the low thousands, with several hundred known to have emanated from Belgium and Denmark, 1,000 from France and ‚Äúat least 150‚Äù from the US. Earlier this week, reports emerged that a 17-year-old boy had become the UK‚Äôs youngest suicide bomber, after detonating an explosives-laden car in Iraq in the name of the Islamic State. In March, 18-year-old Australian Isis fighter Jake Bilardi also died in an Iraqi suicide attack, as did two German twins last month.
Isis has been particularly adept at targeting their propaganda and recruitment efforts at foreigners. But according to Daniel Koehler, a German expert on deradicalization ‚Äì and the co-founder of Mothers for Life ‚Äì families could play a unique role in preventing young people from signing up for violent jihad. The problem for many families is that they are simply unable to spot the warning signs. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt even know what the word ‚Äòradicalization‚Äô was before I found out my son was dead,‚Äù said Karolina Dam, a Danish member of Mothers for Life. Like Boudreau, she heard the news from a stranger on her doorstep ‚Äì this time, a man with ties to Isis recruiters. Dam‚Äôs son Lukas was 18 when he was killed in a US-led coalition air strike in the Syrian border town of Kobani in December. Dam could only confirm reports of his death through social media posts.
Lukas had been diagnosed with Asperger‚Äôs and ADD before converting to Islam, and at first the religion appeared to give him the structure and motivation that he needed. ‚ÄúI saw him struggle his whole life, and he found a religion to give him what I couldn‚Äôt give him,‚Äù Dam said. ‚ÄúThat was the first time I saw my son at ease.‚Äù But, unbeknown to his mother, Lukas soon embraced an extremist vision of Islam, and in the summer of 2014 he made his way to Syria. For Dam ‚Äì who was a single mother ‚Äì the pain of losing one of her two sons was heightened by her feeling that nobody around her could understand what she was going through. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have anyone to talk to,‚Äù she said via Skype from Copenhagen. When she learned of Lukas‚Äôs death, Dam‚Äôs grief was compounded by Danish bureaucracy: without a body, she was unable to obtain a death certificate; without that, she was unable to close his bank account ‚Äì even though she feared other Isis fighters were still using it. ‚ÄúI am fighting to get over this, but I want the [Danish] authorities to do the right thing and stop these bastards from hurting other people,‚Äù Dam said.
As the parents of Muslim converts, Dam and Boudreau may perhaps find it easier to speak openly of their experiences than others in similar situations. The families of western jihadis are often afraid to describe what they are going through to anyone outside their immediate circle, let alone to speak out in public. According to Dam, many parents ‚Äì especially those from communities already under heavy scrutiny by the security services and the media ‚Äì are ashamed or fearful that they could lose their remaining children or even face prosecution. These parents experience a tragic catch-22, said Boudreau. ‚ÄúParents are afraid to come forward, and they‚Äôre afraid their children are going to get arrested,‚Äù Boudreau said. ‚ÄúAs a parent, you have that guilt complex if you turn them in. But if you don‚Äôt turn them in and they don‚Äôt get arrested, then they end up going overseas and dying.‚Äù The relative novelty of the foreign-born jihadi phenomenon has made it difficult for these families to find support. Boudreau‚Äôs biggest fear was that Damian would in turn recruit her younger son, Luke, 11, who desperately missed his elder brother. But she initially found no support from Canada‚Äôs social services and was left to carry out her own research online. That led her to Koehler, an academic and counsellor, who founded the pioneering German Institute on Radicalization and DeRadicalization in Berlin. Six months after Damian‚Äôs death, Boudreau flew to Berlin to meet the mothers of other jihadi fighters. ‚ÄúIt was quite intense emotionally,‚Äù she said. But ‚Äúit felt like we could start some kind of healing process‚Äù. The seed for what would eventually become Mothers for Life was planted at that first meeting. The group aims to help mothers find a stronger voice to counter those intent on radicalizing young westerners. Mothers hold a particularly important role in jihadi ideology, he said, presumably because Islamic theology holds them in such high regard: the prophet Muhammad is thought to have said that ‚ÄúParadise lies at the feet of the mother.‚Äù But jihadi recruiters systematically work to separate children from their families, he said. ‚ÄúThey need to build a wall within families to distance [would-be jihadis] from their mothers,‚Äù Koehler said. ‚ÄúThey know these voices are important.‚Äù Some members of Mothers for Life still have children fighting in Syria and Iraq and hope the group will help their efforts to get their children back home. But there are almost insurmountable practical and legal obstacles to doing so. Home countries often refuse to accept returning jihadis ‚Äì or allow them in only to arrest them. Just a few countries have established deradicalization programs to help reintegrate former fighters or repentent jihadis.
Koehler says that former militants should be given the chance to answer for their actions before the law ‚Äì but also offered psychological support to help them reconnect with their former lives. In almost every country in western Europe there are scores or even hundreds of former militants who have returned home, either because they are injured, traumatized or disillusioned with the brutal reality of life under Isis rule, Koehler said. Most of them have returned illegally and remain off the radar of the security services. That‚Äôs why Koehler argues that deradicalization programs are an essential component of national security policy. ‚ÄúDeradicalization programs like Mothers for Life help the authorities to be more effective, [and] they help communities be more resilient.‚Äù For parents of westerners who have already joined the ranks of Islamic State, and for those who fear their children may yet be recruited, programs like Mothers for Life can offer an ‚Äúemotional safe place‚Äù, said Boudreau. She hopes the group can ensure that no parent will have to suffer alone while their child turns to violent jihad. ‚ÄúIf I had known then what I know now,‚Äù Boudreau said, ‚Äúmy son might still be alive.‚Äù Correction: This story was amended on 19 June 2015 to reflect that Karolina Dam has two sons, not one, and that her son Lukas had ADD, not ADHD, as previously reported.

column4: Hong Kong parliament defies Beijing's insistence and rejects 'democracy' plan
column5: Pro-democracy lawmakers in Hong Kong have defeated attempts to bring ‚Äúfake democracy‚Äù to the former British colony by voting down a controversial Beijing-backed plan that sparked mass demonstrations in 2014. The proposal ‚Äì which China insisted represented true universal suffrage ‚Äì would have seen Hong Kong‚Äôs five million voters granted the right to directly elect their future leaders ‚Äì but only after candidates had been screened by a pro-Beijing committee. The ‚Äúpolitical reform package‚Äù was rejected on Thursday with 28 legislators in Hong Kong‚Äôs parliament voting against it. Eight lawmakers voted for the proposal. There are 70 members in all but more than two dozen pro-government politicians walked out of the session without voting in an apparent attempt to halt proceedings. Pro-democracy lawmakers and activists celebrated the result, even though it means the current system ‚Äì under which Hong Kong‚Äôs chief executive is chosen by a 1,200-member pro-establishment ‚Äúelection committee‚Äù ‚Äì will remain in place. ‚ÄúIt is a victory for those people who refuse to accept fake universal suffrage,‚Äù said Martin Lee, one of Hong Kong‚Äôs most prominent democracy activists. ‚ÄúThis is good news for Hong Kong. Rejecting this fake universal suffrage puts the pressure back on Beijing.‚Äù Beijing lamented the defeat of its package. ‚ÄúSuch a result is a departure from the mainstream public opinion of Hong Kong. It is also not what the central government likes to see,‚Äù a spokesperson for China‚Äôs cabinet-like State Council told the South China Morning Post. An editorial published on the website of the pro-Beijing Global Times attacked Hong Kong‚Äôs pro-democracy legislators. ‚ÄúAll those who voted against the blueprint might be cocky today, but they will face the judgment of history and shoulder the responsibility eventually,‚Äù it said. ‚ÄúWe are concerned that a Pandora box is being opened in Hong Kong and various devils are released to ruin the region‚Äôs future,‚Äù the editorial added. Victoria Hui, a political scientist who runs a blog about Hong Kong‚Äôs umbrella movement protests, said she expected an ‚Äúintensification of resistance‚Äù to Beijing following the proposal‚Äôs defeat. ‚ÄúWhat we are seeing is a very artificial calm. There is a lot boiling under the surface and it is really hard to say what is going to ignite the next bomb. Hong Kong people‚Äôs frustrations could explode again at any time.‚Äù Pro-democracy politicians would now attempt to restart the political reform process and squeeze concessions out of Beijing but the Communist party was unlikely to cave in, Hui added. ‚ÄúIf they had wanted to make compromises they would have done so already.‚Äù Michael Davis, a law professor from the University of Hong Kong, said Beijing had paid the price for its refusal to offer a single concession to those pushing for greater levels of democracy. ‚ÄúWhat they got through this hard line was the whole of civil society protesting and resisting Beijing. It really backfired on them. We would hope that there would be some lessons learned and some acts of contrition going forward. Will that happen? Right now one can‚Äôt be optimistic.‚Äù Hundreds of police had gathered in and around Hong Kong‚Äôs government headquarters and parliament this week amid fears that the highly contentious vote could spark renewed protests or even violence. Tens of thousands of pro-democracy activists spilled out on to the streets in 2014 as part of the student-driven ‚Äúumbrella movement‚Äù demonstrations. For 79 days large swathes of Hong Kong‚Äôs financial heart were transformed into a sea of tents and banners. Police eventually cleared the occupation in December. On Thursday Xinhua, China‚Äôs official news agency, warned that Hong Kong risked ‚Äúbeing torn further apart‚Äù if Beijing‚Äôs proposal was defeated. The Global Times, a nationalist tabloid, said ‚Äúreal chaos‚Äù could ensue. Speaking shortly before the vote around noon on Thursday, Carrie Lam, Hong Kong‚Äôs number two official, lashed out at pro-democracy politicians for opposing the government‚Äôs package. ‚ÄúI am sad and I am disappointed. I do not know how democratic development can be taken forward,‚Äù she said. Fanny Law, a pro-Beijing politician who is close to CY Leung, Hong Kong‚Äôs current chief executive, described the defeat as ‚Äúheart-wrenching‚Äù. ‚ÄúBut I think there was some misjudgment along the way and we really must sit down and mend the fences after the whole saga is over,‚Äù she told RTHK, Hong Kong‚Äôs public broadcaster. ‚ÄúWe must find a way forward and we must address some of the very deep-rooted problems in our society.‚Äù Martin Lee, the founding chairman of Hong Kong‚Äôs Democratic party, said ‚Äúa major change of policy‚Äù was now needed in the former colony. ‚ÄúIf you look at Hong Kong today all the important decisions are not made here but in Beijing or locally through the Beijing agents. The whole thing has gone wrong,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis is a good way to persuade [Chinese President Xi Jinping] that he shouldn‚Äôt continue with this wrong policy of dismissing the democrats as troublemakers or even as traitors.‚Äù Since becoming Communist party chief in 2012 Xi had taken a hardline stance towards government critics, journalists, academics and bloggers, noted Davis, the law professor. To take a similarly tough stance on Hong Kong in the wake of Thursday‚Äôs defeat would be a mistake, Davis said. ‚ÄúOne would hope they‚Äôd cool it and not take the view to punish Hong Kong,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think they have a desire to kill Hong Kong and being aggressive in their posture towards Hong Kong or interpreting this as indicating a need for them to interfere more rather than less would be a bad judgment on their part.‚Äù Compromise was now needed from Hong Kong‚Äôs leaders. ‚ÄúThe government‚Äôs credibility is really low ‚Äì if all they do after this vote is go back to their offices and do nothing ‚Ä¶ then I think the problems of crisis and conflict in Hong Kong will persist.‚Äù

column4: Charleston shooting: state senator Clementa Pinckney among victims
column5:
Clementa Pinckney, a high-flying Democrat state senator who campaigned for police to wear body cameras, was one of those killed in the mass shooting at a historic black church in Charleston, South Carolina, on Wednesday. The 41-year-old was a pastor of the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal church where a gunman, believed to be white, opened fire in what officials are treating as a hate crime. Pinckney won election to the South Carolina senate in 2000 at the age of 27, becoming the youngest African American to do so. He had previously been elected to the state‚Äôs House of Representatives at 23. Reports said he met Hillary Clinton earlier on Wednesday at a fundraising event in Charleston.
In April Pinckney helped lead a prayer vigil for Walter Scott, a black South Carolina man who was shot dead by a police officer as he tried to run away. The veteran civil rights campaigner Al Sharpton, who was also involved in the vigil, tweeted on Wednesday night:
Pinckney campaigned for legislation to require police officers to wear body cameras while working. He said: ‚ÄúBody cameras help to record what happens. It may not be the golden ticket, the golden egg, the end-all-fix-all, but it helps to paint a picture of what happens during a police stop.‚Äù The Rev Joseph Darby, the presiding elder at Beaufort AME Church, described Pinckney as ‚Äúan advocate for the people‚Äù. He told MSNBC: ‚ÄúHe was a very caring and competent pastor, and he was a very brave man. Brave men sometimes die difficult deaths.‚Äù Pastor Thomas Dixon, who has been working with a local chapter of the Black Lives Matter movement, had met Pinckney in the wake of the April death of Walter Scott, the unarmed black man whose shooting by a white North Charleston police officer was caught on video. He said Pinckney was highly respected in the community as both a political and religious leader. In the wake of the latest shooting, Dixon said he was ‚Äúdisheartened but not surprised‚Äù. The Emanuel church website said Pinckney began preaching at 13 and was first appointed as a pastor at 18. He had a degree in business administration, and master‚Äôs degrees in public administration and divinity.
His profile on the church website included a quote from a Washington Post columnist, David Broder, who said Pinckney was a ‚Äúpolitical spirit lifter for surprisingly not becoming cynical about politics‚Äù. Pinckney is survived by his wife, Jennifer, and two children, Eliana and Malana.

column4: Denmark election could seal centre-left comeback or boost David Cameron
column5:
Denmark goes to the polls on Thursday in an election that will either seal a famous comeback for the incumbent Social Democratic prime minister, Helle Thorning-Schmidt, or give a boost to the British prime minister, David Cameron, in his quest for EU renegotiations. Thorning-Schmidt‚Äôs governing centre-left coalition, which campaigned on a resurgent economy, has consistently trailed in opinion polls since the last election in 2011, but in the past few weeks has pulled level with the blue bloc led by the Venstre (Liberal) party.
In what many saw as a concession to the Eurosceptic Danish People‚Äôs party (DPP), the four parties of the rightwing bloc ‚Äì Venstre, DPP, Conservatives and Liberal Alliance ‚Äì last week announced their joint support for Cameron‚Äôs bid to renegotiate the terms of Britain‚Äôs membership of the EU, in particular with regard to welfare benefits for EU migrants. ‚ÄúWe will stand behind Great Britain and like-minded nations‚Äô efforts to ensure that the EU doesn‚Äôt turn into a social union,‚Äù said the statement, titled Danish Welfare in Europe. ‚ÄúWe want an EU where people can go wherever workers are needed, but we don‚Äôt want an EU where people go wherever the social benefits are good,‚Äù the Venstre leader, Lars L√∏kke Rasmussen, said last week. Both Thorning-Schmidt and Rasmussen have promised to further tighten Denmark‚Äôs controls on immigration and access to welfare benefits, but the DPP wants to go further and reinstate border controls with Germany and Sweden. The DPP, which won the biggest share of the vote in last year‚Äôs European elections, looks set to increase its number of MPs in Denmark‚Äôs 179-seat parliament, the Folketinget, and close in on its coalition partner Venstre. With 90 seats needed for either coalition bloc to govern, the election result could come down to the four members elected from Greenland and the Faroe Islands. A new party, the environmentalist Alternative party, has entered the mix this year, and is expected to support Thorning-Schmidt‚Äôs bloc.
The two leaders vying for the premiership clashed in a series of tense TV debates during an election campaign that has been dominated by public spending, welfare and an increasingly harsh line on immigration. While Thorning-Schmidt‚Äôs government has been accused of breaking previous election promises, Rasmussen has been dogged by a series of expenses scandals that have hampered his personal credibility. He was accused last year of excessive spending on clothes and first-class plane tickets and, while the party defended him, was widely expected to step down. On Tuesday, more than 1 million Danish households received a letter from Thorning-Schmidt urging them to ‚Äúsay no‚Äù to Rasmussen and the DPP. ‚ÄúThe Liberals‚Äô key issue is zero growth [in the public sector],‚Äù read the letter. ‚ÄúRather than spending more money on health and care for our elderly, they want to give tax breaks. The Danish People‚Äôs party talks a lot about welfare. But if you vote DPP then you get Lars L√∏kke Rasmussen as prime minister.‚Äù Rasmussen said the letter was ‚Äúa democratic low point‚Äù in a Social Democratic campaign that had been focused solely on him and his party. In an add published in 15 newspapers, the Liberal party hit back: ‚ÄúWe say yes to welfare and using taxpaying citizens‚Äô money with care. We say no to false scaremongering.‚Äù

column4: Pope's encyclical on the environment: key questions answered
column5:
Q. Encyclicals. Are they the top level of papal declarations? A. Second from top. An apostolic constitution is the highest form of papal decree. Only one has been issued so far this century ‚Äì by Pope Benedict to give Anglicans a way of joining the Catholic church without having to forgo their liturgy and so on. Q. So what is an encyclical? A. Originally, it was a circular letter; the term comes from the Greek word for a circle. The earliest papal encyclicals were sent by the pope of the day to members of the Catholic hierarchy, and sometimes only to those in a particular country. So they could be about quite mundane issues of ecclesiastical organisation.
Q. When did encyclicals come into fashion? A. The man who first seems to have gone big on them was the genial and unpretentious Benedict XIV, who was pope in the mid-18th century. He wrote his first encyclical ‚Äì Ubi Primum, which was about the duties of bishops ‚Äì four months after being elected and issued the last of 44 in the year before he died in 1758. The all-time encyclical writing champion, though, was Leo XIII who sat on the throne of St Peter from 1878 to 1903. He penned more than 80, including one of the most influential, Rerum Novarum, published in 1891. Q. Why was it considered so important? A. It was the papacy‚Äôs ‚Äì long overdue ‚Äì response to a changed world of industrial conflict and class warfare. Rerum Novarum laid the foundations of Catholic social teaching, condemning both Marxism and unfettered capitalism.
Q. Other landmark encyclicals? A. Probably the one that has had the greatest impact on humanity is Humanae Vitae, the encyclical that reaffirmed the Catholic church‚Äôs ban on artificial birth control back in 1968. But Humanae Vitae is also probably the papal diktat that has been most widely ignored by Catholics themselves, notably in Italy, which nowadays has one of the world‚Äôs lowest birth rates. Q. Do encyclicals have to have Latin titles? A. No, though most do. There have been French and Italian titles. And one of the most famous encyclicals was written entirely in German. Q. Why? A. Mit brennender Sorge ‚Äì With Burning Anxiety ‚Äì was Pope Pius XI‚Äôs denunciation of the ideas of the Third Reich. It was smuggled into Germany and read out from the pulpits of Catholic churches on Palm Sunday 1937. Q. But wasn‚Äôt the pope a bit soft on the Nazis?
A. That‚Äôs the accusation levelled against Pius XI‚Äôs successor, Pius XII. Q. Are encyclicals really written by popes? A. Not these days. Leo XIII was said to have written his. But nowadays they are a team effort. In the case of Francis‚Äôs encyclical on the environment, much of the work was delegated to the Pontifical Council for Justice and Peace, the Vatican department that most closely resembles an overseas aid and development ministry in a secular government. Nevertheless, it is the pope who does the final editing.
Q. After which the encyclical goes to be translated ‚Ä¶ A. Yes, and that can be a story in itself. Because of the importance attached to the words used by a pope, it is crucial that what he says in each language should be understood in the same way. Publication of Pope Benedict‚Äôs third encyclical, Caritas in Veritate, was held up for a week because of the difficulties of reconciling certain passages. Q. Understandable if what the pope says is held to be infallible. No? A. No. Pronouncements held to be infallible are very rare and limited to matters of faith and doctrine. The last papal declaration indisputably regarded as falling into this category was in 1950. Whatever Pope Francis has to say about climate change or fossil fuels will carry great moral weight. But neither he nor the Vatican would claim his views on the environment are infallible.

column4: Ramadan in St Petersburg ‚Äì the city where the sun doesn't set
column5:
When Ramadan starts on Thursday, the faithful in St Petersburg and elsewhere in northern Russia will face an obstacle that the prophet surely didn‚Äôt envision: in June, the sun never truly sets.
These are the celebrated ‚Äúwhite nights‚Äù, the period lasting from roughly late May to early July when a few hours of twilight is the closest it gets to true night. Although they are observed across the far north, white nights have the strongest association with St Petersburg, the northernmost city with a population of more than 1 million and Russia‚Äôs unofficial cultural capital. For the city‚Äôs Muslim population, it‚Äôs an exacting time. The Qur‚Äôan makes exceptions to the Ramadan fast for people suffering from illness, travellers and women who are menstruating or pregnant. But it does not give explicit instructions on observing the fast in the far north. According to some St Petersburg Muslim authorities, the long-lasting daylight in the city at this time of year is simply an extra challenge to their faith. ‚ÄúIn St Petersburg, Muslims see this as a test. In the time that is now starting they will observe the fast,‚Äù said an employee of the St Petersburg and Northwest Regional Muslim Spiritual Centre, who declined to give his name. ‚ÄúThose Muslims who are observing the fast will wait 21-22 hours to break the fast, they will eat for only three hours.‚Äù
When asked about the difficulty of keeping to this strict schedule, he said it was no burden for the faithful. ‚ÄúIslam is a way of life,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúFor us, fasting is the same as getting up in the morning and brushing your teeth.‚Äù Yelizaveta Izmailova, an administrator at a local school who is originally from the largely Muslim region of Ingushetia, said her parents, brother, sister and husband all observed the Ramadan fast with her, following a schedule handed out each week at the central mosque. ‚ÄúThis month, the time for breaking the fast is really late. We don‚Äôt eat or drink from the morning prayer, at about two in the morning, until the sun goes down at around 10pm,‚Äù Izmailova said, explaining that twilight typically arrived as late as 10.30pm in June. ‚ÄúOf course, this is a heavy burden for the human body, but every Muslim makes this choice consciously.‚Äù Although there are no exact figures on how many Muslims live in St Petersburg, last year‚Äôs Eid al-Fitr festivities, which mark the end of Ramadan fasting, drew 42,000 worshippers to the city‚Äôs two main mosques, according to the interior ministry. As often happens on major holidays, most could not fit inside and had to take part from the street. Some Muslim scholars have written that residents of northern regions can forgo the fasting ritual, which is meant as a way to strengthen the will and rule over desires. ‚ÄúAccording to the instructions of the Holy Qur‚Äôan, fasting in regions [near the poles] is never obligatory, for it is established as such only for a set amount of days, that is, in those places where night and day are comparable in length,‚Äù Russian Tatar scholar Musa Bigiev wrote in a text on fasting. Other religious literature suggests that Muslims living in the far north can observe the Ramadan fast according to the time of sunrise and sunset in Mecca or the nearest Muslim city.
In many cases, those performing hard manual labour don‚Äôt fast for safety reasons. Many of the Muslims in St Petersburg are migrants from former Soviet republics in central Asia and the Caucasus working in construction and other low-wage industries. The labour ministry approved a quota of 164,000 migrant workers in St Petersburg in 2014, but the actual number is likely to be much higher. Shakir, a metal-worker originally from Tajikistan, said generally only the elderly and those without work followed the fast in St Petersburg. ‚ÄúI have a hard job, I can‚Äôt observe it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe day is long, and you can‚Äôt drink water or eat before the sunset. For that reason not everyone observes it ‚Ä¶ There aren‚Äôt any white nights where [most] Muslims live.‚Äù

column4: Former PNG police chief faces jail for failing to arrest country's prime minister
column5: The former police commissioner of Papua New Guinea is facing five years in jail after being convicted of failing to act on an arrest warrant for the country‚Äôs prime minister. A court has been told Geoffrey Vaki wilfully disobeyed when he refused to arrest the prime minister, Peter O‚ÄôNeill, in June last year after a PNG anti-corruption taskforce, Sweep, linked him to allegedly fraudulent multimillion-dollar payments by the government to a Port Moresby law firm. O‚ÄôNeill has long denied the accusation. After the 2014 arrest warrant was issued, O‚ÄôNeill refused to present himself for questioning then sacked numerous law enforcement and government officials, including the attorney general and police commissioner, Tom Kalunga, who had signed off on the warrant. In a move described by police unions at the time as highly suspicious, Kalunga was replaced with Geoffrey Vaki, who then delayed acting on the warrant, saying the case needed further investigation. Within days Vaki was arrested by two senior police officers for attempting to pervert the course of justice after it emerged he and the new attorney general had appointed a new police lawyer and instructed him to agree to O‚ÄôNeill‚Äôs request for a stay of the warrant. He later held a press conference telling the media he wanted to wait until the investigation was ‚Äúwater tight‚Äù and any arrest would be ‚Äúa long way down the road‚Äù, the ABC reported. O‚ÄôNeill was never arrested and won an injunction while he challenged the warrant in a separate court case. On Wednesday Vaki was convicted of contempt for not acting on the warrant. In his ruling, the chief justice, Sir Salamo Injia, said Vaki‚Äôs conduct ‚Äúpresented a real risk of interference with the due administration of justice or interfered with the due administration of justice‚Äù. Injia said he was satisfied Vaki‚Äôs disobedience ‚Äúbrought public respect for the justice system into question and disrepute and undermined the rule of law‚Äù. Vaki was sacked from the police commissioner role in May after reports of police brutality and delays in investigating a January police shooting. While the warrant of arrest for O‚ÄôNeill remains subject to the injunction, Wednesday‚Äôs ruling means it is still ‚Äúvalid for all intents and purposes‚Äù, according to the head of the Sweep taskforce, Sam Koim. ‚ÄúThe case has been meticulously analysed and addressed ‚Ä¶ and the court ruled that the warrant of arrest was a court order and that court order is not defective,‚Äù he told Guardian Australia. In July last year the national court permanently stayed an order by the PNG parliament to disband Sweep, but the anti-corruption body ‚Äì which was launched by O‚ÄôNeill ‚Äì was defunded instead. ‚Äú[The taskforce] exists by operational court order, it exists legally,‚Äù Koim said. ‚ÄúBut for operational effectiveness we need funding and that funding has not been forthcoming. ‚ÄúIt is a political decision not to fund us but it‚Äôs also a decision that is personal in nature. It is not a decision isolated from the arrest warrant we recommended against the prime minister. It‚Äôs a position triggered by the arrest warrant.‚Äù Vaki faces sentencing next Thursday and Koim said the prosecutors and the taskforce were pushing for a jail term of five years, but the decision was for the court. O‚ÄôNeill‚Äôs office has been contacted for comment.

column4: Computer visa glitch leaves migrant workers stranded at US-Mexico border
column5:
A US government computer glitch has left hundreds of migrant farm workers stranded at the Mexican border, as their would-be employers now search for replacements to harvest their summer crops and combat further economic losses on both sides of the border. Farms across the US rely on the H-2A visa program to hire temporary workers for each harvesting season. But the computer failure has prevented the government from issuing these visas to the predominantly Mexican workforce since last Wednesday. ‚ÄúThe longer it goes on, the more it is going to back up and cascade and be a bigger problem for more and more people,‚Äù said Kerry Scott, program manager at Mas Labor, a Virginia-based agency that acts as a middleman between would-be workers in Mexico and farms in the US. On Tuesday, the agency had 357 Mexican workers trapped at various points along the border. Scott said that the level of damage it could cause for harvesting varied ‚Äúfarm by farm‚Äù ‚Äì as some crops ripen more quickly, depending on the time of year. ‚ÄúThis process is always slow and cumbersome, and by the time the workers are arriving, on a normal basis, they are usually already late or about to be late so this just exacerbates the problem,‚Äù said Scott. The majority of seasonal workers come from poor rural villages in states as far flung as Chiapas, Yucat√°n and Guerrero, which can mean bus journeys of up to two days just to reach the border. Some US employers reimburse basic transport and accommodation costs, others only pay for the work visa. None will cover the unforeseen costs resulting from the visa crisis. While US farmers are concerned about the rotting orchards and the potential for prices to rise as a result, Mexicans are losing money as they won‚Äôt be paid for the days missed stuck at the border waiting for the visa system to be repaired. Temporary legal workers are paid an hourly rate, set by the Department of Agriculture, which currently varies from $10 in Alabama to just over $13 an hour in South Dakota. Farm workers typically toil 10 hours a day during the harvest, earning at least $100 a day ‚Äì 10 times what many can earn in Mexico. Most will wire home the vast majority of their salaries to support their families. Zazyl Moreira runs an agency based in Monterrey, Mexico‚Äôs third-largest city in the border state of Nuevo Le√≥n, which helps seasonal workers sort out their temporary visas. On Tuesday, a group of 13 men from Michoac√°n contracted for six months to harvest vegetables by one farm in Indiana arrived at the agency after a 16-hour journey. When they arrived at the consulate in Monterrey for the scheduled interview, they discovered that the office was closed, with no one available to speak to them. These men had given up their farm jobs at home to travel to Indiana, where they‚Äôd been contracted for six months for the third year in a row. Francisco Javier S√°nchez, 26, told the Guardian: ‚ÄúWe cannot afford to stay in Monterrey, so we‚Äôre probably going to have to return home as it‚Äôs too dangerous to cross the border with a coyote. No one will help us pay for this wasted journey. I have a wife and seven-year-old daughter at home, I need to start working.‚Äù
The dangerous, expensive wait for a visa The visa glitch is affecting all seasonal workers, not just farm hands. Activists believe this glitch is showcasing the need for comprehensive immigration reform. Rosalinda Guillen, executive director of Community to Community Development, said that there are enough workers in the US that farmers should not have to rely on the H-2A program. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been extremely easy for the agriculture industry to bring in guest workers to do the work that US-based farmworkers can do,‚Äù she said. She said that the H-2A program leaves immigrant workers at the mercy of the farmers who sponsor them to come over. ‚ÄúWorker rights and civil rights are very difficult to enforce because they are basically tied to the employer and they can be easily deported,‚Äù she said. Because the visa system is down, Guillen said she hopes farmers will turn to skilled workers who are already in the US, but are passed over because they demand higher wages and better protections. ‚ÄúFor us, it means some of the local domestic workers may actually get jobs ‚Äì at least that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm hoping,‚Äù she said. Adrienne DerVartanian, director of immigration and labor tights at Farmworker Justice, echoed Guillen‚Äôs concerns that the H-2A program only offers modest worker protections to a vulnerable workforce. ‚ÄúIronically, there wouldn‚Äôt be a problem here if Congress passed comprehensive immigration reform,‚Äù she said. Her group believes such reforms would offer protections for farmers and workers who are suffering from the delay. ‚ÄúThe debt that H-2A workers carry to the United States ‚Äì from illegal recruitment fees and travel costs ‚Äì increases their desperation to work,‚Äù DerVartanian said. ‚ÄúBecause of their dependence on their employer for their continued ability to work in the United States, it also increases their vulnerability in the workplace.‚Äù Jos√© Mario Salda√±a, 25, also from Michoac√°n, was due to start a six-month contract with a landscape gardening company in Maryland last week. He travelled 12 hours from his home to Monterrey last Wednesday. He completed the biometric test but his visa interview was cancelled. He returned back home two days later, having spent $200 on travel, accommodation and food. Salda√±a told the Guardian from his home in Michoac√°n: ‚ÄúHere, I can only find two or three days‚Äô farm work a week which pays $10 a day, I cannot support my family on that, but in Maryland the company is going to pay me $10 an hour. I‚Äôve been told to wait here until they call me with a new appointment, I hope it is soon, I have four children to support, so I need to get to Maryland as soon as possible.‚Äù Moreira said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve just been told by the consulate that interviews will not be rescheduled until at least 25 June, so lots of workers will lose almost a month‚Äôs work in the US. This means their kids will have to go without tennis shoes or they won‚Äôt be able to afford a birthday party, it‚Äôs a big deal, they really need these jobs.‚Äù Professor Rodolfo Casillas, a migration specialist at the Latin American Faculty of Social Sciences (Flacso) in Mexico City, said that the current crisis reveals a much wider conflict within US migration policies. ‚ÄúThe technical problem will be resolved in a few weeks, but the immediate aftermath for the US agricultural economy, the search by agricultural companies to find enough labor illegally and the need for workers to work, will without doubt encourage the smuggling of migrants, and increase the costs and the risks of crossing the border undocumented,‚Äù Casillas said. ‚ÄúAll this means more tension, more conflict and more profits for those operating outside of the migration scheme.‚Äù

column4: Luxembourg avoids tax haven blacklist as Brussels announces reform plans
column5: A blacklist of the world‚Äôs 30 worst-offending tax havens, published on Wednesday by the European commission, includes the tiny Polynesian island of Niue, where 1,400 people live in semi-subsistence ‚Äî but does not include Luxembourg, the EU‚Äôs wealthy tax avoidance hub. Niue, situated east of Tonga in the Pacific Ocean, has appeared on tax haven lists before. But the island, which has an economic output estimated at just $10m (¬£6.3m) a year, has rarely been cast as a major threat to the tax receipts of Europe‚Äôs largest economies. The list also includes various well-known havens ‚Äî among them the Cayman Islands, British Virgin Islands and Guernsey ‚Äî but other jurisdictions that are commonly labelled as offshore tax avoidance hubs were notably missing. Jersey and Switzerland, for example, were not named. Within Europe, Monaco, Lichtenstein and Andorra made it onto the blacklist. The commission explained, however, that the list of 30 ‚Äúnon-cooperative jurisdictions‚Äù was designed only to assess non-EU members. As a result, the new register does not include countries such as the Netherlands, Ireland, or Luxembourg ‚Äî all of which are under investigation by the European competition authorities, suspected of offering ‚Äúsweetheart‚Äù tax deals to multinationals. The industrial scale on which Luxembourg ‚Äî one of the richest per capita countries in the world ‚Äî was facilitating the tax avoidance ploys of large corporations was laid bare last year in the LuxLeaks scandal. Many years earlier, Luxembourg‚Äôs aggressive tax policy had been shaped by the Jean-Claude Juncker. Juncker is now president of the European commission, having served as prime minister of the Grand Duchy for 18 years. In March, the commission responded to the LuxLeaks scandal by insisting EU tax authorities share with one another the tax rulings they privately grant to multinationals. Six of the 30 tax havens named by the commission were British overseas territories ‚Äî Anguilla, Bermuda, British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Montserrat, and the Turks and Caicos Islands ‚Äî but only one crown dependency, Guernsey, made the list. Twenty-one were small island economies, mostly in the Caribbean Sea, Pacific Ocean or Indian Ocean. Each country on the blacklist had been suggested by at least 10 EU member states as problematic. The UK did not make any suggestions, nor did Germany. Brussels hopes that the list will help member states put pressure on commonly recognised pariah jurisdictions. The register was announced alongside more substantive plans for reforming the way in which multinationals are taxed across the EU, a framework proposal known as the common consolidated corporate tax base, or CCCTB. Pierre Moscovici, European commissioner with responsibility for tax, said: ‚ÄúOur current approach to corporate taxation no longer fits today‚Äôs reality. We are using outdated tools and unilateral measures to respond to the challenges of a digitalised, globalised economy.‚Äù The CCCTB measure will look to harmonise corporate income tax rules among member states in a further effort to combat aggressive tax avoidance. As expected, Moscovici conceded that ‚Äî in the first instance at least ‚Äî the controversial ‚Äúconsolidated‚Äù element of the tax reforms would have to be delayed. His more politically palatable compromise plan seeks to find common ground for the tax treatment of multinationals, making it harder for corporations to build complex structures and transactions between member states that artificially depress tax liabilities. Tax campaigners, however, were quick to raise concerns that the compromised proposals, rather than clamping down on corporate tax avoidance, risked opening up a major new front for tax planners to exploit. In particular, they noted that, in its watered down form, the CCCTB proposal permitted multinationals to offset losses in one EU jurisdiction against profits in another ‚Äî a tax break that is currently unavailable. John Christensen, director of the Tax Justice Network, said: ‚ÄúThe European commission is offering multinational corporations the best of both worlds, and the public will be the losers: the commission proposes to allow cross-border offset of losses without preventing intra-group profit shifting. This widens the possibilities for tax avoidance.‚Äù The commission is understood to be alive to campaigners‚Äô concerns and remains confident of warding against such avoidance strategies by ensuring any directive is tightly drafted. Moscovici conceded that the compromise proposal was not ideal, but had been necessary due to fierce opposition from some member states to the full, consolidated version of CCCTB. Asked if he felt there was sufficient political will among all member states ‚Äî including those such as Ireland, Luxembourg, Belgium and the Netherlands, which are associated with more controversial tax treatments ‚Äî for substantive measures to tackle corporate tax avoidance, Moscovici pointed to parallel crackdowns and national level and at the level of the G20. ‚ÄúI am tempted to quote Bob Dylan,‚Äù he said. ‚Äú‚ÄòThe times they are a-changin‚Äô‚Äô‚Äù.

column4: Greece says bailout deal is up to troika amid speculation over exit from EU
column5:
Greece has put the onus on its creditors to prevent it being forced out of the single currency, warning that an economic collapse on a par with the Great Depression of the 1930s had left it broke and unable to pay its debts. Athens announced on Wednesday that it had run out of money, and would not be able to pay ‚Ç¨1.6bn (¬£1.15bn) owed to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) at the end of this month, on the eve of a meeting of eurozone finance ministers. The meeting is seen as the last realistic chance of striking a deal before Greece‚Äôs current bailout runs out in 12 days‚Äô time. The warning came as the governor of the Greek central bank said that Greece was on the brink of an ‚Äúuncontrollable crisis‚Äù and warned that leaving the eurozone would also mean ‚Äúexit ‚Ä¶ most likely from the European Union‚Äù. But the chances of a breakthrough on Thursday‚Äôs talks, in an increasingly hostile negotiating environment, were seen as remote. Greece‚Äôs Eurogroup partners have said it would be up to Greece to offer concessions at the meeting, but they think it unlikely that Athens will cross any of its ‚Äúred lines‚Äù despite its desperate financial plight. ‚ÄúThings will not be so lengthy,‚Äù said one official in Brussels. ‚ÄúThe ball, ministers will conclude, is very firmly in the Greek camp. I honestly believe this will be pretty short.‚Äù Greek shares fell sharply for a fourth successive day as the UK government said it was making contingency arrangements to minimise the impact on the economy from a default, which the head of the European parliament said would result in Greece having to leave the European Union, not just the single currency.
Euclid Tsakalotos, the chief Greek negotiator in the talks, ruled out any further cuts to pensions and increased the pressure on the IMF, the European commission and the European Central Bank (ECB) ‚Äì the so-called troika of lenders ‚Äì to soften their approach to a country that has seen its economy shrink by a quarter in five years. Earlier this month, Greece said it would bundle up three payments due to the IMF in June and pay them at the end of the month. But Tsakalotos admitted: ‚ÄúAt the moment we haven‚Äôt got the money.‚Äù The troika has been withholding the last tranche of money from Greece‚Äôs second bailout ‚Äì ‚Ç¨7.2bn ‚Äì until Athens agrees to changes to its economy, but they have deemed unacceptable and counter-productive by the Syriza-led government headed by the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras. Tsakalotos, in an interview with Reuters, said that without help Greece could not pay the ‚Ç¨1.6bn to the IMF: ‚ÄúThere is no financing. We haven‚Äôt got access to the markets, we haven‚Äôt got money that hasn‚Äôt been paid since the summer of 2014, so obviously we won‚Äôt be able to pay that.‚Äù He suggested that Athens could be offered debt relief if the European bailout fund ‚Äì known as the European Stability Mechanism ‚Äì took over Greek bonds held by the ECB. Tsakalotos said that option would not increase debt for Greece or its partners. Asked how confident he was that a deal could be done, he added: ‚ÄúI think that question is mostly for [our] European partners now.‚Äù Martin Schulz, president of the European parliament, told the Guardian in an interview that there was no legal avenue for expelling a country from the eurozone and that dropping out of the 19-country eurozone would mean no longer being in the 28-country European Union. The Lisbon treaty, he said, stipulated that ‚Äúa member of the European Union is vowed to the euro. All the countries have to introduce, sooner or later, the euro and once you are a member of the eurozone there is nothing legally foreseen to leave the eurozone and to stay in the European Union.‚Äù Schulz is on the centre-left and was the first senior EU politician to visit Athens after Tsipras won the election in January. He accused the Greek leader of misrepresenting his sole allies in Brussels, such as Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European commission, who has been trying to mediate in the crisis. ‚ÄúJuncker made far-reaching proposals. Tsipras was not fair in what he said.‚Äù He accused the Greek leader of putting ideology before pragmatism but insisted the Greeks had to meet the terms of the bailout package that expires in a fortnight. Schulz‚Äôs comments about a Greek exit from the EU were echoed by the country‚Äôs central bank governor, Yannis Stournaras. In remarks that infuriated Tsipras, Stournaras, who was appointed by the former centre-right administration, said: ‚ÄúFailure to reach an agreement would ‚Ä¶ mark the beginning of a painful course that would lead initially to a Greek default and ultimately to the country‚Äôs exit from the euro area and ‚Äì most likely ‚Äì from the European Union.‚Äù Whitehall contingency planning meetings have focused on the immediate impact of capital controls in Greece ‚Äì limits on bank withdrawals ‚Äì that could be introduced to avoid a bank run if Greece appears to be moving towards a default on its debts. There is a particular focus on the tens of thousands of British holidaymakers who travel to Greece during the summer.

column4: 'This isn't human': migrants in limbo on Italian-French border
column5:
The beaches of southern France and Italy are dotted with sun-bathing tourists this week, and for a moment Mostafa Ali talks like he‚Äôs one of them. ‚ÄúDo you like my kitchen?‚Äù asks the 20-year-old Sudanese refugee as he shows a passerby around his new seaside home on Italy‚Äôs western-most beachfront. ‚ÄúDo you like my bedroom?‚Äù It‚Äôs a cruel joke, made by Ali at his own expense: his holiday-home is in fact a khaki tarpaulin, his bedroom a slab of rock shared with two other refugees. On the opposite side of the bay, many of the beachcombers would have arrived on cheap flights. But Ali arrived in the hold of a packed fishing boat, one of more than 100,000 migrants to be smuggled across the Mediterranean so far this year. From time to time, he and his friends lower themselves into the sea again, but not to swim; they just want to wash. Around 100 migrants have slept on this rocky strip for the last five days, and the scene has quickly become an emblem of Europe‚Äôs worsening migration crisis. The location helps explain why: the beach lies immediately east of the border with France so this is where the French police dump the migrants they catch trying to enter their country by train. ‚ÄúWe try everything ‚Äì hiding under the seats, in the toilets,‚Äù says Ali, who learnt colourful, colloquial English by watching films such as the Italian Job and Ocean‚Äôs Twelve. ‚ÄúThe only thing I didn‚Äôt try was sitting next to the driver.‚Äù
Ali has been dumped here countless times, trapped in an Escherian loop of aborted train journeys and subsequent arrests. After arriving in Italy in late May, he wanted to move quickly through France to Germany and then Sweden. But every time he reached Menton, the first station inside France, he was caught and taken here instead. One day he was caught four times, walking back each time to Ventimiglia, the last Italian station before the border, and trying again. It was an exhausting series of back-to-back hikes that took him almost a day in total. ‚ÄúI already survived the dangerous desert, the war in Libya, the sea,‚Äù Ali says, alluding to the journey from his war-torn village in Sudan to the shores of Europe. ‚ÄúWalking for 20 hours on foot is nothing. But now I‚Äôm out of money and that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm still here.‚Äù But there is more than refugees‚Äô individual hopes being dashed on the rocks in Ventimiglia. For some, the scene is a symptom of the failure of the European dream. The reason this makeshift campsite has sprouted in recent days is, the argument goes, because Italy and France have stopped acting like members of the same European Union.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a test of the values of the EU, of bigger countries helping smaller countries,‚Äù says Claude Moraes, a British MEP who has long focused on migration. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very deep test of what the EU means.‚Äù To understand why is to delve into a Europe-wide debate about where migrants should live after they land on Italian and Greek shores. According to regulations, migrants arriving in Italy and Greece are supposed to stay there. But neither country wants to become home to thousands of newcomers it can‚Äôt afford to look after, and who themselves want to move on. So their governments have asked wealthier European countries to take responsibility for 40,000 of the migrants currently in Italy and Greece. So far most other EU states won‚Äôt agree to the plan, and as a result Italy turns a blind eye to migrants leaving for France. In some cases, officials even drive them closer to Italy‚Äôs northern borders. It‚Äôs a situation that infuriates the French government, which faces a strong far-right movement, and doesn‚Äôt want the problem either. So France increased border patrols last week, arresting many more migrants, and leading to the growing camp on the beach in Ventimiglia. On Tuesday, Italian police dispersed 50 of them, forcing the remainder further on to the beachfront. But it is France‚Äôs actions that have caused most anger. ‚ÄúJ‚Äôai honte (I am ashamed),‚Äù reads a sign dangling from the neck of Georges Faye. A retired French diplomat who says he was a cultural attach√© to several countries in Africa, Faye has come to the roadside next to the beach to show solidarity with the migrants.
‚ÄúI am ashamed to be French,‚Äù Faye elaborates, a cigarillo hanging from his mouth, and a wiry goatee stretching around it. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt human. All these people are from places like Eritrea and Darfur. Eritrea is a jail, and we all know what happened in Darfur.‚Äù Faye gestures at the beach. ‚ÄúThese people should be given political asylum. We are 740 million in Europe, and even if we let in 200,000 ‚Äì it‚Äôs nothing.‚Äù

column4: Britain to send intelligence officers to Sicily to 'disrupt' human traffickers
column5: David Cameron has offered to deploy an extra six British officers from the National Crime Agency to a special Europol intelligence cell in Sicily to ‚Äúdisrupt the trafficking and smuggling gangs‚Äù, Downing Street has announced. In an attempt to deflect criticism that Britain is refusing to take its fair share of refugees rescued from flimsy boats in the Mediterranean, the prime minister made the offer of the extra agents to his Italian counterpart, Matteo Renzi. The two prime ministers agreed over lunch in Milan that Europol needs to redouble its efforts to establish the intelligence cell in Sicily, which was given the green light at an emergency summit in April after the loss of as many as 950 lives in the Mediterranean boat tragedy. Cameron‚Äôs offer of the extra officers came as George Osborne confirmed that HMS Bulwark, which has rescued more than 2,900 migrants trying to cross the Mediterranean over the past six weeks, is to be withdrawn from the role. The chancellor insisted Britain will continue to play ‚Äúour full part‚Äù in search-and-rescue operations in the Mediterranean, but what exactly will replace the 19,000-tonne warship, which is capable of carrying two helicopters, is unclear. Defence sources confirmed HMS Bulwark‚Äôs temporary deployment was only for an initial 60 days, which will expire in three weeks. Downing Street said there was no definitive date yet for the withdrawal of the former Royal Navy flagship. The Ministry of Defence has said it is ‚Äúplanning for a seamless transition of assets‚Äù. In their talks in Milan, Renzi made clear to Cameron that he expected Britain and other EU leaders to do more to take in some of the 60,000 refugees that have crossed, or attempted to cross, the Mediterranean to Italy. He said that Europe as a whole faced a crisis that merits an EU response. Britain says that it is not obliged to take the refugees because it is outside the EU‚Äôs visa-free Schengen travel area. But this is causing the prime minister some political embarrassment in EU capitals where other leaders say that one of the EU‚Äôs largest and richest member states should step up. The prime minister therefore moved to change the focus from housing the refugees to disrupting the smugglers. He told Renzi that the Europol cell in Sicily should be up and running well before the current target date of September. Britain has already deployed one NCA officer to Sicily to help set up the cell. The NCA, which has one officer at Europol‚Äôs headquarters in The Hague, is prepared to deploy an additional intelligence analyst to the Netherlands. Cameron told Renzi that Britain is also prepared to deploy six additional NCA officers to Sicily. The prime minister‚Äôs spokeswoman said: ‚ÄúWe think that the EU needs to be looking at what else we are doing to tackle the root cause of the problem and not just treat the symptom when people arrive here. It is something that was agreed at the April emergency European Council and it is an area where we feel there has been little progress since. Renzi agreed that this is an area where we can seek to make progress together.‚Äù The spokeswoman added: ‚ÄúThe prime minister agreed that the EU needed to do much more to tackle the crisis. He underlined that we thought the focus should be on the other shores of the Mediterranean and on breaking the link between getting in a boat and then getting settlement in Europe. As part of that, he said that one particular area we think the EU should be looking to do more is how we disrupt the trafficking and smuggling gangs that are operating in Africa. The first step in being able to successfully disrupt those gangs is gathering intelligence about them.‚Äù The next step could involve armed force to destroy the smugglers‚Äô boats on the North African coast. But this is seen in Whitehall as a remote prospect in the absence of a national government in Libya.

column4: Burden of debt to IMF and European neighbours proves too much for Greece
column5: Everybody knew it, but Athens‚Äôs stark admission on Wednesday that it simply does not have the money to make a ‚Ç¨1.6bn (¬£1.14bn) repayment to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) at the end of the month underlined just how close the country has come to bankruptcy. For all its defiant swagger, the radical Syriza government simply cannot pay the hefty debts Greece incurred when it was bailed out by the IMF and its European neighbours. Central bank governor, Yannis Stournaras, warned that without an imminent deal ‚Äì which must include debt relief ‚Äì Greece could rapidly find itself, ‚Äúrelegated to the rank of a poor country in the European south‚Äù. But the country‚Äôs desperate scrabble for cash is also reminiscent of the fate that faced many countries thousands of miles south of Europe‚Äôs borders ‚Äì the 36 nations, most of them in sub-Saharan Africa, that eventually received debt relief from the west in the 2000s, after fierce campaigning from anti-poverty charities. Notwithstanding the soup kitchens and the lengthening dole queues, living standards on the streets of Athens or Thessaloniki are a world away from the subsistence existence scratched out by the average citizen of Ethiopia or Niger. But the arguments used to support what became known as the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries programme (HIPC) absolutely apply. When debt repayments reach a certain level, they undermine social solidarity because governments struggle to afford investment in schools, health and public services. And they undermine economic growth, because the state has to divert resources that could be spent on infrastructure, training and export support towards its foreign creditors. The burden of debt was far from the only reason per capita GDP in sub-Saharan Africa stagnated for two decades from 1980 but the west agreed that growth would not get off the ground without large-scale forgiveness. There‚Äôs no magic point at which debt becomes ‚Äúunsustainable‚Äù but in order for countries to qualify for help under HIPC, they had to have debt repayments that swallowed up 20% of government revenues. Calculations by the Jubilee Debt Campaign suggest the figure for Greece has hit 30%. Yet the European commission and the European Central Bank are continuing to hold out against a write-off. That‚Äôs why Olivier Blanchard, the IMF‚Äôs chief economist, became so infuriated with the air of unreality surrounding the Greek talks that he issued a public statement at the weekend insisting debt relief will have to be an essential part of any sustainable deal. The IMF‚Äôs role in the scores of debt crises that have erupted across the global economy in the past half-century has been deeply controversial, with the stringent conditions it attaches to aid often blamed for exacerbating the plight of crisis-hit countries. But that very experience means its experts ought to know a country drowning in debt when they see it.

column4: 'Making us poorer won't save Greece': how pension crisis is hurting its people
column5:
Five years ago, Sissy Vovou‚Äôs pension was ‚Ç¨1,330 (¬£953) and landed in her back account 14 times a year: you used to get, she wistfully recalls, a full extra month at Christmas, plus a half each at Easter and for the summer. Now it is a monthly ‚Ç¨1,050 ‚Äì and there are only 12 months in the Greek pensioner‚Äôs year. ‚ÄúIn all,‚Äù she said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve lost 30% of my income. And I‚Äôm one of the lucky ones. I‚Äôm in the top fifth; 80% of Greek pensioners are worse off than me.‚Äù Vovou, 65, who began work at 17 in the publishing industry and ended her career at the state broadcaster, ERT, is also lucky because her son, now 40, has a good job and a regular salary. She does not need to help him out. Eleni Theodorakis, on the other hand, retired in 2008 from her job as an administrative assistant in a regional planning service, aged 55. ‚ÄúMy pension is ‚Ç¨942 euros a month ‚Äì not too bad, really,‚Äù she said, almost shamefacedly, fishing the statement out of her handbag.
‚ÄúFortunately my son is all right, just about, though sometimes he gets paid late. And once or twice, not at all. But my daughter‚Äôs husband has been unemployed for four years now. They have a baby ‚Ä¶ I give them what I can. It isn‚Äôt easy. Thankfully, my sister has a big garden. We grow things.‚Äù There are many like Theodorakis among Greece‚Äôs 2.65 million pensioners. According to a study last year by an employer‚Äôs association, pensions are now the main ‚Äì and often only ‚Äì source of income for just under 49% of Greek families, compared to 36% who rely mainly on salaries. With a jobless rate of about 26% ‚Äì youth unemployment is at 50% ‚Äì and out-of-work benefits of ‚Ç¨360 a month generally paid for no longer than a year, pensions have become ‚Äúa vital part of the social security net for many, many people,‚Äù said Vovou. ‚ÄúRetired parents are having to help their adult children everywhere. And now they‚Äôre demanding we cut them even more? It‚Äôs just so very wrong.‚Äù Pensions have become arguably the biggest hurdle in the tortuous, on-off negotiations between the leftwing government of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, and Greece‚Äôs creditors: its eurozone partners, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Before they will release ‚Ç¨7.2bn in aid that Greece needs to pay public-sector salaries and pensions and repay ‚Ç¨1.6bn in IMF loans, those lenders want further reforms to the pensions system, including penalties to put people off taking early retirement and more cuts to even the lowest pensions. Tsipras is so far refusing to implement the measures, aimed at shaving the equivalent of 1% of GDP off the country‚Äôs pension bill, arguing they will do nothing to help Greece emerge from a slump that has seen the country‚Äôs economy shrink by 25%, and may only deepen its humanitarian crisis. There is little doubt Greece‚Äôs pensions system needed reform. The EU‚Äôs most expensive, at about 17.5% of GDP, it was made up of more than 130 different pension funds and hid widespread abuse: a pension census ordered in 2012 as part of the country‚Äôs bailout conditions turned up more than 90,000 entirely bogus claimants ‚Äì mostly the relatives of long-dead pensioners ‚Äì and 350,000 more inconsistent claims. Greece also had a remarkable 580 professions deemed hazardous or strenuous enough to qualify for early retirement: firemen and construction workers, certainly, but also hairdressers (because of the chemicals), wind instrument players (gastric reflux) and radio presenters (microbes in microphones). But some reforms are under way: those 130 funds have shrunk to 13, the standard retirement age for men has been lifted to 67, and, above all, since 2010 public and private sector pensions have been severely pruned, on a scale ranging from a 15%-cut for the very lowest (under ‚Ç¨500 a month) to as much as 44% for highest (more than ‚Ç¨3,000).
Greek pensions are now, on the whole, far from exorbitant: social security ministry figures show the average main pension is ‚Ç¨713 a month, and the average top-up pension ‚Äì typically funded by an industry retirement scheme ‚Äì ‚Ç¨169 per month. Some 60% of pensioners get less than ‚Ç¨800 gross a month, and 45% live on less than the monthly poverty limit of ‚Ç¨665. The problems the system faces now are closely related to the country‚Äôs particular plight ‚Äì and Athens is not alone in arguing that further flat, across-the-board pension cuts of the kind envisaged by its creditors are unlikely to accomplish much beyond hurting pensioners even more. The record-high unemployment rate, for example, means the pensions system is running a big deficit: contributions coming in are forecast, this year, to be roughly ‚Ç¨2bn less than benefits going out. That shortfall has widened further because of the large number of older Greek workers seeking early retirement: demand is up 14% in the private sector and 48% in the public sector since 2009.
With unemployment among the over-55s at about 20%, compared to just 6% five years ago, ‚ÄúI felt it was the wisest thing to do,‚Äù said Ioannis Konstatinidis, who retired four years early from a large, now privatised bank in 2012. ‚ÄúPeople were losing their jobs, salaries were being cut, and there was so much uncertainty I just thought it was better to be sure of getting at least something.‚Äù Konstatinidis has ended up getting nearly 40% less than he had counted on, however. ‚ÄúOur retirement will not be quite as comfortable as we‚Äôd thought. But we‚Äôre luckier than lots of people.‚Äù They are. Among the pension cuts being proposed is the abolition of the EKAS, a variable supplementary payment made to nearly 200,000 Greek pensioners to bring their monthly income up to ‚Ç¨700 a month. (Other suggestions made by Greece‚Äôs creditors would hit people like that particularly hard: a hike in the tax on electricity, for example, from 13% to 23%). Few Greeks think further pension cuts will achieve anything. They may also be illegal: the country‚Äôs highest court has already ruled that the private-sector pension cuts pushed through in 2012 were unlawful because they ‚Äúdeprived pensioners of the right to decent life‚Äù. Unsurprisingly, the country‚Äôs pensioners‚Äô unions have called for a major demonstration against further cuts on 23 June. ‚ÄúThe government must absolutely not give in,‚Äù said Anastassios Georgiadis, of the retired postal workers‚Äô association. ‚ÄúAnd Europe has to understand that it is not by making us even poorer that Greece will emerge from this crisis.‚Äù

column4: Former US military personnel urge drone pilots to walk away from controls
column5: Forty-five former US military personnel, including a retired army colonel, have issued a joint appeal to the pilots of aerial drones operating in Afghanistan, Iraq, Pakistan, Syria and elsewhere, calling on them to refuse to carry out the deadly missions. In a joint letter, the retired and former military members call on air force pilots based at Creech air force base in Nevada and Beale air force base in California to refuse to carry out their duties. They say the missions, which have become an increasingly dominant feature of US military strategy in recent years, ‚Äúprofoundly violate domestic and international laws‚Äù. ‚ÄúAt least 6,000 lives have been unjustly taken by US drone attacks in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Yemen, Somalia, Iraq, the Philippines, Libya and Syria. These attacks are also undermining principles of international law and human rights,‚Äù the authors write. Among those who signed the letter are retired US army colonel Ann Wright, who resigned in 2003 over the invasion of Iraq. She is joined by several anti-war veterans and former members of diverse ranks from the air force, army, navy and marines. The new protest comes as the US military is facing a crisis in its armed drone program as a result of a steady decline in the numbers of trained pilots available to fly the missions. The New York Times reported on Wednesday that the air force was planning to cut the number of its daily drone flights from 65 to 60 as a result of the drain of pilots. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) first sounded the alarm in April 2014 when it said that more drone pilots were quitting the armed forces than were being recruited and trained. Though the air force has set a target of 1,700 drone pilots to fly the desired 65 missions a day, overall numbers are now down to 1,200.
