The 1967 Abortion Act was never extended to Northern Ireland and all the main local political parties oppose it.

column4: Republican 2016 hopefuls seek 20-week abortion ban but rebound may be costly
column5:
As they criss-cross early voting states, seeking to woo primary voters, Republican presidential contenders are going all-out with their opposition to abortion ‚Äì even if it could come back to bite them. It all has to do with proposed legislation that would ban women from terminating pregnancies after 20 weeks, a move viewed by pro-life advocates as the most historic debate on abortion in decades. In recent months, support for a 20-week abortion ban has turned into its own litmus test for Republicans eyeing the White House. Nearly every one of them has thrown his or her support behind the measure. In the span of one week, hypothetical backing from some presidential hopefuls has turned into concrete support for legislation that could become law depending on who Americans elect president when they go to the polls next year. Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina senator who launched his presidential campaign this month, introduced a 20-week abortion ban in the Senate last week. His co-sponsors included three other Republicans running for president: Florida senator Marco Rubio, Kentucky senator Rand Paul and Texas senator Ted Cruz. Graham‚Äôs introduction of the bill happened to coincide with the passage of a similar measure by the Wisconsin state Senate, where Governor Scott Walker ‚Äì who is expected to declare his candidacy for president in the coming weeks ‚Äì has said he will sign a 20-week abortion ban without exceptions once it reaches his desk. Republican candidates vying to be the most anti-abortion in order to win over social conservatives is nothing new, but for a party that has struggle to attract women voters in recent elections, the 20-week ban carries with it a political risk that could loom well beyond the primary. Democrats have already revived the so-called ‚Äúwar on women‚Äù narrative that cost Republicans heavily in 2012, when Barack Obama beat Mitt Romney by 12 points among women voters. ‚ÄúIt could hurt them. It feeds right into this Democratic strategy of the Republican war on women,‚Äù said Drew Halfmann, an associate professor in sociology at the University of California, Davis, and author of Doctors and Demonstrators: How Political Institutions Shape Abortion Law in the United States, Britain and Canada. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been successful in the past, it could be successful again. It could hurt them, and it could benefit Hillary Clinton.‚Äù Indeed, Clinton, the presumed Democratic nominee for president, has wasted no time criticizing Republicans for trying to restrict access to abortion. In the first rally of her campaign, in New York on Saturday, Clinton told thousands of supporters that Republicans ‚Äúshame and blame women, rather than respect our right to make our own reproductive health decisions‚Äù. On the day that Graham introduced his 20-week abortion ban, Clinton hit back on Twitter: ‚ÄúA group of senators trying to make medical decisions for millions of women: That isn‚Äôt leadership ‚Äì it‚Äôs malpractice.‚Äù But Republicans and anti-abortion groups believe they have an opportunity to flip the debate. The 20-week abortion ban, they have argued, is supported by the majority of Americans. The Republican party‚Äôs more aggressive approach was perhaps best reflected in a statement made by Paul, shortly after he announced his bid for president. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt we ask Democrats, ‚Äòis it OK to kill a 7lb in the uterus?‚Äô‚Äù he said, after repeatedly refusing to specify to reporters if he supported abortion exceptions for rape or incest. The Susan B Anthony List, a pro-life group that led a campaign to get all 2016 GOP candidates on the record supporting a 20-week abortion ban, applauded Paul‚Äôs response. ‚ÄúThe 2016 election cycle is turning out to be vastly different from what happened in 2012, and the most important thing that‚Äôs happening is we‚Äôre seeing candidates go on the offense,‚Äù Mallory Quigley, the group‚Äôs spokeswoman, told the Guardian. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre already seeing candidates with confidence and with passion explaining the pro-life position ‚Ä¶ and we‚Äôre seeing our candidates call out the other side for their extremism.‚Äù Liz Mair, a Republican strategist who has worked for several candidates ‚Äì including Walker and Paul ‚Äì made a similar argument. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want to go and start playing immediately on your opponent‚Äôs turf, but I don‚Äôt believe we‚Äôre playing on their turf,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf Hillary Clinton wants to come out and say, ‚ÄòNo we should allow abortions after Week 20,‚Äô that‚Äôs going to make her look like an extremist.‚Äù Democrats, Mair added, are ‚Äúseriously mis-gauging where the public stands on this issue‚Äù.
American attitudes on abortion are indeed mixed. The general electorate remains fairly split between voters who are pro-choice and pro-life. But one potential problem for Republicans is that a majority of Americans believe decisions on abortion should be made by a woman and her doctor. Republicans and anti-abortion advocates rest their logic on polls that find majority support for banning late-term pregnancies, but other surveys have found the results to be more complicated. Many Americans identify as both pro-choice and pro-life across every demographic group ‚Äì in other words, voters‚Äô perceptions on abortion can change depending on the circumstances. Pro-choice groups like Planned Parenthood have pointed to such nuances in opinion to illustrate why it is misleading to simply say that most Americans support a ban on abortion after 20 weeks. They argue that outside of those Americans who are staunchly pro-life, in all cases, others are less likely to oppose late-term abortions when the reasons women typically seek them are broken down. Late-term abortions account for less than 1.5% of all abortions in the US, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. They often occur among women who discover fetal abnormalities at a later stage, women who are diagnosed with a life-threatening illness such as cancer, or among women who cannot afford to pay for the procedure. Some women do not even find out they are pregnant until after the 20-week mark. ‚ÄúThere is no science or medicine behind this bill ‚Äì just politics,‚Äù Cecile Richards, the president of Planned Parenthood Action Fund, said in a statement responding to Graham‚Äôs bill. ‚ÄúLeading medical groups oppose these bills as do the majority of the American public when they understand the reality that women and their families face when seeking abortion at 20 weeks in pregnancy.‚Äù Medical studies have also disputed that fetuses can feel pain at 20 weeks, the core argument pro-life advocates have used to push a flurry of 20-week abortion bans at the state level. The US House of Representatives passed its own version of the legislation last month. If Graham‚Äôs bill comes up for a vote in the GOP-controlled Senate, however, it is unlikely that it would overcome a Democratic filibuster. If it did, the Obama administration would most certainly veto it. It is unclear if Mitch McConnell, the Republican majority leader, would want to hold a vote on a bill that could carry also ramifications for the GOP‚Äôs control of the Senate. Several Republican senators are facing tough re-election battles in swing states in 2016 and have sought to curry favor with women voters by pushing legislation that would make birth control available over the counter. A vote on a 20-week abortion ban would only complicate that message. Jennifer Lawless, director of the Women & Politics Institute and an associate professor of government at American University, said Republicans fare better when they are careful not to play into the Democrats‚Äô narrative. ‚ÄúAll it takes is one Todd Akin or Richard Mourdock and the Democrats can put forward a narrative ‚Äì quite compellingly ‚Äì that the GOP just doesn‚Äôt respect or understand women,‚Äù said Lawless, referring to two Republicans who lost 2012 Senate elections after making controversial comments on rape while discussing abortion. ‚ÄúBut with such a large Republican presidential field, and what will surely be numerous debates in which the candidates try to differentiate themselves from one another, stepping into women‚Äôs health issues is slippery.‚Äù Doing so has already proved somewhat slippery for Walker, who recently garnered headlines for saying rape and incest exceptions were only concerns for women ‚Äúin the initial months‚Äù of pregnancy. He also defended a 2013 bill he signed into law that requires women seeking abortions to first undergo a mandatory ultrasound by noting that ultrasounds were ‚Äújust a cool thing out there‚Äù.
Rick Perry, again running for president after an unsuccessful attempt in 2012, has also shown no hesitation defending bills he signed curbing access to abortion while serving as governor of Texas ‚Äì some of which are regarded as the most restrictive anti-abortion laws in the country. When asked on Fox News recently if he supported exceptions for rape, incest or to save the mother‚Äôs life, Perry told host Megyn Kelly he was ‚Äúpro-life on all of those‚Äù. Halfmann said Republicans ‚Äúunderstand the benefits and the risks‚Äù of wading into the abortion debate. For Graham and Perry, both underdogs in the primary, it provides an opportunity to stand out in a crowded GOP field. For Walker, one of the early frontrunners, touting his record gives him a leg up over his main rivals ‚Äì Rubio and former Florida governor Jeb Bush. Voters in the general election do not rank abortion among their top issues, he added, which is why it will be critical for Democrats to build a broader case on Republicans and women as they have done successfully in the past. ‚ÄúAbortion is not a super salient issue for voters,‚Äù Halfmann said. ‚ÄúBut portraying the Republican Party as anti-women has very high salience.‚Äù

column4: Fears of new crackdown as China holds two former members of rights group
column5: Two former members of a prominent Chinese human rights group have been detained, fuelling fears that the country‚Äôs crackdown on civil society has entered a new phase of repression that will see NGOs face increasing pressure. Guo Bin and Yang Zhanqing, who had both worked at Yirenping, a public health group that offers support to people with hepatitis B and HIV, were taken into custody on Friday on charges of ‚Äúillegal business operation‚Äù, according to lawyers and activists. Guo, 32, was detained as he visited his two-year-old son at a children‚Äôs hospital in Shenzhen, his lawyer said. ‚ÄúA nurse called him out of the ward and he didn‚Äôt come back,‚Äù Pang Kun told the Guardian. ‚ÄúAnother nurse told his family he had been taken away and would not be coming back anytime soon.‚Äù Yang, 38, was detained at around 10pm at his home in the city of Huizhou, his wife, who asked not to be named, said. ‚ÄúThe police didn‚Äôt even leave me the arrest warrant when they took him.‚Äù The detentions are the latest chapter in an offensive against Chinese civil society that has been gathering pace since Xi Jinping became Communist party leader in late 2012. Yirenping, a non-profit group that was founded in 1996, has found itself at the eye of the storm since March when it criticised the detention of five feminists who had planned to protest against sexual harassment. The group‚Äôs Beijing offices were subsequently raided with security officials seizing computers and documents. In April, a government spokesperson said the group had ‚Äúallegedly violated the law, and will be punished‚Äù. Maya Wang, the China researcher for Human Rights Watch, said: ‚ÄúThe ongoing campaign against this key NGO signifies the Xi government‚Äôs strengthened resolve to control civil society and to crack down on dissenting voices.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe message is to instil a sense of fear among NGOs so that they don‚Äôt dare do anything that could be perceived as threatening,‚Äù Wang added. ‚ÄúWhen the red line keeps moving inward and you don‚Äôt really know where it is, NGOs will scale back their work significantly just to be safe. The result is a tamer civil society.‚Äù Xi‚Äôs crackdown has targeted a variety of groups from grassroots activists to influential bloggers, journalists, civil rights lawyers and academics. Public security officials are likely to be given far greater control over the activities of foreign NGOs under draft legislation that Beijing says is needed to protect ‚Äúnational security and social stability‚Äù. Eva Pils, an academic from King‚Äôs College London who studies civil society and human rights in China, said the outlook was ‚Äúvery bleak‚Äù with moderate groups and individuals now finding themselves in Beijing‚Äôs crosshairs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs now no longer just a few radicals who are being perceived as somehow suspect and potential enemies of the state. Rather the party-state has communicated the message that actually we just don‚Äôt want civil society as a whole. We don‚Äôt want civil society as a potentially oppositional, liberal force within the system,‚Äù she said. Under Xi, the Communist party had used both nationalistic propaganda and the promise of action on issues such as corruption to try to reinforce its authority, said Joshua Rosenzweig, a Hong Kong-based human rights researcher. ‚ÄúThe repression message is: ‚ÄòIf you persist in criticism ‚Äì in mobilising independently within society ‚Äì then, in the interests of Chinese society at large, we, the party, will stop you, we will throw you in jail, we will cut off or restrict your access to the internet, we will close down your organisation.‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄúMore than in recent years the party is wielding a stick to make sure that its message is received,‚Äù Rosenzweig added. Party leaders had feared the west was seeking to topple them by using foreign NGOs to incite a colour revolution for at least a decade, Rosenzweig said. But under Xi those claims had intensified. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know whether or not that reflects Xi Jinping‚Äôs personal vision. But the fact that this has become such a central part of both the rhetoric and the policy under his leadership suggests that he may have something to do with it.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is significant that there has been such a marked increase in the kind of suspicious stance towards foreign institutions and foreign governments since he came to power.‚Äù The wife of Yang Zhanqing, one of the detained activists, said she had been allowed to visit her husband on Monday. ‚ÄúHe was in a good state despite having had his head shaved and wearing handcuffs,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI have nothing to be afraid of as long as they don‚Äôt plant things on him.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is our belief that the state and government should reward these people who work for the public good, instead of framing them with fabricated crimes,‚Äù Yirenping said in a statement. ‚ÄúSuch campaign-style repression must end,‚Äù it added. Additional reporting by Luna Lin

column4: World leaders accused of shameful failure over refugee crisis
column5:
Millions of refugees have been condemned to a life of misery in the worst displacement crisis since the second world war, a leading human rights organisation has said in a scathing report (pdf) that blames world leaders‚Äô neglect for the deaths of thousands of civilians fleeing wars in the Middle East and Africa. ‚ÄúWe are witnessing the worst refugee crisis of our era, with millions of women, men and children struggling to survive amidst brutal wars, networks of people traffickers and governments who pursue selfish political interests instead of showing basic human compassion,‚Äù said Salil Shetty, Amnesty International‚Äôs secretary general, in a statement.
‚ÄúThe refugee crisis is one of the defining challenges of the 21st century, but the response of the international community has been a shameful failure.‚Äù The report, titled The Global Refugee Crisis: A Conspiracy of Neglect, places a particular focus on the Syrian crisis. Almost 4 million people displaced from Syria have registered with the UN high commissioner for refugees. The burden has fallen almost entirely on the shoulders of neighbouring states, who host 95% of the refugees. In Lebanon, one in five people is a Syrian refugee, the equivalent per capita of the UK hosting nearly 13 million refugees.
With its infrastructure stretched beyond breaking point and its government in a state of disarray, Lebanon has imposed a series of restrictions on the entry of refugees that has led to an 80% drop in new registrations compared with last year, despite the continued ferocity of the Syrian civil war. The report concluded that the countries hosting Syrian refugees have received ‚Äúalmost no meaningful international support‚Äù, with the UN‚Äôs humanitarian appeal to cover the costs of caring for the refugees receiving less than a quarter of the necessary funds. In Turkey, border guards used water cannon over the weekend to push back a fresh influx of refugees fleeing the fighting between Islamic State militants and Kurdish militias near the long border with Syria. Amnesty criticised the international community for similarly failing to respond to massive displacement crises in sub-Saharan Africa, where there are an estimated 3 million refugees, including hundreds of thousands who have fled conflicts in Nigeria, South Sudan, the Central African Republic and Burundi in recent years.
On the Mediterranean migrant crisis, Amnesty called on European nations to share the burden of resettling refugees, and said the scaling back of Operation Mare Nostrum ‚Äì the Italian effort to handle asylum seekers fleeing to Europe by boat ‚Äì had contributed to the increase in the number of people drowning.
About 3,500 people died while trying to cross the Mediterranean to Europe in 2014, with 1,865 dying this year so far. The majority of those fleeing by boat are Syrians displaced by the war. ‚ÄúThe European governments have pushed them back into the sea rather than resettle them,‚Äù Shetty said at the report‚Äôs launch in Beirut. More generally, Shetty added, the world is ‚Äúturning its back to the most vulnerable people‚Äù. In south-east Asia, 300 refugees and migrants have died at sea due to starvation, dehydration and abuse by boat crews, with Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand initially refusing to allow boats carrying migrants to land back, putting many at risk. Amnesty castigated the Australian government in particular for ‚Äúharsh, humiliating‚Äù conditions in which asylum seekers are kept when they attempt to reach the country. Amnesty estimated the number of displaced people globally to be above 50 million, a crisis greater in magnitude than any since the second world war. The rights group called on states to resettle 1.5 million refugees over the next five years, prioritise saving the lives of displaced people over domestic immigration policies, create a refugee fund, hold a global summit to deal with the crisis, and ratify the UN‚Äôs refugee convention.

column4: Sudan president barred from leaving South Africa
column5:
South Africa‚Äôs high court has barred Sudan‚Äôs president, Omar al-Bashir, from leaving the country in a dispute over alleged war crimes that could undermine the authority of the international criminal court (ICC). Bashir, who travelled to Johannesburg for a summit of African leaders, is wanted by the UN-backed court for alleged atrocities, including genocide, committed during the Darfur conflict.
The high court in Pretoria issued an interim order preventing Bashir from leaving South Africa until an urgent application to force authorities to arrest him is heard. A further hearing was scheduled for Monday at 11.30am (9.30am BST) after the Southern Africa Litigation Centre (SALC), which promotes human rights, filed an urgent application to overturn a government decision to grant immunity to all delegates attending the African Union (AU) summit. The prospect of the Sudanese president being formally arrested appeared to recede on Sunday evening, however, when South Africa‚Äôs ruling African National Congress (ANC) said the ICC was ‚Äúno longer useful for the purposes for which it was intended‚Äù. The ANC also called for a review of ICC statutes to make them applicable to all UN members and ensure a ‚Äúfair and independent court for universal and equitable justice‚Äù. Bashir was seen at the conference venue on Sunday evening, but his whereabouts on Monday was not confirmed. African states accuse the court, which is based in The Hague, of only targeting political leaders on their continent and failing to bring to justice those responsible for war crimes in the Middle East and elsewhere.
The initial order preventing Bashir‚Äôs departure was extended on Sunday so that the court could reconvene on Monday to examine the SALC application. Judge Hans Fabricuis urged the government to take ‚Äúall necessary steps‚Äù to prevent Bashir, 71, from leaving the country. If he left, the judge said, it would damage South Africa‚Äôs international reputation. In a statement issued at the weekend, the ICC called on South Africa, which has signed up to the court, to detain Bashir and ‚Äúspare no effort in ensuring the execution of the [two] arrest warrants‚Äù. It also expressed ‚Äúdeep concern about the negative consequences for the court in case of non-execution of the warrants by states parties and, in this regard, urges them to respect their obligations to cooperate with the court‚Äù. South Africa‚Äôs foreign ministry did not immediately comment. As an ICC signatory, the government is obliged to exercise its arrest warrants. Bashir was originally indicted more than a decade ago. ‚ÄúHe would be a fool if he had not sought guarantees he would not be transferred before leaving for South Africa,‚Äù one ICC official was reported as saying. Since his indictment in 2009, he has mostly travelled to countries that have not joined the ICC. ‚ÄúWe are all happy to be here. There‚Äôs no problem,‚Äù a Sudanese official said at the summit. The AU summit is chaired by Zimbabwe‚Äôs president, Robert Mugabe, who has urged African leaders to pull out of the ICC. Human rights groups, however, expressed outrage that Bashir could openly defy arrest. ‚ÄúAllowing president Bashir into South Africa without arresting him would be a major stain on South Africa‚Äôs reputation for promoting justice for grave crimes,‚Äù said Elise Keppler of Human Rights Watch. ‚ÄúSouth Africa‚Äôs legal obligations as an ICC member mean cooperating in Bashir‚Äôs arrest, not in his travel plans.‚Äù Darfur erupted into conflict in 2003 when insurgents mounted a campaign against Bashir‚Äôs government, complaining their region was politically and economically marginalised. More than 300,000 people have been killed in the conflict and about 2.5 million have been forced to flee their homes, according to the UN.

column4: Japanese PM's plan to allow troops to fight overseas angers voters
column5:
Controversial plans by Japan‚Äôs prime minister, Shinzo Abe, to allow his country‚Äôs troops to fight on foreign soil for the first time since the second world war have sent his support ratings to their lowest level since he became leader in late 2012. A poll by Nippon TV network found that almost two-thirds of respondents opposed the change, which requires new legislation to reinterpret Japan‚Äôs pacifist constitution. Growing opposition could threaten Abe‚Äôs recent promise to Barack Obama that he will enact legislation currently being debated in parliament later this summer. Article 9 of the postwar constitution, written by US occupation officials, prohibits Japan from threatening or using force as means of settling international disputes. Successive administrations in Tokyo have interpreted that to mean that troops can only go into battle in defence of direct threats to Japanese territory. A year ago, Abe‚Äôs cabinet reinterpreted the constitution, saying it did not prevent Japan from exercising its right to collective self-defence, or coming to the aid of an ally ‚Äì almost certainly the US ‚Äì even when Japan itself is not attacked. That dramatic shift is reflected in new joint defence guidelines agreed in April between Tokyo and Washington. On a visit to the US later that month, Abe pledged to push the changes through parliament by mid-August, when he will release a much-anticipated statement to mark the 70th anniversary of the end of the Pacific war. The current parliamentary session is supposed to end on 24 June but could be extended to accommodate a vote on the collective self-defence bills. But Abe, a conservative who has long argued for a more robust, internationally active military, is struggling to convince voters and constitutional experts.
The Nippon TV poll showed support for Abe falling to 41.1%, while 63.7% opposed collective self-defence. Almost 80% said the government had not properly explained the new legislation. The poll results come soon after a respected expert on constitutional law invited to address a panel of MPs by Abe‚Äôs Liberal Democratic party [LDP] said the proposed changes were unconstitutional. ‚ÄúThe government should retract the bills because the core element of the bills ‚Äì the use of the right of collective self-defence ‚Äì is manifestly unconstitutional,‚Äù Yasuo Hasebe, a professor at Waseda University, told a news conference after his appearance. The change would require outright constitutional reform, Hasebe added ‚Äì an option Abe has apparently abandoned for now due to public opposition. Two other experts said government assurances that potential missions would be strictly non-combative and risk-free were misleading. In response, Abe told reporters at the G7 summit in Germany last weekend that Japanese forces would operate ‚Äúunder the world‚Äôs strictest conditions on the use of force‚Äù and exercise the right to collective self-defence ‚Äúin a restrained manner‚Äù. The security bills would remove geographical constraints on where Japanese troops could operate in ‚Äúsituations that would significantly affect Japan‚Äôs security‚Äù. They would also allow them to defend allies ‚Äúin situations where there is a clear risk that Japan‚Äôs existence is threatened and its people‚Äôs rights ‚Ä¶ are compromised through an attack on a country which has a close relationship with Japan‚Äù. Opponents say that Abe‚Äôs new interpretation is too broad and would risk dragging Japanese troops into US-led conflicts. The LDP and its junior coalition partner, New Komeito, have comfortable majorities in both houses, but would be wary of alienating voters in order to satisfy the US, which wants Japan to play a bigger role in bilateral security ties to counter an increasingly assertive China. ‚ÄúIt depends on public opinion,‚Äù said Atsuo Ito, a political commentator. ‚ÄúSome LDP executives are now wondering which is the bigger risk: breaking a promise to Washington, or damaging public support.‚Äù About 25,000 people demonstrated in Tokyo on Sunday in defence of the pacifist constitution, organisers said.

column4: ‚ÄòBritain‚Äôs youngest suicide bomber‚Äô mourned by West Yorkshire family
column5:
The family of a West Yorkshire teenager, believed to have become Britain‚Äôs youngest suicide bomber, said they have been left ‚Äúutterly devastated and heartbroken by the unspeakable tragedy‚Äù. Pictures of Talha Asmal, 17, were released by Isis on Saturday, along with a statement saying that he detonated a vehicle fitted with explosives in the northern Iraqi town of Baiji. The militant group said his name was Abu Yusuf al-Britani but following media reports identifying the boy in the pictures as Asmal, his family released a statement on Sunday expressing their grief and anger. ‚ÄúTalha was a loving, kind, caring and affable teenager,‚Äù they said. ‚ÄúHe never harboured any ill-will against anybody nor did he ever exhibit any violent, extreme or radical views of any kind. Talha‚Äôs tender years and naivety were, it seems however, exploited by persons unknown, who, hiding behind the anonymity of the worldwide web, targeted and befriended Talha and engaged in a process of deliberate and calculated grooming of him. ‚ÄúWhilst there it appears that Talha fell under the spell of individuals who continued to prey on his innocence and vulnerability to the point where if the press reports are accurate he was ordered to his death by so-called Isis handlers and leaders too cowardly to do their own dirty work. ‚ÄúWe are all naturally utterly devastated and heartbroken by the unspeakable tragedy that now appears to have befallen us.‚Äù The family said that Isis did not represent Islam or Muslims ‚Äúin any way, shape of form‚Äù. In April, they said the teenager boarded a flight to Turkey with his friend Hassan Munshi, also 17 at the time. The families of both boys issued an urgent appeal for their return, adding they were gravely worried the pair had joined Isis. Isis statements on Saturday named Britani as one of four suicide bombers. The others were said to be a German, a Kuwaiti and a Palestinian. All four were photographed by Isis standing beside SUVs. The suicide attacks are understood to have occurred in Iraq‚Äôs Salahuddin province, around one of the country‚Äôs largest oil refineries, as part of a larger military offensive by the militant group.
If the reports are corroborated, Asmal would be Britain‚Äôs youngest known suicide bomber. Another West Yorkshire teenager, Hasib Hussein, was almost 19 when he blew himself up on a London bus in the 7 July 2005 attacks. Shahid Malik, a former government minister and a friend of the Asmals, described them as ‚Äúa beautiful, caring, peace-loving and incredibly humble family‚Äù. The former MP for Dewsbury said: ‚ÄúThe local community grieves with them today, Ebrahim (the father) and the family‚Äôs world has been shattered in the cruellest of ways and one which no family should ever have to experience. ‚ÄúTalha was a truly sweet-natured, helpful, respectful and friendly kid, and it is incredibly difficult to reconcile this Talha with the suicide bomber at an Iraqi oil installation. ‚ÄúMy thoughts and prayers are obviously also with those killed at the oil installation and their families. ‚ÄúIt is disturbing to see how relaxed he looks in the Isis photographs allegedly taken just prior to his suicide mission. He looks at peace. It‚Äôs like he‚Äôs ready to go and meet his maker. This is a clear indication of just how successful the evil Isis groomers have been in poisoning and brainwashing Talha and kids like him. ‚ÄúWe must defeat Isis in mosques and communities across the country. This is a generational struggle and everyone must be willing to rise to the challenge. Importantly, it‚Äôs a struggle which can only succeed if it is one which is led by Muslims themselves.‚Äù West Yorkshire police said: ‚ÄúThe police have been made aware of media reports with regard to the death of a British national in Iraq. The identity of the person who has reportedly died has not been confirmed at this time and we are unable to comment further.‚ÄùSpeaking on Sunday, Asst Ch Con Russ Foster said: ‚ÄúAs part of the Prevent initiative, West Yorkshire police is committed to working with communities and local authorities, to highlight the dangers associated with radicalisation and travel to regions such as Syria and Iraq. We are all working together to help identify vulnerable members of our society and intervene and engage them before it is too late. ‚ÄúIf anyone has concerns that a friend or relative may be vulnerable to radicalisation, expressing extreme views or contemplating travelling to Syria or Iraq, it is vital that we work together to try and prevent that person from travelling. ‚ÄúFamilies are also encouraged to make contact with specially trained officers for help and advice by visiting preventtragedies.co.uk.‚Äù He said this was a newly created webpage, dedicated to being a ‚Äúa one-stop shop for concerned families to visit if they would like further information or advice around this issue‚Äù.

column4: Dewsbury in 'utter shock' over Talha Asmal's death in Iraq suicide bombing
column5: Community leaders have been left shocked by the death of a teenager believed to have become Britain‚Äôs youngest suicide bomber after being ‚Äúgroomed‚Äù by Islamic State. Talha Asmal, 17, from Dewsbury, West Yorkshire, who reportedly detonated a vehicle fitted with explosives while fighting for the militant group in Iraq, was described as ‚Äúa loving, kind, caring and affable teenager‚Äù by his devastated family. Despite his death not being officially confirmed, his family said images released through an Isis-linked Twitter account showing a young man named as Abu Yusuf al-Britani appear to depict their son. Qari Asim, an imam at the Makkah Masjid mosque who was awarded an MBE for his efforts to build bridges between communities in Leeds since the 7 July 2005 terror attacks, said Isis leaders were acting ‚Äúlike paedophiles‚Äù by grooming young men. ‚ÄúThe community is in utter shock and a sense of disbelief that a young lad from Yorkshire is said to [have] become Britain‚Äôs youngest suicide bomber,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIsis is running a sophisticated social media campaign and the community is concerned their faith is being used by hate preachers and internet groomers to manipulate their religion.‚Äù Farooq Yunus, from the Zakaria mosque in Savile Town, Dewsbury, said the whole system had failed the boys. ‚ÄúI think we have failed. Not just the people in here ‚Ä¶ the council, the police, the community,‚Äù he told BBC Radio 5 Live. Pictures released by Isis online show Talha smiling as he stands by a black Toyota SUV giving the militant group‚Äôs signature one-finger salute. Another shows the teenager clutching a rifle as he sits cross-legged on a mat alongside two other armed men, apparently taking instruction from a uniformed militant in a crudely furnished operations room. Lorraine Barker, executive principal of Mirfield Free Grammar and Sixth Form, where Talha was studying, told the Times he was very quiet and private and a ‚Äútypical teenager‚Äù. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt draw any attention to himself, he was just a conscientious student,‚Äù she said. The 17-year-old lived at the family‚Äôs terraced home with his mother Noorjaha, 38, and father Ebrahim, 42, before he left for Syria via Turkey in April on a Thomas Cook flight with his next-door neighbour and best friend Hassan Munshi, the brother of Britain‚Äôs youngest convicted terrorist Hammad Munshi. In a damning statement, Talha‚Äôs family lashed out at Isis for preying on his ‚Äúinnocence and vulnerability‚Äù. They said: ‚ÄúHe never harboured any ill will against anybody nor did he ever exhibit any violent, extreme or radical views of any kind. Talha‚Äôs tender years and naivety were, it seems however, exploited by persons unknown, who, hiding behind the anonymity of the worldwide web, targeted and befriended Talha and engaged in a process of deliberate and calculated grooming of him. ‚ÄúWhilst there, it appears that Talha fell under the spell of individuals who continued to prey on his innocence and vulnerability to the point where, if the press reports are accurate, he was ordered to his death by so-called Isis handlers and leaders too cowardly to do their own dirty work. ‚ÄúWe are all naturally utterly devastated and heartbroken by the unspeakable tragedy that now appears to have befallen us.‚Äù The family said that Isis did not represent Islam or Muslims ‚Äúin any way, shape or form‚Äù. Isis statements on Saturday named Britani ‚Äì the 17-year-old‚Äôs nom de guerre ‚Äì as one of four suicide bombers. The others were said to be a German, a Kuwaiti and a Palestinian. All four were photographed by Isis standing beside SUVs. The suicide attacks are understood to have occurred in Salahuddin province, near one of Iraq‚Äôs largest oil refineries, as part of a larger military offensive by the militant group. Shahid Malik, a former government minister and a friend of the Asmals, described them as ‚Äúa beautiful, caring, peace-loving and incredibly humble family‚Äù. The former MP for Dewsbury said: ‚ÄúThe local community grieves with them today, Ebrahim and the family‚Äôs world has been shattered in the cruellest of ways and one which no family should ever have to experience. ‚ÄúTalha was a truly sweet-natured, helpful, respectful and friendly kid, and it is incredibly difficult to reconcile this Talha with the suicide bomber at an Iraqi oil installation.‚Äù Charlie Winter, a researcher at counter-extremism thinktank the Quilliam Foundation, said the short amount of time the teenager spent in Syria before he died was an unusual feature of the case. ‚ÄúHe was reported to have left the UK in March, now we‚Äôre in June and we‚Äôre told he has blown himself up ‚Äì that‚Äôs a quick turn around. He was chosen soon after he arrived,‚Äù said Winter. Isis would have deliberately selected a young British person to act as a suicide bomber as it is more provocative and likely to generate publicity, Winter continued. ‚ÄúThey have used young people and children on suicide operations for a while now. The youngest I‚Äôm aware of is 14. Displaying Talha‚Äôs face without a mask, making clear who he is, saying that he was British, they would have calculated this would have caused a media storm.‚Äù

column4: Iran's next parliamentary elections ‚Äòcould be on a par with Turkey‚Äô
column5:
President Hassan Rouhani unofficially kicked off next February‚Äôs parliamentary elections before a gathering of provincial governors on 26 May. ‚ÄúNo political or sectarian belief should be discounted, for they are based in religion, science, and personal beliefs, and of course elections without competition are impossible,‚Äù Rouhani said. ‚ÄúWe have different ideas in our society, and all are free to express their ideas. This is why we have various parties and persuasions.‚Äù Rouhani‚Äôs comments suggest he hopes to prepare the way for increased reformist participation in the majles (parliament). The president suggested he would resist attempts by far-right, fundamentalist elements to improperly leverage money, influence, or advertising in order to influence voters. ‚ÄúHopefully no one will be told that so-and-so from the government, the Revolutionary Guards, the military, the media, the regional or local government, or the mosques, supports so-and-so as a candidate for the majles,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSuch talk constitutes poison for otherwise healthy elections. All officials and people in positions of power are duty bound to serve the interests of the nation as a whole and not those of [particular] political parties or individuals.‚Äù Has this given any encouragement to the reformists? In an interview with Tehran Bureau, a member of the Islamic Iran Participation Front, a leading party suspended since 2009, expressed cautious optimism. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs certainly come out swinging, but he‚Äôll eventually tone down the intensity as time passes,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe may be demanding today that these elections be on a par with those of Finland and the UK in terms of openness and freedom, but ultimately he‚Äôll have to temper his expectations to something resembling Turkey‚Äôs elections. If his strategy gets results, it‚Äôll be a step forward, since it should translate to more moderates and reformists and fewer fundamentalists in the majles.‚Äù Fundamentalists have held a majority in the 310-seat majles since 2004, when they overturned a reformist majority, and changing this will not be easy. The fundamentalists‚Äô predominance goes back to an election when the Guardian Council, which vets candidates, disqualified around 4,000 reformist hopefuls, including 80 sitting members. In 2004, only 50% of those eligible voted, compared with 66% in 2000. Four years later, in 2008, only 51% of eligible voters participated after the Guardian Council disqualified around 2000 candidates and only 29 reformists won seats. The turnout in Tehran was just 30%. By the time of the 2012 parliamentary election, the political situation had been transformed by the authorities‚Äô response to the street protests after the disputed 2009 presidential election. Iran‚Äôs conservatives referred to the protests as the ‚Äòsedition‚Äô and to protestors and their alleged supporters as ‚Äòseditionists‚Äô ‚Äì so justifying the continuing house arrest of Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi, presidential candidates in 2009 and leaders of the Green Movement, which emerged in the protests. In the 2012 parliamentary elections there was a boycott by reformist parties, including the Islamic Iran Participation Front, the Mojahedin of the Islamic Revolution Organisation, and Karroubi‚Äôs National Trust Party. The Executives of Construction Party, led by pragmatic conservative Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, also kept aloof. The reformists then cried foul when the authorities announced a 64% turnout. ‚ÄúObviously there was foul play,‚Äù the Islamic Iran Participation Front member alleged. ‚ÄúThe Revolutionary Guards interfered by supporting certain candidates. Considering that all the reformists boycotted the elections and a large percentage of the voters still had the 2009 elections on their minds, only a Revolutionary Guard intervention could explain such a high turn-out.‚Äù Several prominent individuals from more moderate conservative parties explicitly confirmed this. Parliamentary deputy Ali Mottahari told the majles in May 2012: ‚ÄúDespite its successes, one of the major failures of the ninth majles elections was the degree to which the Revolutionary Guards entered the political arena and offered active, open support to the candidates of their choice. Many candidates, both those who won and those who lost, have confirmed this.‚Äù
Mohammad-Reza Bahonar, a parliamentary deputy from Tehran and the first deputy speaker, made allegations of rigging to the reformist newspaper Etemad at the time. ‚ÄúIn these elections, I was told I would be ranked fifth (in Tehran), but when the results were tallied, I was 25th,‚Äù he said. For next February‚Äôs election, the reformists‚Äô fears centre on the possibility that they or even candidates close to Rouhani‚Äôs government will be disqualified en masse.
A staff member at the politics desk of the moderate newspaper Ebtekar told Tehran Bureau: ‚ÄúTo an extent, Rouhani‚Äôs decisive victory in [the presidential election of] 2013 restored the people‚Äôs confidence in the electoral process: the rulers here seemed to have learned a lesson from 2009, and they weren‚Äôt willing to take quite such a big risk again. Of course it‚Äôs possible that there were some small cases of fraud in smaller cities and rural areas, but there was no sign of the kind of mass, systematic fraud that occurred in 2009 and 2012.‚Äù Concerns around mass disqualifications can be explained in part by recent statements by Ahmad Jannati, 88, chairman of the Guardian Council since 1992. ‚ÄúThe leadership of the Guardian Council has not forgotten the ‚Äòsedition‚Äô as it relates to those candidates who would participate in the elections,‚Äù Jannati told the May gathering of municipal governors. ‚ÄúThe sedition, which occurred after the 2009 elections, was soundly defeated, but its goal was nothing less than the overthrow of the government, and the supreme leader has said that sedition is our ‚Äòred line.‚Äô‚Äù Jannati‚Äôs comments suggest that conservative factions within the governing apparatus are set on continuing revenge against the reformists and the Green Movement, and therefore have no intention of opening up the political arena. But there is clear, and unresolved, tension here with what Rouhani has said. Many prominent reformist politicians, some of whom received prison sentences after the 2009 protests, have yet to comment. Even Mohammad Khatami, the former president still seen by many as the leader of the reform movement, has not talked about the elections in any public appearances over recent months. The chances that the reformists will submit a comprehensive list of candidates for the elections are slim. But if reform-minded politicians hope to clear fundamentalists out of parliament and the government, they could support a list of moderate technocrats.
Some reformists adopted a similar strategy in the 2013 presidential election when Khatami decided against running and former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani was disqualified. They threw their support behind the moderate Rouhani to stop a fundamentalist candidate getting elected.
Such a strategy could have considerable support among voters. In the small village of Lasjerd, 170km east of Tehran, a 55-year-old melon farmer named Akbar, who once voted for Mahmoud Ahmadinejad as president, said he would support whoever Rafsanjani recommended in order to curb ‚ÄúHezbollahis‚Äù, or fundamentalists. ‚ÄúThey cut our bread and water, our medicine, and they filled their own pockets,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey used these sanctions, which devastated the farmers, to further enrich themselves, and now that this [Mohammad Javad] Zarif [the foreign minister leading talks with world powers] is trying to get the sanctions lifted, these bastards are trying to sabotage it! They‚Äôre trying to stop the agreement, so I‚Äôll vote for whoever can keep them out of power.‚Äù Shaghayegh, a 26-year-old reformist and law student at Tehran‚Äôs science and technology university, said she would vote against ‚ÄúFrankensteins and Draculas‚Äù in the parliament. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt mind voting in some sane people ‚Äì as long as I know there won‚Äôt be any funny business.‚Äù Shaghayegh is not optimistic over wider political reform. ‚ÄúIf a bunch of cowardly moderates take over...all we can hope for... is that they don‚Äôt muck things up further. They could at least let Rouhani and Zarif pursue their foreign policy, and maybe they could push some good proposals for the economy. But first we have to get rid of the people who are in control now.‚Äù A similar argument came from a Tehran-based reformist journalist, who argued next February‚Äôs elections were of the ‚Äúutmost importance‚Äù given the wide powers of the majles, including over the selection of ministers. ‚ÄúIn the event that many reformist candidates are not disqualified, there may be considerable room for a competition that decides who controls the majles,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis would not necessarily translate into a democratic transformation of the legal sphere. The biggest gains will probably be seen over the economic situation and corruption. Although [wider] democracy is undoubtedly an urgent matter, the precarious political conditions simply don‚Äôt allow it at present.‚Äù

column4: Fate of al-Qaida's 'Uncatchable' Algerian militant in the balance after US air strike
column5:
Dubbed ‚ÄúThe Uncatchable‚Äù for staying at large for so long, and ‚ÄúMr Marlboro‚Äù after his cigarette smuggling operation to fund jihad, Mokhtar Belmokhtar became one of al Qaida‚Äôs most notorious operatives. Belmokhtar was reportedly killed by a US air strike on Saturday, according to statement from the Libyan government. But his death has not been verified and the truth about the man who lost an eye fighting the Russians in Afghanistan ‚Äì or possibly in Algeria, fighting the military, depending on which source you believe ‚Äì has always been as evasive as the man himself. Belmokhtar was known best for masterminding the 2013 attack on an Algerian gas plant that killed 39 hostages, and was carried out by his own al-Qaida offshoot known as the ‚ÄúMasked Men brigade‚Äù, or ‚ÄúSigned in Blood battalion‚Äù. This is not the first time he has been reported dead. In 2013 Chadian troops claimed to have killed him in an operation against a terrorist base in northern Mali, only for him to resurface months later, linked to terror attacks in Mali and Niger.
Born in Algeria in 1972, Belmokhtar professed to being inspired by jihad as a schoolboy and travelling to Afghanistan aged 19 to train with al-Qaida. He later claimed that during his time in Afghanistan he was in touch with leading lights of the terror group including Abu Qatada and the recently released Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi. Belmokhtar returned to Algeria in 1993 and joined the country‚Äôs fledgling jihadi movement, going on to become a leading figure in the militant Armed Islamist Group (GIA) and later the Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC), a breakaway group formed by former GIA commander Hassan Hattab. In early 2007, it was announced that GSPC would merge with al-Qaida to form al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) and Belmokhtar took control of an AQIM battalion. But in 2012, after in-fighting among AQIM commanders, Belmokhtar broke away once again to form his own group, the Signed in Blood battalion, or ‚ÄúThose Who Sign in Blood‚Äù. It was under this moniker that he masterminded the 2013 attack against the In Amenas gas facility in south-eastern Algeria, the group‚Äôs first big operation. The militants seized control of the facility, taking hundreds of people hostage. By the time the Algerian army stormed the facility four days later, 39 foreign hostages were dead, including six Britons. An Algerian security guard and 29 militants also lost their lives. In recent years, Belmokhtar reportedly made money smuggling cigarettes and other contraband across the Sahara and extorting ransoms for western hostages. In January, he emerged to praise the shooting at satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo in Paris and called on Muslims to carry out similar attacks. In August 2013 it was announced that the Signed in Blood battalion would join with another al-Qaida offshoot, the Movement for the Unity and Jihad in West Africa, to form the al-Mourabitoun group. In May this year, Belmokhtar was forced to deny that he had pledged allegiance to Islamic State after a faction within al-Mourabitoun defected. He issued a statement reiterating his allegiance to al-Qaida and its chief, Ayman al-Zawahri.

column4: London house to become museum to Indian activist
column5:
A six-bedroom house in north London is set to become a museum to one of India‚Äôs most revered ‚Äì but still controversial ‚Äì campaigners and political figures after being bought for ¬£3m-¬£4m by a provincial government in the south Asian country. Dr Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar, a politician, social activist and lawyer who drafted much of the Indian constitution, lived in the house in London‚Äôs Primrose Hill while a student at the London School of Economics in 1921 and 1922. Ambedkar was a Dalit, or ‚Äúuntouchable‚Äù, from the lowest rank of the tenacious social hierarchy known as caste. However, he escaped poverty and discrimination to win scholarships to study economics at LSE and Columbia University, New York and to qualify as a barrister in London. A fierce critic of the caste system, he became India‚Äôs first law minister when the country won its independence in 1947. Ambedkar is still revered today by Dalits there and across the world. The house will be turned into a museum and library, with rooms available for Dalits from India who are studying, like Ambedkar, at the LSE on two new scholarships. It will need up to ¬£1m of refurbishment and conversion work if the sale goes through. Arun Kumar, general secretary of the UK-based Federation of Ambedkarite and Buddhist Organisations, said: ‚ÄúIt is a historical place. [Ambedkar] came to London and was exposed to an atmosphere of freedom and equality and went back to India building on everything he had seen and saying, ‚ÄòIf in western countries there is equality, why not in India?‚Äô‚Äù Ambedkar was born a Hindu but converted to Buddhism before he died in 1956, convinced that caste discrimination was intrinsic to his original faith. Remembered as one of the founders of modern India, his portrait hangs in many homes of India‚Äôs 200 million Dalits. ‚ÄúHe is a hero to us, a saint, like our god,‚Äù said 38-year-old Radhika Kumar, a Dalit and a cleaner in Delhi.
Though some of the harsher aspects of the caste system have been moderated in recent decades, Dalits still suffer systematic discrimination. In some regions, particularly the poor northern states of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, caste tensions can lead to violence. When a statue of Ambedkar in Punjab state was vandalised this weekend, roads were blocked by local Dalits in protest. Ambedkar‚Äôs views on caste contrasted with those of Mahatma Gandhi, the revered independence leader whose statue was recently unveiled in Parliament Square. Gandhi condemned caste discrimination, but believed its causes were not religious and that parts of the caste system should be maintained. The museum is being funded by the government of Maharashtra, the Indian state where Ambedkar‚Äôs family was from. Dalits are an important constituency in India and wooed by politicians. Next year is the 125th anniversary of his birth. ‚ÄúThis is a historical moment for us because it is not just a house but has the emotions of all Indians attached to it,‚Äù Rajkumar Badole, Maharashtra‚Äôs minister of social justice, said in London this year. Badole pledged too to fund an Ambedkar chair at the LSE and scholarships. Supporters of the museum say it will have relevance in the UK, too. Research by the British government has found evidence of caste discrimination among Britons of Asian origin in the workplace and in schools. Legislation is due to be introduced this year to make caste discrimination an offence in Britain. ‚ÄúIt is important to send a message here, too,‚Äù said Kumar.

column4: Rome feels pressure of migration buildup with makeshift refugee camp
column5:
While passengers at Tiburtina, one of Rome‚Äôs main train stations and just a 10-minute ride from the Colosseum, tinkled on the station‚Äôs piano or stopped off for an ice cream, outside there were more urgent matters at hand. Officials were trying to channel a water tap into a makeshift refugee camp that was opened on Saturday, prompted by the growing number of migrants left in limbo after France increased security at the Italian border. Around 100 migrants are staying in tents in the shadow of the station, a modern transport hub from where travellers are whisked on high-speed trains to cities including Florence and Milan. The camp was opened in a joint effort by the Italian Red Cross and local authorities, after a growing number of migrants began gathering at the train station. Alessandro Radicchi, the Red Cross‚Äôs director for combating poverty across Italy‚Äôs rail network, said the worsening situation prompted the organisation to act. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre here because they‚Äôve closed the border; people wanted to go elsewhere in Europe but now the border‚Äôs been blocked. This isn‚Äôt just a problem today, this is a problem in general,‚Äù he said. News that France has increased security checks on its border has prompted many migrants to temporarily halt their journey north. Although under the EU law asylum seekers must register at their first point of arrival, most of those arriving in Italy by sea avoid doing so in order to travel onwards to northern Europe. The new refugee camp is already equipped with beds and toilets. On Saturday an idle digg ing machine signalled the hasty clearing of the building site to make way for the refugees, who have fled from countries including Syria and Eritrea.
But Radicchi was clear that the camp is only a temporary solution; work will begin on Sunday on transforming a disused hotel into accommodation for up to 200 migrants. Italy‚Äôs prime minister, Matteo Renzi, has called for changes to the EU regulation on where asylum seekers must first register. ‚ÄúIf the European Council chooses solidarity, good. If it doesn‚Äôt, we are ready for plan B. But it would above all hurt Europe,‚Äù he told Italian daily Corriere della Sera, without giving further details. Renzi criticised the EU‚Äôs ‚Äúinsufficient‚Äù proposal to relocate 24,000 refugees from Italy and said he would discuss the migration crisis in upcoming meetings with the UK‚Äôs prime minister, David Cameron, and French president, Fran√ßois Hollande. The Italian premier also faces an internal battle, with rightwing politicians rebelling over plans to distribute boat migrants across Italy. Regions across the north were asked by the government to take in 7,500 new arrivals, a request flatly refused by rightwing leaders. The refugee camp at Tiburtina is also intended to take pressure off a nearby Eritrean cultural centre, Baobab, where dozens of migrants queued for meals. Food donations were piled up alongside toys for the children, who passed their time blowing bubbles and playing with rainbow-coloured windmills. Despite the calm atmosphere, the centre‚Äôs Eritrean cook said none of the migrants wanted to stay in Italy. Although he made the sea journey a decade ago, the cook chose not to give his name for fear of the impact it could still have on his family back home. New arrivals were equally scared of the backlash they could face from authorities in Eritrea, where citizens face compulsory military conscription and torture is widespread according to Amnesty International. ‚ÄúIf you go back, you go to prison,‚Äù the cook said. Outside the Baobab centre, a group of young Eritrean men said they planned to travel onwards to France. They had intended to head north by bus or train and were surprised to hear they may now face difficulty in crossing the border. Their counterparts who have already reached north-west Italy tried in vain to enter France on Saturday. Protesting migrants were met with riot police who pushed them back to Ventimiglia, a border town on the Italian coast. Austria and Switzerland have followed France in tightening controls and returning migrants, putting greater pressure on Italy, which has seen more than 50,000 people arrive by sea so far this year.

column4: Israel defends Gaza conflict as 'moral war'
column5: Israel has claimed the Israel Defence Forces‚Äô operation in Gaza last summer was a moral, defensive war conducted in accordance with international law. The publication on Sunday of a report written in conjunction with Israeli government ministries was timed to occur days before the release of the findings of an investigation by the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) into possible war crimes by Israel and Hamas. The UNHRC report, with which Israel refused to cooperate, is expected to serve as the foundation for the Palestinian case against Israel in the international criminal court, which is due to be submitted on 25 June. Israel‚Äôs report highlights efforts by the IDF to avoid harm to civilians and presents the operation as an ‚Äúimperative necessity‚Äù in response to incessant rocket fire from Gaza and the threat of Hamas infiltrating through its tunnels. It states that the goals were ‚Äúrestoring security to Israeli civilians living under Hamas rocket fire‚Äù and ‚Äúdismantling the Hamas tunnel network used to infiltrate Israel‚Äù. The majority of the 250-page report is dedicated to showing Hamas‚Äôs human rights violations and war crimes. It holds Hamas responsible for many of the Palestinian civilian casualties caused by the IDF, arguing that they were unavoidable due to Hamas‚Äôs tactics of embedding militants among civilian populations, whether in homes, schools, mosques or UN buildings. A section is dedicated to Palestinian fatalities, which deals largely with what it claims are Hamas‚Äôs duplicitous numbers. According to the IDF, a total of 2,125 Palestinians were killed during the two-month war, 761 of them, or 36%, uninvolved civilians, including 369 children and 284 women. The UN figures are far higher, with at least 1,483 civilians killed (of a total of 2,205), of whom 521 are children and 283 are women. Binyamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, said the report presented ‚Äúthe true picture‚Äù of what happened in Gaza and that the IDF was committed to international law because ‚ÄúIsrael is a democracy and a moral country with values‚Äù. He added: ‚ÄúWhoever wants to automatically ‚Äì and without foundation ‚Äì blame Israel, let them waste their time with the UN Human Rights Council report.‚Äù Hamas spokesman Sami Abu Zuhri rejected the report, saying ‚ÄúIsraeli war crimes are clear because they were committed in front of live cameras,‚Äù Reuters reported. The Palestinian Authority also rejected the report. ‚ÄúIsrael‚Äôs decision to deny having targeted civilians in Gaza is the logical extension of what it did in the Gaza Strip,‚Äù Ihab Bseiso, a government representative, told AFP.

column4: Art of diplomacy: how French schools abroad cope with censorship
column5:
It is one of the great allegorical paintings celebrating the French revolution: Liberty Leading the People, by Eug√®ne Delacroix, shows a barefoot, bare-breasted woman ‚Äì representing Marianne, the female symbol of the republic ‚Äì brandishing a tricolour in one hand and a bayonetted musket in the other, leading the people over the bodies of the fallen. Pupils at the French Lyc√©e in Kuwait, however, might be forgiven for missing the symbolism of the celebrated work of art used to illustrate their history books after local censors slapped a large red sticker over the robust goddess Liberty. A few pages on, another allegorical revolutionary painting, La V√©rit√© Am√®ne la R√©publique et l‚ÄôAbondance (Truth Bringing the Republic and Abundance) by Nicolas de Courteille, has been given a similar dressing down ‚Äì or dressing up ‚Äì with another judiciously placed sticker.
Pupils opening their science books to the chapter, ‚Äútransformations linked to puberty‚Äù and ‚Äúhow the female reproductive organs work‚Äù will find the human bodies crudely effaced with a black felt-tipped pen and illustrations of reproducing animals scribbled over. Drawings of the male anatomy have not been defaced, though. France‚Äôs ministry of education, which is responsible for ensuring all schools study the same approved list of text books, insisted there was nothing it could do. ‚ÄúAll French establishments abroad are subject to the laws of the countries in which they are established, unlike embassies and consulates, ‚Äú a spokesperson told Le Monde. ‚ÄúObviously they have to work with the social and political reality of each country. There‚Äôs no obligation to use the textbooks that are just there to support the work of the teachers.‚Äù The wielders of the black pens came from somewhere within the ministry of education in Kuwait City, the paper said. The French Lyc√©e in Kuwait City opened in 1988 and has 1,350 pupils, about 13% of them French, and the rest either local children or the children of expats of various nationalities. It is a private school that comes under the foreign and education ministries in Paris and is regarded as an official ‚Äúpartner establishment‚Äù. Under article 2 of French regulations, such educational establishments must offer teaching ‚Äúsimilar to that offered in France in a state school‚Äù. However, the lyc√©e‚Äôs internal regulations clearly state it is subject to Kuwaiti law. Peter Gumbel, a writer on education and a professor at Paris‚Äôs prestigious Institut d‚Äôetudes Politiques, known as Sciences Po, admitted the censorship was surprising in the wake of the rush to uphold republican values after the January attacks on Charlie Hebdo newspaper and a Jewish supermarket in Paris.
However, he said it was part of France‚Äôs realpolitik approach to foreign policy. ‚ÄúThe French do this kind of soft diplomacy through schools and culture very well. It‚Äôs a grotesque irony that after Charlie Hebdo and the defiant call for repbulican values and standing up for freedom, but it‚Äôs a classic clash of different interests and the foreign office has clearly won this battle.‚Äù Delacroix‚Äôs painting, which hangs in the Louvre, is credited with influencing Victor Hugo‚Äôs novel Les Mis√©rables and inspiring the Statue of Liberty, a gift from the French to New York. The Louvre, which is due to open a ‚Ç¨500m (¬£362m) museum in the United Arab Emirates capital, Abu Dhabi, in December, is expected to face similar problems from the country‚Äôs conservative authorities.
However, museum officials insist the UAE has not censored any nudity or religious symbolism in the works going on display. These include a Jewish Torah from Yemen, an ancient Hindu statue, a Buddha and works evoking African animism, according to art experts. ‚ÄúNo work has been refused,‚Äù a source told AFP Sophie Grange, a spokeswoman for the Louvre, insisted the Abu Dhabi museum was not simply a branch of the French museum but independent and it was up to the UAE to decide what was put on display. Titian‚Äôs fully-clothed but voluptuous Woman with a Mirror will be among the paintings sent to Abu Dhabi from the Paris Louvre. The emirati museum has also acquired an unseen portrait by Pablo Picasso called Portrait of a Lady, that is unlikely to raise any embarrassed eyebrows. Art and the censors: recent battles In September last year, the UN criticised the US for ‚Äúwidespread censorship‚Äù in prisons and schools, revealing that books containing the work of C√©zanne, Picasso and Van Gogh, among many others, are banned from Texan state prisons for containing ‚Äúsexually explicit images‚Äù. In May, a local Fox news station in the US was accused of being ‚Äùsexually sick‚Äù by art critics after blurring the breasts in Pablo Picasso‚Äôs cubist painting Women of Algiers, when reporting its record-breaking sale. Also in May, western authors were warned about the censorship of politically and sexuality sensitive subjects in Chinese translations of their work, with the Pen American Centre reporting that many of the expurgations currently occur without the author‚Äôs knowledge.

column4: Bilderberg 2015: TTIP and a travesty of transparency
column5:
Weaving down the alp came the Bilderbus, taking delegates on a whistlestop tour of the Tyrol. Buzzing along above it, at a crazy height, was its helicopter escort. I swear I could have bounced a euro off the roof of the coach and into the blades. If I‚Äôd wanted to have been dropped by an NSA sniper. In the coach below it must have been like being in a washing machine. No wonder the delegates on board looked grumpy. Sitting up front, Jessica T Mathews had a face like thunder. Although maybe the cause of her headache wasn‚Äôt the helicopter, but rather the howling contradiction of being on the steering committee of the world‚Äôs most secretive policy summit and also on the advisory council of Transparency International USA.Also on the bus was James Wolfensohn. A fellow member of TI-USA‚Äôs advisory council, Wolfensohn was the joint winner of their 2014 ‚Äúintegrity award‚Äù, an honour he shared with that other famous transparency campaigner, and the world‚Äôs fourth-biggest arms company, Raytheon. Previous winners of the integrity award include (and I kid you not) Coca-Cola, General Electric and the then secretary of state Hillary Rodham Clinton. The great email deleter herself. I think someone should tell TI-USA what ‚Äútransparency‚Äù means. There may have been a mix-up somewhere down the line. When it comes to transparency, this year‚Äôs Bilderberg summit fails in every way imaginable. Three prime ministers, two foreign ministers, one president, no press conference. No public oversight. Just a bunch of senior policymakers locked away for three days with some incredibly powerful corporate lobbyists, discussing subjects intimately related to public policy. Subjects such as ‚Äúglobalisation‚Äù and ‚Äúcurrent economic issues‚Äù, which in practical terms mean the giant trade deal, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). Writhing around the issue of TTIP is an unholy knot of politicians and vested interests, their tails knotted together in the pitch black of an Austrian sewer. I‚Äôm going to put on some gloves, stick a clothes peg on my nose, and see if I can tease apart one corner of this filthy interconnected mass. Here goes. First, I‚Äôll pick a policymaker: how about Mikael Damberg? He‚Äôs the Swedish minister for enterprise and innovation, and 2015 is his first time round the table at Bilderberg. Sliding on to the chair next to him is Carola Lemne, the chief executive of the Confederation of Swedish Enterprise. This lobby group describes itself as ‚ÄúSweden‚Äôs largest and most influential business federation‚Äù, and it‚Äôs extremely in favour of TTIP. As its website says: ‚ÄúSince 2007, the Confederation of Swedish Enterprise has worked actively to promote the success of these negotiations‚Äù. Cosying up on the other side of Damberg is the chairman of Volvo, Swedish businessman Carl-Henric Svanberg. His company is a strong supporter of TTIP. Just last year, the official Twitter account of the Volvo Group tweeted: ‚ÄúA comprehensive ‚Ä™#TTIP agreement would reduce regulatory and trade barriers and boost US competitiveness.‚Äù Damberg is trapped by Swedes. He slithers down under the table to try to make his escape. But there in the half-light he meets Swedish billionaire Jacob Wallenberg, the chairman of the industrial conglomerate Investor AB. Wallenberg was quoted by the US embassy in Sweden at the end of last year as saying: ‚Äú‚Ä™TTIP is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. With a strong agreement consumers will be the beneficiaries.‚Äù Lobbyist, company chairman, billionaire investor: a close-harmony chorus of influence pushing policy behind closed doors. And the chorus gets louder: Wallenberg and Svanberg, along with five fellow Bilderberg participants, are members of the influential European Round Table of Industrialists. And the ERT is a member of ‚Äúthe European Business Alliance for TTIP‚Äù. Layer upon layer of lobbying. And this is still just a fraction of the big business pro-TTIP influence at Bilderberg. And all of it happening behind closed doors: out of sight of a disenchanted, disenfranchised electorate, 500 of whom gathered in the centre of Telfs on Saturday to protest against the way Bilderberg does business.
‚ÄúPublic representants: let us know what‚Äôs going on,‚Äù implored one placard. ‚ÄúStopps silents,‚Äù urged another. There was anger everywhere at the how elected politicians had tucked themselves away like this with big business. I spoke to Ursel Herbst, who had driven all the way from Cologne for this demonstration. ‚ÄúThe way Bilderberg hide is stupid, like naughty children.‚Äù She smiled a tired smile. ‚ÄúI do not respect them.‚Äù It‚Äôs ironic that the Bilderberg conference puts on such a show of power: taking over an alp for a ‚Äúprivate meeting‚Äù, closing down the airspace, shutting roads, hovering helicopters over their buses ... and yet the net result is they come across as a bunch of naughty kids. They‚Äôll just have to console themselves with exerting a huge influence on large swaths of transatlantic policy. It may not be much but it‚Äôs something.

column4: Israeli artists protest against 'anti-democratic' government
column5: More than 2,000 Israeli artists have signed a petition warning against what they call anti-democratic measures being taken by the government against freedom of expression. The petition, which includes the signatures of prominent figures from film, theatre, cinema, dance, literature and music, claims artists are being silenced for views that do not fall in line with those espoused by the new government‚Äôs ministers. ‚ÄúWe, the signatories below, are the voices you are trying to silence. We hope that Israel will not deteriorate into a country in which artists that express their views are put on a ‚Äòblack list‚Äô.‚Äù The petition was launched after the newly installed minister of culture and sport, Miri Regev, announced she would re-examine the criteria for state funding of the arts. At a meeting with representatives of cultural institutions on Thursday, Regev said that because her Likud party had received 30 seats in the Knesset [parliament], she had the legitimacy to decide how to allocate the funds. ‚ÄúI decide the criteria; I can decide which institutions get money,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe government doesn‚Äôt have to support culture. I can decide where the money goes. The artists will not dictate to me.‚Äù A day earlier, Regev threatened to cut government funding for the Elmina Theater in Jaffa because its manager, the Israeli-Arab actor Norman Issa, refused to perform in a settlement in the Jordan Valley with the Haifa Theater troupe of which he is a member. The petition was also a response to last week‚Äôs decision by the education minister, Naftali Bennett, to stop performances for high-school students of a play by the al-Midan Theater in Haifa entitled A Parallel Of Time, which tells the story of Walid Daka‚Äôs time in prison for torturing and murdering the Israeli soldier Moshe Tamam in 1984. ‚ÄúThe question here is whether the ministry of education in Israel should pay for schoolchildren to go see a play that shows sympathy to a murderer and a terrorist,‚Äù Bennett told the Associated Press, adding, ‚Äúand my answer is no.‚Äù Responding to the petition on Sunday, Regev said ‚ÄúThe signatories do not know me. It‚Äôs a bit uncivilised to make frightening statements about potential McCarthyism that are entirely baseless.‚Äù Supporters of Regev and Bennett claim that Israelis should have the freedom to create art as they please, but if it is disparaging to the state, there is no reason why it should be state-funded. Among the signatories on the petition are the actor Gila Almagor, dancer, choreographer and BatSheva Dance Company artistic director Ohad Naharin and author Yehonatan Gefen.

column4: Zoo animals on the loose and deaths feared after Georgia floods
column5:
Tigers, lions, wolves and bears are feared to be still on the loose in Georgia‚Äôs capital, amid chaotic scenes brought by devastating floods that have reportedly killed 12 people. Images of an escaped hippopotamus being cornered in one of Tbilisi‚Äôs main squares after escaping from the city‚Äôs zoo have emerged, while other animals have been killed or remain at large.
Heavy rainfall turned the Vere river ‚Äì which flows through the capital ‚Äì into a torrent that swept away dozens of buildings and cars. At least 12 people have been killed, according to news agencies, while others are missing. The army has been mobilised to help. ‚ÄúThe damage is substantial,‚Äù the prime minister, Irakli Garibashvili, told reporters. He also called on residents to stay at home as the search for the animals continued.
Carcasses of wild animals that have been shot dead litter the streets and tangled heaps of wreckage scar a large area around Tbilisi‚Äôs zoo after Saturday night‚Äôs flash flood. The zoo itself has been almost totally destroyed, says its director, with most of its animals either drowned or shot after escaping. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an unbelievable tragedy,‚Äù said Zura Gurielidze as he surveyed his stricken zoo park. Three of his staff were among those reported dead in the disaster. Among them was 56-year-old Guliko Chitadze, who was attacked by one of the zoo‚Äôs tigers last month and lost an arm. She had just returned to work, telling fellow staff she did not blame the tiger for what happened. She lived in the zoo grounds with her husband, who died with her. The escaped hippo was cornered in one of the city‚Äôs main squares on Sunday and subdued with a tranquilliser gun, the zoo said. Some other animals also have been seized, but it remained unclear how many were still on the loose.
Police with rifles were still combing the tree-covered hills above the zoo looking for the escaped animals as the remains of a hyena shot dead lay in the nearby grounds of Tbilisi State University. It had chased one of the staff, according to a police officer, who then locked himself in a shed and called for help. There are also reports of people using their hunting rifles to shoot animals they see, and Gurielidze appealed for them not to, in case they could be saved. There were no immediate reports that any of the other fatalities were due to animal attacks. Among the biggest tragedies for the zoo is the loss of a rare white lion called Shumba. It had become one of the zoo‚Äôs biggest attractions after they paired it with a dog to keep it company, after Shumba‚Äôs mother stopped caring for him. They became friends and could be seen playing and sleeping together right outside the zoo‚Äôs main offices. Images on Tbilisi city hall‚Äôs Facebook page showed roads submerged by floodwater and landslides with many vehicles washed away, while rescue workers carried people on their shoulders through waist-high water. Such heavy rain is unusual for this time of year. But many say uncontrolled development in the area made things worse, with the drainage system overwhelmed. The zoo, situated at the bottom of a valley in the city, was right in the target of line of the surge of water that resulted. The head of Georgia‚Äôs Orthodox church, Patriarch Ilia II, said the flood was punishment for the zoo being built by the country‚Äôs former communist rulers. ‚ÄúThey ordered that all the crosses and bells in churches be melted down and the money used to build the zoo,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI am very sorry that Georgians fell so that a zoo was built at the expense of destroyed churches.‚Äù

column4: Climate activists leave Tate Modern after all-night protest against BP
column5:
Climate activists have left the Tate Modern‚Äôs Turbine Hall after an unauthorised all-night performance lambasting BP‚Äôs sponsorship of the gallery. On Saturday night, protesters from Liberate Tate faced down officials who had threatened to call the police if they did not leave when the museum closed at 10pm.
The Tate‚Äôs head of safety, Dennis Ahern, addressed the group along with a member of the Metropolitan police. He said the gallery respected the British right to protest but warned them: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got a duty of care to make sure members of the public leave the licensed premises at the time of closing‚Äù. If the activists did not leave, he said the gallery may ask the police to step in. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a back-down,‚Äù said Mel Evans, a Liberate Tate activist and author of Artwash: Big Oil and the Arts, after it became clear the protesters would be allowed to spend the night inside the hall. ‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôs a sign of how much the groundswell of public opinion has shifted that the Tate doesn‚Äôt feel like they can shut down this discussion.‚Äù The group spent 25 hours scrawling words of warning about climate change in charcoal on the sloping floor of the hall. They brought with them sleeping bags, food and even a toilet, which they placed behind a bamboo frame and curtain. They left at 1pm on Sunday. Thousands of visitors to the Tate filed past the protest on Saturday as if it was another work at the prestigious gallery, but on Sunday officials closed the Turbine Hall to the public. Liberate Tate have staged 14 protest performances since 2010 calling on the Tate to ditch its deal with BP, which is worth around ¬£224,000 a year.

column4: Chinese police 'find suicide note' in case of 'left behind' children deaths
column5:
Police investigating the deaths of four Chinese children who drank pesticide after being abandoned by their migrant worker parents say they have found a suicide note near the eldest victim‚Äôs body. ‚ÄúThanks for your kindness. I know you mean well for us, but we should go now,‚Äù the note said, according to the state-run China News Service. The four siblings, a boy and three girls aged five to 14, were found dead on Tuesday at their home in a rural village outside the city of Bijie in Guizhou, one of China‚Äôs poorest provinces.
