He was a disturbed boy with mental health issues that his father admitted were never addressed. Young Jake craved attention, had wild rages and attacked his parents with weapons such as scissors. A highly intelligent maths whizz, he found school life an agonising social humiliation. He was horribly bullied and friendless. Capsized emotionally by the death of his mother, he converted to Islam. Bilardi wrote a political blog. His extremism grew. So did his paranoia. One post tells how, sitting in his living room, he looked at his brothers and thought they might kill him. He dropped out of school and isolated himself, but, via the internet, developed new attachments, to a world far away, to an ideal of earthly perfection, the caliphate run by Isis.
Ideology has the capacity to make a butterfly out of a grub. Bilardi managed to find moral perfection in beheadings, sexual slavery and attacks on priceless artefacts from the past. In Isis he would find true ‚Äúbrothers‚Äù who would value him, whom he could impress with his willingness to die, such as the burly jihadists flanking him in that photograph. In Bilardi‚Äôs manifesto, From Melbourne to Ramadi, Australia was condemned as ‚Äúa land full of such filth and corruption that no one in their right mind could live there without a craving to let some heads roll‚Äù. A picture of people shopping is captioned: ‚ÄúThe talking pigs of Melbourne, Australia, in their sty ‚Ä¶‚Äù Dehumanised as pigs, his fellow Australians could be slaughtered. Stockpiled in his Craigieburn home were the ingredients for a bomb. His manifesto told of plan B: ‚ÄúLaunching a string of bombings across Melbourne, targeting foreign consulates and political/military targets, as well as grenade and knife attacks on shopping centres and cafes and culminating with myself detonating a belt of explosives amongst the Kuffar.‚Äù This painfully shy, anxious boy, rejected, taunted and bullied, finally felt he had found his place in the world, part of a glorious struggle that promised him a heroic identity and spiritual immortality as a suicide bomber in Iraq. He described driving into Aleppo, and feeling utterly elated when he saw the Isis black flag flying high. After his death, he was no longer invisible, but infamous, acquiring another kind of immortality. Christopher Lasch wrote in The Culture of Narcissism of how the ‚Äúsociety of the spectacle‚Äù encourages the desire to have one‚Äôs life recorded and transmitted to an unseen audience: ‚ÄúThe prevailing conditions thus brought out narcissistic personality traits that were present in everyone.‚Äù And especially, one might add, in mass killers and jihadists. Fame is not just about being known. It is a fast route to high status and social dominance. Fame delivers the illusion that you matter more than other people. One of the Charlie Hebdo killers, Cherif Kouachi, originally sought to escape his life of petty crime and poverty by becoming a famous rapper. He sought a very western form of fame, and failed, before gaining it by launching an attack on the west.
Fame played a part too for Mohammed Emwazi, the British man now known as ‚ÄúJihadi John‚Äù. Formerly an obscure London lad with modest prospects, he is now a new human type, the celebrity beheader. Stern says: ‚ÄúSome experience a different kind of high: they like weapons and they like to kill, and they would do so for almost any reason.‚Äù The only real clue we have to the mystery of Emwazi is his violent, rage-filled outbursts as a youngster. On joining Isis, however, the sadism that Kernberg warns of in malignant narcissism becomes clear, in the evident pleasure with which he kills aid workers and journalists, and in the exultant torture he metes out beforehand. ‚ÄúFeel it? Cold, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Emwazi said to freed Spanish journalist Javier Espinosa, holding a blade to his neck. ‚ÄúCan you imagine the pain you‚Äôll feel when it cuts?‚Äù He describes in horrific detail each stage of the beheading; ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen it before, you all squirm like animals, like pigs. The third blow will take off your head. I‚Äôd put it on your back.‚Äù As justly reviled as he is by many, Emwazi is idolised by Isis recruits as the personification of jihadi cool. Such killers get fans. Breivik complains from prison about the ‚Äúhuman rights abuses‚Äù of being given old versions of PlayStation, while his fans send him his favourite perfume, Chanel Egoiste, also the favourite brand of Isis commander Abou Bilel. Such killers may speak as if they are acting piously under the eye of an all-powerful God, but they actually act with a sharp, greedy eye for their audience of human peers. Getting a narcissistic hit of attention is indissolubly part of what Jessica Stern and JM Berger, authors of new book Isis: The State of Terror call the appeal of ‚Äúthe crack cocaine of violent extremism, all the elements that make it so alluring and so addictive purified into a crystallised form.‚Äù Understanding that truth, repugnant as it is, will have to be a part of any effective programme of counter-terrorism. ‚Ä¢ Anne Manne‚Äôs book, The Life of I: The New Culture of Narcissism, is published by Melbourne University Press and available on Kindle.

column4: Hungarian activists arrested for defacing anti-immigration billboard
column5: Activists in Hungary have been arrested after defacing government billboards which warned immigrants not to take Hungarians‚Äô jobs. The six people arrested are from the Egy√ºtt (Together) opposition party. Police said that five of the six had admitted responsibility for the vandalism and had been released. The posters targeted by the activists were on display in central Budapest and said: ‚ÄúIf you come to Hungary, you cannot take the jobs of Hungarians.‚Äù Hungary‚Äôs government, led by the prime minister, Viktor Orb√°n, and his rightwing Fidesz party, recently launched a national consultation on ‚Äúimmigration and terrorism‚Äù. A series of anti-immigration posters were put up as part of the campaign. As well as cautioning against taking Hungarians‚Äô jobs, the posters demand newcomers to Hungary respect the nation‚Äôs culture and laws. A questionnaire sent to Hungarian voters as part of the consultation appears to connect migration with terrorism, as well as floating the idea of putting all illegal immigrants into internment camps. Last month, Orban, who has ruled Hungary since 2010, described the EU‚Äôs quotas for taking in asylum-seekers as ‚Äúbordering on insanity‚Äù. In response, the EU commission‚Äôs vice president, Frans Timmersmans, condemned Orban‚Äôs questionnaire as ‚Äúmalicious and wrong‚Äù. On Tuesday Orban hit out again, suggesting that mass migration into the EU would amount to the end of Christian Europe and ‚Äúchange the face of Europe‚Äôs civilisation‚Äù. Fidesz has recently been losing ground to the far-right Jobbik party, which is thought to have prompted the government‚Äôs recent anti-immigration push. Orban has also suggested Hungary might consider reintroducing the death penalty, which was abolished following the fall of communism in 1989, again prompting fierce criticism from Brussels.

column4: Turkey election: ruling party loses majority as pro-Kurdish HDP gains seats
column5:
Turkey‚Äôs president, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, has suffered his biggest setback in 13 years of amassing power as voters denied his ruling party a parliamentary majority for the first time since 2002 and gave the country‚Äôs large Kurdish minority its biggest voice ever in national politics. The election result on Sunday, with almost all votes counted, appeared to wreck Erdoƒüan‚Äôs ambition of rewriting the constitution to establish himself as an all-powerful executive president. Erdoƒüan‚Äôs governing Justice and Development party, or AKP, won the election comfortably for the fourth time in a row, with around 41% of the vote, but that represented a steep fall in support from 49% in 2011, throwing the government of the country into great uncertainty.
The vote was the first time in four general elections that support for Erdoƒüan decreased. The fall coupled with an election triumph for a new pro-Kurdish party meant it was unlikely that the AKP would be able to form a majority government, forcing it to negotiate a coalition, probably with extreme nationalists, or to call a fresh election if no parliamentary majority can be secured within six weeks. The new party, the HDP or Peoples‚Äô Democratic party, largely representing the Kurds but also encompassing leftwing liberals, surpassed the steep 10% threshold for entering parliament to take more than 12% of the vote and around 80 seats in the 550-strong chamber. The HDP victory denied Erdoƒüan‚Äôs party its majority. Erdoƒüan campaigned to secure a minimum of 330 seats in the parliament, a three-fifths majority that would have enabled him to call a referendum on the constitution with a view to converting Turkey into a presidential rather than a parliamentary system. But the AKP appeared unlikely to muster even a simple 276-seat majority.
‚ÄúWe expect a minority government and an early election,‚Äù a senior AKP official told Reuters. The prime minister and nominal head of the AK party, Ahmet Davutoglu, had promised to resign if he failed to obtain a simple parliamentary majority. With internal dissent rumbling in recent weeks within the government ranks and at the top of the AKP, the poor result for Erdoƒüan is likely to embolden dissenters and could spark a power stuggle. The atmosphere outside the AKP‚Äôs headquarters in Ankara was muted. Several hundred supporters chanted for Erdoƒüan, the party‚Äôs founder, but there was little sign of the huge crowds that gathered after past election victories. In the conservative district of Tophane, an AKP stronghold in Istanbul, only a couple of men were sitting in a local teahouse to follow Davutoglu‚Äôs balcony speech. ‚ÄúI am not unhappy,‚Äù, said Nusret Aksoy, 50. ‚ÄúThe AKP came out the strongest party by far.‚Äù Pointing at the TV screen, he added: ‚ÄúLook, do these crowds seem unhappy to you? They are not. These elections were good and democratic.‚Äù
He added that he was satisfied that the HDP managed to get into parliament: ‚ÄúThe people gave them a chance to prove themselves. Now they have to show everyone what they are really made of, that they are not just talking, but also capable of delivering.‚Äù By contrast, thousands of jubilant Kurds flooded the streets of the south-eastern city of Diyarbakir as the results came in. Erdoƒüan had repeatedly lashed out at the HDP and its charismatic leader, Selahattin Demirta≈ü, before the election. Demirta≈ü promptly ruled out a coalition with the AKP. ‚ÄúThis result shows that this country has had enough. Enough of Erdoƒüan and his anger,‚Äù said Seyran Demir, a 47-year-old housewife who was among the thousands who gathered in the streets around the HDP‚Äôs provincial headquarters. ‚ÄúI am so full of joy that I can‚Äôt speak properly.‚Äù In Istanbul, enthused crowds chanted ‚Äúwe are the HDP, we will be in parliment‚Äù outside the press conference Demirta≈ü held in Istanbul on Sunday night. ‚ÄúI am so happy,‚Äù said B√ºlent Aras, 40. ‚ÄúThis means that there will be peace, the war is over. This party represents everyone. We will finally all be equal in Turkey. This will put an end to the corruption.‚Äù He added that he was not surprised about the results. ‚ÄúWe expected to do well. It was time for change.‚Äù ‚ÄúI had hoped for this to happen,‚Äù said 61-year-old painter Mehmet Hakki Sabancali. ‚ÄúI was so nervous that the HDP might not get 10%. This rings in a new Turkey. The HDP will do away with old taboos: with LBGT rights, gay marriage, conscientious objection and non-Muslim minorities.‚Äù As head of state since last August following a triple term as prime minister, Erdoƒüan was not on the ballot. But the election was, in effect, a referendum on whether to give his office extraordinary powers that would significantly change Turkish democracy and prolong his reign as the country‚Äôs most powerful politician.
Voters roundly rejected that ambition, with the Kurdish vote in particular swinging the election against the incumbents on an unprecedented scale. The 10% hurdle, dating from the military-authored constitution of 1980, had been intended in part to diminish Kurdish representation in the parliament. The HDP gambled on breaking the built-in disadvantage and triumphed. If it had fallen short of 10%, it would have forfeited all seats. Erdoƒüan‚Äôs divide-and-rule strategy of rallying his religious-conservative base has led to increasing polarisation in Turkey, and in some cases to violence. In the runup to the election, the HDP reported more than 70 attacks on election offices and campaigners across the country. On Friday, two bombs exploded at an election rally in Diyarbakir, killing three and wounding hundreds of others. Official results based on 99.9% of votes counted gave the AKP 41%, followed by the Republican People‚Äôs party (CHP) on 25%, the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) on 16.5% and the HDP in fourth place with 13%. Turnout was at 86%.
‚ÄúThis is the end of identity politics in Turkey,‚Äù said Gencer √ñzcan, professor for international relations at Bilgi University in Istanbul. ‚ÄúThe election threshold is not the only barrier that was overcome tonight in the elections, but also emotional and identity barriers have been breached. This is a golden opportunity for the HDP. Voters in Turkey endorse democracy in Turkey across identity boundaries.‚Äù The HDP ran on a platform defending the rights of ethnic minorities, women, and lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. In a polling station in the predominantly Kurdish suburb of Dolapdere in Istanbul, Hacer Dinler, 25, said that she had high hopes for the HDP. ‚ÄúIf they make it into parliament, everything will be better,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe will have more MPs to speak for us, which in turn will strengthen the peace process.‚Äù The HDP success marked a sea-change likely to have a big impact on national politics. Shackled by the high threshold, pro-Kurdish candidates had previously run as independents in single seats to try to beat the 10% party barrier. But the HDP also successfully sought to reach beyond Turkey‚Äôs roughly 20% Kurdish population, attempting to woo centre-left and secular voters disillusioned with Erdoƒüan.
‚ÄúThe reason the HDP has won this many votes is because it has not excluded any members of this country, unlike our current rulers,‚Äù said 25-year-old Siar Senci. ‚ÄúIt has embraced all languages, all ethnicities and members of all faiths and promised them freedom.‚Äù The secularist Republican People‚Äôs party will be the second biggest group in parliament. Murat Karayal√ßin, the party‚Äôs Istanbul chairman, said the outcome was a ‚Äúclear no‚Äù to the executive presidential system championed by Erdoƒüan. The rightwing MHP, long seen as the AKP‚Äôs most likely partner if it tried to form a coalition government, took close to 17% of the vote. The deputy chairman, Oktay Vural, said on Sunday it was too early for him to say whether it would consider forming a coalition government with the AKP. ‚ÄúIt would be wrong for me to make an assessment about a coalition, our party will assess that in the coming period. I think the AK party will be making its own new evaluations after this outcome,‚Äù Vural said. The high stakes of this year‚Äôs parliamentary elections mobilised a large majority of the population to vote. Aliye Goga, 39, a woman of Armenian descent, said it was the first time she had voted. ‚ÄúI just never saw the point before,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúNow my eyes have opened up. The HDP is the only party for women in this country, and they make realistic promises.‚Äù Leyla √áelik, 38, a part-time student voting in Istanbul‚Äôs conservative Fatih district, hoped the AKP would continue in power. ‚ÄúThis government has exceeded all my expectations. We have good healthcare, and women can go to school and university with a headscarf. They are a party that treats us like human beings.‚Äù

column4: Bee forces Flybe flight BE384 to turn back to Southampton
column5: An aeroplane flown by airline Flybe heading to Dublin was forced to turn back after a bee became lodged inside its instruments. The insect flew into one of the instruments on the outside of the jet shortly after it took off from Southampton on Friday. The pilots, spotting the technical issue, turned the plane around and landed without difficulty, a Flybe spokeswoman confirmed. After the passengers had disembarked, engineers checked the plane from flight BE384 and discovered the rogue bee causing the problem. The spokeswoman said that Flybe was sorry for delaying their customers but added that the airline had to ensure all their planes were safe. It is not the first time bees have affected aircraft. Last year, a swarm of the flying insects clouded the cockpit windows of a domestic flight in the United States and began being sucked into the aircraft‚Äôs engines. The pilots returned the aircraft to the ground safely, but passengers told local media the plane was filled with a burning smell. Wasps were at fault for an air tragedy 20 years earlier in the Dominican Republic. A Boeing 757 carrying 189 people crashed five minutes after taking off in February 1996 because the pitot tube ‚Äì which measures the speed of an aeroplane ‚Äì had become blocked by a wasps nest. Confused by the incorrect airspeed readings, the pilot accidentally stalled the plane before it went into a spin and crashed into the sea, killing all on board.

column4: Juncker vents fury over Greek bailout talks at G7 summit
column5: European Union officials delivered a blistering attack on the Greek government at the G7 summit in Bavaria, and world leaders including Barack Obama sought to avoid a transatlantic split over Ukraine by agreeing to maintain sanctions against Russia. In a day of secluded talks in the Alpine resort of Schloss Elmau, the biggest drama was provided by a verbal attack on the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, by the European commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker. The summit‚Äôs host, Angela Merkel, had hoped to solve the Greek bailout crisis before the summit, but instead Juncker felt forced to open proceedings by staging a press conference accusing Tsipras of undermining negotiations over new terms for a bailout and of effectively lying to the Greek parliament. A visibly angry Juncker said he had told Tsipras during a meeting last Wednesday evening that there was room to negotiate but said the Greeks had been unwilling to take part in in-depth discussions at the meeting. Instead, he said, Tsipras had promised to send him his proposals the following day, but he was still waiting for them on Sunday. ‚ÄúAlexis Tsipras promised that by Thursday evening he would present a second proposal. Then he said he would present it on Friday. And then he said he would call on Saturday. But I have never received that proposal, so I hope I will receive it soon. I would like to have that Greek proposal,‚Äù he said. He told reporters he had said to Tsipras that he continued to exclude the idea of a Grexit ‚Äì ‚Äúbecause I don‚Äôt want to see it‚Äù ‚Äì but that he could not ‚Äúpull a rabbit out of a hat‚Äù. Athens has been trying to secure an agreement from Europe and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for months for access to more than ‚Ç¨7bn in bailout funds. Greece‚Äôs creditors have put strict conditions on any deal, which the Greek government has so far refused to accept. But with Greece running out of money and needing to secure funds by the end of June if it to avoid defaulting on its debts, tensions are high. Juncker, perceived until now as an honest broker in the crisis ‚Äì taking a softer approach than the Germans, who are viewed in Greece as the architects of austerity ‚Äì has rarely been seen in such an irate state, sources close to the EU in Garmisch-Partenkirchen said. They warned that Greece might have lost its closest ally in its long fight to secure a rosier deal. Juncker said he had been disappointed by a speech Tsipras had given to the Athens parliament on Friday. ‚ÄúHe was presenting the offer of the three institutions as a leave-or-take offer. That was not the case ‚Ä¶ He knows perfectly well that is not the case.‚Äù Juncker said Tsipras had failed to mention to parliament his (Juncker‚Äôs) willingness to negotiate over Greek pensions. He added: ‚ÄúI do not have a personal problem with Alexis Tsipras. He was my friend. He is my friend. But frankly, in order to maintain [the friendship], he has to observe some minimum rules.‚Äù Tsipras is due to attend a meeting of European Union and Latin American leaders on Wednesday and Thursday, when Merkel and Fran√ßois Hollande will also be present. Obama underlined his personal determination to see the euro crisis solved after talks on Sunday morning with Merkel. The prolonged standoff predominantly between Germany and Greece is said to be slowing the return to growth, but Obama is siding with the Germans over the need for the Greek government to do more to co-operate. In return, the White House won German support to maintain sanctions against Russia over Ukraine. It issued a statement saying: ‚ÄúThe duration of sanctions should be clearly linked to Russia‚Äôs full implementation of the Minsk agreements and respect for Ukraine‚Äôs sovereignty.‚Äù Germany, Britain and the US want an agreement to offer support to any EU member state tempted to withdraw backing for the sanctions on Moscow, which they say are hurting the Russian economy. Last September‚Äôs Minsk accord involving Russia, pro-Russia rebels and the Ukrainian government included the establishment of a 30km (19-mile) buffer zone between the two sides. However, fighting has intensified in recent weeks. The president of the EU‚Äôs council of ministers, Donald Tusk, signalled a toughening of sanctions in a statement at the G7. ‚ÄúIf anyone wants to start a debate about changing the sanctions regime, the discussion could only be about strengthening it,‚Äù he said. Antagonism towards Russia, until last year a member of the club of leading industrialised nations, is probably strongest among the G7 in Canada. Stephen Harper, the Canadian prime minister, said: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think Russia under Vladimir Putin belongs in the G7. Period. Canada would very, very strongly oppose Putin ever sitting around that table again. It would require consensus to bring Russia back and that consensus will just not happen. ‚ÄúRussia is more often than not trying deliberately to be a strategic rival, to deliberately counter the good things we‚Äôre trying to achieve in the world for no other reason than to just counter them.‚Äù He said the ‚Äúmindset of the guy we are dealing with is that the cold war has never ended and ‚ÄòI‚Äôve got to fight to change the ending somehow‚Äô‚Äù. Beyond Greece and Ukraine, Merkel wants to see progress on a free trade agreement and climate change, two of the staples of these summits. On Monday the G7 nations are expected to endorse the goal of November‚Äôs UN climate conference of limiting warming to 2C above pre-industrial levels. Obama has pledged to reduce US emissions by 26-28% from the 2005 baseline within the next 10 years and last year announced an unexpected agreement with China on capping carbon emission. More difficult than setting the 2C goal is turning promised donations to the Green Climate Fund, a United Nations initiative designed to help poorer countries limit their carbon emissions, into a reality. A 30 April deadline to convert $4.7bn in pledged assistance into specific payment timetables has been missed. In May Merkel and Hollande committed to a goal to cut global emissions by 60% from 2010 levels within the next 35 years. In both 2008 and 2009 the G7 agreed to a goal of 50%. An endorsement of the more aggressive target this time would be a win for the German chancellor. In Athens Mega TV reported that relations between Berlin and Washington over Greece had become increasingly frosty ‚Äì despite the exhortation from Barack Obama at the G7 for a quick solution to the European debt crisis. The Greek television channel, citing a senior German official, described the US treasury secretary, Jack Lew, imploring his German counterpart Wolfgang Sch√§uble to ‚Äúsupport Greece‚Äù only to be told: ‚ÄúGive ‚Ç¨50bn euro yourself to save Greece.‚Äù Mega‚Äôs Berlin-based correspondent told the stationthat the US official then said nothing ‚Äúbecause, as is always the case according to German officials when it comes to the issue of money, the Americans never say anything‚Äù. Meanwhile, negotiations between Greece and Berlin are expected to intensify Monday when the Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis meets Sch√§uble in the German capital. The Greek politician, who will be in Berlin to give a speech, requested the meeting late Friday and is expected to try and smooth over some of the fallout from what Athens‚Äô leftist-led government regards as ‚Äúincendiary‚Äù remarks by Juncker. ‚ÄúThe lenders are trying to rip Greece apart,‚Äù said the energy minister Panagiotis Lafazanis adding that while it was not the choice of the governing far left Syriza party to take the country out of the eurozone, neither could it allow ‚Äúthe extinction of Greece‚Äù within the eurozone.

column4: Turkish election outcome is blow to Erdoƒüan and breakthrough for Kurds
column5:
The mould-breaking outcome of Turkey‚Äôs general election on Sunday will be viewed as a personal rebuff for the president, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, and as a historic political breakthrough for the country‚Äôs 18 million-strong Kurdish minority, which will be represented by a political party in parliament for the first time. With 88% of votes counted, the ruling Justice and Development party (AKP), which Erdoƒüan helped to found, appeared to have lost its overall majority, falling just short of the 276 seats required for control of the 550-seat national assembly. Its share of the vote, at around 43%, was well down on the 49% it obtained in 2011. The AKP had aimed for a total of at least 330 seats, which would have enabled the government to hold a referendum on the constitutional changes that Erdoƒüan needs in order to create an executive presidency. Erdoƒüan personally travelled the country trying to boost the AKP vote. But concerns about a slowing economy, jobs, civil rights and a lack of progress in the Kurdish peace process appear to have combined with worries that Erdoƒüan could assume quasi-dictatorial powers to thwart the president‚Äôs ambitions. Erdoƒüan, a three-time prime minister who has wielded power since 2002, now faces the prospect of continuing in the largely ceremonial post of president, to which he was elected last year, while real executive power is in the hands of his protege Ahmet Davutoƒülu, the current prime minister. Parliamentary democracy in Turkey was also a big winner as the pro-Kurdish, secular centre-left grouping, the People‚Äôs Democratic party (HDP), appeared to slip past the mandatory 10% threshold for representation with about 11% of the vote. Projections suggested that total would translate into about 74 seats.
This result gives Turkey‚Äôs Kurds and the other voters who deserted the AKP and flocked to the HDP banner an unprecedented national platform from which to counter the neo-Islamist AKP‚Äôs assault on Turkey‚Äôs secular tradition, which has gathered pace in recent years. The peace process that followed the 2013 ceasefire with the Kurdistan Workers‚Äô party (PKK) may now also receive a much-needed shot in the arm, after a recent period of stalemate and sporadic violence. But much depends on how Erdoƒüan, still the most formidable figure in Turkish politics, reacts to this reverse. The president is not known as a good loser, and he is certainly unaccustomed to defeat. Rumours abounded before the polls that he was planning a new crackdown on journalists and other opponents who criticised him during the campaign. AKP officials spoke of holding another election if they were forced to form a minority government. Even by his shaky standards, Erdoƒüan‚Äôs behaviour during the campaign was exceptionally boorish. As president, he is expected to adopt a neutral stance. Instead, he barnstormed across the country holding rallies in support of the AKP. The results thus look like a very personal rejection. Erdoƒüan directed insults, accusations and threats at his political opponents, female activists, the media, non-Muslims, and ethnic and cultural minorities of all descriptions. Last week Erdoƒüan dismissed the HDP as a party of gay people and atheists, a description apparently designed to pander to the prejudices of the AKP‚Äôs largely poor, devoutly Muslim working class base. He suggested the HDP supported terrorism and was in league with the PKK. Erdoƒüan notably failed to condemn more than 70 reported violent attacks on the HDP‚Äôs candidates, rallies and offices. After bombs killed two people and wounded more than 200 at an HDP rally in Diyarbakir, in the mainly Kurdish south-east, on Friday, Selahattin Demirtas, the HDP leader, condemned Erdoƒüan‚Äôs silence. ‚ÄúHe should go to Diyarbakir. Is he not the president of 77 million people? He ought to leave flowers where people were killed,‚Äù Demirtas said in Istanbul. Erdoƒüan later offered condolences but said it was Demirtas who should apologise over Syria-related violence last October. Erdoƒüan has also been engaged in a vicious slanging match with opposition media, accusing reporters and commentators who criticise him of being part of a conspiracy to undermine Turkey. This is a familiar Erdoƒüan tactic. He often blames developments he dislikes on the so-called ‚Äúparallel state‚Äù supposedly made up of traitors, misfits and miscreants, more often than not in league with Fethullah G√ºlen, an exiled former ally and fellow Islamist with whom he is now involved in a long-running feud. But this time it seems the ruse didn‚Äôt work. Even allowing for the heightened emotions of a general election campaign, Erdoƒüan‚Äôs extreme behaviour has served to intensify doubts about his reliability and dependability both within Turkey and beyond. Turkey under Erdoƒüan has proved a most reluctant ally in the US-Nato fight against Islamic State. It has played a double game over Syria. Its EU accession talks are at a standstill after Erdoƒüan repeatedly insisted Turkey does not need Europe. Erdoƒüan has fallen out with regional leaders from Baghdad to Jerusalem to Cairo. Meanwhile, he has pursued closer ties with Vladimir Putin ‚Äì a man who, like him, has dictatorial tendencies. As Sunday‚Äôs results confirmed, Erdoƒüan had a bad campaign and was punished for it. His divisive behaviour was rejected by voters and rebounded on him. He emerges a weakened and diminished figure, with his reputation and influence much reduced.

column4: Nepal earthquake survivors get self-defence classes after sexual assaults
column5: Police in Nepal have started self-defence lessons for women and girls in camps for people displaced by massive earthquakes earlier this year after concerns about a number of sexual assaults and an increase in reports of sexual harassment. More than 8,700 people died in the two major quakes that hit Nepal on April 25 and May 12, destroying nearly half a million houses and leaving thousands camping out in the open. ‚ÄúWhile visiting different camps in Kathmandu, we realised the need for such training so that women can protect themselves,‚Äù said Tara Thapa, deputy superintendent of police in Nepal. ‚ÄúWomen and children are more vulnerable to sexual violence in this situation. The culprits are looking to take benefits of the situation.‚Äù The courses started last week. ‚ÄúWe are teaching them several techniques, including how to kick and punch, as well as various locks. There are some lessons of judo and karate, too,‚Äù Thapa said. ‚ÄúEven a weak woman can fight against a strong man. This will help them to save themselves.‚Äù Bipana Tamang, 24, was one of dozens of women who had gathered at the Boudhanath monastery in Kathmandu for training. From Nuwakot district near Kathmandu, she has been living outside since the earthquake and runs a small restaurant. ‚ÄúI have faced many cases of harassment while dealing with the customers. These techniques will help me to tackle such problems,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis is the third day and I have learnt how to punch and to kick. Now, I am confident I can fight to save myself.‚Äù Narayan Singh Khadka, a Kathmandu metropolitan police spokesman, said the initiative had been launched after several cases of harassment and ‚Äúdrunk people entering camps‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe are receiving overwhelming response from the people‚Äù he said. The police in Nepal are planning to expand the sessions to several other camps in Kathmandu. Widespread unemployment, poverty and the impact of a 10-year Maoist insurgency have made Nepali women and children vulnerable to trafficking networks, and campaigners say that the recent disaster has increased the threat. Police and security agencies have increased vigilance against trafficking in quake-hit areas and along the Nepal-India border. In an effort to prevent the trafficking of children, the government recently imposed a three-month ban on adoption and made it mandatory for travelling youngsters to carry permission letters if they are not accompanied by parents. Authorities in India last month rescued more than 20 children from a human trafficking network targeting families who lost their livelihoods in the earthquakes. The children‚Äôs parents, from poor villages in northern India, had been working as migrant labourers in Nepal and were laid off after the earthquake. As they crossed into India at the Raxaul border post, they were convinced to allow their children, between the ages of eight and 14, to travel with the traffickers, who promised to give them well-paid jobs in comfortable conditions. The children were in fact being taken to a bag-manufacturing factory in Mumbai. Four traffickers were detained by the police. The government of the poor south Asian state has struggled to cope with the magnitude of the disaster. Some analysts estimate rebuilding could cost the country between $10bn to $15bn (¬£6.5bn-¬£9.8bn), almost half its annual GDP, with further costs coming from an economic slowdown as a result of the tragedy. There are already fears that the tourist industry, a major employer, will be hit hard. Trekking and mountaineering is a huge revenue earner for the impoverished country, home to eight of the world‚Äôs 14 peaks over 8,000 metres, with Everest alone attracting hundreds of climbers during the April-May spring season, when weather conditions are ideal for ascents. Hundreds of climbers had to abandon their attempts when an avalanche triggered by the earthquake struck Everest base camp, killing 18 people and marking a second year with virtually no summits after the deaths of 16 Nepalese guides in 2014 led to a shutdown of the world‚Äôs highest peak. The climbers may be allowed to use their climbing permits, which could cost up to ¬£16,000, next year, an official said last week. Many aid agencies remain frustrated by bureaucratic and logistic bottlenecks which have slowed delivery of assistance to the most needy.

column4: G7 protesters unite in opposition to TTIP under the alpine sun
column5:
‚ÄúThe Japanese have a saying‚Äù, said Willi Hartenstein, pausing for a reflective puff on a cheroot. ‚ÄúA snail may climb Kilimanjaro, but slowly. Very slowly.‚Äù We were taking a shady break, halfway up a sunbaked alp, on a protest hike to the gates of Hotel Schloss Elmau. When it comes to climbing mountains, snails have one distinct advantage over Hartenstein. They don‚Äôt tend to set off wearing thick black leather motorcycle trousers. I don‚Äôt know what the temperature was inside Willi‚Äôs trousers, but a helicopter came and hovered directly over us for about five minutes, presumably because they thought someone on the march had brought along a thermonuclear device.
It was too loud to speak, so Willi reached down, plucked a yellow alpine flower, and chewed it up, stalk and all. ‚ÄúArnica,‚Äù he shouted, over the roar. There are so many helicopters hovering over Garmisch right now, I keep expecting to hear the Ride of the Valkyries. I don‚Äôt exactly know what they‚Äôre all doing up there. Trying to avoid each other, I hope. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the largest police operation in the history of Bavaria,‚Äù said Martin J√§schke, a journalist from Der Spiegel. ‚ÄúSuch a huge display of power like this, I‚Äôm afraid people feel it‚Äôs a provocation.‚Äù At the very least, it feels a bit weird. There could not actually be any more police in Garmisch than there are right now. There wouldn‚Äôt be room. There are traffic jams of police vehicles. Every spare inch of tarmac has been commandeered for police coaches, riot vans and operations trucks. The only cars on the road that aren‚Äôt police cars are being driven by plainclothes policemen.
This is the kind of response you might expect. ‚ÄúThe massive police presence is extremely intimidating,‚Äù said Lukas M√ºller, a 16-year-old student from Innsbruck. ‚ÄúIt is a show of political power, but also a suppression of political protest. People have been stopped at checkpoints for so long, for hours at a time, that it‚Äôs really difficult simply to show up here. But that‚Äôs all we can do in this situation. Show up.‚Äù What had made Lukas show up today? ‚ÄúFor me, at this instant, there is one issue. It is TTIP.‚Äù This was the word on everyone‚Äôs lips and placards, young and old. The hikers were from across the political spectrum, from anarcho-syndicalists and libertarians, through greens to communists, but the TTIP trade deal seemed to be the one issue that gave focus to their ideological sprawl. Matthias Kolb, a journalist from Munich, agreed. ‚ÄúThe march is super diverse, super colourful, but it seems everybody agrees that TTIP is bad.‚Äù
Hartenstein is 61, a veteran of the anti-globalisation marches of the 1990s. He talked at length about the power Monsanto and Bayer had over the development of environmental regulation. ‚ÄúThey are global companies, with global power. But today we are told, over and over, that globalism is good. Good for a few, yes, very good.‚Äù He chuckled. ‚ÄúTo call yourself a globalist? You would have to be very stupid. Or very, very rich.‚Äù
I walked for a time alongside Hannes Halles, a mathematician from Munich. For Halles, ‚Äúit is all a question of legitimacy. If laws and regulations are made in private, it limits the possibility of overseeing what the politicians do. It seems the only people overseeing are those who stand to gain by the process: big business. ‚ÄúThe process is not legitimate. That is why I am here, because the job of politicians is to represent the people who elected them.‚Äù He gestured up the mountain. ‚ÄúAnd those politicians are not doing their job.‚Äù The Bavarian sun beat down as we puffed our way up the blisteringly beautiful alp. Halles said nothing for a time. ‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù he asked, as we approached a trestle table of water bottles, laid on by mountain rescue. ‚ÄúDo you think they will listen to us?‚Äù We‚Äôd gone too far up the alp for me to tell the truth, so I swallowed a litre of water in eight seconds, lied and said yes, they might. ‚Ä¢ Charlie Skelton is tweeting from the G7 at @deyook

column4: Unsure as eggs: Texas supermarket introduces rationing due to bird flu
column5: A large Texas supermarket chain has begun rationing eggs, in the face of a growing national shortage brought about by an outbreak of avian flu. Customers shopping at many outlets of the H-E-B chain of supermarkets have been confronted by notices telling them they are restricted to buying three cartons of a dozen eggs per shopper. The move follows an announcement by another Texas-based firm, Whataburger, that it is shrinking the hours during which it will serve egg dishes as part of its breakfast menu. Notices have been going up across H-E-B‚Äôs 350 supermarkets, aimed at stopping commercial businesses, such as restaurants, clearing the shelves of eggs. ‚ÄúThe purchase of eggs is limited to three cartons per customer,‚Äù the notices read, according to a local news report in Texas on Thursday. The company issued a statement that called the situation temporary, but was not able to tell customers when ordinary shopping would resume. The outbreak of bird flu began in the midwest. Across much of the nation, egg prices have been rising, along with prices for chicken and turkey meat. ‚ÄúThe United States is facing a temporary disruption in the supply of eggs due to the avian flu,‚Äù the statement said. ‚ÄúH-E-B is committed to ensuring Texas families and households have access to eggs. The signs placed on our shelves last week are to deter commercial users from buying eggs in bulk.‚Äù Whataburger, a family-owned fast-food chain based in San Antonio and controlling more than 700 outlets. It is now serving a breakfast menu from 11pm to 11am, but items with eggs are only available 5am to 11am. The company originally announced that from 1 June it would cut back breakfast hours to 5am to 9am Monday to Friday. ‚ÄúWe know this is no fun for anyone and hope this doesn‚Äôt last long, and we apologise [that] the supply of eggs currently cannot meet demand,‚Äù a statement said. It continued by saying that if customers found the kitchen was out of eggs ‚Äúwe sure don‚Äôt want you leaving hungry‚Äù. Whataburger hoped customers would choose other items from the breakfast menu.

column4: Barcelona mayor-elect Ada Colau calls for more 'feminised' democracy
column5:
Ada Colau, who will be sworn is as Barcelona‚Äôs first female mayor next Saturday, has spoken in her most far-ranging interview yet about the need for a more ‚Äúfeminised‚Äù democracy.
‚ÄúWe can feminise politics,‚Äù she told Amy Goodman, host of the progressive US news programme Democracy Now!, ‚Äúnot just by putting more women in positions of power but also through values and by demonstrating that cooperation is more effective and enjoyable than competitiveness.‚Äù Colau, an anti-eviction activist turned elected politician, said she had a list of 30 tasks to achieve during her first few months in office. These centre on job creation, guaranteeing basic rights and fighting corruption. In her first week she will invite representatives of the city‚Äôs banks to a meeting to discuss how to halt evictions. She said banks that do not allow their empty property to be used as social housing would be sanctioned.
‚ÄúWe have formal democracy but sense that the real decisions aren‚Äôt made in parliament. This awareness of a kidnapped democracy has given rise to grassroots mobilisations, not just here but across southern Europe. ‚ÄúThe main players are not me or Podemos but the people, who have decided to take back their institutions and democratise them. The people are the real players, we are their instruments.‚Äù One of her first tasks will be to slash elected officials‚Äô salaries ‚Äì from ‚Ç¨140,000 to ‚Ç¨28,600 in the case of the mayor ‚Äì and get rid of privileges such as official cars. ‚ÄúThis ending of privileges sends a message that this is the end of a political class removed from the people,‚Äù she said.

column4: Mediterranean migrant crisis: number of arrivals in Italy in 2015 passes 50,000
column5:
The number of migrants to have arrived in Italy by boat this year passed 50,000 at the weekend as over 5,800 people were rescued in the Mediterranean. A total of 3,480 people were rescued on Saturday from 15 separate boats that set off from Libya, and more rescues were ongoing on Sunday. The international effort involved the Italian authorities and naval ships from the UK, Ireland and Germany. It has been one of the busiest weekends so far this year for rescues in the Mediterranean, the start of an uptick over the summer months as people-smugglers take advantage of calm seas. As of Thursday the Italian interior ministry had registered 48,905 arrivals, meaning the total for 2015 is now above 50,000. The Royal Navy‚Äôs HMS Bulwark was brought in on Sunday to save more than 1,000 migrants in seven separate operations, including at least 10 pregnant women. Nick Cooke-Priest, the ship‚Äôs captain, said it had been an ‚Äúintense, complex day‚Äù and praised the work of helicopter crews sent out to locate migrant boats. The series of rescues was the HMS Bulwark‚Äôs largest to date since being sent to the Mediterranean by the UK government on 4 May. A second British warship, HMS Protector, was also involved in rescue operations on Sunday as part of the EU‚Äôs Triton sea rescue operation. The Maltese, Spanish and Swedish navies also took part in rescues on Sunday alongside the Italian coastguard and private vessels. Around 2,200 of the migrants were first picked up by rescuers from the Migrant Offshore Aid Station (MOAS), an independent Maltese operation supported by the medical charity M√©decins Sans Fronti√®res (MSF). Ian Ruggier, who recently retired after 26 years in the Maltese army, said being part of MOAS rescues went beyond his expectations. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never come across anything of this sort, for a moment it looked like a military exercise. We were expecting contact but not of that magnitude,‚Äù he said from the MOAS ship MY Phoenix. Those saved began to disembark in Sicilian ports on Sunday evening, with further landings expected in the toe of Italy‚Äôs boot on Monday. Despite the high volume of barely seaworthy boats leaving Libya, there were no reported shipwrecks over the weekend. Federico Fossi, a spokesman for the UNHCR, put migrants‚Äô safe passage down to increased EU rescue efforts. ‚ÄúTriton is working well, it‚Äôs a big effort and we have to recognised that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe most important thing is that they now go into Libya waters, where the majority of accidents happened in the past.‚Äù Fossi said the current situation marked a big improvement since April, when 800 people drowned in a single shipwreck. The tragedy prompted EU countries to commit greater support for Triton, tripling its monthly funding to ‚Ç¨9m (¬£6.5m) and agreeing to expand the operation‚Äôs patrol area. The deaths of around 1,800 people in the Mediterranean so far this year has also led to increasing discussion of how best to stem the flow of migrants from North Africa. The UK prime minister, David Cameron, has asked his officials to see if more of the country‚Äôs aid budget can be urgently redirected to countries bordering Libya. Cameron has asked Justine Greening, the international development secretary, to see if aid to these governments could help stem the flow could stop the cycle of drawings and rescues. The effective collapse of the Libyan government and consequent power vacuum has led to a flow of economic migrants from other countries into Libya and then onto boats bound for Europe. The vast majority of migrants arriving in Italy are not originally from Libya itself but come from countries further afield, including Mali and Nigeria, while significant numbers have also travelled from Eritrea and Syria. Cameron‚Äôs proposal is modelled on the Spanish response to the flow of refugees to the Canary Islands from west Africa. The Spanish government acted as a partner with West African countries to help stop criminal gangs, easing the migratory flows. European governments have additionally sought UN approval to take military action against people-smugglers operating out of Libya, while also outlining plans to relocate 40,000 refugees from Italy and Greece to elsewhere in Europe over the next two years.
Although welcomed by the Italian government, the proposals have done little to deter the anti-immigrant rhetoric of the country‚Äôs rising far right. Northern League made gains in local elections after campaigning against the migrant ‚Äúinvasion‚Äù. The case for helping new arrivals received a further blow this month after a junior minister was put under investigation over alleged contract-rigging at the Mineo migrant centre in Sicily. Giuseppe Castiglione, undersecretary for agriculture, has denied being involved in the ‚ÄúMafia Capitale‚Äù scandal, after investigations revealed that criminal organisations had infiltrated the state-run immigration system. Italy‚Äôs prime minister, Matteo Renzi, is under growing pressure after refusing to call for Castiglione‚Äôs resignation.

column4: Homily to Catalonia: the nun entering Spain's regional politics
column5:
Whether she‚Äôs advocating an audit of the national debt, lamenting the deterioration of Spain‚Äôs public health services or urging the creation of a public bank, the Benedictine nun Teresa Forcades rarely minces her words. Now the Catalan sister, buoyed by recent municipal elections that saw the housing activist Ada Colau voted in as Barcelona‚Äôs first female mayor, wants to hang up her habit in hopes of leading a leftist coalition that could bring the same sort of change to the region. ‚ÄúI think we are in a very particular moment,‚Äù said Forcades, pointing to the Catalan regional elections, slated for 27 September. ‚ÄúAnd in this particular moment, I think we can all agree we need a people‚Äôs constituent process from below. And if we do that, that‚Äôs the real revolution in Catalonia.‚Äù
In 2013, she and the economist Arcadi Oliveres launched Proc√©s Constituent, a social movement guided by a manifesto calling for an independent Catalonia, where banks and energy companies would be nationalised and all citizens would have the right to a home and a dignified wage. ‚ÄúFrom the beginning it was a project to politicise what had become something real in the streets; a social majority that wanted to stop the neoliberal politics that were happening in Spain,‚Äù she said. Proc√©s Constituent was among the backers of Barcelona en Com√∫, helping turn it into the most voted political force in last month‚Äôs Barcelona municipal elections. As Forcades started musing about an even wider coalition of leftist groups to face off against centre-right Catalan leader Artur Mas in the upcoming regional vote, the one thing missing from the picture was a leader. It was exactly the kind of position that Harvard-educated Forcades ‚Äì one of Catalonia‚Äôs most prominent anti-establishment voices ‚Äì had always been attracted to. But she was loath to trade in the solitude of the monastery for a demanding career in politics.
It was her religious community that ultimately proposed a solution, offering her the chance to take a sabbatical of up to three years, the kind given to nuns to allow them to look after a sick parent. ‚ÄúI said, yes, but my mother is not sick,‚Äù said Forcades. ‚ÄúThey said but society is sick so you can go and take care of it.‚Äù Forcades envisions herself leading a leftist movement that could bring together parties as diverse as Podemos and the Catalan republican left. Last week Podemos‚Äôs Catalan branch said it would be open to the idea of a coalition of leftist parties backing one candidate in the regional elections. ‚ÄúIf we could do that, then this would be the most voted options,‚Äù said Forcades. Her candidacy is set to be debated at an upcoming meeting of Proc√©s Constituent in mid-June. Forcades knows the foray into politics won‚Äôt be easy; while campaigning for Barcelona en Com√∫ during the recent elections, she was rivalled by the Dominican nun Sister Luc√≠a Caram, who was campaigning for Mas‚Äôs Converg√®ncia i Uni√≥.
Spain‚Äôs interior minister took aim at the idea of nuns in politics, insisting it was a relic of times past. ‚ÄúUsing nuns to do politics is odd, it‚Äôs not normal in the 21st century,‚Äù Jorge Fern√°ndez D√≠az told reporters. As Forcades readied herself to step out of the monastery and into the political ring, she‚Äôs steeling herself for more of the same. ‚ÄúCriticisms are to be expected. I follow somebody called Jesus and he had a lot of that.‚Äù It‚Äôs a price she‚Äôs willing to pay in order to try and synchronise politics with the demands of the ‚Äúindignados‚Äù, who occupied squares across Spain in 2011. ‚ÄúThe best political system I can imagine is the one that we call democracy ‚Äì but the real one, not the one we have now, where the people really have the say.‚Äù

column4: Church of England decline heralds calls for innovative use of church buildings
column5:
Occasionally, someone will stick their head around the huge wooden door of the church of St Peter and St Paul in Great Casterton and, on spotting the vicar, express surprise. ‚ÄúThey say: ‚ÄòOh, does something happen here?‚Äô‚Äù says the Rev Jo Saunders. ‚ÄúWell, yes: services, every week.‚Äù She notices something similar at weddings, where guests hover outside before the service, a little intimidated about entering. Occasionally, after the service, they will ask if the church is very old and be astonished to learn that parts date from the 12th century. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs lovely,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúbecause, who knows, maybe they will come back some day?‚Äù Saunders has been vicar at this ancient Rutland parish for six years ‚Äì and also in the neighbouring villages of Little Casterton, Pickworth, Tinwell and Tickencote. Each has a beautiful ancient church building (though Pickworth is merely Georgian), and each hosts regular services, though not all every week. But while Great Casterton (population 365) can attract up to 50 for a Sunday morning service, its little sibling generally hosts around a dozen. Pickwell boasts the same. Average attendance at Tickencote, once a month, is six. Church of England attendance has been slowly declining for decades, with the proportion of Britons attending their local morning service having fallen by half in 40 years, by some measures, to just 1.5% of the population.
New figures, however, have indicated a much steeper fall in the numbers considering their views to be broadly in line with the church. According to the annual British Social Attitudes survey, in just two years between 2012 and 2014, the number of people describing their beliefs as being Church of England or Anglican fell from 21% to 17%, a loss of 1.7 million people ‚Äì leading the former archbishop of Canterbury, Lord Carey, to repeat warnings that the church is ‚Äúa generation away from extinction‚Äù. Britain is not necessarily becoming more godless ‚Äì in the same period, the number of Muslims grew by a million, amounting to 2.4% of the population ‚Äì just less the proportion of Anglicans. That has implications enough for the church in the inner city, but what are the ramifications in the countryside where, for a thousand years, the Church of England has often been the institution that holds rural communities together? Saunders became a full-time priest after retiring as a teacher at the local girls‚Äô high school, and now works six or seven days a week, which inevitably includes, she says, quite a lot of driving. She insists she feels broadly hopeful about the role of her five parishes, but optimism in this context calls for a determination to look on the bright side. She was hugely encouraged, for instance, when one of her congregations gained four new members, taking its total weekly membership to 12. And then there is the ‚Äúconstant worry‚Äù of maintaining her ancient buildings, one of which, Tickencote, contains a spectacular Norman chancel arch of national importance, but which she admits is only kept financially viable by curious tourists ‚Äúwho put their pound in the collection box‚Äù. While we speak, a security firm is surveying the roof at Great Casterton to fit an alarm against lead theft ‚Äì ‚Äúwe‚Äôre insured but it doesn‚Äôt cover the cost‚Äù. ‚ÄúIf you were running the church nakedly as a business, it would be quite simple ‚Äì you‚Äôd close down the uneconomic branches,‚Äù says Nick Spencer, research director of Theos, a thinktank focusing on religion and society, and the author of a book on the future of the English parish church.
‚ÄúBut the Church of England takes considerable, and I think rightful, pride in being a presence in every community in the country. That is the big challenge it faces ‚Äì maintaining that universal service provision, to use public sector language.‚Äù Nearly two-thirds of Anglican churches, 10,199, are in rural areas, but the population of rural England is just 9.3 million, or just over a sixth of the population. The challenge to those who would like to see them all remain open is obvious. One potential solution is to make the buildings themselves work harder, says Canon Dr Jill Hopkinson, the Church of England‚Äôs national rural officer. ‚ÄúWe need to understand how our buildings can be a positive tool for mission, and how we can make them useful for our rural communities,‚Äù she says. At the very least that might involve adding toilets and kitchen facilities; in some places, the church could be used as a post office or community shop, she says. ‚ÄúSo we do need to think creatively about this. But shutting the doors should always be the last option, not the first.‚Äù Hopkinson, who wrote a report on rural churches earlier this year that called for urgent reforms in some aspects of their administration, says a tiny congregation is not necessarily a cause for gloom: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very important to honour the small. Jesus said: ‚ÄòWhere two or three are gathered, there am I also.‚Äô It‚Äôs not about saying that a small church is not a viable church.‚Äù Rev Canon Jim Mynors, vicar of six rural parishes (two of them Grade I-listed) in Northamptonshire, similarly says it is a mixed picture. At his lowest, he says, just one person will turn up for a service, but a quarter of the village is not untypical for harvest, and at Christmas virtually everybody comes. However, few of those are teenagers, he says, and if that is echoed in urban congregations, that may be a problem in future, ‚Äúbecause they will be the incomers to here 10 years from now‚Äù. But although rural priests may be concerned, there are some, even inside the church, who wonder if it really matters if Britain doesn‚Äôt, any longer, consider itself to be vaguely Anglican. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard it described as ‚Äòpruning‚Äô,‚Äù says Spencer. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a slightly brutal metaphor, but there‚Äôs a certain logic to it. If these people don‚Äôt think like a Christian or attend church like a Christian, in what sense are they Christian?‚Äù While church attendance is in decline overall, recent research found 18% of churches are actually growing and where this is the case, the loss of a few tiny churches in sparsely populated villages may take on another character.
Paul Harcourt, for instance, the vicar of All Saints Woodford Wells in Woodford Green, Essex, which attracts 700 worshippers on Sunday mornings, says he is not particularly concerned if Britain‚Äôs Anglican identity is in rapid retreat. ‚ÄúThe collapse of other things doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean the collapse of the church,‚Äù he says. However, he would regret it if the church lost its ‚Äúcredibility‚Äù among non-attenders who, he says, frequently feel warmly disposed to it ‚Äúthanks to generations of love and service‚Äù. For all the optimism, church insiders privately acknowledge the decline of what are often already tiny rural churches means something will have to change. One suggestion is that struggling parishes are turned into ‚Äúfestival churches‚Äù ‚Äì meaning, the parish ceases to have a regular vicar and the church building is effectively closed, to be opened for services at the major church festivals during the year. The suggestion is viewed as a positive and pragmatic step by many, but there is no question it represents a significant retreat for the Church of England. But in some rural communities, says Saunders, villagers recognise the importance of their local church in giving a heart to their community ‚Äì perhaps, as their only remaining shared facility. ‚ÄúI think, in another generation the church will be different and it may well be smaller, but I don‚Äôt think it will be extinct,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI think the spark is there, and I just feel it will always be there in rural churches.‚Äù

column4: Jean-Claude Juncker accuses Alexis Tsipras of lying over bailout talks
column5:
European commission president Jean-Claude Juncker has made a blistering attack on Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, accusing him of undermining negotiations over new terms for a bailout and of effectively lying to the Greek parliament. A visibly angry Juncker, speaking on the fringes of the G7 summit in Bavaria, said he had told Tsipras during a meeting on Wednesday evening that there was ‚Äúroom to negotiate‚Äù but insisted the Greeks had been unwilling to take part in in-depth discussions. Instead, Tsipras had promised to send him his proposals the following day, but Juncker was still waiting for them on Sunday.
‚ÄúAlexis Tsipras promised that by Thursday evening he would present a second proposal. Then he said he would present it on Friday. And then he said he would call on Saturday. But I have never received that proposal, so I hope I will receive it soon. I would like to have that Greek proposal,‚Äù he said. He told reporters he had said to Tsipras that he continued to exclude the idea of a Grexit ‚Äì ‚Äúbecause I don‚Äôt want to see it‚Äù ‚Äì but he had told the Greek prime minister he could not ‚Äúpull a rabbit out of a hat‚Äù. Athens has been trying to secure an agreement from Europe and the International Monetary Fund for months over access to more than ‚Ç¨7bn (¬£5m) in bailout funds. Greece‚Äôs creditors have put strict conditions on any deal, that the Greek government has so far refused to accept. But with Greece running out of money, and needing to secure funds by the end of June if it is to avoid defaulting on its debts, tensions are high.
Juncker, perceived until now as the ‚Äúhonest broker‚Äù in the crisis ‚Äì taking a softer approach than the Germans, who are viewed in Greece as the architects of austerity ‚Äì has rarely been seen so irate, sources close to the EU in Garmisch-Partenkirchen said. They said Greece may have lost its closest ally in its long fight to secure a better deal. Juncker said he had been disappointed by the speech Tsipras had subsequently given to the Athens parliament on Friday. ‚ÄúHe was presenting the offer of the three institutions as a leave-or-take offer. That was not the case ‚Ä¶ He knows perfectly well that is not the case‚Äù. Juncker said Tsipras had also failed to mention to parliament Juncker‚Äôs willingness to negotiate over Greek pensions. He added: ‚ÄúI do not have a personal problem with Alexis Tsipras. He was my friend. He is my friend ‚Ä¶ But frankly, in order to maintain [the friendship], he has to observe some minimum rules.‚Äù

column4: Latest anthrax scare points to dangerous lack of accountability, experts warn
column5:
One week after the terrorist attack in New York on 9/11, another attack on the US began. Letters containing spores of anthrax, a weaponised bacterial agent, were posted to the offices of several newspapers and two Democratic senators. Twenty-two people were infected. Five died. Anthrax is a bacterium often found in soil, according to Jerrold Leikin, a doctor who co-edited a book on ‚Äútoxico-terrorism‚Äù. Its spores are one to five microns across ‚Äì small enough to get into human lungs. The initial symptoms of infection look like flu, but quickly progress to sepsis, hemorrhagic meningitis and death. Once it progresses to those last stages, the fatality rate is around 95%. Over the last few weeks, it was revealed, anthrax was sent to 52 laboratories in 18 states plus South Korea, Canada and Australia. Thirty-one people received treatment for possible exposure. In 2014, a similar incident saw 75 people possibly exposed to the pathogen. The difference is this: the first incident was a terrorist attack. The second and third were accidents. Samples of the pathogen that were supposed to be inactivated were sent to laboratories by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in 2014 and the Department of Defense most recently. The origin point of this year‚Äôs accident was Dugway proving ground in Utah, a military facility which produces anthrax in industrial quantities for the purpose of military research ‚Äì detection, mainly, and as a countermeasure. The post-9/11 era saw a huge expansion in the security state. The bioweapon industry was no different. After the 2001 anthrax attacks ‚Äì known to some as ‚ÄúAmerithrax‚Äù ‚Äì there was a 20- to 40-fold increase in the number of institutions and individuals working with biological weapon agents like anthrax, according to Richard Ebright, a molecular biologist and biosecurity expert at Rutgers university. In response to questions from the Guardian, a spokesperson for the CDC said there were 181 ‚Äúorganizations or entities‚Äù such as Dugway registered as working with live anthrax, and 321 in total working with live pathogens. Within those 321 entities, according to the Government Accountability Office, there are some 1,495 laboratories accredited under the Federal Select Agent Program to work with live pathogens such as anthrax, and a much larger number working with inert versions of the same pathogens. There is no official government body to oversee production and research of bioweapons that does not ‚Äì as the CDC does ‚Äì engage in its own active pathogen research, and no apparent fixed official guidelines regarding their handling.
After the CDC‚Äôs own accident with anthrax in 2014, it said it would hold an official investigation and issue a set of binding guidelines. No such comprehensive set of guidelines appears to have been issued and it is unclear exactly under what authority the CDC could bind, for example, the Department of Defense. A spokesperson for the CDC told the Guardian that it ‚Äúand [the US Department of Agriculture] work jointly on regulating and overseeing the work done on select agents‚Äù. However, a 2013 Government Accountability Office report found ‚Äúa continued lack of national standards for the design, construction, commissioning, and operation of high-containment laboratories‚Äù and said ‚Äúno single federal agency was responsible for assessing overall laboratory needs‚Äù. According to Ebright, basic rules, such as having at least two people in a lab at any one time, or even that accredited laboratories should have CCTV cameras, do not exist in many such facilities. Information regarding the latest breach is relatively scarce. Army chief of staff Raymond Odierno told reporters ‚Äúthe best I can tell there was not human error‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe fact that this has been obviously happening for some time and perhaps at several different places hints at a systemic issue,‚Äù said Stephen Morse, a professor of epidemiology at Columbia University‚Äôs Mailman School of Public Health. Morse, who also worked at the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa) between 1995 and 2000 on biodefence, speculated that the process by which machines irradiate the live pathogens, inactivating them, might be ‚Äúpoorly calibrated‚Äù. ‚ÄúLuckily for us, human beings are relatively resistant to anthrax compared to smallpox,‚Äù said Morse. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs not something we should rely on.‚Äù Indeed, according to Ebright, military contracted laboratories across the US routinely work with other, more dangerous pathogens than anthrax ‚Äì including several virulent strains of avian flu. A mistake with one of those, instead of anthrax, could have devastating results, including ‚Äúa global pandemic‚Äù. Nominally all such labs are working on defences against these pathogens. But it has become, Ebright said, ‚Äúall pork-barrel‚Äù, with at least one lab in every single state. ‚Äú[It‚Äôs] spending that can‚Äôt possibly be defended on any rational basis,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWith each of the incidents in the past there has been a notable absence of responsibility. They know if you mess up, nothing happens; the programmes aren‚Äôt reduced, the personnel suffer no consequences. So it‚Äôs all about the worst you could possibly have: no one watching, no rules, and no accountability.‚Äù But according to Ebright, the real issue isn‚Äôt a question of danger to the public from the accidental sending itself. It‚Äôs the chance that the pathogen ‚Äì which was the same strain used in the 2001 attack ‚Äì could fall into the wrong hands.
‚ÄúEven one spore is a sufficient seed stock from which an amount could grow to mount a biological weapons attack,‚Äù Ebright said. ‚ÄúThe sad circumstance is that this massive effort since 2001 has dramatically increased the chances of a biological weapon attack on the US, precisely by distributing a highly lethal strain of the agent with no structure and no ability to record where they have gone.‚Äù Nor is this the only slip-up that has been made at Dugway. In 2011 the base was placed on lockdown for several hours after a vial containing a deadly ‚Äúnerve agent‚Äù went missing, the BBC reported at the time. ‚ÄúThe major concern is the security breach, that the material will be transferred to domestic terror and international terror and be used as the seed source for a bomb or weapon,‚Äù said Ebright. ‚ÄúIt would be disappointing if the Department of Defense becomes the supplier for al-Qaida that enables a bioweapon attack.‚Äù

column4: Mandarin menus and no rooms with a 4: Spain's hotels adapt for Chinese tourists
column5:
With 300,000 Chinese tourists expected to visit Spain this year and a million by the end of the decade, hotels are rushing to adapt in order to receive a ‚ÄúChinese-friendly‚Äù stamp of approval. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs paradoxical that Spain, the biggest tourist destination after France and the United States, is practically unknown in China,‚Äù said Kurt Gr√∂tsch, chief executive of Chinese Friendly International, whose endorsement is recognised in all 28 EU member states. The World Tourism Organisation estimates that 100 million Chinese will leave their country on holiday this year. Among the adjustments hoteliers need to make is to never give a Chinese visitor a room with the number four in it, nor one on the fourth floor. In Mandarin the number four sounds so similar to the word for death that Chinese go to great lengths to avoid saying it. There should be no physical contact when greeting guests, and the hotel‚Äôs visiting card should be presented with both hands. The restaurant menu and other hotel information should be offered in Mandarin, fruit should always be served in portions, never whole. Hot water should be served with meals, especially if the guests have ordered meat, and all rooms should have a kettle, even though guests often use them to cook noodles. Furthermore, waiters should remember to serve the eldest or the most highly educated person first. They should never point with the finger, only with the hand. ‚ÄúWord of mouth counts for a lot in China,‚Äù said Gr√∂tsch. ‚ÄúIf a Chinese enjoys themselves somewhere, more will come. Often you can become Chinese-friendly without any great investment.‚Äù He recommends that waiters learn a few basic phrases in Mandarin, such as asking diners whether they‚Äôve enjoyed their meal. Currently, 14 hotels in Spain have been rated Chinese-friendly. ‚ÄúBeing rated Chinese-friendly by a recognised association is a big help in dealing with Chinese companies and positioning ourselves in an emerging market,‚Äù said Alex Rodr√≠guez, marketing director of the Vincci hotel chain. The company‚Äôs five-star hotel in M√°laga has acquired the rating and the chain may soon seek approval for its three Barcelona hotels.
Gr√∂tsch admitted that the Chinese were not always the most popular guests, especially those travelling abroad for the first time. ‚ÄúThey can be rude, people see them as arrogant, they talk loud and smoke like chimneys in non-smoking areas.‚Äù One Barcelona hotel that has been approved as Chinese-friendly since 2013 no longer wants to be associated with this type of tourism as it drives away other visitors. Germans, in particular, are inclined to cancel their reservation if they know there will be Chinese in the hotel, a hotel spokesman claimed. However, the Chinese government is anxious to create a good impression and has drawn up a blacklist of citizens who behave badly abroad. People found guilty of antisocial behaviour, vandalism, gambling or going to strip clubs will be placed on the list for two years and will face additional, unspecified punishments.

column4: Merkel welcomes Obama with beer and sausage breakfast before G7 summit
column5:
Accompanied by beer, sausages and men in lederhosen, Barack Obama received a warm welcome to the Bavarian Alps from Angela Merkel on Sunday, before two days of intensive G7 summit talks.
Alpine horns and locals in traditional dress greeted the US president as he arrived in Kr√ºn, a village close to the G7 venue of Schloss Elmau, before the two leaders sat down to a breakfast of the local sausage, weisswurst, a glass of weissbier and pretzels. Locals cheered as Obama saluted them with a ‚ÄúGr√ºss Gott‚Äù ‚Äì a traditional greeting ‚Äì against a stunning backdrop of pine forests and snowcapped mountains, telling them: ‚ÄúThat was without question, the best Alpine horn performance I‚Äôve ever heard.‚Äù In what will no doubt be seen as an open invitation to a local lederhosen tailor looking for some publicity, the president said he had forgotten ‚Äúto bring my lederhosen, but I hope to find some while I‚Äôm here‚Äù.
He later walked through the crowds, talking to locals dressed in traditional Dirndls and lederhosen and accepting an invitation to touch a hunter‚Äôs gamsbart ‚Äì the brush-like tuft of chamois hair adorning his felt hat. But the German chancellor was decidedly cooler than usual during her welcome speech. Despite using his first name, and addressing him in the informal du form, she immediately made a veiled reference to the tensions between the US and Germany over the scandal surrounding Germany‚Äôs intelligence agents allegedly helping the US‚Äôs National Security Agency to spy on officials and companies in Europe. ‚ÄúAlthough it‚Äôs true we have differences of opinion from time to time, the United States of America is our friend and essential partner with whom we cooperate closely because it‚Äôs in our mutual interest,‚Äù she said. Welcoming the two days of talks, during which, Obama said, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre going to discuss our joint future,‚Äù he referred apologetically to the massive security operation involved in staging the G7, which has upset many locals. ‚ÄúI know it‚Äôs a lot of hard work when I come to town,‚Äù he said. He then asked Merkel if the talks could be held outside ‚Äúover a glass of beer‚Äù rather than up at Schloss Elmau, the luxury hotel where the seven world leaders will be meeting, ‚Äúbut I think we‚Äôll have to negotiate with the security people,‚Äù he said. The two leaders, along with Merkel‚Äôs chemistry professor husband, Joachim Sauer, then sat down with locals for a specially brewed G7 summit banana and clove-flavour weissbier, weisswurst and pretzels, all of them appearing to swig back the beer, despite the early hour. Obama sat between a local dairy farmer and Krun‚Äôs mayor, while Merkel was next to the village bank manager and his wife.
The brewer, butcher and baker responsible for the breakfast told the local paper that secret service agents had carried out several tastings to check the safety of the products. The butcher, Zeno Berg, said that agents had also X-rayed the sausages and meatloaf. Victoria Schubert, the local brewer responsible for crafting the beer, who learned her trade at a London brewery, confirmed the leaders had been drinking the real thing. ‚ÄúThey were certainly not drinking alcohol-free beer,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt was 5% proof, with an original gravity of 11%, and like all German beer it was brewed according to the 500-year-old purity laws.‚Äù She said it came from a family recipe that was more than 100 years old and which ‚Äúhas only been tweaked a bit here and there over the years‚Äù. It has been temporarily renamed Summit Weissbier for the occasion and six 180-litre barrels have been delivered to Schloss Elmau. After breakfast the two leaders held bilateral talks in which both agreed to continue to take a hard stance against Russia, a sentiment that was later reflected by other delegates. Leaders arrived late morning in helicopters, with golf carts bringing them to the red carpet of the castle entrance. An official ‚Äúfamily photo‚Äù took place against the imposing backdrop of snow-covered mountains, several hours ahead of schedule because of a thunder storm forecast for later in the day. As dark clouds indeed began to gather over the castle ‚Äì a former recuperation centre for Wehrmacht soldiers ‚Äì they then gathered for talks in the castle‚Äôs grand hall, a space normally used for yoga conventions. Police arrested about 25 demonstrators earlier in the morning who blocked the road leading to Schloss Elmau with a sit-down protest, forcing the leaders to continue the final part of their journey by helicopter. One demonstrator and a police officer were injured in the scuffles in which protesters set off fog rockets to which the police responded with pepper spray. But police said the demonstrations had been milder than expected. Tweeting in multiple languages, an official Twitter account wrote: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre slightly missing the music and samba mood of yesterday. Where are the drums?‚Äù In the forests surrounding the venue, some of the 17,000 police on duty spent the day playing a game of cat and mouse with protesters, some of whom attempted to penetrate with bolt cutters a 10-mile (16 km) wire fence that had been erected around the venue. Merkel is hosting the leaders of Canada, France, Italy, Japan, the US and the UK for two days of talks, which are expected to focus on issues including climate change, global health and terrorism The talks began discussing the state of the global economy, including the European debt crisis. A second meeting was expected to deal with international trade and standards, including the controversial TTIP deal between the EU and the US. Over a working supper, cooked by a Michelin-starred chef, they were due to discuss pressing foreign policy issues, including what Obama referred to earlier in the day as ‚ÄúRussian aggression in Ukraine‚Äù. On Monday the leaders are expected to discuss the climate, global health, terrorism, the empowerment of women and development. NGOs were trying to put last-minute pressure on the Canadian prime minister, Stephen Harper, as it emerged that he is allegedly blocking agreements on development goals. Merkel‚Äôs husband, Joachim Sauer, a quantum chemistry professor, led the spouses present ‚Äì Akie Abe, wife of the Japanese premier, Laureen Harper, wife of the Canadian PM, and Malgorzata Tusk, wife of European council president Donald ‚Äì on a tour of the area in a horse-drawn carriage. Ahead of supper they were to be entertained in the castle‚Äôs grand hall by star sopranist Waltraud Meier performing Richard Strauss lieder. Strauss had a house in Garmisch, the town closest to the summit venue, and died there in 1949.

column4: G7 summit: Ukraine, Greek bailout and climate top agenda for Bavaria meeting
column5:
David Cameron joins the G7 summit of leading industrialised nations in Bavaria expecting to face a crowded agenda dominated by Ukraine, the Greek bailout and climate change.
