The summit host, Angela Merkel, fought hard to try to seal a deal with the Greek government before the summit, but failed, ensuring Barack Obama will want an update on how close Europe is to ending an impasse that still hangs over the world economy.
The summit is being held in the remote Schloss Elmau in Bavaria, and as many as 20,000 police are on patrol in nearby towns to minimise disruption by G7 protesters. The European Council president, Donald Tusk, and the EU commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, as well as the director of the IMF, Christine Lagarde, will be present to update Obama on the state of the bailout talks now not due to reach a climax until the end of the month.
Merkel and the French president, Fran√ßois Hollande, phoned the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, at the weekend, and it was agreed the three politicians were likely to meet in Brussels on Wednesday evening on the edge of an EU summit with Latin America and the Caribbean. Obama will be pressing the Europeans to show more resolve to maintain sanctions against Russia.
Russia remains excluded from the G7 as punishment for its encouragement last year of the rebellion in eastern Ukraine. Vladimir Putin has said the conflict in Ukraine was the result of ‚Äúunprofessional actions‚Äù of the US, and opinion remains divided on the extent to which sanctions, as opposed to a lower oil price, is hurting the Russian economy. The US secretary of state, John Kerry, recently travelled to Sochi for direct talks with Putin in what was seen as a sign of potential softening, but nothing tangible occurred, and if anything the fragile ceasefire in Ukraine is under greater pressure than ever. Obama rang the Ukrainian president, Petro Poroshenko, before the summit and the Japanese prime minister, Shinzo Abe, visited Ukraine on the way to the summit in a sign of solidarity. Benjamin Rhodes, a deputy national security adviser to Obama, said: ‚ÄúMost urgently, the focus is on maintaining the unity around the sanctions effort that has had very significant consequences on the Russian economy. ‚ÄúWe need to maintain the pressure, show that there cannot be cracks in the transatlantic unity, and show that the costs are just going to continue to grow for Russia.‚Äù Merkel has ensured that the communique at this summit will include a long-term aim to limit global warming to below two degrees. Merkel wants countries to commit to the Green Climate Fund, which is aiming for $100bn by 2020. Germany recently doubled its contribution to $8bn and Merkel has personally called on all industrial countries to contribute.
The G7 statement is an important staging post before the UN climate change conference in Paris in December. It is a a sign of how far world opinion ‚Äì or at least American opinion ‚Äì has moved: the last time Merkel was G7 host, in 2007, she was battling to persuade George Bush that climate change existed and was clearly a manmade phenomenon. Doubts remain, however, about Obama‚Äôs ability to get any tough climate change agreement through Congress, as he has been examining ways to circumvent the legislature. The summit is also due to discuss the fight against Islamic State, including a meeting on Monday between Obama and the prime minister of Iraq, Haider al-Abadi. On the economy, Obama is expected to reassure allies that Congress will back the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a massive deal spanning the Pacific Rim. Obama began his visit on Sunday morning with a visit to the picturesque town of Kr√ºn with Merkel, tasting local food, meeting locals and drinking a very early morning beer. Other topics Merkel has tabled for the summit under the motto ‚ÄúThink ahead, act together‚Äù range from improving labour rights for textile workers to fighting antibiotics resistance and cleaning up oceanic pollution.

column4: A grandmother's 36-year hunt for the child stolen by the Argentinian junta
column5:
Practically all of Argentina has cried on this one,‚Äù says Ignacio Montoya Carlotto, patting his right shoulder. We are crisscrossing the old cobblestone streets of San Telmo, the colonial district of the capital, Buenos Aires. The 36-year-old musician, his crinkly curls prematurely greying, his mouth fast to resolve into a smile, is not bragging. It‚Äôs impossible to walk even one city block without someone rushing to hug him and then burst into tears, as he predicted, on his rumpled T-shirt. Maybe it‚Äôs because, thanks to his grandmother, the whole of Argentina had been waiting ‚Äì praying ‚Äì for more than 30 years for the day when he would be ‚Äúfound‚Äù. Most Argentinians can remember exactly what they were doing when that moment finally came in August last year. ‚ÄúWhen I turned 80, I begged God not to let me die before I found my grandson,‚Äù says Estela Carlotto. Estela has led an extraordinary life, rising from tragedy into one of the most loved and respected public figures in Argentina. It took four more years. ‚ÄúWe all cried; everyone has something to say about how they felt to have found this grandson we were all searching for.‚Äù Estela was a 47-year-old schoolteacher, housewife and mother of three in November 1977 when a death squad from Argentina‚Äôs 1976-83 dictatorship picked her daughter Laura off a street in the city of La Plata where she lived, about 32 miles south of Buenos Aires. Laura, a 22-year-old political activist, became one of the thousands of young dissidents who were made to ‚Äúdisappear‚Äù by a bloody, fascist regime. Unknown to Estela, her long-haired, strikingly beautiful daughter was three months pregnant at the time of her abduction. She was taken to a secret ‚Äúdetention centre‚Äù called La Cacha. There, in her presence, they killed her companion and the father of the child she was carrying, 26-year-old Walmir Montoya. Ignacio was born in June 1978 while his mother Laura was still in captivity. One report states she gave birth handcuffed and was allowed only five hours with her baby. Two months later, she was dragged out of the camp and a mock armed confrontation was staged by the military. When her body was turned over to Estela, she had been shot through the stomach and her face was smashed, apparently by a rifle butt. Survivors of the camp told Estela about the birth, and that she had named the newborn Guido, after her father. For 36 years afterwards, Estela devoted herself to finding her grandson. All she had was a name, Guido, and an approximate birth date. An excruciatingly difficult search led her through three decades of legal action against police officers, military officers and doctors involved in the ‚Äúmissing grandchildren‚Äù cases. Leads were hard to come by. Her grandson had been swallowed by the complicity and silence that surrounded so many of the regime‚Äôs horrendous crimes. Estela realised there were many others like herself looking for the babies of their ‚Äúdisappeared‚Äù daughters. They formed a group called the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo, named after the city square facing the presidential palace in downtown Buenos Aires where they marched, drawing attention to their plight. By 1989 Estela had become president of the association. The group believes there are some 500 cases of grandchildren born in captivity. In most cases, the babies were turned over to military families to raise as their own. In the warped thinking of the profoundly Catholic yet murderous generals who ruled Argentina then, it would have been unchristian to kill an innocent, unborn child by executing the expectant mother. By the same token, in their macabre minds turning the babies over to ‚Äúgood‚Äù military families to raise as their own represented the ultimate victory over the ‚Äúgodless‚Äù left-wing enemy they wished to crush into nonexistence.
Even now, three decades after the collapse of the dictatorship, some Argentinians defend the military‚Äôs campaign against Cuban-inspired guerrillas in the 1970s, but even the most die-hard reactionaries draw the line at the baby-snatching cases. Each DNA confirmation that a missing grandchild had been found and reunited with their biological family, usually accompanied by legal action against the ‚Äúmother and father‚Äù who had appropriated them, has been greeted with joy across the political spectrum. Over three decades of work, 113 cases had been resolved by the slowly ageing grandmothers, but despite this, Estela Carlotto‚Äôs missing grandson remained unaccounted for, which left a deep, unhealed wound in the nation‚Äôs psyche. Despite being behind the restitution of the grandchildren of so many of her fellow grandmothers, the white-haired, softly spoken woman who had endeared herself as a perennial hopeful for a Nobel Peace Prize for Argentina, and a worldwide symbol of peaceful women‚Äôs activism, had not yet been able to find her own slain daughter‚Äôs son. ‚ÄúI am such a well-known public figure,‚Äù says Carlotto. ‚ÄúEverybody kept asking me: ‚ÄòWhen is it going to be your turn?‚Äô‚Äù At the time Ignacio Montoya Carlotto still believed he was Ignacio Hurban, the only son of Juana and Clemente Hurban, a couple of humble rural workers who lived near the city of Olavarr√≠a on a farm belonging to Francisco Aguilar, a well-to-do, conservative landowner who died last year.
‚ÄúA few years ago I was watching television with my wife and Estela comes on talking about the search for her grandson,‚Äù Ignacio tells me. ‚ÄúAnd I said: ‚ÄòLook at this poor woman. It‚Äôs heart-breaking ‚Äì she‚Äôs spent her whole life searching, and she may never find him.‚Äô‚Äù Ignacio had, he says, a golden childhood. ‚ÄúI had a great life, but there was always this background noise. I didn‚Äôt look like my parents.‚Äù Growing up on the farm, surrounded by animals and cared for by those he still refers to lovingly as ‚ÄúMother and Father‚Äù, he became a voracious reader, excelled in school, travelled to Buenos Aires to study music and finally returned to Olavarr√≠a to become a successful music teacher and professional musician with his own band, the Ignacio Hurban Grupo. ‚ÄúWhen this all started,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI was scared of it devouring my whole life. Things were really great for me, damn it. I was recording records with musicians I respected, I was able to buy myself a brand-new car working as a musician, teaching and playing the piano. I had my wife and we were thinking of starting a family. And before that I had a healthy childhood on the farm, with lots of love.‚Äù It was precisely that bucolic, protective environment in the deep countryside that made it almost impossible for his despairing grandmother to find him. ‚ÄúWhere he was, 200 miles away in the middle of farm country,‚Äù says Estela, ‚ÄúI was never going to find him.‚Äù A year ago, on 2 June 2014, fate intervened. It‚Äôs the date the then Ignacio Hurban has always celebrated his birthday. Olavarr√≠a is a small city of only 111,000. Among them was Celia Lizaso, a woman who knew the true story of his birth. ‚ÄúCelia Lizaso was the daughter of a farmer who was very good friends with Aguilar,‚Äù says Ignacio today. ‚ÄúShe told my wife that I was adopted.‚Äù After a tearful birthday dinner during which his wife revealed to him the secret of his ‚Äúadoption‚Äù, Ignacio went to see Lizaso, who had only told his wife half the story. ‚ÄúShe left out the part that I was the child of a couple killed by the dictatorship.‚Äù
Both Ignacio‚Äôs adoptive parents are still alive and are certain to face a judicial inquiry due to the fact that he was falsely registered as their biological son. ‚ÄúWhen I went to them about it,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúthey explained their reasons for not telling me. They are humble farm people. They barely finished primary school.‚Äù The circumstances of their employment with Aguilar weighed heavily in the equation, believes Ignacio. ‚ÄúThey couldn‚Äôt have children, and Aguilar gave them the opportunity of bringing them a child born from a woman who didn‚Äôt want to have it, which was common in those days. They never suspected anything. They believed their boss ‚Äì he was like God to them: they lived on his land and he was their only source of income.‚Äù Ignacio is convinced of their innocence and good intentions. ‚ÄúI realise the sacrifices they made to raise me ‚Äì I have nothing but gratitude for that. I also understand that they were tricked, they were made to sign things. They were made to believe things that weren‚Äôt true.‚Äù Although the details remain unclear, and there is a court investigation pending, Ignacio has been able to piece together the essentials. Aguilar received him from the military when he was probably only a few days old and handed him over to the Hurbans, to raise as their own, with a solemn warning never to tell anyone the truth. ‚ÄúAguilar probably did it to collaborate with the military,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúGuys from his social background, sucking up to power ‚Äì he‚Äôd do anything to ingratiate himself with some military officer. It‚Äôs kind of sad, actually.‚Äù Ignacio grew up knowing Aguilar and his children well. ‚ÄúThe kids used to come visit the farm. They live across from the music school where I teach.‚Äù But he has never thought of crossing the street to pound their door in anger. ‚ÄúAguilar is dead and I‚Äôm told his widow has Alzheimer‚Äôs. That‚Äôs for the courts to deal with, I trust justice. There‚Äôs only two things that can affect families like that. Economic consequences, which is losing what they have, because those families often are what they own, or losing their prestige, and that they have definitely lost: their last name is now associated with the worst crime in our history.‚Äù
He is nonetheless adamant that Aguilar‚Äôs sons are innocent in the case. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve met them and talked with them about it. The father was responsible, but the sons weren‚Äôt. They are victims of the shit their father did.‚Äù Over the decades of their search, it was inevitable that some of the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo died. The years are ticking by ever faster for those still in the fight ‚Äì Estela is 84. With hundreds of grandchildren still unfound, they have set up a DNA bank with samples from their own DNA to ensure that anyone who suspects they are a ‚Äúmissing grandchild‚Äù can step forward after they are gone. In what was probably one of the last acts of his life as Ignacio Hurban, Estela‚Äôs missing grandson went to the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo, took a DNA test and then went back to his daily life. Estela says: ‚ÄúSomebody told me ‚Äì and he hasn‚Äôt denied it ‚Äì that he said: ‚ÄòWell, if I turn out to be the son of a ‚Äúdisappeared‚Äù couple, I want to be the grandson of the top grandmother, Estela.‚Äô‚Äù But when the phone call came, it not only showed that he was Estela‚Äôs grandson, it also revealed he was the son of Walmir Montoya, Laura Carlotto‚Äôs slain secret boyfriend. Suddenly the pieces fell into place. Montoya had been a drummer in a rock band. Nicknamed Pu√±o (Fist) as a baby by his mother, Montoya, as a young man in the 1970s, soon gravitated to the Montoneros guerrilla organisation. He moved to La Plata, where he met Laura. They fell in love and lived in hiding, in an unsuccessful bid to outrun the secret police. In 2006 forensic anthropologists unearthed his bones in a common grave. They found 16 bullet wounds, showing he was probably executed by machine gun fire. In Caleta Olivia, the coastal town in Patagonia where he grew up, a statue of Pu√±o Montoya had been erected in his memory. Although there‚Äôd been rumours, no one knew for certain that he had a child, least of all his surviving 91-year-old mother, Hortensia Montoya, who also received a phone call with the surprise DNA results. ‚ÄúGod has given me a long life so that I could live to meet my grandson,‚Äù Hortensia said to the press. Like Estela, Hortensia is an exceptional woman, considered a pioneering teacher in Caleta Olivia. The two grandmothers talked to each other in a joint radio interview after the DNA results were announced, as a wave of joy swept across the nation. ‚ÄúWe still haven‚Äôt met, but I love you so much for sharing this wonderful grandson with me,‚Äù Estela told Hortensia. Referring to the photos in the press of her son Pu√±o, Estela added: ‚ÄúNow I understand why my daughter fell in love with your son.‚Äù
The phone call to Ignacio Hurban had been made by Estela‚Äôs younger daughter, who heads the DNA bank which holds the samples. ‚ÄúI asked for time,‚Äù Ignacio says now. ‚ÄúBut then I thought: ‚ÄòThey‚Äôve been waiting for this for over 30 years. One more day for them must feel fatal.‚Äô‚Äù What followed was a hurried 400km journey with his wife and a group of their friends to meet the Carlottos in La Plata. ‚ÄúWe left early, avoiding the press. We got lost, we went round in circles, it was a total scream.‚Äù By then Argentina‚Äôs media were staked out en masse in front of Carlotto‚Äôs La Plata home, so they had to rendezvous at the home of one of her daughters. What the then Ignacio Hurban encountered at the Carlotto home provoked something akin to culture shock. An only son, raised among animals in a faraway farm, walked into a home where Estela‚Äôs 13 other grandchildren, his cousins, aunts and uncles were eagerly awaiting him. ‚ÄúIt was meeting a whole family who are looking at you and can‚Äôt believe it: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs impossible ‚Äì he‚Äôs there!‚Äô Seeing the joy in their eyes simply because I was there ‚Äì everybody crying, the hugs, the emotion.‚Äù His grandmother Estela understands: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a noisy bunch. He‚Äôs very quiet ‚Äì I think he had more contact with animals than with children of his own age growing up.‚Äù ‚ÄúI was a mess when I arrived after this long trip,‚Äù says Ignacio. As he got out of the car, he was told his grandmother was inside. Estela recalls: ‚Äú‚ÄòThat‚Äôs my grandson,‚Äô I thought. All the love I‚Äôd kept for him came over me, to tell him how much I loved him, how much I‚Äôd looked for him. He stood his ground, holding back. I, of course, had been travelling around the world looking for a baby, looking for a child, looking for a young man, and I‚Äôd always thought: ‚ÄòWhen I find him, you can all meet him because you‚Äôve all helped me look for him.‚Äô‚Äù She soon saw she had to be more careful. ‚ÄúA grandmother‚Äôs anxiety wants everything to be fast, but there‚Äôs been cases where it‚Äôs taken years for a grandchild to accept their grandmother. So my advice to the grandmothers always is: give them time ‚Äì that‚Äôs how you show your love. You must not get angry, you must not hurry them, you must demand nothing.‚Äù For Ignacio, the sweetest moment came a few days later, when Hortensia Montoya arrived and the two grandmothers embraced.
‚ÄúMeeting my two grandmothers was the most moving thing,‚Äù he says, speaking with passionate anger against the military who murdered his parents, ‚Äúbecause it was like: ‚ÄòBam, there it is, this is it ‚Äì we won, we did it, we‚Äôre here, seeing each other, talking.‚Äô Do you know what it was like hearing those two women talking to each other? The ground shakes when they meet. Two such powerful persons talking about their children, getting to know each other through the love their children had, crying for joy in the midst of this terrible tragedy.‚Äù Ignacio has stood his ground by refusing to give in to one of his grandmother‚Äôs most cherished wishes: to rename himself Guido. ‚ÄúIt hurt me when he said he didn‚Äôt want to change his name,‚Äù says Estela, sadness clouding her voice. ‚Äú‚ÄòIf it‚Äôs a boy, I want him to be called Guido,‚Äô my daughter told one of her fellow prisoners who survived. She must have called him Guido when he was in her tummy; that has to resonate. But he told me he is Ignacio. It‚Äôs to reaffirm himself after that explosion. I understood completely. So I told him: ‚ÄòLook, I am going to call you Guido. I‚Äôve been looking for you for 36 years as Guido.‚Äô And he accepted that. But now, I don‚Äôt know ‚Äì sometimes I avoid calling him Guido if he doesn‚Äôt want it.‚Äù As the night descends over Buenos Aires at the end of my time with him, Ignacio Hurban is now fully transformed into Ignacio Montoya Carlotto the rising musician, talking about his new project, the Ignacio Montoya Carlotto Septeto. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre songs with folkloric roots, closer to folk music than to tango.‚Äù Driving his car through the busy streets of Argentina‚Äôs capital, he seems slightly lost, far away from the quiet night skies and open horizons of his home, asking for directions, on his way to a rehearsal for a television show he will be performing on. He insists that he will not give in to resentment nor will he feign a suffering for what happened to his biological parents that he has not felt himself. ‚ÄúIt was horrible, to be ripped from your mother, but I have no recollection of that. Plus, what good would it do me to cry for what could have been? Or to start living a life of suffering that I have not lived? My parents suffered. When I think about what they went through, it‚Äôs so sad, and that willingness to give up their lives for their beliefs, such a strong will to go through with the pregnancy. It‚Äôs incredible. But I didn‚Äôt live through any of that. My memories are of growing up on the farm with a mother and a father. And they did everything any other parents would have done.‚Äù
It is difficult to say whether denial is at play in Ignacio‚Äôs reasoning, although he himself admits to none. Perhaps he is that rare thing, a person determined to make the best of the world he has been born into, even if he discovers at the age of 36 that he had been ‚Äúborn‚Äù into a false world, the victim of a heinous crime. Meanwhile Estela continues her work. She still travels to the offices of the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo in Buenos Aires every day. That‚Äôs about a three-hour round trip. She travels continuously, carrying her message around the world. Her grandson was the 114th missing grandchild to be identified. Two more have been identified since then. Hundreds of others remain unfound. She has no intention of stopping: ‚ÄúThe only thought I had was: Laura can rest in peace now. I felt Laura said to me: ‚ÄòMother, mission accomplished.‚Äô But there‚Äôs so much still to do. I‚Äôm going to keep looking for the other missing ones.‚Äù

column4: Hillsong church drops controversial US preacher Mark Driscoll from conferences
column5:
The head of Pentecostal mega-church Hillsong has dropped US preacher Mark Driscoll from the lineup of the church‚Äôs 2015 Australian and UK conferences, saying furore around his controversial sermons ‚Äì including some describing women as ‚Äúpenis houses‚Äù ‚Äì would be an ‚Äúunnecessary distraction‚Äù. Brian Houston said on Sunday after ‚Äúpersonal interaction‚Äù with Driscoll he had decided to rescind his invitation to the events, the Australian version of which is expected to draw 30,000 this month. Driscoll resigned from Seattle‚Äôs Mars Hill church in October after its board found him ‚Äúguilty of arrogance, responding to conflict with a quick temper and harsh speech, and leading the staff and elders in a domineering manner‚Äù.
But uproar in recent days has focused on the content of his so-called ‚Äútestosterone gospel‚Äù, including one sermon in which he told churchgoers: ‚ÄúUltimately, God created you and it is His penis. You are simply borrowing it for a while. ‚ÄúKnowing that His penis would need a home, God created a woman to be your wife. And when you marry her and look down you will notice that your wife is shaped differently than you and makes a very nice home,‚Äù he said. In pseudonymous posts on an online forum in 2000 Driscoll also wrote the US had become a ‚Äúpussified nation‚Äù where boys were being raised by ‚Äúbitter penis-envying burned feministed single mothers‚Äù. A petition against his appearance at the church‚Äôs conferences in Australia and the UK had drawn nearly 3,000 signatures, and an online activist group in Australia had suggested Driscoll be barred entry into the country, as was serial domestic abuser and boxer Floyd Mayweather. Houston said Driscoll ‚Äúheld some views and made some statements that cannot be defended‚Äù and that his 30-minute scheduled appearance ‚Äúhad the potential to divert attention from the real purpose‚Äù of the five-day event. ‚ÄúIt is my hope that Mark and I will be able to speak in person in the coming weeks to discuss some of the issues that have been raised, what ‚Äì if anything ‚Äì he has learned, and for me to understand better how he is progressing in both his personal and professional life,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe teachings of Christ are based on love and forgiveness, and I will not write off Mark as a person simply because of the things that people have said about him, a small minority of people signing a petition or statements he has made many years ago for which he has since repeatedly apologised. ‚ÄúHowever, I do not want unnecessary distractions during our conference,‚Äù he said.

column4: Hillsong to review decision to invite controversial US pastor as speaker
column5:
The head of Pentecostal mega-church Hillsong will review a decision to invite to the church‚Äôs Australian conference a controversial US preacher who once compared women to ‚Äúpenis-houses‚Äù. Brian Houston told Channel Seven he would be speaking with the former head of Seattle‚Äôs Mars Hill church, Mark Driscoll, later on Sunday to ‚Äúwork out where to go from here‚Äù. ‚ÄúI am going to be talking to him later on today and we‚Äôll talk about the different possibilities,‚Äù Houston said. Nearly 3,000 people have signed an online petition against Hillsong‚Äôs plans to host Driscoll at its Australian conference in Sydney this month, which is expected to attract around 30,000 people.
Driscoll resigned from the Mars Hill church in October after its board found him ‚Äúguilty of arrogance, responding to conflict with a quick temper and harsh speech, and leading the staff and elders in a domineering manner‚Äù. There were also allegations that donations allocated for outreach to India and Ethiopia were spent instead on growing the church‚Äôs online presence. ‚ÄúUltimately, God created you and it is His penis. You are simply borrowing it for a while,‚Äù Driscoll said in one sermon, part of what he called a ‚Äútestosterone gospel‚Äù. ‚ÄúWhile His penis is on loan you must admit that it is sort of just hanging out there very lonely as if it needed a home, sort of like a man wandering the streets looking for a house to live in,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúKnowing that His penis would need a home, God created a woman to be your wife. And when you marry her and look down you will notice that your wife is shaped differently than you and makes a very nice home.‚Äù Activist groups online have suggested Driscoll should be denied entry into the country over his attitudes to women, as in the case of serial domestic abuser and athlete Floyd Mayweather and so-called ‚Äúpick-up artist‚Äù Julien Blanc. Driscoll has apologised for the way he treated members of the church but not repudiated his views on the roles of men and women. In a statement on the Hillsong website on Friday, Houston said he and Driscoll ‚Äústand poles apart on women, their place in society, and their role in the church‚Äù. He said he wanted to hold an ‚Äúopen interview‚Äù with Driscoll and his wife, Grace, because there were ‚Äúlessons to be learned‚Äù from his story. ‚ÄúWe come from different backgrounds, theological positions, and church expressions. I genuinely want to know,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúDid he really say those things? Does he believe those things? Does he have any regrets? Has he been misrepresented? What has he learned and what can we all learn? And where to from here? ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to asking the questions and hearing from Mark directly. Will we agree afterwards or agree to disagree? Time will tell. I doubt we will agree on everything, but everyone deserves an opportunity to be heard.‚Äù

column4: Three-year-old girl dies after bouncy castle blows away in China
column5: A three-year-old girl has died after falling from a bouncy castle that was blown into the air in southern China. She was playing in the inflatable castle outside a supermarket when a freak gale blew it away, the official Xinhua news agency reported. The girl was seriously injured after falling from it and died in hospital, the agency said. It added unverified surveillance footage appeared to show the bouncy castle being swept up in five seconds. A woman tried to grab its edge but failed to stop the flight. It quoted Li Zhongji of the Tianyang county‚Äôs work safety bureau as saying the castle was an unlicensed business. A county government official on duty in the Guangxi region confirmed the accident took place on Thursday evening. AP contributed to this report

column4: China ferry disaster search area is extended 1,000km down Yangtze river
column5: Hundreds of bodies retrieved from the Eastern Star pushed the death toll above 400, China‚Äôs state broadcaster reported on Sunday, as the search for dozens more bodies was expanded to more than 1,000km down the Yangtze river following the country‚Äôs deadliest maritime disaster in nearly seven decades. Authorities have requested that river traffic and others along the river to alert them if they noticed any floating bodies, Hu Kaihong, the vice director-general of the press bureau of the State Council Information Office, told a news conference. Authorities have attributed the overturning of the cruise ship late on Monday to sudden, severe winds, but also have placed the captain and his first engineer in police custody. Passengers‚Äô relatives have raised questions about whether the ship should have continued its voyage after the storm started in a section of Hubei province and despite a weather warning earlier in the evening. The death toll rose to 406 after hundreds of bodies were found on Friday and Saturday, including that of a three-year-old girl in the top deck, officials said. Another 36 people were listed as missing, CCTV reported, citing rescue authorities. Hu said authorities were increasing their efforts to search for the missing and had expanded the target area from the middle reaches of the Yangtze more than 1,000 kilometres (600 miles) downstream to Shanghai. The boat had more than 450 people aboard, many of them elderly tourists, for a cruise from Nanjing to the southwestern city of Chongqing. Fourteen people survived, including three pulled out by divers from air pockets in the overturned hull on Tuesday. Disaster teams put chains around the hull and used cranes to roll the banged-up, white and blue boat upright and then gradually lift it out of the grey currents of the Yangtze on Friday. Forensic teams are using DNA matching to identify the remains, but haven‚Äôt said how long the process would take. On Saturday night, relatives were taken by bus to an area just upriver of the now-righted ship, where they burned incense and tossed flowers into the Yangtze in memory of the dead. The Eastern Star disaster became the country‚Äôs worst since the sinking of the SS Kiangya off Shanghai in 1948, which is believed to have killed anywhere from 2,750 to nearly 4,000 people. China‚Äôs deadliest maritime disaster in recent decades was the Dashun ferry, which caught fire and capsized off Shandong province in November 1999, killing about 280 people. Meanwhile, a TV station, Jiangsu Satellite, canceled the popular dating show If You Are the One and the rest of its entertainment shows on Saturday for three days because it was ‚Äúin deep mourning‚Äù, it said. AP contributed to this report

column4: Dazzling jewels from an Ethiopian grave reveal 2,000-year-old link to Rome
column5:
Spectacular 2,000-year-old treasures from the Roman empire and the Aksumite kingdom, which ruled parts of north-east Africa for several centuries before 940AD, have been discovered by British archaeologists in northern Ethiopia. Louise Schofield, a former British Museum curator, headed a major six-week excavation of the ancient city of Aksum where her team of 11 uncovered graves with ‚Äúextraordinary‚Äù artefacts dating from the first and second centuries. They offer evidence that the Romans were trading there hundreds of years earlier than previously thought. Schofield told the Observer: ‚ÄúEvery day we had shed-loads of treasure coming out of all the graves. I was blown away: I‚Äôd been confident we‚Äôd find something, but not on this scale.‚Äù She was particularly excited about the grave of a woman she has named ‚ÄúSleeping Beauty‚Äù. The way the body and its grave goods had been positioned suggest that she had been beautiful and much-loved.
Schofield said: ‚ÄúShe was curled up on her side, with her chin resting on her hand, wearing a beautiful bronze ring. She was buried gazing into an extraordinary Roman bronze mirror. She had next to her a beautiful and incredibly ornate bronze cosmetics spoon with a lump of kohl eyeliner.‚Äù The woman was also wearing a necklace of thousands of tiny beads, and a beaded belt. The quality of the jewellery suggests that she was a person of very high status, able to command the very best luxurious goods. Other artefacts with her include Roman glass vessels ‚Äì two perfectly preserved drinking beakers and a flask to catch the tears of the dead. There was also a clay jug. Schofield hopes that its contents can be analysed. She believes it would have contained food and drink for the afterlife. Although ‚ÄúSleeping Beauty‚Äù was covered only with soil, her grave was cut into a rock overhang, which is why the finds survived intact. The team also found buried warriors, with each skeleton wearing large iron bangles. They may have been killed in nearby battlefields. Other finds include another female skeleton with a valuable necklace of 1,065 coloured glass beads, and, elsewhere, a striking glass perfume flask. In 2012, the Observer reported that Schofield‚Äôs earlier excavations in the region had discovered an ancient goldmine that may solve the mystery of from where the Queen of Sheba of biblical legend derived her fabled treasures. Aksum, the capital of the Aksumite kingdom, was a major trading power from the first to the seventh centuries, linking the Roman Empire and India. Aksumites were a literate people. Yet little is known about this so-called ‚Äúlost‚Äù‚Äô civilisation. ‚ÄúEthiopia is a mysterious place steeped in legend, but nobody knows very much about it,‚Äù said Schofield. ‚ÄúWe know from the later Aksumite period ‚Äì the fourth and fifth centuries, when they adopted Christianity ‚Äì that they were trading very intensely with Rome. But our finds are from much earlier. So it shows that extraordinarily precious things were travelling from the Roman Empire through this region centuries before.‚Äù In return, the Romans sought ivory tusks, frankincense and metals. Schofield‚Äôs excavations also found evidence of iron working. The finds will go to a new German-funded museum, opening in October. Schofield hopes to organise a loan to the British Museum, but first the finds must be conserved: the mirror, for example, is corroded and slightly buckled. Germany is sending nine conservators. Excavations were paid for by the Sainsbury family‚Äôs Headley Trust and the Tigray Trust, a charity that promotes sustainability in the region; and by individual donations.

column4: Half a million refugees gather in Libya to attempt perilous crossing to Europe
column5:
Up to half a million refugees are gathering in Libya to attempt the crossing to Europe on the deadly boats that have killed thousands already. The toll of misery was revealed by senior Royal Navy officers leading Britain‚Äôs Mediterranean rescue mission off the Libyan coast. Britain‚Äôs amphibious assault ship HMS Bulwark has helped save around 4,000 refugees before they drowned having set sail in unseaworthy boats. The ship‚Äôs 350-strong company of sailors and Royal Marines is bracing itself to rescue a further 3,000. Captain Nick Cooke-Priest said: ‚ÄúIndications are that there are 450,000 to 500,000 migrants in Libya who are waiting at the border.‚Äù As he spoke, intelligence reports were warning Bulwark‚Äôs crew, which is among about 11 rescue vessels in the central Mediterranean, of thousands more migrants in the water. Britain is working with the Italian navy on Operation Weald to rescue migrants who have fallen prey to people smuggling gangs in Libya.
The passengers on some of the overcrowded boats are thought to have been told to scupper them as soon as they see a rescue ship, to ensure they will be saved, even though many of them cannot swim. Commodore Martin Connell, the Royal Navy‚Äôs senior officer commanding Operation Weald on board Bulwark said: ‚ÄúThis is just the most grim situation you could possibly find. It is a grim business ‚Ä¶ most of these boats won‚Äôt make it. If I could get my hands on some of these smuggling gangs. They have no regard for human life.‚Äù The defence secretary, Michael Fallon, visited Bulwark, flown in on one of the ship‚Äôs two Mark II Merlin helicopters, which are used to scour the seas for stranded boats. He urged the rest of Europe to help as Italy and Britain are taking on the brunt of the rescue workload. Asked about the half-a-million already preparing to make the hazardous journey by boat from Libya he told reporters: ‚ÄúWell you have seen today 3,000 people trying to cross in a single day, we could see hundreds of thousands trying to cross this summer. We all have an interest in tackling this much further back. The issue here is poverty and conflict in west Africa and poverty and conflict in east Africa.‚Äù He said more work was needed to smash the ruthless people smuggling gangs who organise the trips across treacherous waters. Fallon added: ‚ÄúWe can pool intelligence, get after the gangs themselves, we can try to cut off their financing. People are making money out of misery and we can do more there to track down the money. ‚ÄúThe Royal Navy stepped up to the plate straight away as David Cameron promised at the emergency summit so we are doing our bit with Bulwark and the helicopters, obviously we want other European countries to do more as well.‚Äù So far this year 76,000 migrants have made the 260-mile crossing into Europe from Libya, with 40,000 remaining in Italy.
On Saturday, Bulwark turned dramatically into the wind as once more it launched a Merlin helicopter to investigate reports of thousands of migrants who needed to be rescued. Meanwhile, Cameron is set to clash with Angela Merkel at the G7 summit over her plans for a pan-EU distribution of the migrants coming across the Mediterranean from north Africa, with the British prime minister insistent that such measures will only encourage the traffickers. The German chancellor has said that finding a way forward on the migration crisis will be a priority during the two-day talks starting in Bavaria on Sunday. She has previously said there should be a new EU system that distributes asylum seekers to member states based on their population and economic strength. Merkel is expected to make further such calls in the days to come. Downing Street, however, insists that it will not go along with the plans. Government officials claim they would deal only with the symptoms and not the cause of the humanitarian disaster. One government official said: ‚ÄúThe more the traffickers see that people are being resettled, the greater the incentive there is for them.‚Äù As part of his freshly announced agenda of tackling corruption, officials said Cameron would instead argue that attempts to dismantle the human trafficking networks should remain the focus, although the idea of an EU military force destroying boats in the Mediterranean has been rejected by the Libyan authorities.

column4: Sympathy and solidarity for migrants on Kos beaches as two worlds collide
column5:
Tourists must get up early to catch a glimpse of the morning procession that is now part of the daily summer routine on the Greek island of Kos. At around 7am, the day‚Äôs arrivals are walked from the small industrial port where their boats have been brought in by police launch and around the corner into the picturesque harbour of Kos Town, past the shuttered shops and cafes and on a 20-minute walk to the very outskirts of town. The knot of tired migrants have little more than a bag each. Those with children to carry bring still less, having paid ‚Ç¨1,200 (¬£875) to make the journey from the Turkish mainland; 40 to 45 people in unsafe, 15ft plastic dinghies, floors lined with plywood, damp with seawater. They are piled into the boat by the traffickers and pointed towards the Greek coastline. Along Kos harbourside they pass the dozen or more big holiday boats which will, in a few hours, load up with tourists and begin their day cruises across the Aegean to the Turkish city of Bodrum. Prices start at around ‚Ç¨25, although cocktails and Greek dancing on board cost a little more. It takes 35 minutes to get to Turkey in one of these boats; in the migrants‚Äô dinghies it is three to four sleepless hours in the dark. A retired British couple on an early stroll stop to watch the migrants‚Äô quiet parade. ‚ÄúFirst time I‚Äôve actually seen them, and we‚Äôve been here a week. So sad really. I hope they find new lives,‚Äù says Julia Brookes, a Scotswoman from Leeds. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ask him, though,‚Äù she says, indicating her husband, ‚Äúhe‚Äôs from the ‚Äòlet them die at sea‚Äô brigade. Terrible man.‚Äù Another woman, from Germany, in a neon bikini top, gets off her bicycle: ‚ÄúI come here every year, and I‚Äôm sorry to say enough is enough. This is testing the patience of people who are resident here, and the tourists who come to get away from the terrible news of wars and whatnot, not to see it. They shouldn‚Äôt be allowed to land.‚Äù One of the elderly fish sellers on the harbourside scolds her: ‚ÄúLady, you‚Äôd rather have bodies on the beaches? Tsk. We knew war here too once,‚Äù he says, fixing her with a beady eye. This weekend the arrivals are Syrian, but Afghans, Iraqis and Libyans have also made the journey. On Friday around 120, on Saturday 60, are led to what the police call the ‚Äúcamp‚Äù. The Captain Elias Hotel is just a shell, deserted during the economic slump. Before Easter local volunteers came in answer to a call from the mayor of Kos to clean the building and install standpipes for water. Dozens of bare mattresses line the floors and tents have gone up around the empty swimming pool. Here people try to find a space to sleep and wait until their paperwork is completed and they can move on, first to Athens, then to other parts of Europe. Officially, Greece allows only seven days on its soil, but on Kos the administrative infrastructure is overstretched and what had taken two days is taking longer. Residents drive up with regularity, dropping off what they can: bottles of water, bags of oranges, clothing. One woman brought a dozen cuddly toy dogs for children, driving off quickly as one of the fathers became tearful with gratitude. ‚ÄúThe Greeks have had bad times, many have nothing,‚Äù says Batoor Sulimankhel. ‚ÄúThis is hospitality. People with nothing understand more than people who have everything.‚Äù The Afghan has been here for three days and hopes to be moving on soon. Swedish holidaymaker Pernille Gusta, 27, and her five friends have cycled out from town to have a look. ‚ÄúThere are not so many people, but it is a shame to see the conditions,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWe asked people what they need, but they were just smiling and embarrassed. There‚Äôs a child with some stomach upset so we‚Äôll find a pharmacy and see what we can do.‚Äù She says there had been a row in her holiday apartment block about the presence there of migrants, who turned out to be a French Muslim family on holiday. ‚ÄúAn English family moved to another place. I can understand that it makes people feel guilty, so it‚Äôs hard to have fun when maybe you have worked hard for this vacation. But they are people too.‚Äù Her friend Sara adds: ‚ÄúIt is prejudice.‚Äù While the biggest entry route into the European Union for migrants remains international airports, the ‚Äúeastern Mediterranean route‚Äù, as Frontex ‚Äì the agency set up to coordinate operational response at Europe‚Äôs borders ‚Äì calls the Turkish-Greek routes, is now a migratory ‚Äúhotspot‚Äù. Some 40,000 people have taken it so far in 2015, compared with a rough average of 50,000 a year crossing from Turkey into Greece since 2008. What‚Äôs new is that traffickers are supplying boats, shortening migrants‚Äô journeys by sea instead of over the land border. The latest figures from Frontex say June has recorded the ‚Äúbiggest wave of migrants we have seen in 2015‚Äù, says its executive director, Fabrice Leggeri. With 2,000 migrants drowning in the Mediterranean this year, there is an exhausted euphoria among the newly-arrived in Kos. Coming off the police launch on Friday was a Syrian teacher, Mohamad al-Shamali. He showed photographs on his phone of the street he had left behind in Aleppo, all rubble and bloodstains and bombed-out cars. He is sad that he might not see his homeland again. ‚ÄúBut life is more important,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe worst is not even death; it‚Äôs the jails. So many people disappear,‚Äù says Shamali. ‚ÄúThere are three kinds of horrible in Syria: the Islamic forces, the Bashir soldiers, and the thieves who take people and want money, then kill them anyway.‚Äù He made it to Kos on his second attempt. He gets his uncle to show the scabs from a beating by Turkish police. ‚ÄúThey hit him hard, they came up on us in their boat and tried to sink it.‚Äù He points to his companions: ‚ÄúThis guy is trying to reach Denmark. His daughter is sick ‚Äì her blood ‚Äì and he has heard there is medicine there.‚Äù The man shows me the medical papers for his five-year-old. Shamali goes on: ‚ÄúThese two guys, they are soldiers and ran away, they crawled for 3km to get out of Syria. This guy is a Christian and ‚Ä¶‚Äù he draws a line across his throat. ‚ÄúThis guy was a law student, they made him army, he ran away to find his wife so they could leave together.‚Äù The young pair, Mouhammed Yusef al-Mnger and Aisha Mouhammed Jeblawi, in matching nylon tracksuits and rucksacks, are unwrapping their phones from makeshift waterproof plastic coverings. Jeblawi, bruised and dehydrated, has to be restrained from excitedly hugging every European she sees. Shamali leans forward and whispers: ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm a communist.‚Äù Biochemist Namir is here without his wife, a civil engineer. ‚ÄúShe is very clever,‚Äù he says. He hopes the engineering skills shortage in Europe might help them to be accepted somewhere, anywhere barrel bombs don‚Äôt fall from helicopters and severed body bits aren‚Äôt carried around his block of flats by feral dogs. Shaama, four, shrieks as a customs officer wearing a balaclava tells her mother to sit down. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the hood,‚Äù her mother Aysha says. ‚ÄúLike Daesh [Isis].‚Äù Another officer tells the Observer: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs unbelievable. We had one person in a wheelchair. Would you use that boat? No! They are so scared that even when they get on our boat they keep their lifejackets. Most are well-educated, not like me with my bad English,‚Äù he jokes. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll be logged and then have to wait for their paperwork. With 20 people in the coastguard and 20 police it‚Äôs tough. We try as fast as we can.‚Äù He says the numbers arriving varied. ‚ÄúThe most we have had in one day is 500, but more likely 100, less.‚Äù
Manolis is a port security guard who is angry to find a British journalist here. ‚ÄúWhy do the British papers say the things they have said?‚Äù he says, referring to a Daily Mail article last month which suggested that Kos was overrun with migrants bothering tourists and hanging dirty washing around the harbour. ‚ÄúIt will destroy us if the tourists stop coming. Already we are 27% down for the month. These people don‚Äôt make trouble. They stay a few days and are gone. These people are quiet and friendly and just escaping war.‚Äù Whatever the tabloid found when it was here, the British press‚Äôs name is now mud. In the week after the article, holiday website Trivago reported a 52% drop in searches for Kos. ‚ÄúWe hear there are a lot of cancellations. If it‚Äôs the economy, or the airlines, or the migrants, or the newspaper reports, we don‚Äôt know,‚Äù says Kos taxi driver Angelo. ‚ÄúBut it is worrying. These people are not thieves, they don‚Äôt steal or be dirty. They are escaping with their lives only. Do they really believe that a person who is trying to survive matters nothing compared to a person on a sun bed?‚Äù Some 1.7 million tourists are expected in Greece this year, where tourism represents 16% of the country‚Äôs GDP. In Kos, the reliance is even higher and the smallest drop in numbers will damage its fragile economy. As Greece teeters on the edge of bankruptcy, airports have announced that they have no money to maintain systems used to land aircraft, while night flights have already been stopped on Lesbos, Greece‚Äôs third-largest island, with Kos, Skiathos and Santorini likely to follow suit. So in Kos, mixed in with fear that tourists won‚Äôt come any more, there is some gratitude that the migrants have euros to spend. At the Captain Elias, Namir the biochemist has returned from buying bread pushing two rather tatty bicycles, far from the shiny ones that tourists are riding. They will have to visit the police station daily to chase up their papers and it‚Äôs a long way. But like the room Shamali and his friends rented this weekend, the price was higher than usual tourist rates. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs OK,‚Äù he grins. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a risk, I know, although why anyone would think I would want to steal a bicycle!‚Äù It‚Äôs funny, he says, that he had to sell his beloved car in Syria to raise cash for a leaky dinghy in Turkey and then a bike nobody else wants in Greece. Everyone makes money from the migrants, say his friends, who joke that if he reaches Germany the Germans will sell him a donkey. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs OK,‚Äù says Namir, ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather they see I‚Äôm willing to pay than think I‚Äôm an animal to be drowned at sea.‚Äù Guardian members and journalists will be discussing the real human stories behind the current crisis and the EU‚Äôs responsibility to migrants arriving in Europe at Migration in Crisis, a Guardian Live event being held at Kings Place, London N1 9GU, on 11 June. Tickets cost ¬£10 (partners and patrons ¬£5) and can be booked at membership.the guardian.com/events

column4: Israeli rights groups join battle to save symbol of Arab resistance to evictions
column5:
In the cool of evening, the Palestinian villagers of Khirbet Susiya go about their business. A beekeeper in a protective suit and veil moves among his hives with a smoke can. Others use the warm wind blowing from the nearby Negev desert to separate rough legumes from chaff. Shepherds move their animals across the low, rolling yellow hills while children run about the playground. It appears a peaceful scene. Except that, for a third time in almost three decades, the few hundred villagers who live in crude temporary houses dotted about this area of the south Hebron hills of the occupied West Bank are under imminent threat of a new forced displacement. Last month an Israeli high court judge ruled against the villagers‚Äô injunction seeking to halt Israel‚Äôs planned destruction of Khirbet Susiya. Now the village has become the centre of a growing international campaign over its future which has drawn in European diplomats and human rights campaigners. Khirbet Susiya is home to between 250 and 350 villagers ‚Äì depending on the season ‚Äì who live in around 100 structures and eke out an existence largely from subsistence agriculture. Built on a scrubby ridge of limestone pavement, the houses of Khirbet Susiya are closely overlooked by a neighbouring Israeli settlement built on land expropriated from the villagers ‚Äì illegal under international law ‚Äì and, unlike the Palestinian village, connected to public services. On the other side of the nearby road is an archaeological site also run by settlers. Khirbet Susiya is sandwiched in-between. It is this proximity ‚Äì critics allege ‚Äì that underlies Israeli plans to move the villagers. The residents say that the destruction of their homes would mean the latest in several forcible expulsions from their land for which they have deeds going back to the Ottoman era. In 1986 they were expelled from their original village ‚Äì the archaeological site run by settlers who also lived nearby. Until then villagers had lived in houses and cave houses there. The army expelled the residents again in 2001 during the second intifada ‚Äì a short time after Palestinians killed an Israeli from the neighbouring Susiya settlement. Then the residents relocated to their current location on their agricultural land. While Israel claims the structures in Khirbet Susiya are illegal because they were put up without building permits, critics say that Israel‚Äôs civil administration has a policy of rarely issuing building permits to non-Jews in Area C ‚Äì the part of the occupied territories under full Israeli administration. Although the Israeli court accepted the villagers‚Äô ownership of the land, it ruled that they did not have permission to build there. Seventy-year-old Mohammad Ahmad al-Nuwaja has lived on the land around Susiya most of his life. ‚ÄúI was born in Tal Arad, but after the Nakba [‚Äòthe catastrophe‚Äô as Palestinians call the mass displacement that occurred when Israel was founded] we moved here. We are the original owners of this land,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúWe have deeds from the Turkish time.
‚ÄúThey claim these houses were built without permits. We have applied so many times and the Israelis rejected permission. They claim we don‚Äôt have the infrastructure to support living here, but they are the ones who won‚Äôt allow the infrastructure. We were offered land in exchange for moving from here near Yatta [the neighbouring town visible from Khirbet Susiya] but they have no right.‚Äù The long saga of Khirbet Susiya is symbolic of a wider problem of demolition and displacement affecting unrecognised villages in both the occupied Palestinian territories and Bedouin communities in Israel itself. According to Rabbis for Human Rights, an Israeli NGO which has been supporting the village in its efforts to get planning permission: ‚ÄúThe village of Palestinian Susiya has existed for centuries, long before the establishment of the [Jewish settlement of Susiya in 1983. There is documentary evidence of a settlement in the area dating back to 1830, and it is also marked on British mandatory maps from 1917.‚Äù There are indications, however, that the Israeli military intends to go ahead with the demolition. Almost immediately following the court ruling an Israeli inspector for the military‚Äôs civil administration, accompanied by soldiers, arrived to survey the houses ‚Äì often a precursor to demolition. The latest threat to Susiya was prompted by a complaint three years ago by Regavim, a rightwing Israeli NGO, which uses the courts to insist on the demolition of Palestinian buildings it argues are illegal. Regavim describes its mission as using the courts ‚Äúto protect national lands and properties and prevent foreign elements from taking over the countries [sic] territorial resources‚Äù and pursued this case despite the fact that Kirbet Susiya is not in Israel but in the occupied Palestinian territories. The villagers‚Äô plight was described in a recent report by the Israeli human rights organisation BT‚Äôselem. ‚ÄúThe state has been abusing the residents of Khirbet Susiya for many years: the army and the civil administration have repeatedly removed the residents from their homes, in which they have lived since before 1967, when Israel occupied the West Bank. ‚ÄúThe [Israeli] civil administration is responsible for all aspects of civilian life in area C and is theoretically supposed to promote the wellbeing of the local population. In practice, the administration uses its planning systems, in which Palestinians are not represented, to prevent them from promoting solutions that would meet their needs, barring them from building legally and from connecting to water and power supplies. ‚ÄúThe authorities also systematically refrain from protecting the residents of Khirbet Susiya from settlers who attack them or vandalise their property, and restrict their free access to the main town in the district, Yatta.‚Äù
For its part, the Israeli civil administration argued in 2013 that the villagers would be better off leaving their land and moving closer to the nearby town. It said: ‚ÄúWe see the current plan [prepared by the village] as yet another attempt to keep a poor, downtrodden population from advancing; from choosing between partial income and other resources; it is an attempt to prevent the Palestinian woman from breaking the cycle of poverty and depriving her of educational and professional opportunities. ‚ÄúSimilarly, by sentencing the Palestinian child to life in a small, stultified village with no means for development, the plan keeps the child from being aware of all the opportunities available to any other person. It is our recommendation that the plan be rejected out of hand.‚Äù The villagers don‚Äôt see it that way. Nasser Nuwaja is a resident who has been leading the campaign to save it. He points out that almost half the representatives on the village council are women and that whether they live on their own land should be their choice. ‚ÄúThe land we were offered is 1.5km from here. But we don‚Äôt own it. It would cause a conflict with another family. ‚ÄúSince the court ruling, people here have gone to bed not knowing whether the bulldozers would come in the morning. It is like trying to balance on a chair with only one leg and not knowing when you will fall off. People here are living on edge.‚Äù And for now international pressure remains their best hope. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been campaigning hard on this issue,‚Äù said one European diplomat. ‚ÄúWe are trying to put pressure on the Israeli government to prevent the demolition.‚Äù Although the villagers will try to go to court again on 3 August many are fearful the village will be destroyed and moved again. ‚ÄúGod forbid they demolish Susiya again,‚Äù says Nasser. ‚ÄúBut if they do, we will rebuild it.‚Äù

column4: Around the world in an autogyro: cancer survivor attempts a global first
column5:
When Norman Surplus was diagnosed with advanced bowel cancer at 40, it was ‚Äúa body blow‚Äù. The prognosis gave him only a 40% chance of living for 18 months. He still gets emotional when he describes the ‚Äúmental challenge‚Äù he faced 12 years ago, knowing that the odds were that very soon he would be leaving his young family behind. One day, when recovering from surgery, he saw a reality TV show involving the restoration of an old autogyro that had been sitting for decades at the back of a barn. ‚ÄúI thought to myself: ‚ÄòIf I get out of this mess, that‚Äôs something I‚Äôd like to try.‚Äô‚Äù Suddenly, he had a goal to reach. The goal helped him stay positive through surgeries and particularly aggressive bouts of chemotherapy. When, against the odds, he was finally up and about again, he duly got his license at the only school that then offered training, in the UK. He flew his autogyro home from Northumbria to Northern Ireland, across the Irish Sea, and started thinking about how far he could take it.
After some research, he realised with delight that despite a few recent attempts, no one had yet flown an autogyro around the world. ‚ÄúTo find an aviation record that‚Äôs not been set is very rare,‚Äù he said. He decided to try, and after four years, he‚Äôs still going. In 2010 he set off from Belfast, and over the next year he flew through 18 countries in Europe, the Middle East and east over Asia to reach Japan. Then he fell foul of the worsening geopolitical situation between Russia and the rest of the world. ‚ÄúWe had written permission but we were delayed en route. We had to reapply, but we never got permission again to fly across Russia.‚Äù The aviation authorities were okay with it, but they had to run everything by a number of agencies, including the spooks at Russia‚Äôs FSB. The intelligence agency didn‚Äôt say no; it simply didn‚Äôt reply to the request. Surplus thinks that this let officials in effect stop the flight without having to explain their objections. For three years, the gyro was in mothballs in Japan. Surplus looked into other routes through the Japanese islands and the Aleutians, or the South Pacific, but the craft just didn‚Äôt have quite enough range. Finally he couldn‚Äôt delay any further. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to keep an aircraft legally registered and active when it‚Äôs stuck in one place,‚Äù he said. He shipped the autogyro to Tacoma, Washington, and it wintered at the Evergreen Air and Space Museum in McMinville, about an hour south-west of Portland. Now he‚Äôll track across the US, and spend the summer island-hopping across the north Atlantic, from northern Canada, to Greenland, then Iceland and the outer Hebrides, and back to Belfast. This in itself will be a record: ‚ÄúNo autogyro has ever flown across the Atlantic.‚Äù That‚Äôs remarkable since this is a 92 year old technology, the ‚Äúforgotten cousin of the helicopter‚Äù. Unlike the more familiar chopper, the autogyro‚Äôs top rotor is not powered. ‚ÄúIt looks like a helicopter, but it flies much more like a fixed wing.‚Äù The rear propeller provides thrust; the top rotor spins ‚Äúlike a windmill‚Äù, driven by the rushing air. In the 1930s, it was hailed as a miracle technology. During the second world war, the aircraft had an unsung, secret role in helping to calibrate radar signals, and helped to win the Battle of Britain. But after the war, the autogyro was entirely displaced by more powerful helicopters. Surplus thinks its time might be coming again. In an energy-conscious age, its efficiency is attractive ‚Äì it only uses a third of the the aviation fuel of a helicopter of similar size. It‚Äôs also cheap, simply maintained, and easy to fly. It can take off after 50 metres and can land in 10. Surplus mentions the autogyro‚Äôs current use on big Australian sheep stations, and he reckons it‚Äôs ideal for everything from traffic reporting to border patrols. Surplus himself can attest to its ability to survive tight spots. When flying across Saudi Arabia, he found himself with huge storms approaching him fore and aft, and an almost empty desert below. Spying a gas station, he landed on a desert highway nearby, and was given shelter by the amused attendants, who only spoke Arabic. In the morning, with the storm passed, he filled up at their bowser with the cheap, high-octane gas that‚Äôs de rigeur in the kingdom, and went on his way to Riyadh. It‚Äôs these moments of goodwill from strangers, Surplus candidly admits, that have kept the whole enterprise going. There‚Äôs no big ground or support crew, and never a guarantee that he won‚Äôt be ensnared by red tape or worse as he flits from country to country. But he‚Äôs determined, raising funds for bowel cancer along the way: ‚ÄúI love an underdog, and the autogyro is the ultimate underdog of aviation.‚Äù With Surplus at the controls of his small yellow gyrocopter, two underdogs are having their day.

column4: India and Bangladesh seal border deal, four decades later
column5: Bangladesh and India have sealed a deal to swap border territories, more than 40 years after it was negotiated. The prime ministers of both countries watched as bureaucrats signed the pact in Dhaka, Bangladesh‚Äôs capital. The deal, reached in 1974 but only recently ratified by India‚Äôs parliament, will be seen as a major achievement for Narendra Modi, the Indian prime minister, who won a landslide election last year to take power. ‚Äú[The deal] will make our borders more secure and people‚Äôs lives more stable,‚Äù the 64-year-old leader said. Modi has had difficulty delivering achievements domestically, but has been active on the international scene and compared the agreement with the dismantling of the Berlin Wall. ‚Äú[Foreign policy] is one area where there has been unexpected and major progress,‚Äù said C Raja Mohan, an Indian foreign affairs analyst. ‚ÄúThis will open the door for significant co-operations and economic engagement.‚Äù Just an hour after Modi‚Äôs arrival in Dhaka, top Indian conglomerates signed outline agreements with Bangladesh‚Äôs state-run electricity agency to invest some $5bn in the country‚Äôs rickety power sector. Indian officials said yesterday‚Äôs agreement sent an important signal that the border disputes that plague India‚Äôs relations with other regional powers could be solved, but added that disagreements with Bangladesh were easier to resolve than those with rival Asian giant China, or with Pakistan, with which India has fought four wars. The agreement was also a boost for Sheikh Hasina, the prime minister of Bangladesh. Hasina won a disputed election last year which was boycotted by the opposition and dismissed as lacking credibility by some western governments. She has been criticised since for cracking down on dissent. Scores of people have been killed in firebomb attacks on vehicles since opposition leaders called a transport blockade at the start of the year in an attempt to oust the current government. Relations between India and its smaller neighbour have significantly improved since Hasina promised her administration would not allow India‚Äôs separatist insurgents to use the porous 2,500-mile border to carry out raids. Eighteen soldiers died in an ambush blamed on the separatists last week. The Indian army helped Bangladesh gain independence from Pakistan in a bloody nine-month war in 1971 and relations have usually been warm. There are hopes now that the border agreement will also boost trade. It will allow tens of thousands of people living in 162 enclaves resulting from ownership arrangements made centuries ago by local princes either side of the border enclaves to choose their nationality after decades of stateless limbo. ‚ÄúThis is a way of cleaning up the mess left by partition [of British India in 1947],‚Äù said Mohan. India‚Äôs parliament only gave its approval last month. People living in the enclaves will be allowed to choose to live in India or Bangladesh, with the option of being granted citizenship in the newly designated territories, and the enclaves would effectively cease to exist. Wary of China‚Äôs growing interest in India‚Äôs backyard, Modi has been keen to play a greater leadership role in South Asia since coming to power. He is set to meet Khaleda Zia, the main Bangladesh opposition leader. Indian officials have played down the idea of Modi playing a mediation role in the dispute between Hasina and Zia, although he might press on Zia to ensure an end to anti-government attacks. India held off from criticising Hasina‚Äôs re-election in January 2014.

column4: How Turkey‚Äôs pro-Kurdish party HDP could derail Erdogan push for power
column5:
In the towns and villages of south-eastern Turkey, Kurdish clan leaders have long experience of dealing with disputes. In mediation practices going back hundreds of years, they have perfected conflict resolution techniques to negotiate rivalries and blood feuds. In recent weeks the traditions have found a novel field of play ‚Äì national politics. The tribal chiefs and clan leaders are trading their loyalties and allegiances for votes, with results that will become apparent on Sunday on Sunday when Turkey goes to the polls in an epic election that will determine the fate of the country‚Äôs president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Something is stirring in Turkey‚Äôs Kurdish region, and some predict a seismic shift in Turkish politics. The focus of this trend is the People‚Äôs Democratic party (HDP), a new group of leftists and liberals that centres its election programme on minority rights and the rights of women. Its co-chair is Selahattin Demirtas, a young politician and surprise star of the election campaign. Recent polls show the HDP hovering just above Turkey‚Äôs 10% election threshold to enter parliament, one of the highest in the world. The stakes could not be higher. If the party manages to get into parliament, it could secure up to 70 seats, possibly putting an end to the 13-year majority government of Erdogan‚Äôs AKP, or Justice and Development party, and dashing the head of state‚Äôs hopes of engineering a more powerful executive presidency. With the help of local ‚Äúpersuasion committees‚Äù many large tribes ‚Äì Kurds, Arabs and Turkmen ‚Äì have pledged their allegiance to the HDP, taking thousands of voters, most of whom previously cast their ballots for the AK party, with them. Take Burhan Saran, for example. A prominent local AKP politician for the duration of the party‚Äôs ascendancy, he resigned 20 days ago and joined the HDP, taking with him around 4,000 votes now denied to Erdogan and gifted to his most feared rival. ‚ÄúWe drove to the HDP‚Äôs headquarters in Batman with a celebratory convoy of 650 cars to announce our decision,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI had high hopes for AKP before. I invested a lot of time and work in them, but they did not deliver on their promises of peace. When it comes down to it, we are all Kurds, and peace is all that matters to us now.‚Äù The last straw, he said, was the government‚Äôs unwillingness to assist the Syrian-Kurdish border town of Kobani during the attack by Islamic State last year. ‚ÄúThe AK party has failed us.‚Äù The shift marks a significant change in local Kurdish politics. Many members of Saran‚Äôs tribe are village guards, a huge force of mainly Kurdish paramilitaries created almost 30 years ago by the Turkish state to patrol Kurdish settlements of the south-east. Village guards, being Kurds, are seen as traitors and opportunists by their compatriots, and many have been accused of grave human rights violations. ‚ÄúI talked to many of the guards,‚Äù Saran said. ‚ÄúWe are ready for reconciliation. Those that hesitate are afraid to lose their livelihoods, but they will come around. With or without the AK, we will end the politics of pitching Kurd against Kurd.‚Äù After he handed in his resignation to the AKP, the calls started piling in. ‚ÄúI turned off my phone and locked up my house for a week,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMany high AKP officials tried to persuade me to come back. A minister called me.‚Äù He added that they promised him ‚Äúanything‚Äù in order to change his mind. ‚ÄúBut my decision was made.‚Äù Batman‚Äôs mayor, Sabri √ñzdemir, himself a member of the HDP-led ‚Äúpersuasion commissions‚Äù that negotiate with local leaders, said that it has been ‚Äúeasy‚Äù to convince many former AKP supporters. ‚ÄúThe AKP actually did most of the work for us,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTheir hostility towards Kobani and Kurdish fighters, the corruption scandals, their disputes among themselves, and their constant stalling of the peace process made people lose faith in the government.‚Äù In Batman, AKP took almost 37% of the vote in the last elections in 2011, securing two of the four available seats. But since then support has been waning. Many blame the lack of progress on the ongoing peace process between the Turkish government and the outlawed Kurdistan Workers‚Äô party (PKK), whose guerrillas have been fighting Ankara for the past 30 years, as well as AK party blunders in Syria. Expectations of, and confidence in, an HDP victory are high in Batman. But many fear that there might be attempts at ballot-rigging. Opposition parties have called on citizens to volunteer as election monitors, and the HDP leadership has announced that they are ‚Äúwell prepared‚Äù to ‚Äúprotect all votes‚Äù. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt been able to sleep for a week,‚Äù said Ibrahim Yilmaz, 60. ‚ÄúI am so worried they will steal our votes, that they will try anything to push the HDP below the threshold.‚Äù According to a survey published by Istanbul‚Äôs Ko√ß University in May, trust in fair elections dropped to 48% from 70% in 2007. While the AKP was previously able to take around 50% of all Kurdish votes on promises of peace and economic development, many of their supporters in Batman now voice their disappointment that only very few pledges have been delivered. According to official statistics, the province still suffers the highest unemployment rate in the country, at more than 20%, double the national average. But at a local AKP election office, the mood is defiant. Only a few men sit in chairs, and leaf through stacks of glossy election pamphlets. ‚ÄúThe AKP is the only party in Turkey that cares about us Kurds,‚Äù said Celat Turan, 56, pointing to a brochure that advertises infrastructure built in Batman under the ruling party. ‚ÄúThere is no Kurdish problem here. The roads here are now better than the roads in Istanbul ‚Äì how can anyone still speak of discrimination?‚Äù His friends nod in agreement. ‚ÄúWe are proud of our leader. Whatever president Erdogan wants we want as well.‚Äù Ilhan Alta√ß, a local village headman, would have agreed, but recently decided to pledge all 714 votes of his constituency to the HDP. ‚ÄúI got sick of Erdogan‚Äôs polarising language,‚Äù he said. He is one of 50 village headmen who switched sides in May. His predominantly Kurdish village has been supporting parties loyal to the Turkish state for over 25 years. But no longer. ‚ÄúNever in my life had I expected to find myself voting for this party,‚Äù Alta√ß said. ‚ÄúUp until last month, I would not even come to have a cup of tea with these people, because I had a bad image of the HDP. Everyone should come and see who they really are, and what they do. I found that my prejudices were all wrong.‚Äù The AKP has tried to use these prejudices against their rivals during the election campaign, berating the HDP as a bunch of ‚Äúmarginals, gays and atheists‚Äù. Some say that the aggressive rhetoric has led to more than 70 attacks on HDP campaigners all over Turkey. On Thursday, a mob attacked HDP supporters in the eastern city of Erzurum before an election rally. Around 150 HDP campaign vehicles were burned, 200 people were wounded, three of them critically. In the most serious attack so far, two bombs exploded in the main Kurdish city of Diyarbakir , killing at least two. Hundreds were injured. Amid rising tension, the HDP leadership has managed to keep calm among its supporters. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt give in to your anger,‚Äù Demirtas told the crowd after the bomb attacks. ‚ÄúWe will win, we will bring peace to this country.‚Äù In campaign speeches only thinly veiled as impartial ribbon-cutting ceremonies all over the Kurdish south-east, Erdogan has repeatedly brandished a Kurdish translation of the Qur‚Äôan, warning ‚Äúhis Muslim Kurdish brothers‚Äù not to support ‚Äúthese people who have no relationship with Islam‚Äù. Referring to Ali Atalan, the HDP‚Äôs top candidate in Batman and a member of the Yazidi religious minority, conservative rightwing politicians demanded that voters not vote for ‚Äúpagans‚Äù.
But many in Batman, a religiously conservative region, are indignant about the president‚Äôs blatant use of Islam to rally his base. Selim Yilmaz, an Islamic scholar and imam for 27 years, criticised the AKP‚Äôs attempts to discredit the HDP as ‚Äúheathen‚Äù. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs such nonsense. The Qur‚Äôan does not support such a statement. The HDP unites all kinds of people: religious people, atheists, gays, and others. It‚Äôs like a beautiful garden where all kinds of fruit are growing. But he conceded that the AKP‚Äôs propaganda resonates with some. ‚ÄúI get calls from people asking if they will turn into Yazidis if they vote for a Yazidi, or if it is a sin to support a candidate who drinks alcohol,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI tell them they cannot have a healthy democracy if they expect a politician who will represent their interests to be and live exactly like them.‚Äù For Yilmaz, the idea of an executive presidency under Erdogan is abhorrent. ‚ÄúThat man does not recognise anyone‚Äôs interests. All he cares about and fights for is his own power.‚Äù

column4: Modi‚Äôs plan to change India and the world through yoga angers religious minorities
column5: Every morning, before the temperatures in India‚Äôs capital start to rise, a handful of old friends gather. On the parched grass not far from the India Gate monument at the centre of Delhi, they stretch, breathe and meditate. ‚ÄúIt is the only healthy way to start the day. Much better than an egg or a sandwich or a cup of tea,‚Äù said Arvind Singh at 6.15am as he did his breathing exercises on a bench. Singh, a 42-year-old salesman, and his friends are far from alone. All across India, in the overcrowded cities, on whatever green space is left, similar scenes are being played out. On 21 June ‚Äì the new International Yoga day ‚Äì Narendra Modi, India‚Äôs prime minister, hopes the world will join in. The grass near India Gate will be transformed into the venue for what it is hoped will be the biggest single yoga session ever held, with up to 45,000 people running through a 35-minute routine. The participants will include 64-year-old Modi, most of his government and, they hope, a range of celebrities. Officials have been sent to round up volunteers from scores of countries to reinforce the international credentials of the ancient Indian practice. Getting Indians, and others, stretching has emerged as something of a focus for Modi, who led his Bharatiya Janata Party to a landslide election victory last year. Last month schools were directed to make sure students attended yoga events timed to coincide with the big demonstration in Delhi, even though it is being held on a Sunday. Officials have already signalled the introduction of compulsory yoga for India‚Äôs famously out-of-shape police officers, and said that daily yoga lessons would be offered free to three million civil servants and their families. Air India, the national carrier, has also said it will introduce yoga for trainee pilots. More controversially, senior politicians in India have suggested more widespread practice of yoga could bring down soaring levels of sexual violence in the country. Modi, an ascetic who is a committed vegetarian and an enthusiastic yoga practitioner himself, suggested an international yoga day when speaking to the United Nations on a visit to New York last year. ‚ÄúYoga is an invaluable gift of India‚Äôs ancient tradition. It embodies unity of mind and body, thought and action, restraint and fulfilment, harmony between man and nature, a holistic approach to health and wellbeing. It is not about exercise but discovering the sense of oneness with yourself, the world and nature,‚Äù Modi said at the time, adding that yoga could help in tackling climate change. The discipline is between 3,000 and 6,000 years old and originated somewhere on the Indian subcontinent, possibly among religious ascetics. Its meditative practices as well as physical exercises have long been associated with local religious traditions including Buddhism and Jainism, as well as the Hinduism practised by 80% of Indians. Yet this association with faith has led to some criticism of Modi‚Äôs campaign from religious minorities. ‚ÄúMany Muslim scholars say that yoga is against the fundamental tenets of Islam ‚Äì to pray to the sun, for example,‚Äù said Asaduddin Owaisi, a Muslim member of parliament. ‚ÄúWhy make this a nationalist issue?
