Two homes were targeted for demolition, according to the mayor‚Äôs office, which claimed residents pelted police, municipal guardsman and city officials with ‚Äústones, rocks and bricks‚Äù as soon as the work was authorized. It said four guards were injured. Residents give a different story. They say about 50 or 60 of them tried to form a human chain around the homes that were due for demolition and that the police used violence, as well as pepper spray, to try to break them up. Only then, they say, did they throw rocks. In response, the police used rubber bullets and percussion grenades. Residents posted images on their Facebook page of the injuries sustained on their side. It showed blood streaming from the head wounds of a middle-aged woman and man. One of the injured, Penha Silva, was hit near the eye with a riot-police baton, according to her daughter Natalia. ‚ÄúI was right next to her and saw it happen. She is at the hospital right now doing some tests, an x-ray, but thank god she is out of danger.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey came with bulldozers and fired rubber bullets at the residents as well as percussion grenades,‚Äù said the head of the Vila Aut√≥dromo association, Altair Guimar√£es. ‚ÄúI was hit with a baton by the municipal guard.‚Äù Ocimar da Silva Miranda, whose home was targeted, said he was hit in the arm by a rubber bullet. ‚ÄúWe have the right to live here, but they want to take it by force. It‚Äôs not right,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe mayor is using our lives, our homes, as a way to pay back the loans from the big construction companies that financed his campaign. But it‚Äôs our lives, our homes.‚Äù The holdouts have protested before against what they believe are unjustified and unnecessary demolition plans. They believe they are being evicted so developers can make higher profits once the Olympic Games are finished. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs strange that we are being forced out of our homes in the name of public works, yet this is a private investment,‚Äù said Jane Nascimento de Oliveira, who says she has been offered 400,000 reals (about $128,000) to move. The city hall says all residents have been offered compensation and alternative housing at a newly built condominium, Parque Carioca, about a kilometre away. Mayor Paes originally said he would not order forced relocations. Additional reporting by Shanna Hanbury

column4: American Red Cross squandered aid after Haiti earthquake, report alleges
column5:
Despite collecting nearly half a billion dollars for Haiti earthquake relief, the American Red Cross has built only six permanent homes and seemingly squandered millions in the country, according to a new report. A joint investigation by ProPublica and NPR uncovered rampant mismanagement, high overhead costs and deeply rooted acrimony from Haitians toward the aid organization. Among the investigation‚Äôs findings was that although the Red Cross apportioned about $170m to the category of ‚Äúshelter‚Äù relief, and although it at first planned to build some 700 houses, it only constructed six permanent homes. The report charges the Red Cross with consistent misrepresentation of its projects, especially in housing. The authors cite promotional materials that say the Red Cross provided more than 130,000 people with homes, and then note that that total includes people in ‚Äútransitional shelters‚Äù, recipients of short-term rent assistance, and people who had been ‚Äútrained in proper construction techniques‚Äù.
The Red Cross disputes the report and asserts it has ‚Äúhelped build and operate eight hospitals and clinics‚Äù and ‚Äúmove more than 100,000 people out of make-shift tents into safe and improved housing‚Äù. In a statement, the organization said it is ‚Äúdisappointed‚Äù by the ‚Äúlack of balance, context and accuracy‚Äù on the part of ProPublica and NPR. A major problem for the organization was leadership and staffing, according to the report. Integral positions, including experts for health and shelter, were left vacant for months and sometimes years. The positions that were staffed were predominantly held by expats or by people flown in from the United States, many of whom could not speak French or Creole. In one 2011 document, Red Cross official Judith St Ford notes that there are ‚Äúserious program delays caused by internal issues that go unaddressed‚Äù, including for cholera relief. ‚ÄúThere is a clear lack of foresight and planning,‚Äù she wrote, and ‚Äúthe lack of leadership ability has contributed to poor morale in the field.‚Äù She also urged her superiors to hire more Haitians: ‚Äúthe implication that talented, smart, competent Haitians cannot be found in Haiti has to be dispelled.‚Äù In its statement the Red Cross says 90% of its current staff are Haitians; the organization did not break down the hierarchy or positions of its staff.
‚ÄúIf they were an organization that had a real history in Haiti I think this would‚Äôve gone a lot better,‚Äù said Justin Elliott, one of the journalists who co-wrote the report. ‚ÄúThe entire Haiti reconstruction effort has been really problematic, but the outside groups that have done better have roots there, have Haitian people working at high levels, have people who speak the language.‚Äù In one 2013 email published by ProPublica, CEO Gail McGovern admitted a project had failed and that she did not know what to do with a $20m remainder. ‚ÄúNow that the Northern project is going bust and we are still holding $20 million of contingency, any ideas on how to spend the rest of this?‚Äù she asked, before mentioning a mysterious ‚Äúwonderful helicopter idea‚Äù. Without Haitians in leadership positions, the Red Cross was particularly ill-prepared to deal with Haiti‚Äôs land tenure rules, a system so tangled and unforgiving that it has intimidated USAid and Vatican relief efforts.
‚ÄúLand tenure is probably the biggest stumbling block,‚Äù said Jonathan M Katz, a freelance journalist and author of a book about the earthquake, The Big Truck That Went By. The system has stymied aid organizations for years, and Katz said that for years aid organizations have ‚Äúthrown up their collective hands and said ‚Äòwe don‚Äôt really want to deal with this.‚Äô‚Äù The Red Cross entangled itself in a web of other organizations, often paying them to do relief work, themselves struggling in Haiti. This outsourcing is commonplace in the international aid industry, Katz said, and leads to inevitable but not necessarily unreasonable overhead costs. But eager to better solicit donations, organizations often try to downplay these costs.
The report notes that overhead charges by the Red Cross and its contractors undermine McGovern‚Äôs claim that ‚Äúminus the nine cents overhead, 91 cents on the dollar will be going to Haiti.‚Äù In one case, Elliott and his co-author, NPR‚ÄôS Laura Sullivan, found that the International Federation of the Red Cross (IFRC) exacted $1.56m in overhead from the American Red Cross‚Äôs payment of $6m, all to help give Haitians rental subsidies so they could leave tent camps. The IFRC said the costs were related to ‚Äúadministration, finance, human resources‚Äù. In another case, the Red Cross commissioned Swiss and Spanish Red Cross societies to upgrade shelters, but still took 24% of the money for the project in additional overhead costs, according to the report. Where exactly the $488m of the American Red Cross‚Äôs Haiti budget has gone is unclear, Elliott said, since ‚Äúthe whole international aid sector is pretty opaque in general. And the spending of the American Red Cross is incredible opaque. You can tell hardly anything from their disclosures.‚Äù He said that the issue of money was particularly sensitive to Haitians who had coordinated with the Red Cross. ‚ÄúThey were furious basically over broken promises,‚Äù Elliott said. ‚ÄúAbout three years ago, the Red Cross told people they were going to build hundreds of new homes in this very hard-hit area, and this thing was just stalled. Over the next two years they had meetings with the community, handed out juice boxes and so on, and nothing happened for a long time.‚Äù
The Red Cross is now helping build a road and install solar lights in the area. Katz said that the problems of the American Red Cross are ‚Äútypical of the aid industry in general. The Red Cross is sort of the biggest kid on the block. Because they make way more money than anybody else, what they do is magnified.‚Äù The interconnected NGOs and aid organizations of the world, ranging from the many satellites of the Red Cross to Doctors Without Borders to the Clinton Foundation, Katz said, should deserve more skepticism from the public. Reports have traced the 2011 cholera epidemic to United Nations relief efforts, he noted, adding that many organizations operate more like businesses than anything else. ‚ÄúEven when an aid group is pulling off a project well,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúif it isn‚Äôt going to be there forever, if it isn‚Äôt going to be accountable for successes and failures, if it isn‚Äôt leaving something behind that‚Äôs permanent, then it‚Äôs still capable of doing damage.‚Äù Last year the Red Cross similarly took issue with another ProPublica report that said the organization had disastrously mismanaged aid relief after hurricane Sandy.

column4: Brazil makes space for indigenous people with new reserve in S√É¬£o Paulo
column5:
Indigenous activists in Brazil are celebrating a ruling by the country‚Äôs government to declare a new indigenous reserve on the fringes of Latin America‚Äôs largest city. For the past 10 years, members of a Guarani community just inside S√£o Paulo‚Äôs northern city limits have been attempting to get their village and 72-hectare [178-acre] swath of forest recognised as traditional tribal lands. In an announcement published on Monday in the Di√°rio Oficial da Uni√£o, Brazil‚Äôs journal of record, the justice Minister Jos√© Cardozo declared the settlement traditional Guarani territory, as part of a wider 532-hectare area around the Pico de Jaragu√° mountaintop. The announcement marks the second stage in a three-step process, following the recognition of the land as Guarani in 2013 by Funai, Brazil‚Äôs federal agency for Indian affairs. The third step is the signing of a presidential decree declaring the land demarcated Indian territory. The decree, once signed, would make the Guaranis legal owners of the land. ‚ÄúThe apprehension we‚Äôve been living with has suddenly lifted,‚Äù said the community‚Äôs 74-year-old leader, or cacique, Ari Karai. The group, which occupied the land in 2014 following a previous occupation in 2005, was served an eviction order in April, at the petition of a former politicianwho claimed that his family owned the land.
Karai said that help from supporters in S√£o Paulo and beyond helped swing the minister‚Äôs decision. ‚ÄúWe had support from so many people, including from abroad,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt was very important for us ‚Äì I think it made a big difference.‚Äù Three families from cramped, impoverished settlements at the foot of Jaragu√° peak have already taken up residence in the new village, named Tekoa Itakup√©, which is flanked on one side by forest and on the other by the community‚Äôs crops. More families are expected to move up to the forest, but Karai said the group were determined to limit it to 20-30 families, to avoid more overcrowding. ‚ÄúThe last thing we want is to end up living on top of one another again,‚Äù he says. Following the victory in Jaragu√°, the Guarani‚Äôs struggle now shifts 60km to the southernmost edge of S√£o Paulo, where four villages await demarcation as indigenous territory. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hoping that will be easier now,‚Äù said Karai, ‚Äúbut we know we need to keep up the pressure, and to keep gathering as much support as we can.‚Äù Compounding the encouraging news, in Brazil‚Äôs senate as of last week a decisive 60% of senators signed a manifesto opposing the constitutional amendment PEC 215. The proposed amendment, driven by Brazil‚Äôs powerful ruralist congressional caucus, seeks to shift the power to demarcate land ‚Äì or not ‚Äì to Congress. The PEC is fiercely opposed by the indigenous community and its growing ranks of supporters.

column4: Qatar's World Cup officials put on brave face for post-Blatter era
column5:
It was business as usual for Qatar‚Äôs preparatory work on the 2022 World Cup on Wednesday, even as the shockwaves of Sepp Blatter‚Äôs resignation led to more speculation that the Fifa chief‚Äôs sudden departure could see the emirate stripped of the coveted global sports event.
But there was something in the air ‚Äì and not just the 46C mid-afternoon heat that is a scorching reminder of long-standing controversy about the location and its drawbacks. In downtown Doha, in the steel and glass HQ of the Supreme Committee for Delivery and Legacy, frantic officials were fielding calls on how the Gulf state might respond to a new threat to its moment of glory seven years hence. If anyone in Al Bidda Towers was bothered by the warning from the English Football Association chairman Greg Dyke that Qatar should not be ‚Äúfeeling comfortable‚Äù in the post-Blatter era, they were putting a brave face on it ‚Äì but with a hint of anger. The bland, terse statement that emerged at the end of the day conceded not the slightest hint of crisis. ‚ÄúThe recent events at Fifa will not impact on our preparations for the 2022 Fifa World Cup,‚Äù the committee insisted. ‚ÄúWith five stadiums currently under construction, we are ahead of schedule to deliver on our promises.‚Äù Earlier, Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa bin Ahmed Al Thani, president of the Qatari FA, noted pointedly that the emirate had been ‚Äúcleared of any wrongdoing‚Äù by Michael Garcia, the US investigator hired by Fifa ‚Äì and welcomed a Swiss investigation into the bidding process for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups. But Al Thani, a member of the ruling family, added a sharp jibe that reflected nationalist sentiment in one of the smallest and wealthiest countries on earth. ‚ÄúMr Dyke‚Äôs instinct to focus immediately on stripping Qatar of the World Cup speaks volumes on his views concerning what will be the first Fifa World Cup to take place in the Middle East,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe would urge Mr Dyke to let the legal process take its course and concentrate on delivering his promise to build an England team capable of winning the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.‚Äù Elsewhere, the mood was a mixture of the defensive and the defiant. Four male friends in traditional white robes sipping fruit juice in the lobby of one of the capital‚Äôs many luxury hotels were looking forward to the competition. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know about Blatter but will put on a good show and we will have excellent stadiums,‚Äù said Issa. ‚ÄúEverything is being prepared ‚Äì the infrastructure, communications. The government has devoted a lot of effort to it.‚Äù Mohammed, his friend, chipped in: ‚ÄúThey say there has been corruption in Fifa but Qatar won fairly. It is an honour for us to host the World Cup ‚Äì as Arabs and Muslims. We have stability here. We have the infrastructure. So what‚Äôs all the fuss about it? We don‚Äôt have strikes here like in Britain. Does someone have a monopoly?‚Äù Officials made a distinction between the competition itself and Blatter‚Äôs fate. But foreign observers saw a clear and possibly ominous link. ‚ÄúIt does complicate things for Qatar,‚Äù one diplomat mused. ‚ÄúEver since they won the bid, Blatter was a staunch supporter and him getting re-elected gave them a degree of confidence that the Fifa investigation wouldn‚Äôt be re-opened. Now he‚Äôs gone they will be worried that a new president won‚Äôt hold back on that. He gave them a feeling of protection.‚Äù The possibility of months of delay and uncertainty before a successor is chosen is another cause for concern. Doha looks likely to welcome the candidacy of Sheikh Ahmad al-Fahad Al Sabah of Kuwait, a fellow member of the Gulf Cooperation Council ‚Äì the regional grouping. It might also be happy with Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan, a poor Arab country which might expect Qatari financial largesse for broader political and economic reasons. The Qatari stock market gave its own blunt judgement, falling on the news of Blatter‚Äôs departure just as it rose when he was re-elected a few days ago. The World Cup remains a matter of huge national pride and sensitivity. Al-Watan, the main Arabic daily, splashed on Wednesday with an angry rebuttal of a Washington Post story about the death rate amongst migrant labourers, the subject of intense global scrutiny since a Guardian investigation in 2013. It was not the only one: a separate statement was issued flatly denying a Buzzfeed story suggesting that Qatari officials now faced arrest if they set foot in the US. Qataris are proud to have won the bid but question the motives of their critics, noting that for every time Russia is mentioned Qatar is mentioned many more times. ‚ÄúI believe it is because of prejudice and racism that we have this bashing campaign against Qatar,‚Äù the foreign minister, Khaled al-Attiyah, told Reuters, in Wednesday‚Äôs strongest official response to the Fifa drama. Doha‚Äôs stunning skyline makes plain why the stakes are so high. Cranes and building sites are strewn across a city that is building at least eight new stadiums, new roads and flyovers as well as $35bn metro and rail system. In all, Qatar plans to spend $200bn on infrastructure in the period up to 2030. In the lobby of Al Bidda Towers, an air-conditioned refuge from the furnace-like heat outside, is a reminder of why it matters so much. In a glass case that might house a precious ancient relic is a lavishly-bound book open at an interview with Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani, the previous emir, who stepped down in favour of his son Tamim two years ago. ‚ÄúHosting the 2022 Fifa World Cup will obviously further enhance our country‚Äôs standing and reputation globally, raising the awareness of Qatar and providing a positive focus for the region as a whole.‚Äù The supreme committee made a strikingly similar point: ‚ÄúQatar has faced criticism from the moment we won the right to bring this tournament to the Middle East for the first time,‚Äù it said. ‚ÄúWe remain committed to using the World Cup as a platform to break down prejudice and misconceptions, while leaving a lasting legacy for our country and the rest of the region.‚Äù Ian Black, the Guardian‚Äôs Middle East editor, was visiting Doha to attend the US-Islamic World Forum as a guest of the Brookings Centre for Middle East policy and the Qatari Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

column4: Chechen leader's show of strength muddies loyalty to Putin
column5: Chechnya‚Äôs macho leader Ramzan Kadyrov is the most loyal of Vladimir Putin‚Äôs regional heads, at least in theory. The central street of the captial, Grozny, is called Putin Avenue, and the lampposts lining it are adorned with the Russian tricolour. Putin‚Äôs portrait looks down from dozens of buildings across the city, and Kadyrov‚Äôs Instagram account, his main method of communication with the outside world, is full of protestations that he is a ‚Äúfoot soldier‚Äù, supremely loyal to Russia‚Äôs great leader. But recent events, especially the murder of Boris Nemtsov in Moscow, have led to renewed debate over whether the Kremlin‚Äôs political control over the region, won back after two gruesome wars in the post-Soviet years, may be loosening. While pledging a feudal-like loyalty to Moscow, Kadyrov has been provided billions of roubles to rebuild Grozny, which has been transformed from a ruined shell reminiscent of Stalingrad to a modern city studded with shiny Dubai-style skyscrapers. Wealthy locals dine in the 32nd-floor restaurant at Grozny City, a five-star hotel, the football team plays at a newly renovated stadium. But Kadyrov has also built up his own private armies. In an extraordinary address to thousands of his troops, gathered in fatigues and armed in Grozny‚Äôs main stadium in December, a black-shirted Kadyrov said his men were ready to fight for the motherland at any time. ‚ÄúAmerica and Europe have declared an economic war on Russia,‚Äù he declared to the assembled ranks of fighters. ‚ÄúBut the Russian people have rallied around their leader Vladimir Putin ‚Ä¶ Long live our great motherland Russia! Long live our national leader Vladimir Putin! Allah-u Akbar!‚Äù The pictures were not widely broadcast on Russian television, and the sight of a regional leader commanding such a fierce army gave many pause for thought. ‚ÄúOne theory is that this was a genuine show of loyalty to Putin, while another theory is that it was actually a warning, showing everyone that Chechen forces have this extraordinary potential. Of course, it‚Äôs quite likely that both of these theories are true,‚Äù said Grigory Shvedov, editor in chief of Caucasian Knot, one of the only independent news sites specialising in Russia‚Äôs North Caucasus region. Kadyrov‚Äôs forces have long had a dubious reputation. For many years, rights activists and analysts have worried that the rebuilding of Chechnya has come at a huge price, both in terms of money and in terms of turning a blind eye to human rights abuses committed by Kadyrov‚Äôs battalions and special units. On Wednesday, one of the last human rights groups in the republic said a large mob of people had gathered outside its office, smashing windows and destroying its car, apparently accusing it of fighting an ‚Äúinformation war‚Äù against Chechnya for documenting rights abuses. The group already had its offices in Grozny burned down in December. This kind of attack on rights groups or freedom of speech has long been considered the price Moscow has to pay for keeping Chechnya under its formal control. But the assassination of Nemtsov, in the shadow of the Kremlin, has led many to wonder whether Chechnya has slipped too far out of Moscow‚Äôs orbit. Investigators arrested several Chechens in connection with Nemtsov‚Äôs murder, including a deputy commander of one of Kadyrov‚Äôs special battalions. Russian agencies reported that one of the main suspects, Ruslan Geremeyev, who is close to Kadyrov, was being guarded in a Chechen village and was later helped to flee the country. Kadyrov wrote on his Instagram account that Zaur Dadayev, one of the arrested men, is ‚Äúa true patriot of Russia‚Äù. In recent days, there have been reports that investigators have a video of Dadayev saying goodbye to Geremeyev at the airport in Moscow in the days after the killing. The trail appeared to lead directly to the Chechen leader. Joining the dots between the investigators‚Äô leaks in the press and Kadyrov‚Äôs Instagram belligerence, many analysts have speculated there is a battle going on between different parts of Putin‚Äôs security services: those who want to take Kadyrov down, and those who believe he must be protected at all costs to stop Chechnya sliding into chaos. A former Kremlin insider told the Guardian earlier this year that ‚Äúnobody in Moscow has ever liked Kadyrov‚Äù because no state bodies work normally in Chechnya: not the police, prosecutors office or courts. A source in Grozny confirmed that almost everyone in a position of power in the republic is locally appointed, with just a few people in the FSB security service coming from Moscow. Ten days after Nemtsov‚Äôs murder, as the Russian media was full of speculation linking those close to Kadyrov to the hit, the Kremlin announced Kadyrov would receive the Order of Honour, a top state award. It was read by many as a sign that the Chechen leader is untouchable. Lawyers for Nemtsov‚Äôs family want Kadyrov himself questioned over the killing, but that appears unlikely. Some play down the idea of a feud between the FSB and Kadyrov, and point out instead the usefulness of the Chechen leader. Andrei Soldatov, a specialist on the Russian security services, said he believes talk of a full-blown feud is exaggerated. The FSB needs Kadyrov, he believes: ‚ÄúLinks with western security services are important for the FSB leadership and the main thing Russia has to share is information on people going to Syria to fight. The main source of this information is Kadyrov.‚Äù Others say that while Kadyrov may have become more unruly, the Kremlin‚Äôs new antagonism with the west makes him more important than ever. ‚ÄúWith the events in Ukraine and the changing political climate, I think there has been a much greater need for Ramzan over the last year,‚Äù said Shvedov. ‚ÄúKadyrov is a unique politician on the Russian scene. What other local leader could rail at the west in the same way he does, or personally insult Obama? They would be too worried about their houses in California and so on, but Kadyrov can and does speak his mind freely.‚Äù But the tension has at times spilled out into the public domain, an extremely rare occurrence in Putin‚Äôs ‚Äúpower vertical‚Äù. Kadyrov reacted furiously to a ‚Äúspecial operation‚Äù carried out in Grozny by special police troops from nearby Stavropol region, which led to the wanted man being shot dead. Kadyrov ordered Chechen law enforcement that they should ‚Äúshoot to kill‚Äù any police officers from other regions who came to Chechnya without informing local authorities first. The Interior Ministry in Moscow reacted with a statement that the outburst was unacceptable, and Kadyrov‚Äôs words quickly disappeared from local television broadcasts. Later, the Chechen leader said he had been misinterpreted. Last month, exiled oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky‚Äôs Open Russia foundation released a film about Kadyrov‚Äôs Chechnya. ‚ÄúRussia‚Äôs policies in Chechnya will lead to the creation of two dangerous enemies ‚Äì Ramzan Kadyrov‚Äôs clan and the people of Chechnya. Sooner or later, one or the other of them will start a war with us,‚Äù wrote Khodorkovsky in an accompanying article. Kadyrov‚Äôs response, as usual, came on Instagram. With the somewhat sinister title ‚ÄúIf you haven‚Äôt understood by now, you soon will.‚Äù The supposed ‚Äútrailer‚Äù for the ‚Äúfilm‚Äù featured Kadyrov running across a plain, weapon in hand. He wrote it was directed by a Hollywood star and featured ‚Äúinternational A-list stars‚Äù. Given there is almost certainly no Hollywood film, it felt like a threat. ‚ÄúKadyrov has done everything to rebuild the republic, everything is thanks to him,‚Äù said a former member of one of Kadyrov‚Äôs militias in an interview in Grozny over the weekend. ‚ÄúBut if you‚Äôve read anything of Caucasus history, you‚Äôll know this is unlikely to be the end. We can never trust Russia, and there is sure to be more trouble in the future.‚Äù Another contentious incident was the marriage of a 17-year-old schoolgirl to a middle-aged police chief who already had a wife. Kadyrov intervened after human rights activists criticised the marriage, and the chief of his administration personally brought the bride to the registry office. In the days after the marriage, Kadyrov gathered a group of locals who had ‚Äúspread rumours‚Äù about the marriage. It was not made clear how they were identified. He blamed gossiping women for spreading rumours about the marriage using WhatsApp and called on men to ensure their female family members did not spend time using the app. ‚ÄúLock them in, do not let them go out, then they will not post anything,‚Äù he said, according to translation from Chechen language by Russian media. ‚ÄúFamily honour is the most important thing. Do not write such things. Men, take your women out of WhatsApp.‚Äù Some say allowing Kadyrov so much breathing space risks provoking the very war Russia is so keen to prevent. ‚ÄúIt turns out the price for Russia of ‚Äòpeace‚Äô in the Caucasus is the de facto semi-independence of Chechnya, which our regime has to accept because it can‚Äôt keep ‚Äòconstitutional order‚Äô in the Caucasus without Kadyrov and his personal army,‚Äù wrote Gennady Gudkov, an opposition politician former KGB officer who sat on the Duma‚Äôs security committee until recently, in a column. ‚ÄúOf course we can just pretend that Chechnya is a part of Russia just like Yaroslavl, Sakhalin or Petersburg. That‚Äôs what we did at the end of the 1980s when the USSR‚Äôs laws stopped working in this proud Caucasus republic. And we know what happened then. Are we risking a repeat?‚Äù Some Chechens express love for Kadyrov and say a place such as Chechnya can only be governed with strong rule. Even for many Chechens who are uneasy about Kadyrov‚Äôs role, the memories of a decade living amid war and chaos are still fresh, and most people say they are willing to put up with a lot to avoid war. Many locals say Russian criticism of Chechnya‚Äôs existence outside Russia‚Äôs legal system is unfair. Polygamy is fairly widespread in Chechnya, explained partly by local traditions and partly by a shortage of menfolk after all the tragedies the Chechens have experienced in recent decades. ‚ÄúThe Qur‚Äôan gives men the right to have up to four wives,‚Äù said Murad, the eldest of 25 children that his now-deceased father had with three separate wives. ‚ÄúWhat man wouldn‚Äôt want several wives? It‚Äôs never been a problem here. In Russia they do the same thing, it‚Äôs just there they call it having a mistress. Here it‚Äôs official and honest.‚Äù At a wake on Saturday in Grozny, held for a well-known Soviet-era wrestling trainer who had just passed away, the smell of sweat wafted through the air as the men performed the zikr, a sufi-inspired local tradition of prayer and swirling dance, while the headscarved women prepared hunks of meat and a giant vat of soup. The scene felt far removed from Moscow. But there was bemusement among the guests over the idea that by operating according to sharia law rather than the Russian constitution, Chechnya was somehow more lawless than the rest of Russia. ‚ÄúThere they ignore the law and here we ignore the law. It‚Äôs just that there it‚Äôs based on wealth and corruption, and here it comes from Allah,‚Äù said one.

column4: Surveillance reform explainer: can the FBI still listen to my phone calls?
column5:
Something surprising happened in Washington DC on Tuesday: Congress passed surveillance reform. Last weekend, three parts of the Patriot Act ‚Äì a bill disapproved of in its current form by many Americans across party lines ‚Äì expired, ending authority for several forms of surveillance of US citizens introduced by the Bush administration, backed by Barack Obama, and altered in secret by the National Security Agency (something Edward Snowden later exposed). The Senate on Tuesday passed the USA Freedom Act, which restores expired powers of the FBI, notably the ‚Äúbusiness records‚Äù, ‚Äúlone wolf‚Äù and ‚Äúroving wiretap‚Äù provisions, but puts an end to the NSA‚Äôs indiscriminate collection of American phone records. The fight was hard-won: Senate GOP leader Mitch McConnell advanced three different amendments that would have defanged the reforms in various ways. All three failed.
So that‚Äôs it ‚Äì the FBI can‚Äôt listen to my phone calls anymore, right? Wrong. The FBI will do whatever it wants with your phone calls, provided it has a warrant. Section 215 of the Patriot Act, used by the FBI ‚Äúto obtain large collections of metadata‚Äù, had indeed expired, but the USA Freedom Act restored it. (The Freedom Act, as mentioned, will stop the NSA from collecting Americans‚Äô phone records in bulk. More on that in a second.) The main statute the FBI uses to listen in directly on phone calls is called Calea ‚Äì the 1994 Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act. Calea was designed to make it easier for the FBI to listen in on calls as telecoms technology shifted from copper wires to digital. Essentially, giving the FBI a backdoor key to your network is a condition of running a phone or internet company. Where phone records are concerned, the FBI has a history of circumventing the requirement for a warrant, notoriously in the years after 9/11 with ‚Äúexigent letters‚Äù seeking billing records, which claimed ‚Äì often falsely ‚Äì that the situation was an emergency and a grand jury was about to be convened. And there are National Security Letters, which allow the FBI to collect ‚Äúbusiness records‚Äù (and that includes credit card statements and phone information) without having to get permission from a judge. National Security Letters are sticking around, though they can‚Äôt be used to collect phone records in bulk anymore. But the Freedom Act specifically states that you won‚Äôt be able to tell anybody you received a National Security Letter. If this provision sounds to you like it does not belong in something called the Freedom Act, you have a point.
Speak English. What are ‚Äòlone-wolf‚Äô capabilities? Sorry. First up, we‚Äôre talking about the 2004 ‚Äúlone wolf‚Äù amendment to the 1978 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (Fisa). See, Fisa created a secret court that issues warrants for surveillance to the FBI (and helped the NSA retroactively shoehorn metadata collection into the Patriot Act in 2006). This allows for the possibility that there‚Äôs one guy out there who might blow something up. Rather than an agent of a foreign power, or a person with connections to terrorism, the definition of lone wolf is nebulous ‚Äì to say the least. The amendment changes the definition of ‚Äúagent of a foreign power‚Äù to include people who might be planning to engage in ‚Äúinternational terrorism‚Äù in the judgment of the court. ‚ÄúIf an order is sought under this definition of an ‚Äòagent of a foreign power‚Äô,‚Äù the amendment says, ‚Äúthe applicant is not required to demonstrate a connection between the target of the electronic surveillance or the physical search and a foreign nation, foreign group, or international terrorist group.‚Äù The FBI says it has never even used this provision. And ‚Äòroving wiretaps‚Äô? ‚ÄúRoving wiretaps‚Äù are supposed to allow the government to track suspects who change phones, but their definition is very broad too ‚Äì so broad a court can issue them without having to know the identity of the target. The FBI has used this provision, notably to spy on children for five days. Go back. Secret court? Yes. Fisa created a secret court that issues orders related to the surveillance of ‚Äúforeign intelligence information‚Äù between people who are ‚Äúagents of foreign powers‚Äù, including US citizens. Which Americans? Definitely everybody on Verizon, who had their data swept up by the NSA, as first revealed by Snowden, for example. Also US customers of other phone companies. Will the USA Freedom Act get rid of that secret court? Nope. So what does the Freedom Act even do then? At this point in the debate, its biggest change is to make a big trade: it junks the NSA‚Äôs bulk collection of US phone data in exchange for restoring the now-expired, aforementioned FBI powers in the Patriot Act. (The reason you might be confused about that is weeks‚Äô worth of imprecise reporting, as the media has ‚Äì understandably ‚Äì had trouble making heads or tails of this). Various writers and talking heads have used ‚ÄúSection 215‚Äù or the ‚ÄúBusiness Records Provision‚Äù to mean ‚ÄúNSA bulk collection‚Äù because the NSA secretly jammed its domestic bulk collection into Section 215 back in 2006. But they‚Äôre totally not the same thing. To ensure that the NSA or the FBI doesn‚Äôt try to reconstitute bulk collection, or some domestic surveillance operation similarly massive, the act also creates a kind of ‚Äúearly warning‚Äù system at the secret Fisa court. ‚ÄúSignificant‚Äù Fisa court opinions, ones that would substantially reinterpret the laws (again, in secret), would have to be publicly disclosed within 45 days. Also, since the Fisa court right now only hears from the government ‚Äì another way the Fisa court is unlike every court you‚Äôve ever heard of in this country ‚Äì it would also create a kind of privacy advocate, called an ‚Äúamicus‚Äù, for those kinds of novel cases so that it‚Äôs not overseeing itself. Those are the transparency provisions McConnell and Senate intelligence committee chief Richard Burr wanted to scuttle. Wait, so how can I be sure nobody‚Äôs listening who isn‚Äôt supposed to be listening? The short answer is that you can‚Äôt, but the long answer is more interesting. Fear of government surveillance and malicious hackers have meant a boom in apps and proxies that purport to offer secure alternatives to plain old telephone service connections, mostly using VPNs ‚Äì virtual private networks. Sure, your data goes through open phone lines, cell towers and fiber cables, but it can be encrypted in a number of ways, some more effective than others. Some of these privacy tools keep a log of your username, IP address and when you use the network (which can then be turned over to law enforcement if subpoenaed); others use ‚Äúdark tunnels‚Äù and do not keep logs ‚Äì there are proxies that even accept bitcoin so that financial records are harder to trace. So this isn‚Äôt big news? No, it‚Äôs HUGE news. The steps forward represented by the USA Freedom Act may seem small to people outraged by government overreach, but it‚Äôs frankly astonishing that they‚Äôre going forward at all. For the past 15 years Congress‚Äôs favorite thing to do has been to expand NSA powers. Now it‚Äôs restricting them for the first time since 1978. The issue of broad government surveillance has become such a powerful motivator to action that the passage of the Freedom Act is likely to have all kinds of ramifications, from the NSA having to justify its actions more frequently to a more knowledgeable public, to Rand Paul being taken more seriously as a presidential candidate. It‚Äôs also an issue others seeking the US‚Äôs highest office will have to develop a public-friendly stance on, and quickly. Additional reporting by Spencer Ackerman in New York

column4: Nigeria's army behind countless acts of torture and 8,000 deaths, Amnesty says
column5:
Senior military officers in Nigeria should be investigated for war crimes including the murder, starvation, suffocation and torturing to death of 8,000 people, Amnesty International has said. An investigation carried out over several years, perhaps the most damning account yet of the military response to Boko Haram, casts a shadow over the first foreign trip of the new Nigerian president, Muhammadu Buhari, during which he is set to discuss a fresh regional strategy against the Islamist group. Amnesty set out on Wednesday the case against five senior Nigerian officers in a 133-page report based on hundreds of interviews, including with military sources, and leaked defence ministry documents.
During security operations against Boko Haram in the north-east, it says the armed forces ‚Äúcommitted countless acts of torture; hundreds, if not thousands, of Nigerians have become victims of enforced disappearance; and at least 7,000 people have died in military detention as a result of starvation, extreme overcrowding and denial of medical assistance‚Äù. The report, Stars on Their Shoulders. Blood on Their Hands: War Crimes Committed by the Nigerian Military, also alleges that more than 1,200 people have been extrajudicially executed by soldiers or allied vigilante groups since February 2012. It claims the worst case took place on 14 March 2014 when the military killed more than 640 detainees who had fled Giwa barracks after Boko Haram attacked. Many of these killings appear to be reprisals following attacks. A senior military official told Amnesty that soldiers ‚Äúgo to the nearest place and kill all the youths ‚Ä¶ people killed may be innocent and not armed‚Äù. The report alleges that military forces arbitrarily arrested at least 20,000 people, mostly young men and boys, some just nine years old. It says detainees are held incommunicado in extremely overcrowded, unventilated cells without sanitary facilities and with little food or water. Amnesty claims that a high-ranking military officer gave it a list of 683 detainees who died in custody between October 2012 and February 2013. The organisation also obtained evidence that in 2013, more than 4,700 bodies were brought to a mortuary from a detention facility in Giwa barracks. A former detainee who spent four months in detention described how, on arrival, the soldiers said: ‚ÄúWelcome to your die house. Welcome to your place of death.‚Äù Only 11 of 122 men he was arrested with survived, he said. Amnesty researchers also witnessed emaciated corpses in mortuaries, and one former Giwa detainee told the organisation that around 300 people in his cell died after being denied water for two days: ‚ÄúSometimes we drank people‚Äôs urine, but even the urine you at times could not get.‚Äù The conditions for prisoners in Giwa barracks and detention centres in Damaturu were allegedly so overcrowded that hundreds of detainees were packed into small cells where they had to take turns sleeping or even sitting on the floor. ‚ÄúHundreds have been killed in detention either [by soldiers] shooting them or by suffocation,‚Äù a military officer told Amnesty, describing the situation in Sector Alpha detention centre, known as ‚ÄúGuantanamo‚Äù. Amnesty claims that on a single day, 47 detainees died there as a result of suffocation. To combat the spread of disease and stifle the stench, cells were regularly fumigated with chemicals. Fumigation may have led to the deaths of many detainees in their poorly ventilated cells. One military official based at Giwa barracks told Amnesty: ‚ÄúMany Boko Haram suspects died as a result of fumigation. They fumigated with the chemicals you use for killing mosquitoes. It is something very powerful. It is very dangerous.‚Äù Former detainees and senior military sources described how detainees were regularly tortured to death, hung on poles over fires, tossed into deep pits or interrogated using electric batons.
Boko Haram has been fighting to impose sharia law across Nigeria‚Äôs north for the last six years, massacring civilians and kidnapping thousands of women and children, most notoriously a group of more than 200 schoolgirls in Chibok. But Amnesty alleges that the military‚Äôs response has resulted in further atrocities against civilians. The international criminal court (ICC) in the Hague has previously said there was insufficient evidence tying Nigeria‚Äôs military to systematic and orchestrated atrocities targeting civilians. But the report says: ‚ÄúAmnesty International believes that the evidence contained in this report and submitted separately to the ICC office of the prosecutor is sufficient to reopen this issue.‚Äù Amnesty also called on Buhari, who was sworn in as president last week, to act against those responsible and end the culture of impunity in the armed forces. Commanders based in the north-east ‚Äúshould be investigated for potential responsibility for war crimes of murder, enforced disappearances and torture‚Äù, it said. It named five officers it believes should be investigated: Major General John A H Ewansiha, Major General Obida T Ethnan, Major General Ahmadu Mohammed, Brigadier General Austin O Edokpayi and Brigadier General Rufus O Bamigboye. The Nigerian government said it took the allegations seriously but the officers were innocent until proven otherwise. ‚ÄúThe government of Nigeria has zero tolerance of the mistreatment of citizens, especially when human rights are involved,‚Äù spokesman Mike Omeri said. ‚ÄúWhen such allegations are made, the government will not hesitate to investigate. The armed forces are professional in training and conduct. Unless they are investigated we cannot accuse them of this. They are not known to be engaged in this.‚Äù Asked about the alleged abuses at the Giwa barracks, Omeri replied: ‚ÄúGiwa is like any other military barracks. I am not aware of any such things.‚Äù The government of former president Goodluck Jonathan was repeatedly pressured to try all Boko Haram suspects in court. After taking the oath of office, Buhari promised he would review the military‚Äôs rules of engagement in a bid to end concerns of rights violations by soldiers. He also promised to improve ‚Äúoperational and legal mechanisms so that disciplinary steps are taken against proven human right violations by the armed forces‚Äù. He vowed that he would tackle ‚Äúhead on‚Äù the six-year insurgency and said the military command centre will be relocated from the capital, Abuja, to the north-eastern city of Maiduguri. On Tuesday, Buhari met his security chiefs for the first time and on Wednesday began a visit to neighbouring Niger and Chad, where he is expected to discuss changes to the regional offensive against Boko Haram. Japheth Omojuwa, a political commentator and blogger, said: ‚ÄúWe will see a change in strategy and that is a no-brainer really. The strategy of the immediate past administration ‚Äì if ever there was a strategy ‚Äì failed woefully. I see Buhari working with Nigeria‚Äôs neighbours Niger, Chad and Cameroon more closely in a less combative or competitive way as it was with Jonathan. That shows already with his first travel outside the country being Niger and Boko Haram clearly the main subject of discussion.‚Äù He added: ‚ÄúHe will also enjoy a lot of intelligence support from the United States and technical and moral support from the likes of the United Kingdom and France. I see him fully focused on insecurity while his vice-president, Yemi Osibajo, concentrates on the economy. That would help. The movement of the military‚Äôs base from Abuja to Maiduguri shows pro-activeness, his willingness to take the war to the terrorists.‚Äù Antony Goldman, a west Africa risk analyst at London-based PM Consulting, said: ‚ÄúThere have been significant gains over the last four months but there remains a lot of structural work to be done to create a fully professional military. There are some long-term issues that, even with the will, are not going to be fixed with the change of leadership, but the change might be part of that process.‚Äù

column4: Abu Khdeir murder trial: defendant tells court he did not plan to kill teenager
column5:
One of two Israeli teenagers accused with a 30-year old man of the kidnap and murder of Palestinian boy last summer has described the killing in detail for the first time in evidence at his trial in Jerusalem. Mohammed Abu Khdeir, 16, was snatched from outside a mosque in east Jerusalem and driven to a forest where he was knocked insensible with a crowbar and burned alive. His murder triggered an international outcry and violent clashes in the city. The killing was condemned at the time by the US secretary of state, John Kerry, the EU and by the UN secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, as well as by the Israeli prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu. Speaking in his defence at his trial at a Jerusalem district court, the teenager, who cannot be named because he is a minor, blamed Yosef Ben-David, his 30-year-old co-accused, as motivating the hate crime, adding that he had never planned to kill Abu Khdeir. In an angry outburst in the court, and in comments outside later, Abu Khdeir father accused the teenager of lying. Ben-David, a resident of the West Bank settlement of Adam, admitted last year he had been responsible for setting Abu Khdeir alight. He has, however, refused to testify, invoking his right to remain silent, while his lawyer has insisted his client is ‚Äúinsane‚Äù and therefore unfit for trial. The teenager, who has claimed he was emotionally dependent on the older man, said in his defence that he had felt pressured to join in the kidnapping. ‚ÄúWhen [Ben-David] picked me up at my home he told me we had to do something ... to avenge God‚Äôs honour. It was hard for me to say no to him,‚Äù the teenager said. ‚ÄúI was conflicted. I was afraid to do something but on the other hand I also couldn‚Äôt say no to him. I find it difficult believe that I was involved in such a horrific incident. It‚Äôs not true that I planned to kill him. I never dreamed that it would end in the way it did.‚Äù
The teenager said Ben-David had been angry after attending the funeral of three Israeli youths ‚Äì Eyal Yifrach, Naftali Frenkel and Gilad Shaer ‚Äì the day before, who had been kidnapped and killed while hitchhiking in the West Bank in a case that dominated the Israeli headlines. ‚ÄúBen-David was at the boys‚Äô funerals,‚Äù the teenager said on Wednesday during the court hearing, which was interupted several times by Abu Khdeir‚Äôs father, Hussein, as details were disclosed. ‚ÄúHe was much more enthusiastic and heated up. We met at the central bus station, bought some cigarettes and drank energy drinks to spur us on.‚Äù During the evening, the teenager said, Ben-David ‚Äústarted talking about wanting to pick someone up in his car and beat him. He gave us pills to calm us down. The other youth and I said it was dangerous. We drove around for hours. He stopped next to five small children and every time we were looking for a way to get out of it. I was distressed over the children.‚Äù After kidnapping Abu Khdeir, the teenager said: ‚ÄúI was sure [Ben-David] would let us off on the side of the road. I didn‚Äôt think he would take him into the woods and beat him there. I thought he would drop it. ‚ÄúThere was shouting in the car and there was tension. We reached the Jerusalem forest, and the whole trip we held him from behind. Ben-David asked where the crowbar was, and said that they (the Arabs) have seven souls, then he gave him two blows to the head with the crowbar. ‚ÄúI said to Ben-David: ‚ÄòEnough!‚Äô I got into the car and suddenly I saw a huge bonfire and understood the meaning. I didn‚Äôt see with my own eyes that it was Yosef who lit it, but from what was said, he lit it.‚Äù

column4: Families' anger grows after China cruise ship sinking
column5:
Forty-eight hours after a Chinese cruise ship carrying 456 people capsized and sank on the Yangtze river, anger and frustration is growing among relatives of those feared to have died. Dozens of family members arrived in Jianli on Wednesday, the town nearest to the disaster scene, seeking news of their loved ones. By Wednesday night, just 40 of those travelling on the Eastern Star cruise ship had been accounted for ‚Äì 14 survivors and 26 dead. Liu Gang, whose 68-year-old mother is missing, told the Guardian he had arrived in Jianli with a group of about 20 other families in the early hours of Wednesday. The group had hoped to visit the disaster site and accompany the rescue efforts. However, authorities prevented the families from reaching the site and had provided scant information about their operations, he complained. ‚ÄúWe are here but we still have to get all our information from the internet. We can‚Äôt go to the [disaster] site and have no way of finding out what has happened,‚Äù said Liu, whose mother, Shen Zhijuan, is still missing. ‚ÄúWe are prepared for the worst but [the government] should let us know what is really happening,‚Äù said a second relative ‚Äì a 35-year-old from Shanghai who asked to be named only as Mr Gu and whose mother and father-in-law were on the ship. ‚ÄúWhy they won‚Äôt talk to us?‚Äù
‚ÄúRescue crews in orange overalls began cutting a 55cm by 60cm hole in the ship‚Äôs hull on Wednesday night in the hope of finding further survivors inside, Xinhua, China‚Äôs official news agency reported.‚Äù Earlier, navy divers had used their hands to feel their way through sections of the submerged vessel, Zhang Jianxin, a transport ministry official, told state-run CCTV. Li Keqiang, the Chinese prime minister, urged rescue workers tocontinue their efforts despite the difficult conditions. ‚ÄúThe whole nation is putting their hope on you,‚Äù he said, according to state media. But while the Communist party has been keen to emphasise its swift response to the tragedy, both Liu and Gu said the government‚Äôs lack of transparency was fuelling suspicion among relatives. ‚ÄúTo be honest, we don‚Äôt trust all the official information that is being published,‚Äù said Gu. ‚ÄúThe families can remain calm for a day or two, but what if one day we are unable to take it any more?‚Äù ‚ÄúI wonder why they won‚Äôt let us go to the site,‚Äù said Liu. ‚ÄúWe told them that if they were worried they could organise for us to go there, but they didn‚Äôt respond to our request. We came here on our own because we are anxious and sad. We want to see our families, and we are not here to cause trouble.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf they insist on not letting us in, we might think there could be flaws in their rescue efforts,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúOtherwise, why are they so scared of us, the families, being there?‚Äù Liu said he had not given up hope of finding his mother alive. ‚ÄúIf she comes back safely, I will never let her go on tourism trips again,‚Äù he said.
However, at Jianli‚Äôs main funeral parlour authorities were preparing for the worst. Shen Yuanhai, the owner of a coffin factory in the neighbouring province of Henan, said he delivered four lorries to the funeral home on Wednesday, each stacked high with refrigerated caskets. After being unloaded by a forklift truck, the coffins, which have transparent, flower-covered lids, were packed side-to-side into four halls where wakes will be held over the coming days. Zou Jinlin, a 40-year-old local who was among crowds gathered at the Rongcheng Crematorium, said she would comfort relatives by telling them: ‚ÄúIt was a natural disaster. It wasn‚Äôt human error.‚Äù Her words echoed reports in China‚Äôs government-controlled media that have repeatedly pointed to a tornado or cyclone as the most likely cause of Monday‚Äôs disaster. ‚ÄúUnder the special circumstance of cyclone, the pressure on the one side of the boat went beyond the standard it was designed for, resulting in the overturning of the boat,‚Äù Zhong Shoudao, the president of China‚Äôs Chongqing Boat Design Institute, told a press conference, according to the Associated Press. However, some relatives remain unconvinced by the official narrative. Liu Gang said he could not grasp how ‚Äúsuch a big ship could turn upside down‚Äù in the river and why the 251ft-long Eastern Star appeared to have been the only ship affected by the storm. ‚ÄúThere were many other ships ‚Äì big and small ‚Äì and they were all fine. If it really was the bad weather, other ships would have been affected too,‚Äù he said. Questions over whether human error could have played a role grew on Wednesday after the Wall Street Journal reported that the Eastern Star had been cited for ‚Äúsafety infractions‚Äù two years ago. Safety inspectors in Chongqing had given the Eastern Star the green light as recently as last month, the People‚Äôs Daily, Beijing‚Äôs official mouthpiece newspaper, said. Chinese authorities appear nervous about the potential for unrest as hundreds of grieving relatives flock to the riverside town. As well as the massive rescue operation, large numbers of security forces have descended on Jianli, setting up roadblocks at major intersections. Foreign and Chinese journalists have been prevented from independently travelling to the disaster site. Attempts to interview relatives who had gathered outside Jianli‚Äôs main hospital were thwarted by government volunteers in red armbands. One family was ushered into a black sedan, apparently against their will, and driven away from reporters. ‚ÄúToo many journalists! You have to get into the car!‚Äù a government volunteer told them. ‚ÄúWe feel powerless as a member of the public, especially when government officials block the roads and do not allow us go to the site,‚Äù complained Liu. For relatives thre two key questions remained: what had happened to their loved-ones and why. ‚ÄúYou tell me, how could such a horrible disaster happen?‚Äù Liu said. Additional reporting by Luna Lin

column4: Israel brands Palestinian-led boycott movement a 'strategic threat'
column5:
Israel and key international supporters have sharply ratcheted up their campaign against the Palestinian-led Boycott Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement, with senior Israeli officials declaring it a strategic threat. Using language the Israeli government usually reserves for the likes of Hamas or Iran‚Äôs nuclear programme, senior figures ‚Äì including the prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, and a key backer in the US, casino magnate Sheldon Adelson ‚Äì have turned on the movement, which is prominent on university campuses and among international trade unions. The moves came as the UK‚Äôs National Union of Students (NUS) voted on Tuesday to formally ally itself with the aims of BDS. Following the vote, Hebrew media reported that Israeli MPs were due to hold a special session in the Knesset to discuss the issue.
The non-violent grassroots movement, founded with the support of dozens of Palestinian organisations, is modelled on South African anti-apartheid campaigns and calls for an end to the occupation, equality for Palestinian citizens of Israel, and a resolution for Palestinian refugees of 1948. Israeli critics point to the call for a right to return and the opposition of some leaders of the movement to a two-state solution ‚Äì which they describe as a mistake ‚Äì as evidence that BDS is antisemitic. After years in which Israeli officials and commentators have loftily dismissed the impact of BDS ‚Äì which seeks to persuade businesses, artists, governments and academic institutions to boycott Israel over its long occupation of the Palestinian territories ‚Äì Israel‚Äôs new rightwing government has in recent days singled out the movement for criticism. The issue appears to have been given added impetus since Palestinian efforts to have Israel suspended from the scandal-ridden world football organisation Fifa failed on Friday. Comments by senior Israeli politicians over the last week have been amplified in the Hebrew media by sympathetic commentary by columnists. Among those who have allied themselves with the latest efforts are the mass circulation Israeli paper Yedioth Ahoronoth ‚Äì which earlier this week allied itself on its front page with ‚ÄúFighting the boycott‚Äù ‚Äì and its rightwing columnist Ben-Dror Yemeni, who has echoed the comments of officials. ‚ÄúThe success of BDS,‚Äù Yemini wrote earlier this week, ‚Äúis particularly impressive because it is a movement that uses the language of rights, but deals in practice with denying Israel‚Äôs right to exist. The result is a major deception.‚Äù The latest rhetoric has coincided with growing evidence of pro-Israeli activism over BDS, not least in the US. Last week, a new website emerged whose aim was to identify US college students active in the BDS movement with the explicit aim of identifying then to future possible employers. It was not clear who was behind the site. This weekend, Adelson will reportedly convene a meeting of super wealthy pro-Israel donors for a summit in Las Vegas on countering the influence of BDS and similar movements on US campuses. On Sunday, Netanyahu explicitly attempted to link boycott movements to historic ‚Äúanti-semitism‚Äù, echoing remarks that Netanyahu made in his keynote address to the US pro-Israel lobby group AIPAC last year, when he described BDS as being on the ‚Äúwrong side of the moral divide‚Äù while predicting that the ‚Äúmovement will fail‚Äù.
The latest rhetoric was immediately condemned by Barghouti, who dismissed the recent moves as a ‚Äúpanic-driven, racist and patently propagandistic Israeli attack on the movement‚Äù. He told the Guardian: ‚ÄúPlacing a non-violent human rights movement that seeks freedom, justice and equality on par with the so-called Iranian ‚Äònuclear capacity‚Äô as a ‚Äòfirst-rate strategic threat‚Äô ‚Äì as Israeli president Reuven Rivlin announced a few days ago or as the new minister of strategic affairs and public security in the far-right Israeli government Gilad Erdan tweeted on his first day on the job ‚Äì reflects Israel‚Äôs failure in hindering the fast growth of BDS. ‚ÄúIt also betrays Israel‚Äôs inherent inability to face such popular, anti-racist, human rights-based and nonviolent challenges to its regime of oppression.‚Äù Israeli officials told the Guardian that the focus on BDS was not an acknowledgement of its success but rather the reaffirmation of a principal of ‚Äúmoral outrage‚Äù both over the recent move by the NUS and by efforts to have Israel suspended from Fifa. That, however, has led to accusations from critics that Israel is deliberately conflating the BDS movement with separate Palestinian efforts to hold Israel accountable for the occupation. Facing growing warnings of international isolation in the absence of a peace process with the Palestinians and amid continued settlement building in the occupied territories, the latest moves appear designed to conflate BDS with separate initiatives by Palestinian diplomats to internationalise support for the end to occupation and for the creation of a Palestinian state in global forums. One Palestinian official familiar with efforts on the international stage said he believed the latest effort was aimed not only at BDS but at the wider Palestinian effort to promote its case in the international criminal Court, the UN and Fifa. ‚ÄúThey are trying to combine all the efforts to hold Israel accountable into creating a monster that is not there yet,‚Äù the official said. ‚ÄúIf ask the Palestinian leadership, some love BDS as a movement, others hate it. I think what Netanyahu is trying to do is create an idea that even if you believe Palestinian moves in international forums are legitimate, they are undermined because BDS ‚Äì in the Israelis argument - seeks to ‚Äôdestroy state of Israel‚Äô.‚Äù

column4: Hundreds of coffins prepared as China realises scale of cruise ship tragedy
column5:
Undertakers at a small-town funeral parlour in central China are bracing themselves for the arrival of hundreds of corpses after the country‚Äôs worst shipping disaster since the 1940s. More than 400 people are feared to have died when the Eastern Star cruise ship capsized on the Yangtze river during a rainstorm on Monday night. Officials raised the official death toll to 18 on Wednesday but said rescue teams were still hunting for survivors in and around the vessel‚Äôs upturned hull.
With almost no underwater visibility, navy divers used their hands to feel their way through sections of the submerged vessel, Zhang Jianxin, a transport ministry official, told Chinese television. ‚ÄúThe whole nation is putting their hope on you,‚Äù Li Keqiang, the prime minister, told a group of divers, according to the China Daily newspaper. ‚ÄúYou are brave enough to challenge the extremes.‚Äù Of 456 people travelling on the Eastern Star, 14 people have been found alive, including the captain, a 65-year-old woman and a tour guide who survived 10 hours in the river despite being unable to swim.
However, 40 hours after the ship sank while travelling from Nanjing to Chongqing, hopes that others might be rescued were fading fast. ‚ÄúThe chances are small,‚Äù said Shi Chengming, who was leading a team of civilian rescue workers from a Buddhist charity in Chongqing to the disaster site.
Instead, staff at the Rongcheng crematorium in Jianli ‚Äì the town nearest to the wreckage ‚Äì were preparing to receive the dead. Shen Yuanhai, the owner of a coffin factory in Henan province, said he had driven through the night in a convoy of four lorries, each stacked high with refrigerated caskets. ‚ÄúWe have brought 200,‚Äù said Shen, whose factory is more than 400 miles from Jianli in the city of Zhengzhou. After being unloaded by a forklift truck, the caskets, which have transparent, flower-covered lids, were packed side-to-side into four halls where wakes will be held over the coming days.
Xie Xuening, a coffin factory employee, said the scale of the loss had shocked him. ‚ÄúI feel upset,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt is a disaster.‚Äù By Wednesday morning, the bodies of seven victims had arrived at the Rongcheng crematorium. Their identities were not immediately clear. A black-and-white noticeboard had been placed outside one of the halls for staff to record the names and ages of victims, alongside their photograph. The majority of the Eastern Star‚Äôs passengers were tourists aged between 50 and 80, state media has reported, although a three-year-old boy was also on board. A funeral parlour employee, who declined to give his name, said staff were expecting the worst. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve contacted all of the crematoriums around here so that if we don‚Äôt have room we can send the bodies there,‚Äù he said.
A doctor at the Jianli People‚Äôs hospital said his team was treating five survivors, two of whom were in intensive care. Asked if medics were expecting more survivors, the doctor, who asked not to be named, said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre still waiting for information.‚Äù As the families of Eastern Star passengers began arriving in Jianli, dozens of local women gathered at the Rongcheng Crematorium to watch the grim preparations. ‚ÄúI would tell the families not to be sad,‚Äù said Zou Jinlin, 40. ‚ÄúIt was a natural disaster. It wasn‚Äôt human error.‚Äù Additional reporting by Luna Lin.

column4: Egyptian football's 'magician' denies funding Muslim Brotherhood
column5:
They call him the magician, or the ‚Äúsmiling assassin‚Äù, for his lightning attacks and last-minute goals. But now Mohamed Aboutrika, one of Egypt‚Äôs greatest footballers of all time, is battling an adversary far more formidable than even the best international defence as he faces down a government freeze on his assets over allegations that a company he co-founded aided the Muslim Brotherhood. The furore surrounding the footballer underscores the enduring importance of the game in Egypt‚Äôs politics and how the political situation remains unsettled nearly two years after the military ousted the elected president, Mohamed Morsi, a Brotherhood member. The case is also a rare example of a public dispute that cuts across political lines in Egypt, where the rift between the state and its Islamist opponents runs deep. A state campaign against Islamists and political dissidents has left more than 1,000 dead and as many as 40,000 arrested. Abdel-Rahman el-Barr, the Muslim Brotherhood‚Äôs top religious cleric, and Mahmoud Ghozlan, the group‚Äôs former spokesman and a member of its top decision-making body, became part of their number on Monday. ‚ÄúWe come by wealth so that it can be in our hands, not in our hearts, and so our hearts cannot be confiscated, no matter what they confiscate. I will remain in this country and continue to work for its betterment,‚Äù Aboutrika said on his official Twitter and Facebook accounts. Since announcing his retirement in 2013, Aboutrika remains a hero to millions in Egypt after leading the Cairo club Al Ahly to a series of national and regional titles. He is now relying in part on his superpower status to combat the accusations that he aided the Brotherhood, which has been banned and branded a terrorist organisation. Last week, he filed an appeal against the decision by a state committee tasked with seizing assets linked to the Brotherhood. A parade of other prominent football players have lined up behind him, and the news of the seizure of his assets triggered a flood of sympathetic posts on social media. ‚ÄúThere are very few instances in Egypt today where both sides of the divide agree on anything, or would line up on the same side. Aboutrika is one of those rare instances where that is happening,‚Äù says James Dorsey, a scholar studying Middle East football, and senior fellow at the S Rajaratnam school of international studies at Singapore‚Äôs Nanyang Technological University.
The committee that seized Aboutrika‚Äôs assets alleges that a travel company he co-founded in 2013, Ashab Tours, financed the Brotherhood, a charge he denies. Over the years he built a complex public profile. In the aftermath of Egypt‚Äôs 2011 revolution that ousted president Hosni Mubarak, Aboutrika sided with the most insurrectionary force in Egyptian football: militant fans known as ultras, who fought police in the immense street battles of the revolt. In 2012, after more than 70 people were killed in a deadly stadium melee in Port Said, he backed the ultras by heeding a demand not to play in the opening match of the following season. The ultras have not escaped the government crackdown. On Saturday, an Egyptian court declared them a banned terrorist organisation. The ruling came the same day as another court sentenced Morsi to death for fleeing prison after being detained during the 2011 uprising. Aboutrika has also expressed support for the Palestinian cause. After scoring against Sudan during the 2008 Africa Cup of Nations, he pulled up his red national team jersey to reveal a white T-shirt reading ‚ÄúSympathise with Gaza.‚Äù In perhaps his most controversial move, he backed Morsi in the 2012 presidential election. Aboutrika is widely known as an avowedly religious person but denies any explicit ties with the Brotherhood. ‚ÄúFootball isn‚Äôt simply a game. He knows that football is life as far as people are concerned. Football is politics. This football is part of the life of the people,‚Äù says Alaa Ezzat, a journalist and friend of Aboutrika, who conducted a recent interview with the footballer for the state-owned al-Ahram newspaper. ‚ÄúAboutrika‚Äôs name is known in Egypt‚Äôs streets, for a very positive role in religion, in relations with the Arab nation, with Palestine.‚Äù

column4: Japanese spa fudo no yu closed after string of orgies revealed
column5: One of Japan‚Äôs most famous hot springs ‚Äì usually a place for a contemplative soak in mineral-rich waters ‚Äì has been closed indefinitely following complaints that groups of bathers were regularly using it for orgies, footage of which has been posted online. The hot spring, or onsen, tourism association in Shiobara, Tochigi prefecture, near Tokyo, said it had closed Fudo no Yu, an outdoor bath that was popular for its mixed bathing and panoramic views. What the outdoor onsen lacks in size ‚Äì the circular bath is just three metres (nine feet) in diameter ‚Äì it makes up for in atmosphere. Only about 10 people can bathe comfortably at any one time, but it draws large numbers of visitors hoping to relax in its mountain forest setting. However, the bath‚Äôs secluded location encouraged exhibitionists, who took advantage of the absence of a caretaker and its policy of collecting a modest 200 yen admission fee through an honesty box, according to Japanese media reports. Local residents and other bathers had been complaining about witnessing lewd acts for about a year, but the last straw appeared to have been a succession of weekend orgies involving as many as 15 middle-aged men and several younger women, according to the Tokyo Reporter website. The bath, part of the popular Shiobara onsen resort, is also thought to have been targeted by voyeurs armed with cameras, the site said, citing a report in the Mainichi Shimbun. Shigeki Tashiro, the head of the local council, said action had to be taken to safeguard Fudo no Yu‚Äôs reputation as one of Japan‚Äôs finest onsen. ‚ÄúWith the resort being promoted by the prefecture as a tourist attraction, it was a tough decision,‚Äù Tashiro was quoted as saying. ‚ÄúHowever, if left as it is, the image of the area as a tourist destination could be downgraded.‚Äù Onsen are an important part of the tourism economy in Japan, whose vast reservoirs of geothermal activity support more than 3,000 hot springs. Fudo no Yu‚Äôs popularity as a location for al fresco sex has embarrassed local tourist authorities, which had featured it on their website and promotional posters. ‚ÄúWe are sorry, but it was breach of manners that was impossible to overlook,‚Äù an unnamed member of the local residents‚Äô association told the Asahi Shimbun. ‚ÄúWe had no choice but to close the bath.‚Äù The offending onsen, which has now been drained of its water, has existed since the Meiji era (1868-1912), media reports said.

column4: Japanese robot cat Doraemon helps ease diplomatic tensions with China
column5: Just a few months ago, Chinese media denounced him as a counter-revolutionary. Now, though, Doraemon ‚Äì Japan‚Äôs beloved robot cat ‚Äì is easing diplomatic tensions between Tokyo and Beijing, and breaking box-office records in the process. The 3D animated film Stand By Me Doraemon brought in 30m yuan ($4.8m) in receipts on its opening day last Thursday, and repeated the feat the following day. As parents and children packed out Chinese cinemas, receipts surged to 85m yuan and 88m yuan on Saturday and Sunday, surpassing the previous single-day record for animated movies, held by the US film Kung Fu Panda 2. According to estimates, revenue from the Doraemon movie accounted for more than half of China‚Äôs total box-office revenues on Sunday, easily beating the US superhero blockbuster Avengers: Age of Ultron. Doraemon, a chubby, perennially cheerful cat from the 22nd century, has charmed generations of Japanese fans with his teleportation powers, addiction to sweet bean pancakes and array of ingenious gadgets he uses to help his hapless schoolboy friend, Nobita. The popularity of Stand By Me Doraemon reflects an easing in tensions between Japan and China over ownership of the Senkaku islands and interpretations of wartime history. China‚Äôs leader, Xi Jinping, and his Japanese counterpart, Shinzo Abe, have met twice in the past six months, raising hopes of friendlier ties between the world‚Äôs second and third-biggest economies. In recent remarks to a Japanese delegation of tourism and local government officials, Xi said he understood the importance of people-to-people exchanges, adding China was ‚Äúready to [negotiate] with the Japanese side to advance neighbourly friendship and cooperation‚Äù. The Doraemon film, which will be shown at 5,500 screens across China over the coming month, is the first Japanese movie to go on general release in China since 2012, when Japan‚Äôs government bought the Senkaku islands from their private Japanese owners, effectively nationalising them. The move sparked protests in several Chinese cities and sent bilateral ties to their lowest point in decades. Doraemon‚Äôs attempts to win over China haven‚Äôt always been so well received, however. Last October, a Chinese newspaper accused the blue cat of political subversion claiming his presence at an exhibition in the city of Chengdu was part of a plot to portray Japan in a kinder light as the countries traded verbal blows over the Senkakus and wartime history. ‚ÄúDoraemon is a part of Japan‚Äôs efforts of exporting its national values and achieving its cultural strategy; this is an undisputed fact,‚Äù the Chengdu Daily said in an editorial. ‚ÄúTaking this to heart, we should be less blind and keep a cool head while kissing the cheeks of the chubby blue guy.‚Äù In South Korea, where a ban on Japanese popular culture has been lifted in increments since the late 1990s, disputes over territory and the legacy of the second world war show little sign of easing. A recent survey showed that mutual suspicion among the public remains high: 52% of Japanese polled said they had a negative view of South Koreans, while in South Korea, 73% said they felt similarly towards the Japanese. Doraemon‚Äôs global popularity is such that in 2008 he was made an ambassador to promote Japanese popular culture overseas. Having built a huge following in Japan since his comic book debut in 1969, he has become instantly recognisable throughout East Asia and, more recently, in the US. The manga, created by Fujiko F Fujio, has sold well over 100m copies, making it one of the best-selling comics in the world, while the TV series has won over audiences in more than 30 countries. Last summer, Doraemon made its US debut on the Disney XD satellite channel. In 2002, Time magazine named Doraemon one of its 22 Asian heroes.

column4: Bison tosses Australian tourist into air at Yellowstone national park
column5: An Australian tourist, 62, survived being tossed in the air three times by a bison while he was visiting Yellowstone national park, US park authorities have said. It is the second time in three weeks a bison has seriously injured a tourist in Yellowstone. Park officials said the man‚Äôs injuries were not life-threatening despite being thrown about repeatedly by the animal. The man, whom authorities did not name, was flown by helicopter for medical treatment. Yellowstone officials said several people crowded the bison as it lay near a path not far from the famous Old Faithful geyser on Tuesday morning. The bison charged as the man took photos from a few feet away. Bison can weigh as much as a full-size sedan and run three times faster than a person. A bison in the Old Faithful area gored a 16-year-old girl from Taiwan as she posed for a picture near the animal on 16 May. The park service said in a statement: ‚ÄúThe girl turned her back to the bison to have her picture taken when the bison lifted its head, took a couple of steps and gored her.‚Äù The exchange student, who was staying with a US family, was airlifted to hospital for treatment. Yellowstone is home to wild animals including bears, elk, deer, moose, coyotes and wolves, a park official said. ‚ÄúVisitors are reminded that Yellowstone wildlife is wild ‚Ä¶ and should not be approached, no matter how tame or calm they appear.‚Äù Bison in particular were fast, ‚Äúunpredictable and dangerous‚Äù, the official said. Many believe grizzly bears and wolves are Yellowstone‚Äôs most dangerous animals but bison and elk attacked a couple of people in the park every year and were responsible for more injuries, said Yellowstone spokeswoman Amy Bartlett. In the case of the Australian man, he wasn‚Äôt the only person to blame, Bartlett said. Other people had crowded around the bison and it was ‚Äúalready getting agitated‚Äù before he got out his camera. The Associated Press and Agence France-Presse contributed to this report

column4: Tiffany & Co backs investigative reporter in Angola blood diamonds case
column5:
Tiffany & Co has called on Angola to drop the prosecution of an investigative reporter known for his groundbreaking investigation into blood diamonds. The diamond retailer is one of a host of famous names, including 12 Years A Slave director Steve McQueen, who have signed an open letter to Angolan president Jos√© Eduardo dos Santos over the treatment of Rafael Marques de Morais.
Marques, who uncovered stories of widespread torture and murder in the country‚Äôs diamond industry, was last week given a six-month suspended sentence over claims made in his 2011 book, Blood Diamonds: Corruption and Torture in Angola. The book accused seven army generals of complicity in more than 100 killings and widespread torture by a private security company, owned by the generals, in the country‚Äôs diamond fields. ‚ÄúMarques‚Äô vital investigations into human rights abuses should not be impeded by the threat of jail, which is set to loom over him for two years under the court‚Äôs terms,‚Äù the letter reads. ‚Äú[His] reporting is fundamental not only to Angola, but to the world at large. We call on you to ensure standards of international law are applied during the appeal process.‚Äù Marques had faced 24 defamation charges that could have resulted in a nine-year prison sentence and a fine of ¬£800,000. Human rights groups were cautiously optimistic after seven generals appeared to drop charges last week after an out-of-court settlement, as international political and media interest grew.
