But, in an unexpected twist, judge Adriano Cerveira on Thursday handed down a suspended six month sentence for ‚Äúslander‚Äù and ordered Marques to ‚Äúwithdraw the book from the market, including on the internet, and not to republish or translate it‚Äù. It is unclear how that would be enforced in international markets. Following the sentence, Marques said that he believes the generals had deliberately misled him, and had wished to avoid the public embarrassment of being cross-examined in court, while still intending to pursue him. The six-month suspended sentence is a way to ensure he does not continue his investigations into torture and corruption in the southern African nation, he added. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a victory for treachery and ill-faith and it just proves the generals were aware of the abuses in the region,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf they were unaware, they would not have resorted to such laws to clear their names in such a crude and manipulative manner.‚Äù
Other signatories to Tuesday‚Äôs letter include Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales; actors Janet Suzman and Juliet Stevenson; playwright Howard Brenton; former Times editor Sir Harold Evans and the paper‚Äôs current editor, John Witherow. Several other diamond merchants have also signed, including ethical jewellers Brilliant Earth and Leber. The letter will be delivered to the embassy of Angola in London by the free expression group Index on Censorship. ‚ÄúRafael‚Äôs trial was a sham. He was told charges would be dropped, only for him to be hit with new charges out of the blue, and he was not allowed to present his evidence or call witnesses,‚Äù said Jodie Ginsberg, chief executive of Index, which gave Marques a Freedom of Expression award earlier this year. ‚ÄúRafael is a courageous journalist, working with little support to expose corruption in Angola. This absurd trial and verdict is meant to stop him from speaking out. We want to make sure that does not happen.‚Äù

column4: Alexis Tsipras to face take-it-or-leave-it ultimatum from lenders over debt offer
column5:
The Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, will be presented with what is expected to be a take-it-or-leave-it plan on Wednesday after five months of drama-filled negotiations to keep his debt-stricken country afloat. The radical left leader is to be given the ultimatum after lenders at the EU, European Central Bank (ECB) and International Monetary Fund (IMF) agreed on the contours of a cash-for-reform deal late on Tuesday. The agreement, reached after emergency talks in Berlin on Monday, would unlock ‚Ç¨7.2bn (¬£5.2bn) in rescue loans for the cash-strapped country but demand tough economic changes in return. ‚ÄúIt covers all key policy areas and reflects the discussions of recent weeks,‚Äù a senior EU official said on Tuesday. ‚ÄúIt will be discussed with Tsipras tomorrow.‚Äù Greece‚Äôs anti-austerity leader was scheduled to fly to Brussels at the request of the EU commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, a Greek government official said. ‚ÄúThe prime minister will be in Brussels tomorrow with the Greek proposal in his luggage,‚Äù said the official on Tuesday night, suggesting the bargaining was far from over for Tsipras‚Äôs government. Both the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, and the French president, Fran√ßois Hollande, were also expected to put the blueprint to Tsipras in a bid to win his acceptance by Friday when Greece must pay the first in a series of loan instalments to the IMF. The accord ends months of stalemate in the wake of the election of Tsipras‚Äô anti-austerity Syriza party in January. But whether Athens will accept the offer remains in doubt. Taking a defiant stance earlier on Tuesday, Tsipras said: ‚ÄúWe have submitted a realistic plan for Greece to exit the crisis. A realistic plan, whose acceptance by the institutions, our lenders and our partners in Europe will mark the end of the scenario of divisions in Europe.‚Äù He said it was up to the bloc‚Äôs political leadership to decide whether it wanted ‚Äúto adjust to realism‚Äù. Sources suggested the 47-page proposal had been submitted by Athens before Merkel convened Monday‚Äôs mini-summit of protagonists in Europe‚Äôs debt drama. Hollande, Juncker, and the heads of the ECB and IMF, Mario Draghi and Christine Lagarde, would all have seen it, they said.
Faced with empty coffers and debt repayments worth ‚Ç¨1.6bn to the IMF this month alone, crunch time has come for Greece. Failure to honour loan instalments would automatically lead to default and a euro exit. The Washington-based IMF is expecting a first repayment of ‚Ç¨300m to be made this Friday. Last week, the national economy minister, George Stathakis, said Athens would utilise internal resources to ensure the bill was paid. But, ratcheting up the pressure on Tuesday, a Greek government official implied that the country might think twice if an agreement with creditors had still not been concluded. ‚ÄúIf we judge that a deal has been sealed, then we will make the 5 June payment normally,‚Äù he said, explaining that the money would still be transferred even if a preliminary agreement had not been approved by eurozone finance ministers. The countdown to possible economic Armageddon was infused with yet more tension as eurozone officials disagreed over the degree to which progress had been made. A French presidency official, speaking after Monday night‚Äôs talks, hinted that creditors were still at odds over the terms of a deal. Others, including the Dutch finance minister, Jeroen Dijsselbloem ‚Äì who chairs the Eurogroup of euro area finance ministers ‚Äì continued to blame the lack of headway on Athens. ‚ÄúThere is some progress, but it‚Äôs really not enough,‚Äù he told Dutch television. The primary budget surplus that Greece must sign up to is believed to remain at the heart of the discord between the two, along with pension changes and labour deregulation. Greece‚Äôs outspoken finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, has argued that a primary surplus above 1% will simply exacerbate Athens‚Äô debt deflationary spiral after six years of austerity-fuelled recession. The nation‚Äôs debt-to-GDP ratio stands at 180% ‚Äì the highest in the EU.
Mounting dissent from within Tsipras‚Äô Syriza party ‚Äì catapulted into office in January on the back of promises to scrap foreign-imposed budget cuts ‚Äì has deepened the uncertainty and added to speculation over whether a deal is possible. The young premier has come under growing pressure from hardliners rattled that the government has already made too many concessions to creditors. Amid talk of fresh elections ‚Äì on a day punctuated by fiery rhetoric ‚Äì the country‚Äôs usually mild-mannered deputy leader, Yannis Dragasakis, insisted that any deal would have to include a roadmap to debt sustainability. After being impoverished by belt-tightening, he said, Greeks could not bear any more austerity. ‚ÄúAs a government we do not accept ultimatums, nor do we surrender to blackmail,‚Äù tweeted the former communist, who is now in charge of the coalition‚Äôs economic policy. The debt crisis, which has seen the Greek economy contract by a depression-era 26%, has also triggered record levels of joblessness and poverty, prompting senior Syriza figures to say that any compromise will have to be honourable. ‚ÄúIf a deal is achieved that is not deemed honourable and promoting of compromise, the people will have to be asked before we sign it,‚Äù the labour minister, Panos Skourletis, told SKAI TV. ‚ÄúWhen you are elected you are not given carte blanche.‚Äù Several politicians suggested that polls could be held on 28 June. A second scenario ‚Äì one that could be prompted by lenders deciding on a short-term deal that would tide Greece over a summer of heavy debt repayments ‚Äì might also involve a referendum.

column4: Greece to face ultimatum from eurozone and IMF
column5:
Eurozone and International Monetary Fund officials appeared to have put the finishing touches on an ultimatum to Greece after Monday night‚Äôs emergency mini-summit between Athens‚Äôs creditors.
With Greece running out of money and due to repay ‚Ç¨300m (¬£219m) to the IMF on Friday ‚Äì and owing a further ‚Ç¨1.3bn this month ‚Äì Angela Merkel fears the crisis could hijack her hosting of a G7 summit in Bavaria this weekend. The hastily and secretly arranged mini-summit of the key leaders in the German chancellor‚Äôs Berlin offices late on Monday signalled that after five months of stalled negotiations between technocrats and civil servants, the Greek crisis is now to be tackled by national and international leaders. In Brussels and eurozone capitals, there is a strong sense of foreboding that the extreme brinkmanship on both sides is careering out of control and will end badly. The radical Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, and his governing far-left Syriza party ‚Äúis underestimating unity in the rest of the EU‚Äù, said a senior EU official involved in five years of negotiations with the Greeks. ‚ÄúThat will probably cause default or breakdown. No one is trying to prevent it any more.‚Äù A finance minister from a key eurozone country, who is party to the negotiations, said eurozone policymakers were considering how to help Greece after it had defaulted on its huge debts and been expelled from the single currency. ‚ÄúThe possibility of an accident is real,‚Äù said the minister, speaking on condition of anonymity. ‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs going to be an accident, we will need a big humanitarian programme for Greece.‚Äù
Merkel, long criticised as a ditherer on the euro crisis who habitually leaves everything to the last minute, appears to be in a hurry to strike a deal. It is not clear whether she is prepared to make concessions to keep Greece in the euro. On Tuesday, Brussels insisted it remained up to Tsipras to table an acceptable raft of austerity policies to access the ‚Ç¨7.2bn available in bailout funds. ‚ÄúIt is for the Greeks to present a comprehensive package which the [EU] institutions will then discuss,‚Äù said a second EU official, while adding ‚Äúthere are many different proposals being discussed‚Äù. But Merkel‚Äôs sudden initiative is also good news for Tsipras, who has long sought to shift the negotiations from the technical to the political level. In a tirade against the eurozone in Le Monde newspaper on Sunday, he demanded that Merkel and her peers take charge of the negotiations. ‚ÄúThe decision is now not in the hands of the institutions, which in any case are not elected and are not accountable to the people, but rather in the hands of Europe‚Äôs leaders,‚Äù he said.
However, the eurozone finance minister told the Guardian: ‚ÄúTsipras thinks everything has to be a political decision.‚Äù The minister argued that the centrist governments of the eurozone were unwilling to do any favours for a hard-left administration in Greece and that risk-averse eurozone leaders, personified by Merkel, were running scared of public opinion. ‚ÄúNo one is going to push for a real agreement because the one who takes the lead takes too much risk. Because it can finalise in an accident. Who will lead? [European commission president] Jean-Claude Juncker? No. The ECB? No. Merkel? No. Everyone knows being close to Syriza is detrimental.‚Äù That view was echoed by the senior official who said: ‚ÄúNot a single EU government has an interest in helping Syriza find a solution they can sell as an end to austerity.‚Äù While there are divisions between the IMF and the Europeans over what to do next, officials and diplomats say Tsipras and Syriza have failed to split the eurozone, which is more united behind the harder line espoused by the German finance minister, Wolfgang Sch√§uble, than before. ‚ÄúBelgian, Finnish, Dutch opinion is hardening. The Germans are actually the softies compared to the Slovakians and Estonians,‚Äù the official said. A senior diplomat in Brussels said Spain and its finance minister, Luis de Guindos, who hopes to take over the presidency of the Eurogroup of eurozone finance ministers in July, take the hardest line of all because they are worried that a success for Tsipras and Syriza will boost the leftwing Podemos movement in elections later this year in Spain. Then there are the Americans who are alarmed at the prospect of Greece falling out of the eurozone for geopolitical reasons. A Greek departure will present an opportunity for Russia‚Äôs Vladimir Putin that he is unlikely to waste, that Athens could be bought off by the Russians and become Moscow‚Äôs Trojan horse inside the Nato military alliance. Merkel‚Äôs ally, Gunther Krichbaum, who chairs the German parliament‚Äôs Europe committee, brushed off such fears on Tuesday. ‚ÄúThere are other Nato members who are not in the EU,‚Äù he told German radio. Merkel is expected to come under strong US pressure to act more decisively at the weekend when she hosts the G7 summit. The eurozone finance minister, who has taken part in most of the crisis meetings for years, was pessimistic about the outcome. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not used to dealing with a government like Syriza. It‚Äôs totally new for us. Usually we deal with mainstream parties,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf there is a default, we will have to react right away. The ECB will have legal difficulties maintaining emergency liquidity assistance to Greece. If we go to capital controls, it‚Äôs the first step in a very difficult process. The Greeks will need a new sort of currency. There is no precedent, no procedure. It will be a mess.‚Äù

column4: Independent El Bronco aims to buck Mexico's politics-as-usual trend
column5:
Jaime Rodr√≠guez likes it when people call him El Bronco. The nickname, he claims, reflects an untamed nature that explains how he became the first independent candidate with a realistic shot at winning a major election in Mexico. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt be pushed around, and people respond to that,‚Äù said El Bronco of his attempt to become governor of the northern state of Nuevo Le√≥n in elections this Sunday that will also completely renovate the lower house of Congress, elect eight other new governors and nearly 900 new mayors. ‚ÄúWe need to push the mafias out of power,‚Äù he said. El Bronco‚Äôs swashbuckling candidacy directly challenges the stranglehold maintained by Mexico‚Äôs two main political parties, and could pave the way for a serious independent contender in Mexico‚Äôs next presidential elections in 2018. A win by El Bronco, as predicted by some polls, would hint at the biggest potential shake up of the Mexican political system since the National Action Party (the Pan), ended 71 years of continuous rule by the Institutional Revolutionary Party (Pri) in 2000. ‚Äú[El Bronco‚Äôs campaign] is very important because it loosens the political imagination to go beyond politics as usual,‚Äù said political analyst Federico Est√©vez. ‚ÄúThe message that independent candidates can win is very worrying for the political parties.‚Äù
Est√©vez stressed that El Bronco‚Äôs popularity bears little resemblance to the success of insurgent parties in Europe, such as Spain‚Äôs Podemos or Syriza in Greece ‚Äì after all, the candidate was a member of the Pri for 33 years. He resigned in September, just after a constitutional reform giving independents in Mexico the possibility of standing. But his message that ‚Äúit‚Äôs all about corruption‚Äù nevertheless resonates in a country weary of scandal: fresh allegations of wrongdoing emerge every week, from allegations of kickbacks given for government contracts to deals with organised crime. And whatever his party political roots, his campaign ‚Äì relying on the internet to channel frustration over politics-as-usual ‚Äì remains an extraordinary feat. While his opponents can draw on huge amounts of public financing for blanket advertising campaigns, El Bronco has been sidelined by mainstream media. Local TV and radio stations have either ignored him completely or portrayed him as a dangerous populist. During the campaign one of his two ex-wives accused Rodr√≠guez of assaulting her during their marriage, an allegation he both denied and charged was part of a smear campaign against him orchestrated by the Pri. Silvia Gonz√°lez, his former wife, has publicly backed the candidate of the Pri. At two recent rallies in poor neighbourhoods of the state capital Monterrey, supporters cheered loudly when Rodr√≠guez pledged never to pay TV stations for favourable coverage ‚Äì a tactic which many high-profile candidates are alleged to have used in the past. Several in the crowd said their trust in El Bronco stemmed from his willingness to take on the cartels while he was mayor of the city of Garc√≠a, on the edge of the Monterrey metropolitan area, between 2009 and 2012 ‚Äì a period when Nuevo Le√≥n became a battlefield for the rival factions of the Gulf cartel and the Zetas.
Rodr√≠guez was himself targeted by the narcos twice; in one attack, the story goes that he ordered his driver to turn back and use his armoured car to provide cover for his bodyguards, rather than speed away to safety. ‚ÄúHe went back to protect the people working for him,‚Äù said 63-year-old former builder Jos√© Estrada with admiration. ‚ÄúIt makes me think he is sincere when he says he will go after the corruption in the political parties.‚Äù Up on stage, El Bronco milked the emotional power of his life story ‚Äì one which reflects the extraordinary levels of drug-fuelled violence that have become part of everyday life in much of the country. He pledged to dedicate his life to changing the country, he told the crowd, while cradling the corpse of his 22-year-old son, killed in a car accident while trying to escape a kidnapping attempt. ‚ÄúI know that I can deliver what I promise,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt bring you food handouts like the candidates of the political parties. I have brought you my heart and my strong character.‚Äù
What marks El Bronco‚Äôs campaign as unique is not his rhetoric, however, but his development of a digital version of the post-rally walkabouts in which he firmly shakes supporters‚Äôs hands and listens to their concerns. Chatting in the van that drives him between campaign events, El Bronco said he begins each morning with two hours dedicated to answering the WhatsApp messages on his mobile, a number he gives out everywhere he goes. But it is Facebook, he added, that sets the rhythm of his campaigning day around the state that shares a nine-mile border with Texas, and is home to some of Mexico‚Äôs biggest companies. Whipping out an iPad with a cracked screen, he scrolled down the comments below a Facebook invitation to the rally he was about to attend. ‚ÄúThe comments tell you what people feel, which is more important than what they think,‚Äù he said. A few moments later he found one about drainage in the area of the rally, which he duly included into his stump speech to general approval. ‚ÄúHe blew open the normal model of political communication on social media,‚Äù said Juan Manuel Ramos of Quinto Poder, a platform set up in 2012 to monitor the political use of the web. While most Mexican politicians‚Äô use of social media consists of anodyne tweets and Facebook posts which read like something from a motivational handbook, Rodr√≠guez uses colloquial language to respond to his constituents, said Ramos. This, Ramos added, has given El Bronco a ‚Äúnear-religious‚Äù political fanbase with a mission to get him elected. With El Bronco becoming a genuine contender, the business elite has also begun to jump on the bandwagon, along with the young and progressive who might otherwise be put off by his macho image. El Bronco‚Äôs rise in Nuevo Le√≥n inevitably brings comparisons with Vicente Fox, another northern politician who changed the country‚Äôs political history by wresting the presidency from the Pri in 2000. Fox launched his presidential bid after winning the governorship of his state of Guanajuato in 1995. Like Bronco, Fox wore a cowboy hat and peppered his speeches with swearwords. He was also an innovative campaigner, producing unusually bold and direct TV spots. And like Bronco, Fox‚Äôs mould-breaking popularity eventually drew in parts of the business elite and the leftwing intelligentsia. But as the years ticked by critics charged that the advent of political pluralism did little to limit the abuse and corruption of those in power. One-party hegemony had fallen, the argument went, only to be replaced with a kind of political cartel.
The Pri returned to federal government in 2012, when Enrique Pe√±a Nieto was elected president ‚Äì a victory which for many cemented a sense of disillusionment with Mexico‚Äôs first attempt at democratisation. One recent poll found that just 9% of Mexican voters trusted the country‚Äôs national parties. ‚ÄúOur system at the federal level and at the local level, really needs to be shaken up,‚Äù said Mauricio Sada, a businessman and former head of the Pan in the Nuevo Le√≥n congress who now supports El Bronco. ‚ÄúHe has a natural persona that fits the circumstances. There are a lot of elements that are lacking, or at least not proven, in terms of his actual capacity, but you just have to trust him.‚Äù With the tension mounting ahead of Sunday‚Äôs election, El Bronco said he deals with the stress with the help of yoga-style breathing exercises every morning, adding yet another contradictory element into his singular mix of old and new. But, the candidate mused, what really keeps him focused and calm is a sense of himself as usefully unhinged. ‚ÄúNever doubt that it is those who are a little crazy who manage to change the world,‚Äù the candidate said, after waving to another motorist giving him the thumbs up. ‚ÄúThose who reason everything, those who plan everything, and those who stay in their comfort zone ‚Äì they never change anything.‚Äù

column4: Secret report urges treaty securing US web firms' cooperation in data sharing
column5: A top secret report to the British prime minister has recommended that a new international treaty be negotiated to force the cooperation of the big US internet companies in sharing customers‚Äô personal data, the Guardian has learned. Privacy campaigners said the decision to classify the report, written by the former diplomat Sir Nigel Sheinwald, as top secret was designed to bury it and its key recommendation for an international treaty could provide a legal, front-door alternative to the government‚Äôs renewed ‚Äúsnooper‚Äôs charter‚Äù surveillance proposals. It is believed the former British ambassador to Washington concluded that such a treaty could overcome US laws that prevent web giants based there, including Facebook, Google, Twitter, Microsoft and Yahoo, from sharing their customers‚Äô private data with British police and security services. It would also mean not having to revive the powers, which require British phone companies to share data from the US giants passing over their networks, from the 2012 communications data bill that would enforce their compliance. Jim Killock of the Open Rights Group said: ‚ÄúThe Sheinwald report should be published. Any attempt to hide it can only be interpreted as an attempt to close down debate about whether the snooper‚Äôs charter is really needed. ‚ÄúA new international treaty is the right approach to cross-border requests for data by law enforcement agencies. This approach undermines Theresa May‚Äôs claim that there is a need for a new snooper‚Äôs charter when there is a simple, transparent and workable solution.‚Äù But the Cabinet Office defended its decision to keep the report secret. It said Shinewald ‚Äúreports on progress to the prime minister but ‚Ä¶ is not undertaking a public review‚Äù. The Guardian understands the report has been classified as top secret by the Cabinet Office because it goes into the detail of each company‚Äôs operations. Shinewald was appointed by Cameron in September 2014 as his special envoy on intelligence and law enforcement data sharing. Campaigners said the Sheinwald report could be published by redacting or stripping out the confidential detail of each company‚Äôs operations and having the report declassified. May, the home secretary, is due to publish within the next few months an ‚Äúinvestigatory powers bill‚Äù that is expected to extend the powers of the security services to access personal communications data, which tracks everyone‚Äôs email, web and social media use, and enhance their powers for the warranted intercept of their content. The bill has been described as a ‚Äúturbo-charged snooper‚Äôs charter‚Äù and is expected to revive the original 2012 communications data bill that was blocked by the Liberal Democrats in the coalition government. That bill had included highly controversial powers requiring British phone and web companies to collect the personal third-party data passing over their networks from US web companies that refused to cooperate on a voluntary basis with British requests. The concerns of the US major web companies over this point was a key factor behind Nick Clegg‚Äôs decision to veto the bill. There is currently a system of general mutual legal assistance treaties, known as Mlats, but they are regarded as cumbersome and slow. The Home Office has said they are completely unsuitable to facilitate the real-time exchange of data for day to day crime and counterterrorism investigations. The Home Office confirmed that in extreme cases it was considering inserting ‚Äúblack box‚Äù probes into the transatlantic networks to collect the data it says it needs. Cameron acknowledged the problem facing internet firms when he appointed Sheinwald as a special envoy. The prime minister said a number of overseas companies had said their ability to work with the British government was severely constrained by international conflicts of jurisdiction, ‚Äúfor example, where they think they have a British law saying they should share data, and an American law saying they shouldn‚Äôt‚Äù. This week‚Äôs vote in the US Congress allowing some domestic data surveillance powers to lapse underlined the growing difference in US and British policies. Eric King, deputy director of Privacy International, accused the government of avoiding an honest debate about surveillance: ‚ÄúThe role of US companies is critical to surveillance reform, but now the report commissioned to assess the situation, and report back to parliament and public, is being classified top secret. Why?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúPerhaps the report hints that last summer‚Äôs Data Retention and Investigatory Powers Act [Dripa] didn‚Äôt solve the problem it claimed to, or acknowledges that greater international reform is a better option than rushing through broad powers at home to try and strong-arm companies abroad. Unless it‚Äôs published, we‚Äôll never know. ‚ÄúThis is not how complex reforms should be conducted. Must the same mistakes continue to be made, time and time again? Or will this government allow public and parliament the space for an honest debate about surveillance that it so sorely needs?‚Äù In response, a Cabinet Office spokesman said: ‚ÄúSir Nigel Sheinwald has been leading the discussions on intelligence and law enforcement data-sharing with overseas governments, communications service providers, and other key international partners on ways to improve access to data when it is stored in other jurisdictions. ‚ÄúThis includes consideration of new international frameworks to facilitate data sharing. He reports on progress to the prime minister but unlike David Anderson QC, is not undertaking a public review.‚Äù The Sheinwald report was commissioned by Cameron when the emergency Dripa legislation was introduced last year. At the same time he asked Sir David Anderson, the official reviewer of counterterrorism laws, to undertake a review of the current surveillance and intercept laws. The emergency data retention legislation is due to expire in December 2016 and the government is currently discussing its options to replace it. The Cabinet Office said the Anderson review would be published soon and his ‚Äúthorough and comprehensive report will be important as we draw up new legislation‚Äù. But privacy campaigners fear the Anderson review will focus on the legalities of the surveillance laws rather than the bigger picture. The home secretary had tried to fix the problem of requiring the cooperation of the US internet giants in last summer‚Äôs Dripa legislation which asserted the ‚Äúextra-territoriality‚Äù of UK intercept warrants and requests for communications data. But US law has various blocks on sending data overseas which has limited the impact of the move. An international treaty would allow these blocks to be dismantled to facilitate data exchange between trusted countries.

column4: Syria: Isis advance on Aleppo aided by Assad regime air strikes, US says
column5:
The US has accused the Syrian government of providing air support to an advance by Islamic State militants against opposition groups north of Aleppo. Fighters opposing the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, have made the same claims since Sunday, when Isis began advancing towards the town of Azaz near the Turkish border. The seizure of Azaz, 20 miles north-west of Aleppo, would imperil the main opposition supply line into Syria‚Äôs biggest city, the rebel-held east of which has been besieged by government forces for more than two years. A post to a Twitter account used by the US embassy in Syria said late on Monday: ‚ÄúReports indicate that the regime is making air strikes in support of [Isis‚Äôs] advance on Aleppo, aiding extremists against Syrian population. ‚ÄúWe have long seen that the regime avoids Isis lines, in complete contradiction to the regime‚Äôs claims to be fighting Isis,‚Äù the embassy said in a separate tweet.
The Isis offensive, which began on Sunday, was the first launched inside Syria by the jihadist group since it was forced out of northern Aleppo 18 months ago in a six-week battle that claimed the lives of at least 1,500 opposition fighters and allowed government forces to tighten a stranglehold around the city. Since then, loyalist forces have twice attempted and failed to completely surround Aleppo. Rebel groups, including Islamist and more mainstream factions, had consolidated supply lines north to the Turkish border after the second failed attempt in March. Islam Alloush, a spokesman for the Islamic Front, one of the main opposition groups in northern Syria, said: ‚ÄúYesterday, the regime bombed Mare‚Äôa (which was held by the opposition) exactly at the same time when Isis was attacking us, and this helped them greatly. ‚ÄúIt has become a matter of fact since 2013 that the Syrian regime has bombed us to stop us fighting Isis properly. Isis have never attacked Syrian planes. They owe their success to the regime.‚Äù
A second opposition leader from the Suqr al-Sham group said: ‚ÄúThey have hit us with Grad rockets, artillery, air strikes and everything else since Sunday. They have not hit an Isis position.‚Äù On Sunday a Syrian air force jet attacked a marketplace in the Isis-held city of al-Bab, 30 miles north-east of Aleppo, killing at least 30 civilians, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a British-based monitoring group. Opposition groups have repeatedly pleaded for US air strikes to deter Isis from taking ground in the north. US warplanes have often attacked targets in eastern Syria, but there have been few forays around Aleppo. Strikes by the US and an Arab coalition were decisive in forcing Isis out of the Kurdish border town of Kobani in January and have been instrumental in pushing the terror group back from parts of Iraq‚Äôs Kurdish north. However, Washington has faced persistent criticism that it lacks a uniform strategy to deal with the group, which remains in control of a vast area of land roughly the size of Jordan that straddles the border between Iraq and Syria. The US says it is about to begin training vetted anti-Assad rebels in Syria‚Äôs north. However, more than four years into the civil war, a strong Salafi jihadi alliance has emerged from the fractured opposition to take a lead role in much of the fighting. ‚ÄúIt will be hard now for us to fight our own battles,‚Äù said an Islamic Front member, Mahmoud Hamza.Separately, at a meeting in Paris of members of a US-led coalition against Isis, a senior American official pledged to make it easier for the Iraqi army to get hold of new weapons to support its effort to recapture Ramadi and other lost territory. Tony Blinken, the US deputy secretary of state, was responding to an appeal from the Iraqi prime minister, Haider al-Abadi, who complained that promised military support had failed to materialise and that western sanctions made it hard for his government to buy Russian and Chinese arms. ‚ÄúArmament and ammunition, we haven‚Äôt seen much. Almost none. We‚Äôre relying on ourselves, but fighting is very hard this way,‚Äù Abadi said early on Tuesday. Blinken, who was representing the Obama administration at the Paris meeting after John Kerry, the US secretary of state, broke his leg, said that US anti-tank rockets were on the way to Iraqi forces to help them counter Isis truck bombs, and said that constraints on Iraq‚Äôs access to weapons would be lifted. ‚ÄúWe will redouble our efforts,‚Äù Blinken said. The anti-Isis coalition is supporting the Iraqi military effort with air strikes, drone surveillance and other intelligence. The UK, which is carrying out air strikes and flying surveillance drones over Iraq as part of its contribution to the coalition, said in Paris that it would contribute ¬£2m to EU-UN funding for stabilising areas recaptured from Isis. The Paris meeting ended in a coalition statement vowing support for Abadi and his plan to win back Ramadi and other territory lost in Anbar province, including the development of an Iraqi national guard as an umbrella for the various armed groups fighting Isis. It also said that only the formation of a new government in neighbouring Syria would ‚Äúcreate the necessary conditions to reverse the tide of extremism and radicalism generated by the regime‚Äôs abuses‚Äù. However, both Russia and Iran, which were not invited to the Paris meeting, restated their commitment to the Assad regime on Tuesday. Sergei Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, said: ‚ÄúIt is absolutely clear to me it was a mistake ‚Äì still is ‚Äì not to coordinate the air strikes with the activities of the Syrian army. That‚Äôs what we believe must be done ‚ÄúThat is what, unfortunately, our American colleagues cannot accept for ideological considerations,‚Äù he told Bloomberg Television in an interview. Meanwhile, Iran‚Äôs president, Hassan Rouhani, was quoted on the state news agency IRNA as saying: ‚ÄúThe Iranian nation and government will remain at the side of the Syrian nation and government until the end of the road. ‚ÄúTehran has not forgotten its moral obligations to Syria and will continue to provide help and support on its own terms to the government and nation of Syria.‚Äù

column4: Missile firm offers to recreate MH17 crash in bid to clear Russia
column5: A Russian defence conglomerate has suggested recreating the MH17 plane crash by shooting another Boeing 777 aircraft out of the sky using a Buk missile system. Almaz-Antey, which makes the Buk systems, said such an experiment would help prove its thesis of how the plane was shot down over eastern Ukraine in July last year. All 298 people on board died in the incident. Almost all the circumstantial evidence appears to point to a Buk system fired from separatist-controlled territory. Russia has denied supplying the system to the separatists, just as it has denied providing any military aid, despite much evidence to the contrary. At a press conference in Moscow on Tuesday Almaz-Antey presented an ‚Äúexpert report‚Äù on the crash, in which it said it believed the plane had indeed been downed by a Buk system. However, it placed the launch position in a different place to others, and said the attack could only have been carried out using a discontinued Buk M-1 system, which it claimed the Ukrainian army operated but the Russian army did not. The company‚Äôs general director, Yan Novikov, said Almaz-Antey was prepared to stage a reconstruction of the crash, ‚Äúdespite the significant costs involved‚Äù, in order to prove the angles. He said the company could invite international observers could take part. ‚ÄúThey would probably buy an old out-of-service plane, fly it on autopilot, and then shoot it down over a military testing ground,‚Äù said Igor Korotchenko, a Russian defence analyst. ‚ÄúThe aim would be to get all the angles the same and show the damage.‚Äù Almaz-Antey said it had carried out its own investigations as it was furious at having been put on EU and US sanctions lists along with other companies involved in Russia‚Äôs actions in east Ukraine. Russia‚Äôs defence ministry has previously suggested MH17 may have been shot down by a Ukrainian fighter jet, and state television gave prominent airtime to people who claimed to have seen a second plane in the sky. That story is now changing, possibly under the weight of evidence that a Buk surface-to-air system was indeed involved. The Dutch commission investigating the tragedy has not yet published its final report. An Almaz-Antey expert presented several slides showing graphs, equations and 3D-reenactments, which he said showed that damage to the aircraft was consistent with the impact from a Buk missile but only from the older Buk M-1 system. The company representatives said they had used secret information about the properties of the missiles, which the Russian defence ministry had agreed to declassify especially for the purposes of the report. They said they could not speculate on which side had fired the missile but intimated heavily that they believed it to be the Ukrainians. Novikov said the 9M38(M1) missiles used with the Buk M-1 system had not been produced since 1999. He said Ukraine had 991 of the missiles, which the company knew as it helped perform maintenance on them in 2005. He said they were not currently in use with the Russian armed forces. However, even if all of their findings are correct, it is unclear whether this would prove that Russia had not supplied the missile system. At the press conference it appeared that the representatives were willing to answer only friendly questions. There was no chance to ask how many M1 systems were still in Russia, including decommissioned or out-of-use systems. Reporters from the Associated Press said they saw a Buk system in the rebel-held town of Snizhne in eastern Ukraine on the day of the attack, and there were numerous photographs purportedly of a Buk system being moved through rebel territory. Locals in the nearby town of Torez said they had seen a Buk drive past. In the days after the attack, a rebel commander admitted the rebels had a Buk system, which he believed had arrived from Russia. He later retracted his words. A number of studies using open-source photographs and tracking have suggested the missile was launched near Snizhne, but Almaz-Antey‚Äôs directors said their analysis proved the missile must have been launched further away, near the village of Zaroshchenskoe. Zaroshchenskoe was very close to the front line at the time MH17 was downed, but is believed to have been under rebel control. This made it unclear why Almaz-Antey wanted to recreate the incident and what such a re-enactment would prove. It may mean that Russia is preparing to accept that rebels downed MH17 but is now working to show that the Buk system involved did not come from Russia but was captured from Ukrainian forces. On Sunday the citizen journalist group Bellingcat released a report that it said proved that the Russian defence ministry had used doctored images in an earlier presentation about MH17. Almaz-Antey said it had carried out the investigation as part of an appeal against its inclusion on sanctions lists, saying that the development of a new ‚Äúcluster‚Äù near St Petersburg had become significantly more expensive now that equipment could no longer be purchased from suppliers it had previously planned to use.

column4: Anger and resignation at scene of Chinese cruise ship sinking
column5:
The call that transformed Deng Liping from minivan driver to corpse collector came out of the blue at dawn on Tuesday. ‚ÄúThe government told me to come to the river and pick up the bodies,‚Äù the 52-year-old said. ‚ÄúThey said a ship had sunk, get ready to leave.‚Äù Less than two hours later, Deng and dozens of other volunteer drivers found themselves on the waterlogged banks of the Yangtze river at the scene of what looks likely to be China‚Äôs worst shipping disaster since 1948. Just offshore lay the upended shell of the Eastern Star, a luxury cruise ship that was carrying 458 people, including dozens of elderly tourists and a three-year-old boy, when it capsized and sank on Monday night. By Tuesday afternoon 15 survivors had been found, including the ship‚Äôs captain and chief engineer who were detained for questioning. Five dead were brought to shore. Deng, the driver-cum-undertaker, pointed to 10 bright orange bodybags he had been given to take away some of the hundreds more who are feared dead. ‚ÄúNothing like this has ever happened before,‚Äù he said. Details of the Eastern Star‚Äôs terrifying final moments began to emerge on Tuesday night as darkness enveloped the small port of Damazhou, which rescue teams are using as their base. The vessel was travelling along the world‚Äôs third longest river from Nanjing to Chongqing, a major city in the south-west of the country, when it ran into trouble after hitting a ferocious storm that China‚Äôs weather bureau classified as a tornado. Residents of Miaoling village, around two miles from the boat‚Äôs final resting place, described a furious cyclone that uprooted trees and flooded fields and homes. ‚ÄúIt was a level-12 storm out on the river,‚Äù said Liu Pingshan, a 45-year-old farmer. ‚ÄúI have never seen one like that before. It is very rare.‚Äù The storm alarmed the 406 tourists on the Eastern Star, most of them retirees from eastern China aged between 50 and 80, according to local reports. One passenger, named as 60-year-old Zhang Lifen, was so worried that she called her husband who was hundreds of miles away in Shanghai. ‚ÄúIt is raining heavily and the wind is blowing like crazy,‚Äù she told him, according to the Southern Metropolis Daily newspaper. Less than half an hour later, at 9.28pm, the ship keeled over in the murky brown water. It took less than two minutes for it to sink, according to the People‚Äôs Daily newspaper, the Communist party‚Äôs official mouthpiece.
By dawn a rescue operation had kicked in as hundreds of Chinese troops, police and emergency workers poured into the rural area around Jianli, the nearest city to the disaster. ‚ÄúWe will do everything we can to rescue everyone trapped in there, no matter if they‚Äôre still alive or not and we will treat them as our own families,‚Äù said Chen Shoumin, a senior military commander from Hubei province. Images broadcast on Chinese television showed a rescue worker tapping on the ship‚Äôs hull with a small hammer in an apparent attempt to find survivors trapped in underwater air pockets. As the hours passed, stories of survival began to emerge: first of a 65-year-old woman who was pulled from the wreck, then of Zhang Hui, a tour guide who escaped despite spending 10 hours in the water and not knowing how to swim. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still alive,‚Äù a jubilant Zhang told his wife and 15-year-old son in his first call home, according to Chinese state media. The 43-year-old painted a chilling portrait of the cruise ship‚Äôs last moments. As the rainstorm pounded the vessel, he recalled, he began to notice more and more water coming on board. ‚ÄúThe water continued to seep through even when you shut the windows,‚Äù he said. Within minutes the ship was listing at a 45-degree angle, sending bottles clattering to the floor. ‚ÄúLooks like we are in trouble,‚Äù he told his friend. Seconds later the boat was submerged. ‚ÄúIf it had not happened so fast, a lot of people could‚Äôve been saved.‚Äù During a visit to the disaster site on Tuesday, China‚Äôs prime minister, Li Keqiang, praised the rescue effort and hailed Zhang‚Äôs survival as a miracle. He urged rescuers to ‚Äúseize every second, battle the fatigue and challenge the extremes‚Äù in the race to find survivors, Xinhua reported. Zhang Hongxia, a local doctor, was among hundreds of people gathered on the banks of the Yangtze hoping for further miracles. ‚ÄúThe chance of survivors is really slim,‚Äù said Zhang, who works at Jianli‚Äôs Number Five People‚Äôs hospital. ‚Äú[But] it‚Äôs the duty of a doctor to be here. If we can save one person we will still feel really happy.‚Äù
Mostly, however, the atmosphere was of quiet resignation as Jianli‚Äôs amateur body collectors lined up on the muddy riverbank waiting for their grisly cargo to come ashore. ‚ÄúIt is a natural disaster,‚Äù shrugged Xu Houwu, 62, a subsistence farmer who had also been asked to turn his hand to the funeral trade. ‚ÄúIt is not something we can change.‚Äù By nightfall the families of 17 passengers from Fujian province had arrived in Jianli seeking news of their loved ones and answers. There was anger among some relatives that human errors as well as meteorological conditions might have contributed to the tragedy. ‚ÄúWhy did the captain leave the ship while the passengers were still missing?‚Äù asked Huang Yan, a Shanghai accountant who believed that her husband and father were on board. ‚ÄúThe government must meet its responsibility,‚Äù said Huang Jing, who had two relatives on board. ‚ÄúWe need to learn what happened to our loved ones.‚Äù Additional reporting Luna Lin

column4: Why Turkey's elections could upend its politics ‚Äì the Guardian briefing
column5:
What‚Äôs happening? Turkey holds its parliamentary elections on Sunday 7 June. In Turkey‚Äôs last parliamentary elections, in 2011, 43 million of the country‚Äôs 50 million eligible voters came to the polling station. On Sunday, a similar number are predicted to turn out to elect 550 people to form the 25th parliament of Turkey. The parliament is known as the grand national assembly. Turkey is an emerging democracy and has an interesting electoral system, which will be tested during this election. The president is hoping his party will gain a ‚Äúsuper-majority‚Äù in the parliament, allowing it to make changes to the constitution without holding a referendum, and thus enabling it to introduce stronger presidential powers and change the shape of Turkish politics. What‚Äôs the background?
Turkey has a president and a prime minster. The prime minister is the leader of whichever party wins a majority in parliamentary elections, such as those being held on the weekend. The president used to be appointed by parliament, but a referendum in 2010 changed that to allow for direct presidential elections, the first of which was held last August and won by Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan. Erdoƒüan had been, until that point, prime minister of Turkey and leader of the ruling Justice and Development party (AKP). Erdoƒüan claims the current parliamentary system is ineffective and is calling for Turkey to move to a strong presidential system of government, which he believes necessary to turn Turkey into a world power. In order to strengthen presidential powers, the ruling party would need to change Turkey‚Äôs constitution, which can happen in different ways depending on how many seats the ruling party wins. A party needs to win 276 seats to form a government, but if it wins 330 seats it can call referendums on proposed constitutional changes throughout its rule. If it wins 367 seats ‚Äì a two-thirds majority ‚Äì it can change the constitution without calling a referendum, giving the ruling party an enormous amount of power. Despite a constitutional requirement that the president should remain impartial during parliamentary election campaigns, Erdoƒüan has been touring the country campaigning for the AKP, in the hope that his party will win 367 seats and make the constitutional changes to presidential powers that he would like. In the 2002 parliamentary elections, the AKP won almost 60% of the country‚Äôs seats and was just four seats shy of the 367-seat threshold that would have allowed it to make constitutional changes without referendums, despite winning only 34.3% of the vote. The reason for this discrepancy is Turkey‚Äôs electoral system, which reallocates the seats won by small parties if they do not receive a certain percentage of the national vote. Erdoƒüan is hoping this electoral quirk will work in his party‚Äôs favour again this year, though polling suggests he will be disappointed, with the AKP predicted to win the election, but not the super-majority Erdoƒüan is hoping for. How does the voting system work? Turkey is broken into regions that can elect a certain number of MPs based on population. However, Turkey employs the D‚ÄôHondt voting system, which requires a party to win a certain percentage of the national vote in order to take up any seats it has won. The D‚ÄôHondt method is used in other countries such as Denmark, Spain, Israel, Poland and Russia, but Turkey has the highest threshold of any country in the world, requiring a party to receive 10% of the national vote before any of its elected representatives can enter parliament. What this means is that if a party wins 40 seats but receives only 9.55% of the national vote, as the True Path party (DYP) did in the 2002 Turkish elections, it forfeits those 40 seats, which are then reallocated to larger parties. This system gives larger parties an obvious advantage, as they often end up with bonus seats, allowing the ruling party to increase its parliamentary majority dramatically.
To put the Turkish system in context, if a 10% threshold applied in the UK, the current parliament would be made up of Conservative, Labour and Ukip MPs only, with the SNP, Liberal Democrats, Greens and all other parties forfeiting their seats. Under the Turkish system, the Conservatives would have gained 28 bonus seats, Labour would have gained 49 and Ukip would have increased the number of seats it won from one to 10.
The 10% threshold does not apply to candidates who run as independents, and some parties use this to their advantage. For example, in the 2011 elections the Peace and Democracy party (BDP) received only 5.67% of the vote across the country, but 35 of their members were elected as independents ‚Äì and then rejoined the BDP after the election. Who are the parties?
Founded by politicians of various existing conservative parties in 2001, the Islamicconservative Justice and Development party (AKP) has ruled Turkey since it won in landslide elections in 2002. In the last national elections the party gathered 49.8% of all votes. The former foreign minister Ahmet Davutoƒülu became party leader and prime minister after Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan was elected as president of Turkey in a popular vote last year. He also stands as the party‚Äôs top candidate on 7 June, despite his often criticised and only thinly veiled support for the AKP, when as president he should be impartial. One main target for the AKP is to win a twothirds majority ‚Äì or 367 seats in parliament ‚Äì in order to change the current constitution and introduce an executive presidential system without a referendum. This seems to have become an unattainable goal. While it is pretty much certain that the AKP will emerge as the winner from the elections, recent polls suggest that they might lose up to 10 points ‚Äì which would put a referendum, for which the party needs a three fifths majority, or 330 seats, out of reach. The AKP faces a number of serious challenges in this year‚Äôs elections. Internally the party is more divided than ever before. Furthermore, an important number of AKP voters show little support for the party‚Äôs executive presidency plans. Foreign policy troubles, a stalling economy and the government‚Äôs increasing authoritarianism might drive an important number of former AKP voters to cast their ballots for one of the opposition parties.
Established by Mustafa Kemal Atat√ºrk, the founder of the Turkish Republic, in 1923, the Republican People‚Äôs party (CHP) is the oldest party and represents the main opposition. The party leader and its top candidate is Kemal Kili√ßdaroglu. In the last parliamentary elections, the CHP was able to garner 25.98% of all votes. The CHP‚Äôs election manifesto is centred on economic and labour issues: the party promises to introduce higher pensions, to tackle the current unemployment rate of 11.2%, and to improve employment among young people. It also promises to increase the minimum wage from 950 lira (¬£235) to 1,500 lira a month, whereas the work week is not to exceed 40 hours. The CHP supports the reform of the current constitution, introduced by the military junta after the 1980 military coup, but opposes the AKP‚Äôs plans of an executive presidency. The CHP is the only party that organised primaries for the candidates standing in the 7 June elections and the election manifesto was written over a period of eight months and in cooperation with unions, trade chambers and other civil society groups. While the party has certainly changed under its current leader, many voters, especially Kurds and the religiously conservative, still distrust the CHP as a dogmatic and elitist party, making an election victory highly unlikely.
The far-right Nationalist Movement party (MHP), informally known as the Grey Wolves, will likely retain its place as the third largest group in the Turkish parliament. In 2011, the party got 13.01% of all votes, and runs again under the leadership of Devlet Bah√ßeli. While the MHP supports a certain degree of Kurdish and minority rights ‚Äì the party promises in its manifesto that Cemeviler, Alevi houses of worship, will receive state support ‚Äì they are against the peace process between the government and the outlawed Kurdistan Workers‚Äô party (PKK), arguing that the Kurds need to accept the authority of the Turkish state. They promise to end all ongoing negotiations should they come to power. Therefore the MHP draws their support mainly from a non-Kurdish base and is likely to generate MPs in all major Turkish cities. The MHP is expected to improve their vote count this year but has no traditional stronghold anywhere in the country. Polls suggest they will take votes both from the ruling AKP as well as from the main opposition CHP, from Turks who do not agree with the peace negotiations or who long for a return to more Turkish-nationalist government policies. Lately both Erdoƒüan and AKP candidates have criticised Kurdish politicians and the peace process in campaign speeches, well aware that the MHP might eat into their nationalist voter base.
Often described as Turkey‚Äôs answer to Greece‚Äôs Syriza and the Spain‚Äôs Podemos, the pro-Kurdish Peoples‚Äô Democratic party (HDP) arguably has the highest stakes in this year‚Äôs national elections. In order to enter parliament after 7 June, it will have to garner at least 10% of the national vote to get over the election threshold. Should it succeed, it will secure at least 50 seats, but if it fails all of these seats will go to the other parties and might hand the AKP a huge majority. Founded in 2012 and led by chairman Selahattin Demirta≈ü and chairwoman Figen Y√ºksekdag, this democratic-socialist party will stand the first time as a party. In 2011 the HDP‚Äôs MPs stood as independent candidates since Turkey‚Äôs election threshold of 10% only applies to political parties. It is the only political party in Turkey that has a 50% women‚Äôs quota. The HDP centres its election programme on minority rights, the rights of women and LGBTs and aspires to end ethnic, religious and gender discrimination. The party promises to drive forward the Kurdish peace process and to introduce mother-tongue education. It also plans to abolish obligatory (Sunni) religious lessons in schools in favour of electives that correspond with pupils‚Äô religious beliefs. The HDP describes itself as an environmentalist and anti-capitalist party that opposes nuclear power and vows to improve workers‚Äô rights. What are the issues? An Ipsos poll conducted earlier this year found that the most significant issue for Turkish voterswas the condition of the economy, closely followed by unemployment. The AKP has campaigned strongly on these issues, claiming credit for the financial growth experienced by Turkey, which is now the world‚Äôs 17th-largest economy. The CHP, however, claims that the financial growth Turkey has experienced has led to greater inequality between rich and poor and has pledged, if elected, to tackle youth unemployment, which sits around 20%. A key issue in the campaign is rights for the 14 million Kurdish people in Turkey. The AKP originally promised they would increase rights for Kurds by establishing Kurdish-language media and university departments, but the party seems to have changedits mind on these issues, with Erdoƒüan claiming earlier in the campaign that there was ‚Äúno longer a Kurdish problem‚Äù. The AKP‚Äôs refusal to engage on Kurdish issues could see it lose support and bleed seats to the pro-Kurdish BDP. Both main parties have promised that, if elected with a sufficient majority, they will make changes to Turkey‚Äôs constitution, which was written in 1982 by the military leaders who ruled Turkey. The AKP promises a completely new constitution, focused on the individual and freedom, though opponents fear the changes are to consolidate Erdoƒüan‚Äôs power. The CHP promises to change the constitution to introduce press freedoms - Turkey is currently ranked 148th in the world for journalistic freedom by Reporters Without Borders - a reduction in the electoral threshold to 3% and greater rights for minority ethnic groups. Where can I find out more? For more on what it would mean if Erdoƒüan had his way with constitutional change, read this. Follow Constanze Letsch, the Guardian‚Äôs Istanbul correspondent, on Twitter. Polling numbers are based on an average of the last five poll results before the pre-election polling restriction, which came into effect on May 28.

column4: Cyclone hits Chinese cruise on Yangtze river: 400 missing ‚Äì live updates
column5: More than 24 hours after the ship went down we are going to bring this blog to a close. There have been no reports of survivors for several hours, and more than 400 people on board remain missing.

column4: Tahera Ahmad: 'This isn't about me and a soda can, it's about systemic injustice'
column5:
Tahera Ahmad‚Äôs allegations of discrimination on a United Airlines flight over the weekend spread like wildfire. ‚ÄúPeople know this isn‚Äôt just about a can of diet soda,‚Äù she told the Guardian after arriving back in Chicago on Monday evening. The level of interest, she said, shows ‚Äúthere‚Äôs something greater to the story that resonates with many minority groups not only in this country, but all over the world‚Äù. Ahmad, who is a chaplain at Northwestern University, has received support from countless people on every corner of the globe, which she finds to be proof that her experience isn‚Äôt uncommon. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt about me and a soda can,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúit‚Äôs about systemic injustice that is perpetuated throughout our community.‚Äù
Ahmad had been traveling to speak at a conference that was promoting dialogue between Israeli and Palestinian youth in Washington DC. While on her flight to DC on Friday, she requested an unopened can of diet soda, but was told by a flight attendant that it was against policy to give passengers unopened cans because these could be used as weapons. The flight attendant then gave the man next to her an unopened can of beer prompting Ahmad‚Äôs calls of discrimination. Another man across the aisle to say to Ahmad, ‚ÄúYou Muslim, you need to shut the fuck up. You know you would use it as a weapon, so shut the fuck up.‚Äù Ahmad recounted the details of her story on her Facebook page while in-flight, sparking global coverage, and leading to calls for a boycott of the airline. The airline has since released a statement where they call the incident a ‚Äúmisunderstanding regarding a diet soda‚Äù and do not label it as discrimination or mention the hate speech.
‚ÄúI asked United to recognize it as an act of discrimination,‚Äù Ahmad said, ‚Äúmy hope was they would say, ‚ÄòYou know what, this should have never happened and here‚Äôs what we are going to do to make sure this never happens to anyone again.‚Äô‚Äù But that doesn‚Äôt look to be happening, leading Ahmad and her supporters to continue their boycott of United. According to Ahmad ‚Äì who filed a formal complaint with United Airlines after exiting the plane with the pilot escorting her to customer service ‚Äì there will be an investigation into her allegations, but the airline has not yet announced any plans to discuss issues around potential discrimination on their flight. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre basically failing to recognize the humiliation that happened to me,‚Äù she told the Guardian. ‚ÄúSo I am going to look into options to ensure that of course this type of discrimination doesn‚Äôt happen again. Not to minorities, not to anybody else.‚Äù As for the alleged policy of unopened cans that led to this mishap: Shuttle America who was operating the United Airlines flight 3504 that Ahmad was on doesn‚Äôt actually have one that discusses cans being used as potential weapons if unopened. ‚ÄúThere is no policy difference in serving alcoholic or non-alcoholic canned beverages to passengers,‚Äù says Bob Birge, director of corporate communications at Republic Airways Holdings, which owns Shuttle America, ‚Äúno differentiation in opened or unopened cans, and no policy speculating what may or may not be done with a container.‚Äù Birge also tells the Guardian they have yet to receive a formal complaint from Ahmad on their end, unlike United Airlines, and cannot further formally address the issue with staff because like beverage services on a flight, ‚Äúthere is a process passengers are expected to follow if they have a complaint or issue they would like addressed‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe extraordinarily unprofessional and humiliating treatment of one of our community members is shockingly disappointing,‚Äù the Northwestern University president, Morton Schapiro, said in an official statement released on Monday. As Ahmad‚Äôs story continues to garner more attention, she has also begun receiving an enormous amount of hate-filled messages and phone calls. ‚ÄúSomebody called me and acted like they were a United representative,‚Äù Ahmad told the Guardian. Realizing that the caller might not be an actual employee of the airline, Ahmad asked for evidence of his employment. ‚ÄúSo he said, ‚ÄòWhat? You don‚Äôt believe me? You want to see my dick? You want to suck on my dick? I know you Muslims like that.‚Äù Ahmad‚Äôs social media account has also been continually hacked. The hate hasn‚Äôt concerned the woman considered to be a ‚Äúleading Muslim woman‚Äù by the White House. She plans to continue using the momentum of her story to elevate the conversation. In a 2013 study conducted by Pew Research Group, 45% of respondents said that Muslim Americans face ‚Äúa lot‚Äù of discrimination, and 28% said Muslims are subject to discrimination. ‚ÄúFerguson happened, ‚Äòblack lives matter‚Äô happened, and what is it these minority groups were saying? They were saying: understand my pain; understand my injustice. There is a lot of pain there,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúAnd I think that‚Äôs why this story resonates with so many people.‚Äù Ahmad is pushing for United Airlines to call this incident what many have joined her in calling it: discrimination, because ‚Äúthis is just one example of injustice that continues to happen and I cannot remain silent‚Äù.

column4: Turkey at a crossroads as Erdoƒüan bulldozes his way to lasting legacy
column5:
The rolling hills by the Black Sea, 90 minutes north-west of Istanbul, have long been prized for their dense forest and pristine lakes. Now the water buffalo that graced this landscape and supplied the city with much of its dairy produce are vanishing from what Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, the president of Turkey, has turned into one of the world‚Äôs biggest building sites. About 2.5m trees are being cleared from an area of 6,000 hectares (15,000 acres). The lorries are bumper to bumper, 24 hours a day. The locals can barely sleep, nor cross the street for the noise and the traffic. ‚ÄúThe forests are gone, the villages are gone, the livestock is gone,‚Äù says Cemalettin G√ºn, a farmer. Prominent among the tens of thousands of election posters covering Istanbul is the explanation for the construction frenzy. ‚ÄúWe are building the world‚Äôs biggest airport,‚Äù boast the posters of the governing Justice and Development party, or AKP, that Erdoƒüan created and turned into the most formidable political machine in the country‚Äôs history.
Erdoƒüan loves gargantuan, world-beating projects ‚Äì a huge election poster of himself and the prime minister, Ahmet Davutoƒülu, entered the Guinness Book of Records last week as the biggest ever, anywhere. And he seems to like felling trees. Less than a year ago in Ankara he moved into a new presidential palace of pharaonic proportions, worthy of Nicolae Ceau»ôescu or Saddam Hussein. It outstrips Washington‚Äôs White House by a factor of 30. The staff include five experts, who check Erdoƒüan‚Äôs food for poisoning or contamination. The Ankara palace also required a major exercise in forest clearance. Turkish courts, most recently last week, repeatedly ruled the building illegal. ‚ÄúLet them try to knock it down. I‚Äôm moving in anyway,‚Äù the president responded. When Turkey goes to the polls on Sunday, in what is shaping up to be an epic and fateful election, Erdoƒüan and his legacy will be the main, if not the only, issue on voters‚Äô minds. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what he calls the new Turkey,‚Äù says Cengiz √áandar, a leading political analyst. ‚ÄúThis is about his legacy and he‚Äôs very ambitious. He needs a strong presidency. He‚Äôs also very uneasy about corruption allegations and needs safeguards. Some fear it might be Turkey‚Äôs last election ‚Äì before a dictatorship.‚Äù
The reason for such worries is that Erdoƒüan has turned the ballot into a kind of referendum on his one-man drive to rewrite the country‚Äôs constitution, abolish parliamentarianism and install a powerful new executive presidency occupied by himself. Paradoxically, he is not even running for election. As head of state since last August, following a three-term, 12-year premiership, he is supposed to be non-partisan, above the political fray. Instead he is pounding the country, speaking himself hoarse. During a recent campaign week, he notched up 44 hours on loyalist national television. ‚ÄúErdoƒüan has proven since 1994 ‚Äì when he was mayor of Istanbul ‚Äì that he can reach any goal he sets himself,‚Äù says Metin Y√ºksel, the deputy editor of Sabah, a daily newspaper and AKP mouthpiece. ‚ÄúNo opposition has been able to stop him. Turkish voters like a leader.‚Äù The main question in the election is whether Turkish voters will opt not so much to stop Erdoƒüan as to clip his wings and deny him, for now, his big plans for systemic change, entrenching his own power. Since his 2002 landslide thrust Turkey into a new era that started with great promise and in recent years, by general consensus, has degenerated into whimsy and authoritarianism, Erdoƒüan has led the AKP to three election victories, increasing its vote every time and securing comfortable absolute majorities in the 550-seat parliament in Ankara.
Constitutional grapple To change the system, the AKP needs a two-thirds, or 367-seat, majority enabling it to rewrite the constitution. Failing that ‚Äì and it looks highly improbable ‚Äì it needs a three-fifths, or 330-seat, majority, which would allow it to call a plebiscite on constitutional revision. That, too, is unlikely, according to the opinion polls. But there is general agreement that the party is the slickest, most organised political machine Turkey has ever seen. All bets are off. The AKP owns the bureaucracy, controls the media, has returned the army to barracks and marginalised the military, traditional arbiters of Turkish politics. Erdoƒüan used his final term as prime minister to curb the independence of the key institutions of state ‚Äì the constitutional court, the parliament, the central bank, the prosecution and judiciary services.
Independent media are cowed. Social media are regularly threatened. Schoolchildren are prosecuted for making fun of a president who appears increasingly thin-skinned. He remains the undisputed party leader and is said to have vetted for loyalty to him the AKP‚Äôs lists of candidates for seats next Sunday. In discussions on the election campaign, the name of Davutoƒülu, who is party president, hardly crops up, while talk of Erdoƒüan is ubiquitous. ‚ÄúThis is a presidential system already. It‚Äôs just not legal,‚Äù says √áandar. ‚ÄúThe question is whether he can legalise it and legitimise it.‚Äù There are ample indications that he may fail. In Istanbul‚Äôs wondrous Grand Bazaar, the traders are often seen as representing Erdoƒüan‚Äôs core constituency ‚Äì conservative, religious small business owners. To ask a few questions about the election is to press the button on a vigorous debate revealing sophisticated and nuanced views on what is at stake. Firat Inci, a 32-year-old bazaar restaurateur originally from the southern town of Siirt, has always voted for the AKP and for Erdoƒüan. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a fantastic person. You need to understand his background and what he has achieved. We used to have military coups every 10 years and Erdoƒüan pushed back 70 years of military domination.‚Äù
But, for the first time since he has been able to vote, Inci this time is opting for the opposition HDP, or People‚Äôs Democratic party, a new grouping of leftists and liberals mainly representing the large Kurdish minority that has always struggled to be represented in parliament. ‚ÄúErdoƒüan‚Äôs attitude and behaviour make me uncomfortable,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHe got drunk on power. And a presidential system won‚Äôt be good for Turkey.‚Äù Sezgin Tanrikulu, a human rights lawyer and an MP for the main opposition CHP, or Republican People‚Äôs party, echoes the allegations of presidential megalomania. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre so glued to power that they could try anything to keep it. It‚Äôs a fixation. But they‚Äôre on the defensive.‚Äù To judge by his non-stop speechifying, Erdoƒüan views politics as a majoritarian blood sport in which the winner takes all, loyalty is rewarded and opposition denounced as treachery. It is a highly polarising approach, especially for a head of state who is supposed to preach inclusiveness.
Kadir Karapinar, who co-owns a small shoemaking business in Istanbul‚Äôs bustling Beyoƒülu district, criticises the reluctance to compromise. ‚ÄúIn Turkey, supporting a political party has become like supporting a football team. You can be either with one party or against them, but none really wants to be a party for everyone in Turkey.‚Äù The AKP and Erdoƒüan, he adds, use very divisive language to rally their base. ‚ÄúThey still present themselves as victims. They say that anyone who votes against them wants to return to the Turkey of 15 years ago. But I have always defended the right of women to wear a headscarf, the right to practise one‚Äôs religion freely. If anyone is being victimised in Turkey today, it is those that criticise Erdoƒüan.‚Äù
After years of such aggressive rhetoric from Erdoƒüan, particularly following the protests that erupted in central Istanbul two years ago and spread like wildfire around the country, the president‚Äôs us-and-them narrative may be taking its toll. If half the country still adores him, the other half now seems to revile him. This is one reason that Nedim ≈ûener, an investigative journalist jailed for a year in 2011 on terrorism charges that were then dropped, believes that Erdoƒüan‚Äôs presidential campaign will flop. ‚ÄúMaybe Erdoƒüan wants this, but he can also see that it‚Äôs not possible. He is just using it to rally his support. It is too dangerous, there is a lot of tension, there could be clashes if you try to change the system. All opposition groups oppose constitutional change because it‚Äôs too important and it‚Äôs about Erdoƒüan and one-man rule. It‚Äôs become a symbol, like the palace in Ankara. The palace has become this hate object.‚Äù
A neo-classical presidency? Even within the AKP, it is hard to discern support for an executive presidency. Senior figures are reluctant to challenge Erdoƒüan directly but have meekly voiced their reservations. A trio of senior critics ‚Äì Erdoƒüan‚Äôs predecessor as president, a deputy prime minister, and the economics minister ‚Äì are not running for parliamentary seats, however, and have less to lose by speaking out. There is no doubt that the AKP will win the election for a fourth consecutive term. The question concerns the margin of victory, with some polls putting the party at 41-45% of the vote. That would leave Erdoƒüan sulking in his vast palace and be seen as a defeat. ‚ÄúThere is governing fatigue within and with the AK party,‚Äù says ≈ûener. But the key to the all-important parliamentary arithmetic is the new and unknown element of the HDP, mainly representing the Kurds but also bringing together younger civil libertarians born of the mass protests against Erdoƒüan‚Äôs overweening control in 2013. The HDP‚Äôs leader, Selahattin Demirta≈ü ‚Äì young, telegenic, and persuasive ‚Äì has been the surprise star of the campaign. But Turkey has one of the highest thresholds in the world for entering parliament. A party must get 10% of the vote nationally to qualify for seats. The HDP can win roundly in the Kurdish heartlands of the south-east and still fail to muster the national 10%. There are up to 70 seats at stake. Most of them will go to the AKP if the HDP fails to get in in Ankara. ‚ÄúThe critical point is the HDP,‚Äù says ≈ûener.
Karapinar is thinking about voting for the HDP, which is contesting its first election. ‚ÄúDemirtas is a very good politician, and I like the things he says. But what about the connections of his party? It is difficult for me and many Turks to support such a thing.‚Äù This is a reference to the HDP‚Äôs links with the PKK, the Kurdish guerrillas at war with the Turkish state for most of the past 30 years. Inci in the Grand Bazaar gives the HDP the benefit of the doubt over the PKK and will vote for the new party, which in the opinion polls is hovering around the 10% mark.
‚ÄúWe fully expect that there will be attempts at cheating,‚Äù said Ay≈üe Erdem, the HDP‚Äôs co-leader in Istanbul and an ethnic Turk. ‚ÄúThe AKP has every reason to try and keep us under the threshold. But we are prepared. There will be someone with a smartphone at every ballot box.‚Äù If the HDP scrapes in, the ruling party‚Äôs majority could be imperilled and the presidential ambitions wrecked. But if the AKP gains the seats from an HDP failure, Erdoƒüan‚Äôs plans will be boosted. He has managed the referendum issue before. In his final term as prime minister, he pushed through and won a popular vote to make the president directly elected by the people. He then stood and won by more than 50%.
His supporters say there is no point in having a directly elected president unless the office is vested with executive powers. Erdoƒüan and the ruling party are playing the ethnic card, fanning fear among Turks that a pro-Kurdish party in parliament will spell the end of democracy, while also jeopardising the ongoing peace process between the Turkish government and the PKK. ‚ÄúWe want to tell those who vote for the HDP: if the HDP gets over the threshold, if the ruling AK party loses power, there will be no peace process left,‚Äù the deputy prime minister, Yal√ßin Akdoƒüan, said. ‚ÄúThis plan only aims to bring chaos to Turkey.‚Äù In arguing for the constitutional changes, Erdoƒüan commonly invokes the US and French systems as inspiration. √áandar says this is misplaced. ‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt be French or American, more like South American.‚Äù Erdem says: ‚ÄúWe need to get the 70 MPs. That‚Äôs the only thing that will stop Erdoƒüan changing the constitution on his own. People are aware of that. This is about the democratisation of Turkey. It‚Äôs not about the system; it‚Äôs about Erdoƒüan. The presidential system would mean dictatorship.‚Äù

column4: Danish cowboy bares all in bid to be prime minister
column5:
Conversations tail off mid-sentence; students stop to take selfies and parents shield young children‚Äôs eyes. The cause of their embarrassment: giant posters of a man wearing nothing but a cowboy hat, a gun holster and a knowing smile. This is John Erik Wagner, and he wants to be Denmark‚Äôs next prime minister. It may not be a conventional political billboard but, in this time of frenetic campaigning before the Danish general election this month, every available tree or lamppost is plastered with images of politicians and wannabes, and a relatively unknown candidate needs to work hard to make an impression.
For Wagner, a 51-year-old Copenhagener, the way to do that was to bare all. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been trying to get elected for 10 years now, and this is my third election, so I thought I‚Äôd try something different,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúOther candidates‚Äô posters are boring ‚Äì just like passport photos ‚Äì so I wanted mine to surprise people.‚Äù He adds: ‚ÄúIt helps to look good if you want to be in government and people say I have a nice body, so I thought, ‚ÄòThis is me, here I am.‚Äô I wanted to get my name out there.‚Äù But it‚Äôs not just his name that‚Äôs out there. Wagner‚Äôs so-called ‚Äúpenis posters‚Äù are attracting attention from all over the world. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had interest from China, Italy and Spain so far as well as a lot of people in Denmark. People seem to like them ‚Äì and most Danes are okay with nudity,‚Äù he says.
On 18 June, when voters decide the makeup of the country‚Äôs 179-strong parliament, prime minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt of the ‚Äúred block‚Äù centre-left Social Democrats will go head to head with former premier and opposition leader Lars L√∏kke Rasmussen of the ‚Äúblue block‚Äù centre-right party, Venstre. The resulting government is likely to be a coalition, with the anti-immigration Danish People‚Äôs party forecast to gain more seats than in previous elections.
But what does Wagner stand for, other than Stetsons and unabashed nudity? Key policies include making trips to the dentist free (Danes currently pay around 300 DKK ‚Äì about ¬£30 per visit) and scrapping unemployment benefit by introducing a basic income and making everyone work six months on and six months off. ‚ÄúI know what it is like to be out of work,‚Äù he says, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a clothes designer by trade but I don‚Äôt have any work right now. So I want a job. I want to go into government to get work. And help other people who don‚Äôt have work.‚Äù Anyone interested in finding out more about Wagner‚Äôs policies can visit his Facebook page (‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have time for a website‚Äù) to read his manifesto and catch a glimpse of the man behind the oiled torso. Recent posts include Grace Jones‚Äôs Slave to the Rhythm video; pictures of Wagner, clad in double denim, petting a horse, as well as selfies with his Chinese crested powderpuff, Dolly. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my dog, named after Dolly Parton,‚Äù he says.
