‚ÄúI really like country music and westerns ‚Äì I‚Äôm inspired by the Burt Reynolds/Clint Eastwood cowboy look, like in my poster. It‚Äôs my style. And I have many women ‚Äì and some men ‚Äì getting in touch saying they like it, and me!‚Äù Wagner is confident about his chances in the election. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs going to be a more successful year for me,‚Äù he says. But if he doesn‚Äôt get elected this year, he‚Äôs got a plan B: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do one more run, but that will be my last. I‚Äôve worked as a municipal garbage man before. So if it doesn‚Äôt work out, I might consider going back to that.‚Äù ‚Ä¢ This article was amended on 3 June 2015 to remove a reference to a red block and blue block coalition.

column4: Was this indigenous leader killed because he fought to save Ecuador's land?
column5:
Dark clouds loom over the Tundayme bus station where Jos√© Isidro Tendetza Ant√∫n said goodbye to his family for the last time. The moody skies above the Cordillera del Condor would have been a familiar sight to the indigenous leader as he set out on 28 November to join a protest meeting against a huge Chinese-backed mine being carved out of his ancestral homeland. He never arrived. Four days later, his son Jorge found Tendetza‚Äôs body in an unmarked grave, showing signs of torture and strangulation. Six months on, that murder continues to reverberate among the residents of this jungle mountain range straddling Ecuador‚Äôs Amazon frontier with northern Peru.
Tendetza was a prominent critic of President Rafael Correa‚Äôs government, which he accused of making a U-turn on its pledge to respect nature and indigenous lands. In 2008, Ecuador became the first country in the world to legally recognise the rights of nature in its constitution, but it has since approved a series of mega-projects, including large-scale mines and hydroelectric dams ‚Äì mostly in Chinese hands. One of seven siblings, Jos√© Tendetza grew up in the Cordillera del Condor, learning to farm, hunt and fish just as his forefathers had. This biodiverse cloud forest is the home of the Shuar, Ecuador‚Äôs second-largest indigenous group who fought both the Incas and the Spanish conquistadors, but are now struggling to cope with the arrival of El Mirador ‚Äì a $1.4bn gold and copper mine. Locals say the community has experienced a surge of conflict since work began at El Mirador, which has been owned by Chinese company EcuaCorriente SA ‚Äì a subsidiary of CRCC-Tongguan Investment ‚Äì since it was bought from a Canadian firm in 2010. Shuar families have already been displaced by the project, which if completed will result in the destruction of 450,000 hectares of cloud forest. Tendetza‚Äôs family, supporters and lawyers suspect that his opposition to the mine led to his death ‚Äì the third violent death of a Shuar leader in six years. (Freddy Taish was shot during a military operation against illegal mining in 2013 and Bosco Wisum died from gunshot wounds in clashes with police in 2009.) Tensions are still high. On a recent visit to the Shuar territory, the Guardian was followed and filmed by men who locals identified as employees of the mine‚Äôs security detail. Ecuador‚Äôs ambassador to the UK, Juan Falconi Puig, said the government had offered a $100,000 (¬£66,000) reward to anyone who could provide accurate information about the crime. In a letter to the Guardian, he said the investigation into Jos√© Tendetza‚Äôs death would be independently overseen by the Shuar federation. Then, on 23 May Ecuador‚Äôs interior minister, Jos√© Serrano Salgado, announced on Twitter that police had arrested two men on suspicion of Tendetza‚Äôs murder. The two suspects are both Shuar men employed as labourers by EcuaCorriente, and according to Serrano, one was found in possession of Tendetza‚Äôs mobile phone. In another tweet the minister praised the police and attorney general‚Äôs office and said they would pursue the ‚Äúintellectual authors‚Äù of the crime. The two men, however, have not been charged with any crimes, after a judge ordered their release for procedural reasons following a preliminary hearing. Bruno Segovia, a lawyer representing the Tendetza family, says they remain sceptical. ‚ÄúThe family knows the accused men and say they have never had any problems with them,‚Äù he told the Guardian. Tendetza‚Äôs relatives say they have long lost faith in the authorities. Just a week after the murder, helicopter-borne police armed with automatic weapons raided Tendetza‚Äôs family‚Äôs home in Yanua hamlet. The raid was allegedly ordered by the local prosecutor with the purported aim of finding evidence and ‚Äúweapons‚Äù which would explain his death, according to the US-based NGO Amazon Watch, which, along with 13 other non-governmental organisations, wrote a letter calling for transparency in the state‚Äôs investigation into the murder. ‚ÄúMy brother was a leader who defended our rights, our rivers, the rights of nature as the government had set out but we don‚Äôt believe the government any more,‚Äù said Tendetza‚Äôs brother Carlos, as seasonal rain drummed on the corrugated iron roof of the family home. With quick, dark eyes framed in an angular face atop a wiry frame, Carlos resembles his late brother, a man who friends and family describe as a charismatic and natural leader.
At the time of his death, Tendetza, 47, was organising local indigenous federations which were protesting against the contamination of local rivers by mining sediments and the eviction of local people, both Shuar and colonos ‚Äì a term used for mixed-race Ecuadorian settlers. He had filed a complaint against El Mirador mine with the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. His supporters say he had been the subject of a campaign of harassment, and had received a string of threats against his life and home. In 2012 his house and crops were set on fire by a group of men his family claim were EcuaCorriente employees. The last time Tendetza‚Äôs family saw him, he was getting on the bus to a small town called Bomboisa, on his way to meet his uncle, Domingo Ankuash, and other Shuar leaders. The family say they planned to discuss how they would report the harassment they faced to the UN climate change summit in Lima the following month. He never arrived. Four days later, his son Jorge, alerted by a tipoff, travelled to the morgue in the town of Yantzaza, where he discovered that his father‚Äôs corpse had been pulled from the Zamora river by mine workers. An autopsy had been carried out, and Tendetza was buried in a grave marked ‚Äúno name‚Äù. At the request of his family, the body was exhumed and a second autopsy was carried out. While the first autopsy concluded the cause of death was drowning, the second determined that Tendetza had been asphyxiated. Segovia, the family‚Äôs lawyer, said witnesses had said his hands had been bound to the waist and the body had shown cuts and bruises. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs curious that a body is found in the river and without any investigation, without identifying the body, without letting the family know so they could investigate what happened, they bury it as ‚ÄòNN‚Äô ‚Äì no name,‚Äù said Segovia. Tendetza‚Äôs brothers blame his death on his opposition to EcuaCorriente, the company he worked for as a temporary labourer until 2006 when he witnessed a family‚Äôs home being burned down to allegedly drive them off land ceded to the company. From then on, he actively opposed the company‚Äôs plans to build El Mirador.
In a statement to the Guardian, a spokesman for EcuaCorriente said: ‚ÄúWe regret that insinuations have been gathered which constitute an affront to the company‚Äôs reputation and law-abiding behaviour. We have demonstrated, and we will continue to do so, total respect and regard for people and cultures, and that is reciprocated by the communities which surround us, who as proof, participate and mostly collaborate in the decent and respectful work of our company. ‚ÄúThe loss of a human life causes consternation, even more so when some of Mr Tendetza‚Äôs relatives are workers with the company, to whom appropriate condolences were paid at his death. ‚ÄúWe fully trust in the Ecuadorian state‚Äôs ongoing investigations through the ministry of the interior and the police; whose conclusions we expect to expose those responsible for such a deplorable incident.‚Äù The impact of El Mirador is clearly visible as soon as you enter the Shuar‚Äôs ancestral lands where fields and woodland are now dotted with orange signs marked ‚Äúprivate property‚Äù demarcating the areas bought by the Chinese company. As we cross a swollen river that has washed part of the road away, a sign in Spanish and Mandarin on a clapboard house warns: ‚ÄúThe person or company which enters or does damage to this property will be criminally prosecuted or subjected to indigenous justice.‚Äù We are followed. A motorcyclist in a balaclava films our movements on a red digital camera then speeds away but continues to trail us. Security guards at checkpoints also film us, surreptitiously at first, then openly when they realise they have been spotted. The mist rolls back and a red scar emerges on an emerald hillside. It‚Äôs several kilometres away but heavy diggers can be seen on the edge of the site. El Mirador‚Äôs first opencast mine will be 1.5km across and 650m deep. To extract some 2m tonnes of copper, about 145m tonnes of earth and rocks will be excavated, according to the company‚Äôs 2010 environmental impact assessment report, producing hundreds of millions of tonnes of acidic tailings during its lifespan. Environmentalists are horrified.
‚ÄúA mine like this shouldn‚Äôt have been developed in an area like this. There‚Äôs too much at stake,‚Äù said Richard Kamp, the director of E-Tech International, a US-based engineering consultancy which has studied the potential environmental impacts of El Mirador since 2011. His principal concern is the company‚Äôs plan to store millions of tonnes of toxic mining waste in an enormous tailings pond just half a mile from the Quimi river. The river flows into the Zamora river, which in turn supplies the Santiago river which winds south into Peru connecting with the Mara√±√≥n, a major tributary in the Amazon watershed. Kamp cites the Mount Polley mine spill in British Columbia, Canada, in August 2014 as a worrying precedent. A dam at a waste pond burst releasing 4.5m cubic metres of toxic slurry into virtually untouched forest, affecting an area mostly populated by First Nation peoples. Historic decision According to lawyer Mario Melo ‚Äì who helped Tendetza bring his case against El Mirador at the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights ‚Äì Ecuador failed to seek prior, informed consent from the Shuar to develop El Mirador mine on their land. In failing to do so, the government reneged on its commitment to the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, said Melo, who last year won a landmark ruling obliging the country to apologise to the Sarayaku people for drilling for oil in their territory without their consent. Although he was largely responsible for Ecuador‚Äôs historic decision to recognise the rights of nature, President Correa has said the 2008 constitution does not prohibit the country from using its non-renewable resources. Correa ‚Äì who has warned against ‚Äúinfantile environmentalism‚Äù ‚Äì argues that Ecuador‚Äôs natural riches offer the best chance for ‚Äúsovereign development‚Äù to improve education, healthcare and standards of living. But his political opponents accuse the president of handing out a string of oil, hydroelectric and mining concessions in an effort to secure Chinese funds. The map of government land concessions is a patchwork of geometric boxes overlaying southern Ecuador‚Äôs mountains and rivers.
Any hope of respecting the rights of nature was ‚Äútotally erased when the government began to give away concessions like flyers‚Äù, said Carlos P√©rez, the flamboyant leader of the Ecuador‚Äôs Kichwa Confederation, which represents the country‚Äôs largest indigenous group. P√©rez ‚Äì a former ally turned opponent of President Correa, who has been jailed three times during the current administration ‚Äì said most of the concessions had gone to Chinese companies.Ecuador started borrowing from Beijing in 2008 when it defaulted on $3.2bn of foreign debt, and the country‚Äôs dependence on Chinese credit shows no signs of abating. Analysts say the country has racked up more than $15bn of Chinese debt, but the terms of the loans lack transparency and may include a ‚Äúsovereignty immunity waiver‚Äù that would allow China to seize Ecuadorian assets if the country fails to repay them. The government says the investment has helped improve public services across the country. For the Shuar, however, the opening up of indigenous territory to foreign resource extractors has so far brought misery. Tendetza‚Äôs family say it has rained solidly and heavily since Jos√© was killed. It is the wettest rainy season they can remember. ‚ÄúWe, the Shuar, are the owners of all this, the forest, the waterfalls, the animals, the rivers,‚Äù said Carlos Tendetza with a broad sweep of his hand encompassing the horizon and beyond. ‚ÄúBut the company is destroying it and we‚Äôve got nothing but abuse in return.‚Äù The once-warlike tribe resisted the Spanish for centuries and was notorious for the practice of shrinking heads. Much has changed, but the continued advance of the mine and the perceived lack of justice over his brother‚Äôs death has made the Tendetza consider taking matters into their own hands. ‚ÄúWe are civilised now,‚Äù he added, as if giving voice to an internal debate. ‚ÄúBut we are willing to fight to the death to get our own back.‚Äù

column4: Australian law groups urge Coalition to pressure Nauru over growing legal crisis
column5: Australia‚Äôs peak legal bodies have called on the federal government to intervene in the growing legal crisis on Nauru after a senior Australian lawyer scheduled to appear for asylum seekers on the island was denied a visa. Jay Williams, a barrister, was denied a visa by the Nauru government shortly before he was scheduled to appear in two cases on the island, one of which could see the president, Baron Waqa, and the justice minister, David Adeang, face contempt of court charges. The second case relates to the lawfulness of the detention of more than 1,000 asylum seekers at the Australian-run detention centre on the island. The visa decision is being challenged in a fresh judicial review, where it is being argued that the Nauruan justice secretary ‚Äúexercised power for an improper purpose‚Äù in an attempt to ‚Äúpervert the course of justice‚Äù. The Australian Bar Association president, Fiona McLeod, said the asylum seekers held in detention were still in Australia‚Äôs care, and should be afforded proper legal representation. ‚ÄúThese recent developments are most concerning,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey indicate a continued pattern by the Nauru government of failing to observe the rule of law, which commenced with the sacking of magistrate Peter Law and their failure to renew the visa of the chief justice, Geoffrey Eames, over a year ago. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs vital that clients, including those placed in the care of the Australian government, have access to legal representation, and the Australian Bar Association would urge the Australian government to intervene to ensure that this occurs.‚Äù The president of the Australian section of the international commission of jurists, John Boyd, also called on the government to place pressure on Nauru to allow Williams to enter the country. ‚ÄúThe Australian government should bring pressure to bear to allow a visa to be granted for Mr Williams to have access to the court,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAustralia has a duty of care in respect of these people and neither the Australian government nor the Nauruan government should be scared of the rule of law.‚Äù Major concerns about the state of democracy on Nauru continued to be raised by opposition MPs and human rights groups. Recently the government also blocked access to Facebook and other websites, and deported the general manager of telecommunications provider Digicell. The Nauru government has continued to object to concerns about the island, and has rejected criticism of the nation.

column4: Philippines police to mount strong case against accused Australian paedophile
column5: A detective with the bureau of investigation in the Philippines says prosecutors have a ‚Äúvery strong case‚Äù against Melbourne man Peter Scully, who was arrested in March for allegedly operating a global paedophile ring from Mindanao. Scully will face court in the Philippines on Tuesday to enter a plea in one of two court cases against him, having been charged with the murder of a 12-year-old girl, human trafficking and child sexual abuse offences. Scully, 51, is accused of sexually abusing at least eight girls over a three-year period, with police alleging he streamed their torture to paying customers using the internet. His victims ranged from 18 months to 13 years old, police allege. Speaking to Guardian Australia from the Philippines on Tuesday, a senior investigator on the case, Roy Zu√±iga, said it had been a difficult investigation. ‚ÄúWe began investigating Scully in January, after the investigation of serious child abuse videos commenced and those videos showed a male, Caucasian perpetrator,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe had so few leads to begin with, and working with our foreign law enforcement counterparts we were able to identify the man. From that case, we found other cases of child abuse involving him. ‚ÄúWe definitely now have a very strong case against Mr Scully.‚Äù The investigation has also involved Dutch and Australian authorities. Zu√±iga said police would be pursuing the maximum penalty of life imprisonment for Scully, who has been living in the Philippines since 2011. Customers allegedly paid Scully up to $10,000 to view the child exploitation and abuse material, police say. Another investigator on the case, Angelito Magno, told the ABC that one video involved an 18-month-old baby girl being hanged upside down while being tortured. ‚ÄúShe was crying all the time,‚Äù he told the ABC. Four of Scully‚Äôs alleged victims have provided statements to police. According to statistics from the United Nations and the FBI in the US, there are about 750,000 child sex predators online at any one time. The Australian federal police described the sexual exploitation of children online and through child sex tourism as ‚Äúone of the most serious emerging transnational crime threats in the Asia-Pacific region‚Äù.

column4: South China Sea: Australia won't rule out expanded surveillance flights
column5: The Australian government has not ruled out expanding its existing program of surveillance flights over the South China Sea amid regional tensions over China‚Äôs land reclamation activities in disputed territory. The office of the defence minister, Kevin Andrews, said Australia would ‚Äúcontinue to transit the South China Sea‚Äù but emphasised that such patrols were not a new phenomenon and that the government had not had any formal discussions with its close ally, the US. The government moved to clarify its position after a report in the Australian newspaper on Tuesday said Canberra was actively considering sending a P-3 surveillance aircraft within 12 nautical miles of artificial islands built by China, the standard extent of territorial seas from a coastline. Australian government lawyers believed such a flight would comply with international law, the report said, ‚Äúbecause only land features above high tide can generate territorial rights‚Äù. The opposition‚Äôs defence spokesman, Stephen Conroy, supported a potential ‚Äúfreedom of navigation‚Äù exercise within 12 nautical miles of the artificial islands, saying the structures were not internationally recognised. ‚ÄúWe can do that. International law is on our side,‚Äù Conroy said. A spokeswoman for Andrews issued a statement on Tuesday saying it was in the interest of all countries ‚Äúto ensure free and unencumbered transit through international waters, including those in the South China Sea‚Äù. ‚ÄúAustralia will continue to transit the South China Sea, including conducting maritime surveillance missions consistent with our rights under international law, as it has been doing for more than three decades now,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt is well known by all countries in the region that Australia has been patrolling the South China Sea from the air for over 30 years as part of ‚Äòoperation gateway‚Äô. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been doing it on an ongoing basis since 1980 and will continue to in the future as part of Australia‚Äôs enduring contribution to the preservation of regional security and stability in south-east Asia.‚Äù China objected to recent US military surveillance missions over the disputed region, but a Pentagon spokesman suggested that US patrols within 12 nautical miles of the artificial islands ‚Äúwould be the next step‚Äù. Andrews‚Äô spokeswoman said the Australian government had ‚Äúnot had formal talks with the United States on ‚Äòfreedom of navigation‚Äô missions in the South China Sea‚Äù. The minister had met the US defence secretary, Ash Carter, twice but ‚Äúthe expansion of current operations or new missions in the South China Sea was not discussed‚Äù, she said. Australia‚Äôs deputy opposition leader, Tanya Plibersek, who previously warned against language that would escalate tensions, said her party had sought briefings from the government on the South China Sea issue. Plibersek, Labor‚Äôs foreign affairs spokeswoman, avoided expressing a view on the potential surveillance missions but said the territorial disputes were ‚Äúplainly making some of China‚Äôs neighbours anxious‚Äù. ‚ÄúOf course, we take no position on the territorial disputes in question, but we do say that it is important to have freedom of navigation and freedom of flight through an area that is an extremely busy trading route, an area that Australian vessels have been travelling through for many years,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe urge the parties, of course, to use international laws and norms to settle any disagreements about sovereignty and, of course, it is important that this area remains open to trading.‚Äù But Conroy, Labor‚Äôs defence spokesman and deputy leader in the Senate, was prepared to venture an opinion on the maritime patrols. He backed the legitimacy of Australia‚Äôs program to sail and fly through the region. ‚ÄúThis is nothing new. Let‚Äôs be clear. Australia will continue to travel through internationally recognised waters and we call on all countries that have been constructing artificial islands and reclaiming land to settle this matter through the normal international processes,‚Äù Conroy said. Asked about potential travel within 12 nautical miles of the structures, Conroy said: ‚ÄúIn international law there is no claim because these are recognised under the international law of the sea as international waters and we can safely and legitimately enter these waters at any stage.‚Äù Peter Jennings, the executive director of the Australian Strategic Policy Institute, also backed further ‚Äúfreedom of navigation‚Äù missions. Jennings said such missions were likely to trigger criticism from the Chinese government, but he argued the bigger risk was not to take such action. ‚ÄúFailing to do so makes a de facto concession to China‚Äôs claim for treating the area for internal sovereign control,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat does put the freedom of navigation and air space access at risk.‚Äù But Hugh White, the professor of strategic studies at the Australian National University, said he would not be surprised if the government decided to back away from the proposal, which he described as risky. White told the ABC: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a smart idea to try standing up and bringing on a confrontation where the international law is not plainly on your side, and international law is not plainly on anyone‚Äôs side on this issue. It‚Äôs a very muddy question.‚Äù He questioned the motivations of the US: ‚ÄúI think for the US certainly the concern about these artificial islands is really just a kind of pretext to draw what one might call a red line around China‚Äôs expanding regional power and influence.‚Äù The debate followed comments from the secretary of the Australian Department of Defence, Dennis Richardson, that China‚Äôs land reclamation activity in the South China Sea ‚Äúhad been at a pace and scale over the last two years beyond anything we have previously seen‚Äù. This raised legitimate questions about its purpose, Richardson told a Senate estimates committee hearing on Monday. Asked whether any exercises were planned to test the Chinese government‚Äôs territorial claims, Richardson said ‚Äúno decisions have been taken at this point‚Äù. The acting chief of the Australian defence force, vice admiral Ray Griggs, told the same hearing that HMAS Perth was in the western part of the South China Sea. Andrews told a security summit in Singapore on Sunday that Australia was concerned about ‚Äúthe prospect of militarisation of artificial structures‚Äù and countries should ‚Äúagree as soon as possible‚Äù on a code of conduct for the area.

column4: Iranians warn that distrust could replace sanctions as obstacle to business
column5:
With relatives and friends returning to Tehran in search of opportunities ahead of the expected lifting of economic sanctions, Haj Hossein holds court at his Grand Bazaar shop and doles out business advice. He warns his cousins, nephews and old acquaintances returning from abroad about corrupt judges and scheming entrepreneurs. ‚ÄúI tell them not to believe and not to trust anyone,‚Äù stresses the 70-year-old merchant, who primarily sells rugs but trades anything that comes his way. ‚ÄúThey think they are still in Europe or America, but this is a different country, with very different rules.‚Äù
Decades of economic isolation have made Iran‚Äôs business scene difficult to navigate for outsiders accustomed to playing by globally accepted principles. Attempts to shift state-owned property to private hands have led to the creation of a complex conglomerates with shadowy ownership structures. The corrupt legal system also favors the well-connected, giving rise to an environment of distrust. ‚ÄúYou have to bribe,‚Äù says Haj Hossein, ‚Äúbut also make sure you are paying the bribe to someone who can actually help you.‚Äù The number of breach-of-contract cases has skyrocketed since the start of nuclear negotiations in 2013, when foreign investors began to reset their sights on the Iranian economy, says Alireza Darbandi, a corporate lawyer who handles dozens of cases in Tehran as well as provincial courts. ‚ÄúMany Iranians will return to the country to invest, but will be the victims of schemers and charlatans,‚Äù Darbandi predicts. Alireza Keyvani, an engineer and entrepreneur, moved back to Iran from North America last year to start an acquisitions company focused on the burgeoning hi-tech scene. ‚ÄúI thought I would be in everything from robotics to medical equipment,‚Äù he says. After signing several contracts laying out his business plan, Keyvani says that he learned that one of the partners had cut his company out of the deal and was receiving a commission directly from the client. Keyvani sought legal action, but his lawyer warned him against taking the case further. Keyvani‚Äôs former business partner would likely try to bribe the judge or produce forged documents, the lawyer argued. ‚ÄúI had to wake up to see Iran as it really is,‚Äù Keyvani recalls. The absence of rule of law has allowed impostors to thrive. Darbandi says most of his cases involve ‚Äúsomeone pretending to be an intelligence officer or a Revolutionary Guard Corps commander‚Äù, who intimidates and manipulates the investor. Later, it is difficult to prove that the perpetrator had used false identity. While he advises potential investors to protect themselves by seeking legal advice, Darbandi says he ‚Äúcannot guarantee a peaceful and productive business experience‚Äù in Iran. The atmosphere of distrust has raised the cost of financial transactions, most of which only take place after extensive negotiations and legal guarantees, says Ahmadreza Mohammadi, a business analyst in Tehran. Even these do not guarantee a desirable outcome, however. Mohammadi says he witnessed many cases in which ‚Äúboth sides find a way to create difficulty‚Äù.
As foreign investors await Iran‚Äôs economic opening pending the nuclear deal, businessmen such as Keyvani are discovering that the country lacks the necessary legal system to protect the interests of private investors. The Islamic republic ranks 130th on the 2015 Ease of Doing Business index (pdf) of 189 global economies, below Mozambique, Pakistan and Lesotho. Iran‚Äôs standing in the index improved by two points since 2014, but remains among the region‚Äôs lowest. GCC countries remain the primary destination for many potential investors. ‚ÄúIf the business practices in Iran are unethical, it is partially because of the sanctions, which provided great opportunities for corruption and created monopolies,‚Äù says Keyvani. ‚ÄúTo have global business ethics, one has to be part of the global community.‚Äù

column4: Nauru blocks visa of Australian barrister for deportee and asylum seekers
column5: The Nauruan government has blocked a visa application from an Australian barrister involved in a high-stakes case that could see the Nauruan president Baron Waqa and justice minister David Adeang face contempt of court charges. Australian barrister Jay Williams was seeking to appear in court to represent Rod Henshaw, an Australian who lived on Nauru and who was deported in controversial circumstances by the Nauruan government. He also represents more than 1,000 asylum seekers on the island in an ongoing legal case surrounding their detention in the Australian centre on the island. The Nauruan government is now seeking to strike out Henshaw‚Äôs claim as well as those on behalf of the asylum seekers who alleged their human rights are being violated in the detention centre. In an email from the Nauru immigration office, Williams‚Äôs application for a business visa is refused with only the words ‚ÄúThis is denied‚Äù provided to explain the decision. The visa refusal is now facing an appeal in the Nauruan district court, while the government is continuing with its own motion to strike out both major court cases. The application for judicial review by Henshaw, obtained by Guardian Australia, said the decision to deny Williams‚Äôs visa is a breach of natural justice and procedural fairness, and names the secretary of justice, Lionel Aingimea, as the respondent. ‚ÄúThere was no evidence or other material to justify the making of [the] decision to deny the legal representative of the plaintiff a visa,‚Äù it said. It said Aingimea ‚Äúexercised power for an improper purpose, to deny the plaintiff his constitutional and common law right to legal representation‚Äù and was an attempt to ‚Äúpervert the course of justice‚Äù. A series of other court documents also reveal that the Nauruan secretary of justice personally intervened to prevent Williams being admitted to the Nauruan supreme court. Williams applied for admission as a barrister of the Nauruan supreme court on 10 October 2014. But two weeks later, on 28 October 2014, he was issued with a summons by the district court of Nauru, facing charges of accessing a restricted area dating back to events in January. Aingimea‚Äôs objection came a day after Williams was charged with the offence. While on a previous visit to Nauru in February 2014, Williams had been a passenger in a car with a Salvation Army employee, Adam Savage, who dropped Williams off at the airport. On his way to the airport, Savage turned off onto the airstrip entrance ‚Äì a restricted area ‚Äì and performed a number of ‚Äúdonuts‚Äù on the airport runway. Savage said in a statement that Williams urged him not to take the action, and Williams was not charged at the time. In a letter to the Nauru DPP, Williams‚Äôs counsel said the charges were ‚Äúbaseless‚Äù and a way to block the proceedings. ‚ÄúA baseless charge is brought against Mr Williams, in an attempt to block his admission and to further obstruct the Henshaw matter and the asylum seeker case,‚Äù the letter said. It continued: ‚ÄúIf at any stage, the Office of Public Prosecutions has received undue interference or pressure from members of the executive, to prosecute the charge against Mr Williams, without foundation and without evidence, then the Office of Public Prosecutions has a duty to the court and to the administration of justice to vigorously resist such interference and pressure, no matter what the professional or personal cost may be and ventilate such interference and pressure with the court at the first opportunity.‚Äù The charges were later dropped by the DPP and Williams succeeded in being admitted. But in May 2015 his business visa was denied without reason, despite the imminent proceedings. A legal challenge to the visa decision is now under way. The maze of dynamic legal proceedings on the island have emerged as part of an ongoing dispute that first began when Henshaw ‚Äì a former resident of Nauru ‚Äì received a deportation order from the government. His deportation was temporarily halted by former magistrate Peter Law. But Law himself was then deported from the country and prevented from re-entering, in the first of a series of blows to the integrity of the judiciary on the island nation. Henshaw, whose wife died on the island in 2013, said the long-running case was a serious denial of natural justice and had placed immense pressure on him. ‚ÄúPsychologically it‚Äôs just devastated me, quite frankly. Whatever way this case goes, I would have liked this to have been over, quite frankly, a lot sooner.‚Äù ‚ÄúNot being able to get back to the island to visit my wife‚Äôs grave has been difficult enough, but being bashed around the head with these proceedings has been incredible hard. ‚ÄúThere are serious consequences here for these proceedings. You‚Äôve got to wonder how the Australian government and the New Zealand government feel about these kind of decisions.‚Äù Henshaw and Law‚Äôs deportation was followed by the resignation of the former chief justice, Geoffrey Eames, as well as the solicitor general Stephen Bliim. While his legal case is a civil claim relating to seeking damages, his claim was later amended to include the contempt of court charges against the Nauruan president, Baron Waqa and the justice minister, David Adeang, following the deportations. Further concerns continue to be raised about Nauru, with the blocking of several websites including Facebook and the recent deportation of the general manager of telecommunications provider Digicell. The Nauruan government and Adeang have not responded to requests for comment.

column4: David Cameron must be willing to walk away from EU talks, says Boris Johnson
column5:
David Cameron should be prepared to walk away from his EU negotiations and allow Britain to forge a ‚Äúglorious‚Äù future outside the European Union if the talks fail, Boris Johnson has said. In his first speech in parliament for seven years, the mayor of London set himself as the potential leader of the Tories‚Äô no campaign, saying that Britain could be just as prosperous if it negotiates a free trade agreement with the EU.
‚ÄúIf you are going to go into a difficult international negotiation of this kind then you have got to be prepared to walk away if you don‚Äôt get the result that you want,‚Äù the new Tory MP for Uxbridge and South Ruislip said. ‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt get the deal that is either in the interests of this country or of Europe, we should be prepared to strike out and forge an alternative future that could be just as glorious and just as prosperous with a free trading arrangement.‚Äù Johnson qualified his remarks by saying that he was confident the prime minister would succeed in his EU negotiations as he praised Cameron for embarking on a ‚Äúschmooze-athon‚Äù across Europe. Johnson told MPs: ‚ÄúWe now have a Tory majority government with a clear mandate to seek change and therefore a government in the most powerful position in our lifetimes to deliver reform and improvement in Europe. We can. We can win that argument by being relentlessly positive and of course by making it clear that what we are advocating is not simply in the interests of Britain but in the entire EU. ‚ÄúI congratulate the prime minister and the elan and the success with which he has begun his pan-European schmooze-athon in the chancelleries of Europe. I believe his efforts will be crowned with success.‚Äù The London mayor, who first made his name as the Daily Telegraph‚Äôs Brussels correspondent by baiting the former European commission president Jacques Delors in the early 1990s, has been keen in recent months to quash speculation that in private he is strongly pro-EU. Johnson knows that he will need to emphasise his Eurosceptic credentials if he is to succeed Cameron as Tory leader. But Johnson‚Äôs remarks suggest that he might even be prepared to take a leading role in his party‚Äôs no campaign, which will be launched after the prime minister concludes his EU negotiations. The ranks of this group will swell if Cameron is seen to have secured a weak deal. Johnson has been made a member of Cameron‚Äôs political cabinet and is due to be given a full cabinet post when his term at City Hall ends next May, by which point the prime minister hopes to have completed his EU negotiations. Johnson, who has recently had a biography of Winston Churchill published, warned both sides in the EU debate to be careful about claiming the mantle of Britain‚Äôs wartime leader. Churchill argued in favour of a ‚ÄúUnited States of Europe‚Äù but said that Britain should not be a member. The London mayor said: ‚ÄúI notice, in the course of trying to settle this argument over the last few days, assorted speakers have invoked the memory of Winston Churchill in one way or another. I have tell you Churchill was absolutely useless on this subject. He is biblical on this matter. You can find a text to justify almost any proposition about our relations with Europe that you choose. But one thing he believed in passionately ‚Äì and that was in parliament as the expression of the will of the British people. He would want to see that democratic principle upheld today.‚Äù

column4: Mitch McConnell seeks to limit transparency in surveillance reform bill
column5:
The Senate‚Äôs top Republican renewed his quest to gut surveillance reform on Monday, this time removing a measure that would disclose major reinterpretations of surveillance law made by a secret court. Privacy-minded legislators, fresh off what appeared to be a victory after the Senate agreed on Sunday night to advance the USA Freedom Act, said that the latest legislative gambit by Mitch McConnell of Kentucky would leave the public vulnerable to what Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon has called ‚Äúsecret law‚Äù. McConnell‚Äôs amendment would strip the bill of its mandate to ‚Äúmake publicly available‚Äù novel interpretations of the law before the secret Fisa court ‚Äì a measure that advocates consider an early warning system to alert Congress and the public of efforts by the intelligence agencies to expand their powers.
‚ÄúRepublican leaders lost the fight to continue mass surveillance of Americans through the Patriot Act and now they want to water down the commonsense reforms that have overwhelming bipartisan support in the House and Senate,‚Äù Wyden, a Democrat on the intelligence committee, told the Guardian on Monday. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a strong bipartisan coalition ready to slam the door shut on this latest attempt to prolong the dragnet and strip out new rules on transparency from the USA Freedom Act.‚Äù Senate aides said on Monday that McConnell was already running into headwinds, however, making it unclear if the version of the bill without the transparency requirement will come up for a vote. Privacy campaigners, some of whom consider the USA Freedom Act to be an insufficient fix for widespread government surveillance, denounced McConnell‚Äôs amendment. Some believe it would end up costing the compromise bill its remaining support in the House of Representatives ‚Äì which would ensure that portions of the Patriot Act that expired at midnight would not be restored, via passage of the USA Freedom Act. Without the transparency provisions ‚Äúthere‚Äôs a very high likelihood this bill goes down in flames in the House‚Äù, said Patrick Eddington of the Cato Institute, a former House staffer. In a statement, Constitution Project attorney Rita Siemion said: ‚ÄúThe Senate should reject the harmful and unnecessary amendments proposed by Majority Leader McConnell ‚Äì especially those designed to keep the American people in the dark about the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance [Fisa] court ‚Äì and send the bill to the president‚Äôs desk without any additional delays and without weakening the bill.‚Äù McConnell also seeks to pass other amendments to the USA Freedom Act, which ends the NSA‚Äôs bulk collection of US phone data, a move by the majority leader which would delay the end of the phone-data dragnet for a year. These amendments would require the top US intelligence official to certify the implementation of the new phone-records regime; demand notification of changes made by telecoms companies to the kinds of call records they generate; and revise the creation of a new public-interest advocate before the Fisa court, which currently only hears from the government.
McConnell on Monday morning referred to the amendments as ‚Äúcommon sense‚Äù. The amendments would only need a simple majority to pass ‚Äì all but ensuring their adoption by the GOP-led Senate, where the majority of Republicans oppose surveillance reform and have advocated renewing the Patriot Act in its entirety. But the amendments are being met with opposition from most Democrats as well as libertarian-minded Republicans, who view them as so-called ‚Äúpoison pills‚Äù designed to weaken the product of marathon negotiations between Congress, the Obama administration and the intelligence community. It is also unlikely that the provisions would pass muster in the House, where GOP leaders have sought to retain pressure on the Senate to pass their bill as is. ‚ÄúThe USA Freedom Act is a good, strong bill,‚Äù Kevin McCarthy, the Republican House majority leader, said in a statement on Monday. ‚ÄúIt protects civil liberties. It provides for the capabilities our intelligence agencies need to keep the homeland safe. And it passed with a veto-proof majority of 338 votes in the House. Now is not the time to be playing games with our national security. The Senate should act quickly and send the USA Freedom Act to the president‚Äôs desk.‚Äù Adam Schiff, the top Democrat on the House intelligence committee, warned McConnell that changing the USA Freedom Act would imperil House passage of the revised bill, and increase the amount of time during which three sections of the Patriot Act that expired at midnight on Sunday are no longer available to the FBI. ‚ÄúAny departure from this carefully crafted compromise will undoubtedly reduce support for it in the House and prolong the expiration of these intelligence tools, and I urge the Senate to pass the USA Freedom Act as is and without any further delay,‚Äù Schiff said on Monday. The White House spokesman, Josh Earnest, dismissed the one-year transition period as ‚Äúcompletely unnecessary‚Äù and continued to push for the passage of the House version of the USA Freedom Act. ‚ÄúWe believe that six months is enough,‚Äù Earnest told reporters on Monday. ‚ÄúThe Senate should not start getting into a game where it passes amendments that require House consideration again. ‚ÄúThey have had a year and a half to exercise that prerogative and, now that they have blown through that deadline, most people would acknowledge that is a privilege they should relinquish ‚Ä¶ rather than get into additional political gamesmanship.‚Äù On the Senate floor on Monday, the chairman of the Senate intelligence committee, Richard Burr of North Carolina, said he hoped a final vote on the USA Freedom Act could proceed by lunchtime on Tuesday. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe that the threat level has dropped to a point where we can remove some of the tools ‚Äì if anything, the threat level has gotten higher, and you would think we‚Äôd be talking about an expansion of tools,‚Äù Burr said. ‚ÄúBut I accept the fact that this debate has gotten to a point where a bulk data storage capacity within the government is not going to be continued long term.‚Äù Additional reporting by Dan Roberts

column4: Cold turkey and shackles ‚Äì¬†how Afghan 'clinic' helps drug addicts
column5:
Agha Shahi had been using drugs for 10 years when his family decided it was time for rehab. In Uruzgan, an impoverished and often-neglected rural province in southern Afghanistan, there was only one place to go: the private home of a freelance treatment guru. In the provincial capital, Tarin Kot, a hand-painted sign of an opium smoker points to Hamidullah Bawari‚Äôs drug ‚Äúclinic‚Äù. In a small courtyard among well-tended flowerbeds, a handful of recovering addicts shuffle around with their feet in chains. The treatment here is rudimentary, consisting of little more than cold turkey eased by painkillers. Even cigarettes are banned. In the first 72 hours, patients have their heads shaved and their ankles shackled. ‚ÄúIf we didn‚Äôt have chains on, we would escape like this,‚Äù Shahi says as he snaps his fingers. Despite its basic amenities, facilities such as this fulfil an urgent need, even if it is the brainchild of an amateur drugs counsellor who buys his painkillers at the local bazaar. A recent US-funded drug survey suggests that up to 11% of the Afghan population use drugs. The report, which is the first nationwide toxicological survey of drug use in Afghanistan, was based on saliva, urine and hair samples from more than 10,000 Afghans. Addiction, the report says, is particularly endemic in rural areas where about 39% of households tested positive. Such estimates are notoriously tricky, particularly because Afghanistan‚Äôs last census was conducted in 1979. In earlier estimates, the UN put the number of addicts at 1.6 million, or around 5% of the population. Regardless of the exact number, health authorities are overpowered. Over the past decade, international donors have helped Afghanistan set up about 100 treatment centres across the country, offering space to over 30,000 addicts.
Tawab Saljuqi, a spokesperson for the Ministry of Public Health, said the government had achieved a lot with limited resources. ‚ÄúBut the pool of addicted is increasing, and the resources are decreasing,‚Äù he said. Bawari, the director of the Tarin Kot clinic, opened his home to addicts three year ago. Every day he saw addicts in the street, rummaging through rubbish to find sellable items for their next fix. ‚ÄúI thought, ‚Äòthey have a family too. What would I do if I were in their place?‚Äù says Bawari, whose only training consists of a four-day course with the ministry of counter narcotics. Bawari‚Äôs house can accommodate upto 40 patients, but rarely sees more than 20. A month‚Äôs treatment costs $100 (¬£65), a hefty expense for families. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very difficult for the family to bring a person here,‚Äù says Shahi. Shahi, rail-thin with a thick black beard, started using when he was in his early 20s. Friends who had migrated to Iran returned with a drug habit, and he quickly got hooked on opium and heroin. Even after treatment, many patients are doomed to live perpetually on the edge of addiction. Jobs are scarce and the abundance of poppy fields and drug smugglers in Uruzgan make a habit even harder to kick. ‚ÄúIf they leave this place and don‚Äôt find a job, they will start using again,‚Äù says Bawari. Yet, a job is not always a safeguard against addiction. Jalil, 22, worked with the highway police, protecting lorries driving from Tarin Kot to Kandahar. His work, rife with corruption and close to drug routes, helped sustain a heroin habit he said cost him about ¬£20 a day. ‚ÄúWhen I brought my son here, he was very weak, almost dead,‚Äù says his father, Zafron. It took him five years to notice Jalil‚Äôs habit, and he is grateful to Bawari for his treatment. ‚ÄùHe gave a second life to my son.‚Äù
The clinic is men-only but plenty of women and children are addicted too. In the US survey, 11% of rural children tested positive for drugs, most of them exposed through second-hand smoke or from residue in rugs and pillows. Until recently, Save the Children ran a drug clinic in Tarin Kot that was free of charge for both genders. But at the end of May, after treating more than 500 patients over two years, the organisation handed over the programme to the provincial health directorate of Uruzgan, which did not have the money to maintain it. Jennifer El-Sibai, spokesperson for Save the Children, said the closure was an indirect consequence of aid cuts in Australia which funded the clinic. ‚ÄúWe were hopeful we might continue the programme in some form. However that has not happened,‚Äù she said. Afghanistan‚Äôs drug crisis also illustrates a wholesale failure to eradicate opium. This year‚Äôs poppy harvest is expected to beat all records, surpassing last year‚Äôs unprecedented 224,000 hectares. Since 2001 the US has spent $8.4bn on combating drugs in Afghanistan. On a recent visit to Kabul, William Brownfield, assistant secretary of the State Department‚Äôs bureau of international narcotics and law enforcement affairs, suggested that other countries should take more responsibility. Brownfield told reporters in a briefing that in the US, ‚Äúthe amount of heroin consumed that is of Afghan origin is about 4% ‚Ä¶ There should be more nations and governments that are focusing their efforts and resources to this problem‚Äù.

column4: Houthi rebels release American journalist held in Yemen
column5: Houthi rebels have released at least one of ‚Äúseveral‚Äù Americans in captivity in Yemen, the State Department has confirmed, as neighboring Oman plays peacemaker for the region‚Äôs warring factions. State Department spokeswoman Marie Harf identified the freed American as Casey Coombs. An official told the Associated Press that Coombs, who had been injured under unknown circumstances, had reached Oman. Harf said Coombs was in ‚Äústable condition‚Äù and said diplomats in Oman were ‚Äúproviding all consular assistance‚Äù. Harf added that the US was ‚Äúgrateful to the government of Oman‚Äù for its assistance, and that the US was aware of reports of other Americans being held in Yemen. Assistant secretary of state Anne Patterson was in Oman to talk with ‚Äúa wide swath of Yemenis‚Äù, Harf said, and ‚Äúa variety of organizations inside Yemen‚Äù. She would not confirm that Patterson had met with Houthi leaders. Patterson had held talks about ‚Äúthe crisis writ large‚Äù, Harf said, in an effort to broker peace between all sides. Working with a ‚Äúthird-party country‚Äù as mediator was preferable, Harf said, to ‚Äúsending in American assets‚Äù to free the captives. In December, a failed raid by US special forces resulted in the deaths of the American journalist Luke Somers and South African teacher Pierre Korkie, who were held by al-Qaida militants in south-east Yemen. There are believed to be at least three Americans still held by Houthi militants, who took over the capital of Sana‚Äôa and ousted the US- and Saudi-backed government earlier this year. An official in Sana‚Äôa told Reuters the Houthis still held another captive, who appears to be American Sharif Mobley, who disappeared from his pre-detention trial in 2014 and briefly resurfaced in May. Terrorism charges against Mobley were dropped under the government of President Ali Abdullah Saleh, but he remained in custody, accused of murdering a prison guard. The official said that the American is of Smoali origin and had been detained for several years on suspected links to terrorism. A campaign of air strikes against the Houthis, led by Saudi Arabia and assisted by US intelligence, has complicated any tentative diplomacy. Before the Houthi takeover, the US had few contacts with leaders of a militia that has fought against a key US ally, Saudi Arabia, and is accused of acting as a proxy force of Iran. Oman is the only country of the Gulf Cooperation Council that has not joined the military campaign in Yemen, where Houthi forces continue to fight against coalition forces, various militias and al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula. On Monday, coalition forces launched another round of air strikes on Yemeni cities. Many members of Yemen‚Äôs ousted government, including President Abd Rabbu Mansour Hadi, fled to Saudi Arabia to escape a conflict that has killed as many as 2,000 people. A Yemeni government spokesperson said the United Nations envoy to Yemen had made progress toward a longer ceasefire and the release of several detained people. The Omani News Agency reported that a missing Singaporean had also been evacuated to Muscat on Monday, after coordination with ‚Äúrelevant authorities in Yemen‚Äù. Late on Sunday, Representative Ed Royce, chairman of the House foreign affairs committee, told CNN ‚Äúit looked like [one of the captives] was going to be let out of the country, escorted toward the airport and then many officials changed their minds‚Äù. Unknown militants have also detained a French woman, Isabelle Prime, and on Monday released a video in which she pleaded for assistance and appeared frail and in poor health. A French official confirmed the video‚Äôs authenticity and said the government was ‚Äúmobilized to obtain [her] release‚Äù. Prime was kidnapped in February. She had been working as a consultant for a World Bank project. The translator with whom she was captured was freed in March.

column4: Tehran auction shifts millions of pounds worth of art in spite of sanctions
column5:
In Tehran‚Äôs luxurious Grand Azadi hotel, a row of women dressed in black with red headscarves hold the lines open to bidders as the auctioneer tries to conjure up increasingly large sums with his hammer. As artworks are displayed, prices in the tens of billions of Iranian rials ‚Äì hundreds of thousands of pounds ‚Äì light up the large Samsung screen on the wall. In the crowd are some familiar faces including actors, politicians and the retired Iranian football star Ali Daei. The auction of modern and contemporary Iranian art, which is jockeying to be among the big auctions in the Middle East, is an annual event and was being held for the fourth time. But this year was different: the prices that were bid were astonishing for a country still struggling with international sanctions. And the auction, held on Friday, made nearly double what had been predicted, totalling ¬£4.3m. A tree trunk painting by celebrated Iranian poet and painter Sohrab Sepehri sold for around 28bn rials (¬£560,000), becoming the most expensive painting ever sold in Iran. Other works that attracted large sums include those of the New York-based artist Manoucher Yektai and sculptor Parviz Tanavoli, as well as pieces by Bahman Mohassess and Aydin Aghdashloo. ‚ÄúIt exceeded our expectations,‚Äù a Tehran auction spokeswoman told the Guardian. ‚ÄúWe sold almost 180% ... [of] what we had estimated. We had buyers both from inside and outside Iran. Out of 126 works that had been presented, 125 of them were sold.‚Äù Due to sanctions, Iran‚Äôs banking system is cut off from the outside world but that did not stop international bidders participating in the auction. ‚ÄúForeigners had an intermediary paying on their behalf in Tehran,‚Äù the spokeswoman said. The event was sponsored by Samsung‚Äôs Iran branch, among other companies. Shiva Balaghi, a cultural historian of the Middle East at Brown University, said the auction showed art purchases were increasing in Iran. ‚ÄúThe growing art market in Iran is significant and is sustained by a new generation of local collectors,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe recent Tehran auctions have been showing consistently strong prices. There has been notable interest in Iranian modern masters like Sohrab Sepehri, Marcos Grigorian and Parviz Tanavoli.‚Äù Interest in Iranian art from the 1950s through the 1970s is also strong on the international front among private collectors and museums, Balaghi said. ‚ÄúThough prices for these works are rising, they are still fairly modest compared to their western counterparts,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúFor relatively smaller sums, one can build a significant collection of modern and contemporary Iranian art. So for Iranians, art is a smart financial investment as well as a way to tap into one‚Äôs cultural heritage.‚Äù The record for the most expensive Iranian artwork was set by Tanavoli‚Äôs sculpture Oh Persepolis, which sold for $2.8m (¬£1.8m) at Christie‚Äôs Dubai in 2008. Balaghi added that the sanctions will mean art auctions in Tehran will be largely limited to domestic collectors. She said: ‚ÄúThe integration of the Iranian art market with the international art market will only really happen when sanctions are lifted.‚Äù
Nicky Nodjoumi, whose ink on paper work The Accident was recently acquired by the British Museum, also had a work sold in Tehran on Friday. An Iranian art journal has put him in the list of top 10 Iranian artists. ‚ÄúThere has been some criticism to the auction but overall, I think it‚Äôs a positive move,‚Äù Nodjoumi told the Guardian. ‚ÄúIt would be a financial help to Iranian artists, something that we didn‚Äôt have much in the past.‚Äù Nodjoumi‚Äôs acrylic work in Tehran‚Äôs auction, called Last Touch, was the first piece by him to have gained official permission for sale inside Iran. He has many works that have been critical of the Iranian establishment. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt believe the sums I was hearing from the auction,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt is a question for people like me that how can a country be under sanctions and then sell works in such staggering amounts?‚Äù According to the Tehran Times, the famous Iranian actor Reza Kianian, who conducted the auction, said: ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt think that we could organise the second edition of the Tehran auction and now, I am happy that the fourth edition is being held.‚Äù The auction is run by Alireza Sami-Azar, a former head of Tehran‚Äôs Museum of Contemporary Art, which has a hidden treasure of original works by the likes of Jackson Pollock, Francis Bacon, Andy Warhol, Edvard Munch, Ren√© Magritte and Mark Rothko. The attitude of Iranian politicians towards art is also changing. Last month, Tehran‚Äôs mayor replaced billboards ads in the city with art pieces by local and international artists, including Picasso and Magritte, for a period of 10 days.

column4: South Africa beach service to honour slaves drowned in 1794 shipwreck
column5: A small, solemn memorial service will be held on one of South Africa‚Äôs most popular beaches on Tuesday, close to a recently discovered shipwreck where more than 200 African slaves drowned at the bottom of the sea. The Portuguese ship, the S√£o Jos√©-Paquete de Africa, was sailing from Mozambique to Brazil when it sank in turbulent waters near Cape Town in December 1794. Researchers say it is the first time that the remains of a slavers‚Äô ship that went down with its human cargo on board has been identified. Albie Sachs, a former constitutional court judge, will give a speech welcoming diplomats, activists and community leaders at the ceremony on Clifton beach, near the wreck site. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs profound and terrible to feel this is one of the most beautiful beaches in the whole world and within such a short distance lie the bodies of 200 slaves who died there,‚Äù the 80-year-old said on Monday. ‚ÄúPresumably they were still in shackles or they could have swum to shore. This has been an untold story that has repercussions and reverberations for us today. Somehow their memories survive even though they‚Äôre not in the history books.‚Äù The S√£o Jos√© was making one of the earliest voyages of the transatlantic slave trade from east Africa to the Americas, which persisted well into the 19th century. More than 400,000 east Africans, shackled in ships‚Äô holds, are estimated to have made the four-month, 7,000-mile journey from Mozambique to the sugar plantations of Brazil between 1800 and 1865. The S√£o Jos√© had only been sailing for 24 days when, tossed by strong winds in view of Lion‚Äôs Head mountain, it was smashed on submerged rocks 100 metres from shore. An estimated 212 slaves perished. About 300 survived and were resold into slavery in the Cape. The Portuguese captain, Manuel Jo√£o, and his crew were also rescued. The wreck lay undisturbed for nearly 200 years but was found in the mid-1980s by local amateur treasure-hunters who misidentified it as the remains of an earlier Dutch vessel. But in 2011 Jaco Boshoff, a maritime archaeologist, discovered the captain‚Äôs account of the wrecking of the S√£o Jos√© in local archives. Those on board ‚Äúmade ropes and baskets and continuing like this were able to save some men and slaves until five in the evening, when the ship broke to pieces‚Äù, it recorded. Evidence steadily built. Copper fastenings and copper sheathing indicated a wreck of a later period, and there was also iron ballast ‚Äì often found on slave ships as a means of counterbalancing the variable weights of their human cargo. The Slave Wrecks Project, an international collaboration, found an archival document in Portugal stating that the Sa√µ Jos√© had loaded 1,500 iron bars as ballast before she departed for Mozambique. Further research located a document in which a slave was noted as sold by a local sheikh to the captain of the Sa√µ Jos√© prior to its departure, definitively identifying Mozambique Island as the port of departure for the slaving voyage. Objects retrieved from the ship this year include fragile remnants of shackles, iron ballast to weigh down the ship and its human cargo, copper fastenings and a wooden pulley block. There has been no trace of human remains. Boshoff, co-originator of the Slave Wrecks Project and principal archaeological investigator on the Sa√µ Jos√© excavation, said: ‚ÄúThe more information we get the better. The memorial service will be a bit more emotional, but when we start work again we‚Äôll have to dial back the emotion.‚Äù He added: ‚ÄúEvery day there are discoveries made but, in the history of the slave trade, this one is important. It‚Äôs the first time we‚Äôve been able to look at a ship that sank with slaves still on board.‚Äù The wreck site is located between two reefs and is prone to strong swells, making conditions difficult for archaeologists. So far only a small percentage has been excavated. ‚ÄúThere is a lot to do,‚Äù Boshoff said. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt scratched the surface. It‚Äôs a wide-ranging project and I‚Äôm fortunate it‚Äôs on my doorstep.‚Äù A public symposium, called Bringing the S√£o Jos√© Into Memory, will be held in Cape Town on Wednesday. Some of the recovered objects are to be displayed on long-term loan at the Smithsonian‚Äôs new National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington DC. Lonnie Bunch, director of the museum, who is due to attend Tuesday‚Äôs event, said: ‚ÄúPerhaps the single greatest symbol of the transatlantic slave trade is the ships that carried millions of captive Africans across the Atlantic never to return. ‚ÄúThis discovery is significant because there has never been archaeological documentation of a vessel that foundered and was lost while carrying a cargo of enslaved persons. The S√£o Jos√© is all the more significant because it represents one of the earliest attempts to bring east Africans into the transatlantic slave trade ‚Äì a shift that played a major role in prolonging that tragic trade for decades. ‚ÄúLocating, documenting and preserving this cultural heritage through the S√£o Jos√© has the potential to reshape our understandings of a part of history that has been considered unknowable.‚Äù Plans for divers from Mozambique, South Africa and the US to deposit soil from Mozambique Island, the site of the Sa√µ Jos√©‚Äôs embarkation, on the wreck site has been abandoned due to Cape Town‚Äôs volatile winter weather and high tides. For Sachs, an anti-apartheid activist who lost an arm and the sight in one eye in a bombing in Mozambique while in exile in the 1980s, the international flavour of the day will be important. ‚ÄúThere is a wonderful cooperation between the Smithsonian and the Iziko Museums of South Africa. People are diving together and compiling the information together. This is a beautiful example of present-day globalisation recovering an example of terrible globalisation from the 18th century. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a healing to have people getting together to memorialise the dead. I was nearly killed by a car bomb planted by South African agents in Mozambique. Mozambicans saved my life. Here South Africans are honouring colleagues from Mozambique for this commemoration.‚Äù

column4: Praise her, praise her: should we refer to God as a woman?
column5: Age: Ageless. Appearance: Well, now you‚Äôre asking. Rare, certainly. Last embodied, sort of, more than 2,000 years ago. Allegedly. Why‚Äôs He in the news? Don‚Äôt tell me He‚Äôs averted some kind of humanitarian crisis at freaking last? Come to the aid of the poor and needy? Smitten a few of those who are long overdue being smited? Got His arse into gear at last in any way? I‚Äôm afraid I have to take issue with your phraseology there. Don‚Äôt tell me ‚Äì at the secular, liberal, all-must-have-prizes, drooping, dripping bloody Guardian you don‚Äôt capitalise the ‚Äòh‚Äô in ‚ÄòHe‚Äô. I should have known. I wish I could smite every last one of you personally. Then you‚Äôre going to love this. It shouldn‚Äôt even be ‚Äòhe‚Äô at all. With all due sense of impending fury, contempt and dread I ask ‚Äì what should it be? She. You are the living end. It‚Äôs not us, though. People in the Church of England are saying it. Which people? Bring them before me. The pressure group Watch ‚Äì Women and the Church ‚Äì are arguing that it is more inclusive to refer to God as ‚Äúshe‚Äù. Calling him ‚Äì or her, or it, or whatever ‚Äì ‚Äúhe‚Äù all the time suggests that men are closer to God. Have you seen how many parliamentary and FTSE 100 positions we have? We ARE closer to God. That‚Äôs obviously the way He wants it. The conception of God as a man raises a lot of complex issues ‚Äì linguistically, theologically, about patriarchal power structures, of historical prejudice. Changing the language of worship is a step towards recognising if not solving some of them. God‚Äôs a man. Big beard, white robe, on a cloud. Problem solved. That‚Äôs not a terrifically useful approach to broadening our understanding of the divine. That‚Äôs good, because I‚Äôm not interested in broadening our understanding of the divine. I understand Him just fine. Do you not think that‚Äôs a little egocentric? If you believe in God, is the idea not that he/she/it is more than you can ever understand? Is that not the basic premise of most faiths? Not mine. Bloody Anglicans. They‚Äôre the Guardian newspaper of Christianity. D‚Äôyou think the Catholics are recruiting. Always. Mind how you go. Do say: ‚ÄúGod surely transcends mere binary gender divisions.‚Äù Don‚Äôt say: ‚ÄúWell, are we going to capitalise ‚Äòshe‚Äô?‚Äù

column4: Rightwing Northern League makes gains in Italian elections
column5:
He is virulently anti-immigrant, has called for Roma camps to be razed and once referred to the euro as a ‚Äúcrime against humanity‚Äù. Matteo Salvini, the bombastic rightwing leader of Italy‚Äôs xenophobic Northern League, has even accused Pope Francis of doing a disservice to Catholics by promoting dialogue with Muslims. None of this appears to be doing him any harm at the ballot box. On the contrary, in the divided and economically battered Italy of 2015, it seems to be a winning formula. The 42-year-old is riding high after his party made significant electoral gains in central and left-leaning parts of Italy, results that reflect growing opposition to the EU and concern over the thousands of migrants landing on Italy‚Äôs shores each week. In what can only be viewed as a personal affront to Matteo Renzi, the charismatic left-of-centre prime minister who used to be mayor of Florence, Salvini‚Äôs Lega Nord, as it is known in Italy, even managed to win 20% of the vote in Tuscany ‚Äì unheard of in the leftwing bastion of the country that counts Renzi as its favourite son. Salvini called the Tuscan result ‚Äúsensational‚Äù. Although Renzi‚Äôs Democratic party (PD) emerged from Sunday‚Äôs regional elections as the overall victor, it lost a bellwether race in Liguria, in northern Italy, to the League-backed candidate from Silvio Berlusconi‚Äôs centre-right Forza Italia, and was trounced by the League in Veneto, the region around Venice.
Apart from the rightwing resurgence, the results also reflect dissatisfaction with Renzi on the left wing of his party, where his support is waning. ‚ÄúI have been listening to chatter on the television for an hour: I am happy that we are a bogeyman for lots of mummies, it must mean we are right,‚Äù a gleeful Salvini said on Italian radio. ‚ÄúThree months ago it was unthinkable that the League would be fundamental in Liguria or able to win again in Veneto. Our work begins tomorrow; for many parties it ends tonight.‚Äù Salvini, who often appears at events wearing T-shirts and hooded sweatshirts ‚Äì he once posed for the cover of Oggi magazine in nothing but a green tie ‚Äì could not be more different to the other Matteo. Renzi, a former boy scout with Machiavellian political instincts, came to power after an intra-party coup last year and promised to reform Italy. He is seen by many, particularly those outside of Italy, as the only viable option to lead the country among a host of politicians who are either too rightwing, too anti-establishment or, on the left, relics of the past. But Sunday‚Äôs election results show that ongoing economic pessimism ‚Äì despite the economy showing meagre growth for the first time after years of stagnation ‚Äì is fuelling opposition to the prime minister and could challenge his ambition to rebuild a lasting centrist majority in Italy. ‚ÄúWe are the real alternative to Renzi,‚Äù Salvini said in a Facebook post. On Twitter, he thanked supporters and warned Renzi ‚Äúwe‚Äôre coming‚Äù, using his usual signoff #Salvini.
Salvini is nipping at Renzi‚Äôs heels in large part because he has managed to turn what was a regional force in Italy into a national party. The Northern League started as a secessionist party that argued for a separation of rich northern Italy from the poor south, but Salvini has ‚Äì with mixed success ‚Äì changed the party‚Äôs focus. He likes to compare the migrant crisis in the Mediterranean to an invasion and is a frequent critic of Italy‚Äôs Roma population. He has claimed that Muslims in Italy are ‚Äútrying to impose a way of life that is incompatible with ours‚Äù. He has even called on Italians to renounce their nationality and ask for asylum so that they can get benefits. The question now, according to Wolfango Piccoli, an analyst at Teneo Intelligence who follows Italian politics, is whether Salvini will emerge as the new leader of Italy‚Äôs centre-right bloc, therefore replacing Berlusconi, the former premier who was forced to step down from high office following a slew of sex and corruption scandals. Salvini had an answer to that question on Monday: ‚ÄúI am the leader of the centre-right,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBerlusconi knows how to read the numbers.‚Äù There was only one real bright spot for Renzi on Sunday, and even that was somewhat dulled. The PD won the race in Campania, in southern Italy, but did so with a slate of candidates who have been criticised by anti-mafia authorities for their links to corruption and organised crime.

column4: Berlin becomes first German city to make rent cap a reality
column5:
Berlin has become the first city in Germany in which rent-control legislation has come into force in a bid to put the brakes on some of the fastest rising rents in Europe. From Monday, landlords in the capital will be barred from increasing rents by more than 10% above the local average. Such controls were already in place for existing tenants but have now been extended to new contracts.
‚ÄúThe rent ceiling is very important for Berlin because the difference between the rent paid in existing contracts and new contracts is so high,‚Äù said Reiner Wild, managing director of the Berlin Tenants‚Äô Association. ‚ÄúThe other problem is that we have 40,000 more inhabitants per year. Because of this situation the housing market is very strong.‚Äù Berlin is pioneering the rent cap after the national parliament approved the law, aimed at areas with housing shortages, in March. Berliners say flat-hunting is becoming increasingly competitive. ‚ÄúWe were looking for the best part of a year,‚Äù said Vlasis Tritakis, a student. He, his partner Sofia and their 18-month-old son moved out of a flat-share into a one-bedroomed apartment in the district of Kreuzberg in April. But sooner or later they will have to find a place big enough for his son to have a room of his own. They say they don‚Äôt stand much of a chance against competition from potential tenants with better finances. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how we will do it,‚Äù said Tritakis. Although rents are still low compared with other European capitals, Wild says it is vital to keep the city affordable for lower-income residents. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want a situation like in London or Paris,‚Äù said Wild. ‚ÄúThe reality in Paris or London is that people with low income have to live in the further-out districts of the city.‚Äù
Wild said his organisation would like to see more action taken to address the problem, including the building of more affordable housing. Kerstine Appunn and her boyfriend took three and a half months to land a spacious two-bedroomed flat in Prenzlauer Berg, one of Berlin‚Äôs pricier inner-city districts, where organic cafes populate the pretty, tree-lined streets. ‚ÄúI heard that it was quite good going to find somewhere you really like without making too many compromises in such a short time, and in such a nice area,‚Äù Appunn, a journalist, said. ‚ÄúBut I guess we are paying for it. It is quite expensive for Berlin.‚Äù Average rents in the German capital rose from just over ‚Ç¨5.50 (¬£3.60) a square metre in 2005 to close to ‚Ç¨9 last year, according to a report by property services company Jones Lang LaSalle. Between 2013 and 2014, rents went up by more than 9%. Lance Anderson, a translator, arrived from the UK in 1998. He moved into a two-bed flat close to Potsdamer Platz, in the heart of the city, six years ago, before ‚Äúthings went crazy‚Äù in terms of rent rises.
‚ÄúI used to be able to pay my rent for the whole month just by working one shift as a waiter,‚Äù he said of his housing situation in 2003, when he lived in a shared flat in a now very desirable neighbourhood on the eastern edge of Kreuzberg. He conceded that the flat was heated with coal stoves and said it was directly above a flat that a neighbouring tenant rented just for his dogs. But Anderson also says Berlin‚Äôs much-bemoaned gentrification has had its benefits: better places to eat out; more diverse, international communities; and the pleasant feeling of living in a lively, populated city. But he says it is difficult to adjust to the rapid rise in rents in a city where wages are still low. ‚ÄúAll my friends who have been in the city a long time have old leases ‚Äì we know we cannot afford to move,‚Äù Anderson said. ‚ÄúWe are stuck in our flats, kind of like polar bears on our little ice sheets. It sounds like a privileged position to complain about, but for example for couples wanting to move in together ‚Äì it‚Äôs like: ‚ÄòWell, can we really afford to?‚Äô‚Äù ‚Ä¢ This article was amended on Wednesday 3 June 2015 to correct a misspelling of ‚Äúbrakes‚Äù in the opening paragraph.

column4: Hey neighbor! A 'Black Lives Matter' sign on your lawn is an act of solidarity
column5:
St Louis has become a region awash in signs. In the impoverished, majority black north, block after block of houses post signs with a stark message: ‚ÄúWe must stop killing each other‚Äù. In the region‚Äôs racially mixed, wealthier center, houses post signs with another message: ‚ÄúBlack Lives Matter‚Äù. Together, the signs tell the story of a region struggling to deal with questions of race and violence in the aftermath of the Ferguson events and a spate of homicides. On the blighted city‚Äôs Page Boulevard sits Better Family Life, a nonprofit organization whose vice-president of community outreach, James Clark, spearheaded the ‚ÄúWe must stop killing each other‚Äù campaign. ‚ÄúOne day I walk into the gas station, and a young man says: ‚ÄòWith all this crime and violence going on, man, we got to stop killing each other,‚Äô‚Äù Clark recalls. ‚ÄúNext day, walk into the office, a young man is standing at the front table: ‚ÄòMr Clark, man, my cousin got killed last week. We got to stop killing each other.‚Äô Walk into my office after about an hour, a grandmother calls: ‚ÄòMr Clark, my son didn‚Äôt come home last night. We don‚Äôt know where he is. We got to stop all this killing.‚Äô For about three days, that message came to me.‚Äù
After years of a steady drop in crime, homicides surged in St Louis in 2014, up more than 30% from the year before. The trend continues in 2015, with incidents including two rolling gun battles on the highway, a toddler shot in a park, and a homicide near the baseball stadium in broad daylight. Most of the victims were black. The violence has prompted more than 2,000 homes in the St Louis region to place ‚ÄúWe must stop killing each other‚Äù signs on their lawns since April. According to Clark, ‚Äúwe‚Äù, in St Louis, is everyone. ‚ÄúWhat these signs have done is establish a narrative,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt is a narrative that is of course relevant to us in the African American community, but it is also a narrative that can go to police officers ‚Äì you all must stop killing people. This is a message everyone can reflect on. I‚Äôve got drug dealers and gang members and pastors, the whole spectrum of people, saying: ‚ÄòWe are with you.‚Äô‚Äù Clark says the demand for the signs is so high his organization cannot produce them fast enough. He sees the grassroots, door-to-door campaign as a public outpouring of frustration by those who have been ‚Äúsystematically shut out‚Äù. He says he saw the rise in violence coming since 2005, but no one believed him. I ask what makes people believe him now. ‚ÄúThe bodies keep dropping,‚Äù he answers. ‚ÄúWhat we have is a new mentality: ‚ÄòI will kill‚Äô. This is not like the 1990s, when crime was over drugs. Today it comes from disconnected individuals who have no hope, nothing they really value, because no one has valued them.‚Äù Clark plans to plaster the St Louis region with signs, expanding beyond the black neighborhoods of St Louis into the whiter suburbs. ‚ÄúBlack Lives Matter is a good campaign,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt raises public awareness of the biased-ness that exists in America, the inherent racism that discounts black lives. But as an African American, I think that black lives have to matter first in the black community.
