However, Renate Samson, chief executive of Big Brother Watch, said the tiny rate of rejections raised questions about the claim that police forces are being frustrated in their quest for information.
‚ÄúModern policing and the use of technology in investigating crime should be more transparent,‚Äù Samson said. ‚ÄúWe are repeatedly told that communications data plays a significant role in modern policing, yet the report‚Äôs findings pose serious questions about the internal approval process, which differs from force to force. ‚ÄúWith police forces making over 730,000 requests for communications data in the past three years, political mutterings of diminishing access to our communications are clearly overstated. If greater access to our communications is to be granted, increased transparency and independent judicial approval should be introduced as standard. ‚ÄúUntil these safeguards exist, the public will have little confidence that the powers to access their communications are being used only when it is truly necessary and proportionate.‚Äù The group‚Äôs report made five policy suggestions, including the introduction of judicial approval for all requests, a revised definition of what constitutes ‚Äúcommunications data‚Äù, standardised procedures for making requests for all forces and telecoms companies, and making police forces produce ‚Äútransparency reports‚Äù about how they make requests. Communications data is defined by Big Brother Watch as ‚Äúthe who, where and when of any text, email, phone call or web search‚Äù.
A ‚Äúdesignated person‚Äù ‚Äì who must not be involved in the investigation and who must have a working knowledge of human rights legislation ‚Äì is approved to access those details. Currently, the police and security services generally require approval from a secretary of state when they want to intercept the contents of communications. Sir Anthony May, the interception of communications commissioner, reported this year that the intelligence agencies and all other authorities collectively had permission to look at communications data more than half a million times in 2014, but he dismissed claims that there was any ‚Äúsignificant institutional overuse of communications data powers‚Äù. However, he did say: ‚ÄúA proportion of the applications did not adequately deal with the question of necessity or proportionality. There were some examples where the powers had been used improperly or unnecessarily.‚Äù This included ‚Äúbreaches‚Äù in the way legally privileged material ‚Äì private conversations between lawyers and their clients ‚Äì had been handled by the various agencies. Responding to the report, a Home Office spokesman said: ‚ÄúIt is absolutely vital that our police and security services are able to obtain communications data in certain, limited circumstances, to protect the public and ensure national security. ‚ÄúThis information helps to disrupt terrorist plots, smash criminal networks and keep us safe, and it is a government priority to ensure our legislation is updated to deal with changing threats and evolving technologies.‚Äù
Ch Supt Stephen Graham, head of the West Midlands Police intelligence department, said: ‚ÄúMobile phones now play a vital role in the investigation of crimes and help to locate missing people or in cases where we have threats to life. ‚ÄúThe application to obtain these details is subject to guidance and strict codes of practice. All police forces are regularly and rigorously inspected by an independent body on the way in which we use this tactic. ‚ÄúThe information gives details of when a call was made and which phone number was called. It may also give details of the location of the people making and receiving the call but would not include what they say or what data they pass on within a communication ‚Äì including text, audio and video. ‚ÄúPeople may think that it is an extension of police powers when all it is doing is giving us the ability to do what we already do.‚Äù

column4: NYU confronts stereotypes with exhibition of racially charged art
column5:
When the late British writer, art connoisseur and friend of the Queen, Sir Harold Acton, bequeathed his family‚Äôs Italian villa to New York University in 1994, the gift included a vast trove of art valued at hundreds of millions of pounds. But among the 6,000-piece collection were 35 works that left some of La Pietra‚Äôs new owners feeling uncomfortable. Ellyn Toscano, who has served as the director of La Pietra since 2004, recalls being taken aback the first time she was confronted by the pieces that are now known as the ‚ÄúBlackamoors‚Äù, a collection of sculptures and paintings of black figures, elegantly dressed and depicted in acts of servitude ‚Äì and are located throughout the villa‚Äôs grounds. ‚ÄúYou go to a room and there is a Blackamoor holding a lantern, lighting the way,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI had been working in the south Bronx for 20 years, and [the statues] have these strange resonance with [black] lawn jockeys,‚Äù she adds, referring to the controversial ‚Äì some say misunderstood ‚Äì lawn statues in the US that are seen as romantacising the US‚Äôs history of slavery.
Toscano says that during her first tour of La Pietra, Italian art historians viewed the works as an afterthought and not particularly controversial because they were considered as minor decorative art in comparison with the ‚Äúimportant‚Äù other works on display in the 15th-century villa. ‚ÄúBut to an American racialised consciousness, the Blackamoors are startling,‚Äù she says. Now, NYU in Florence has assembled a thematic exhibit called ReSignifications in which both established and emerging artists are presenting new work inspired by the controversial decorative art. The exhibit is part of an effort by NYU to come to terms with its own holding of the racially charged art and, Toscano says, is meant to help students studying at the campus ‚Äúconfront and understand them‚Äù.
The work on display is centred around the theme of the objectification of black bodies today ‚Äì whether in sport, stereotypes, or the anonymous images seen in the news every day of black migrants fleeing war and economic hardships in Africa for Europe via the Mediterranean. The controversial works on display in La Pietra are believed to have been collected by Acton‚Äôs parents in the 1920s and 1930s, but are from the 17th and 18th century, when bourgeoisie owners of such statues ‚Äì made by local craftsmen in Italy ‚Äì wanted their homes to emulate those of aristocratic families. ‚ÄúBlackamoors were currency. People were buying and trading them. They were in the rooms where people were having parties and socialising. These objects became synonymous with what it meant to be an upper middle-class person,‚Äù said Prof Awam Amkpa, curator of the NYU exhibit. Amkpa says the ‚Äúcontext of objectification‚Äù of black bodies is continuing, even as progress has been made to stamp out historical objectification. Whether it is images on the news of police shootings in the US against ‚Äì predominantly ‚Äì black men, the presence of African migrants in Europe, or atrocities in Africa, such as the kidnapping and raping of women by the Boko Haram in Nigeria, Amkpa says the exhibit puts today‚Äôs objectification of the black body in the context of history. Blackamoor imagery has even seen a revival in some fashion houses, including Dolce & Gabbana in their spring 2013 show. The NYU exhibit has also highlighted Italy‚Äôs own particular colonial relationship with Africa, which Toscano says is not often discussed in Italy today. Slaves were brought to Italy on Portuguese ships, Toscano says, and were used as house servants during the renaissance. ‚ÄúThere is a record of the Sassetti family ‚Äì the family that built La Pietra ‚Äì buying a slave girl. There is a chapel and a painting where all the children of the family are depicted and there is a black girl off to the side, which we assume was her,‚Äù Toscano says. Slavery in Italy was different to that in America, she says. It did not endure ‚Äì unlike the US ‚Äì and children born to black mothers and white fathers were free, taking on the status of a white person. Local factories in Florence and Venice still produce Blackamoors, which Amkpa says wealthy people still buy. But today they are also being sold in Africawhere they are purchased by wealthy people in Angola and Nigeria, he says. ‚ÄúIt is kind of stunning, but that tells you that it is not just about race but about class and aspirations of people who have come into money and want to live up to the stereotype of that wealth.‚Äù

column4: Creationist hopes his fossil find will get two plaques ‚Äì one fitting his world view
column5: If a Canadian museum decides to exhibit a recent fossil discovery, the man who found it, Edgar Nernberg, hopes it will be displayed with two plaques. One would contain local paleontologists‚Äô explanation, that the fossil is around 60 million years old. The other would explain Nernberg‚Äôs view that his find is from the past 6,000 years, after the world began. Nernberg is a long-time excavator, fossil collector and creationist. He believes in the biblical history of the creation of the world, not the scientifically accepted one. The Calgary Sun newspaper, to which he has sent between 30 and 40 letters on the subject, has said he is the ‚Äúgreatest promoter of creationism in Alberta‚Äù. Fossils found in Alberta are the property of the province, but in keeping with Canada‚Äôs trademark reasonableness, Nernberg said he was comfortable with his find going to scientists whose beliefs were ‚Äúdiametrically opposed‚Äù to his. ‚ÄúWe agreed to disagree but we‚Äôre amicable about it,‚Äù he said. Nernberg‚Äôs discovery ‚Äì which he called a ‚Äú10 out of 10‚Äù and the University of Calgary described as ‚Äúastounding‚Äù ‚Äì is roughly 4ft-square and includes five fossilized fish. Nernberg found it while digging a basement for a new home in the Paskapoo Formation, a roughly 60-million-year-old rock formation under Calgary. ‚ÄúThe first thing I said to myself is: ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre coming home with me,‚Äô‚Äù said Nernberg. ‚ÄúThe second thing I said is: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm going to have to get a fishing license.‚Äô‚Äù Nernberg contacted paleontologist Darla Zelenitsky about the fossil. She said it was one of the only fish fossil finds in Calgary in the last few decades. ‚ÄúBecause complete fossils are relatively rare from this time period in Alberta, any such discoveries are significant as they shed light on the nature and diversity of animals that lived not long after the extinction of the dinosaurs,‚Äù said Zelenitsky, an assistant professor at the University of Calgary, in a statement. ‚ÄúThese fossil fish are important because they are very primitive representatives of a large group of bony fish known today.‚Äù Nernberg said he was happy his fossil was going to the Royal Tyrrell Museum, even though the museum uses scientific explanations of the world with which he fundamentally disagrees. ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôd like to maintain possession of it, but then only a few people would see it,‚Äù he said. This is why the fossil will not be on display at the Big Valley Creationist Museum, which is about 70 kilometers away. Nernberg donated money to help create the museum, which includes a replica of Noah‚Äôs Ark that he built. The museum‚Äôs exhibits are designed to provide geological proof of the great flood described in the Bible and show that dinosaurs and humans lived at the same time. Nernberg believes the science museum has the best tools to prepare and maintain his fish fossil. The museum has invited him to watch the process and is making him a replica of his find. When it does go on display though, he hopes two plaques will account for the fossil‚Äôs history. ‚ÄúI would hope they would do it willingly,‚Äù he said.

column4: Justice for Jos√©? Border shooting of Mexican teen raises constitutional issue
column5:
Anger, pain and disbelief rang in the voice of Araceli Rodr√≠guez as she talked about her son‚Äôs killing by an American agent, whose 10 rounds shot through a border fence have raised questions over policing and whether the US constitution can apply to a Mexican teenager on foreign soil. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs still a part of me,‚Äù Rodr√≠guez said of her son, Jos√© Antonio Elena Rodr√≠guez, who was 16 when border patrol agent Lonnie Swartz shot him dead in October 2012. ‚ÄúEven though he‚Äôs not here he‚Äôs still my son in spirit, in soul, in thoughts, in words. My son, my son, my son.‚Äù She remembered him in terms any mother would find familiar, through his hopes and everyday joys. ‚ÄúHe liked cloudy days, chocolate cookies, spending time with his sisters,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe was a 16-year-old boy who would today be 19, full of passion for life [and] love. He wanted to be a soldier, to serve his country, to know what life is. ‚ÄúHe was a wonderful son, and they snatched that away from in a moment. It‚Äôs unforgivable.‚Äù Rodr√≠guez‚Äôs grief has turned to anger and bafflement over the delays and twists of the American justice system. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see the case to have a trial, or why there are so many questions when it‚Äôs clear that he was murdered,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not just saying that ‚Äì it‚Äôs a reality. They threw away his life.‚Äù But to the US, Jos√© Antonio‚Äôs killing raises serious and knotty questions about the role of the border patrol and the potential impunity of its agents when acting on one side of the border with effects on the other. Last year, with a federal investigation dragging on and the statute of limitations for a civil suit drawing near, Rodr√≠guez sued in federal court. She aims to bring evidence against Swartz before a judge and jury. ‚ÄúThe whole world knows what justice would be,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúTo have my son‚Äôs killers pay for what they did, that would be justice.‚Äù Agents rushed in Although the Justice Department has refused to release its video of what happened at the border on the night of 10 October 2012, Rodr√≠guez‚Äôs attorneys have pieced together events from witness accounts. Neither the government nor Swartz‚Äôs attorney have disputed this version of the facts. Jos√© Antonio was walking down a road along the border fence in Nogales, Mexico, the attorneys say, as border patrol agents and local police officers swarmed in response to a 911 call about men scrambling across the border. As those men climbed the 18ft fence back into Mexico, agents rushed in. The police report on the incident says that people began to throw rocks.
As the suspects ran past Rodr√≠guez, Swartz reached the fence, pointed his gun through a small gap between posts, and fired his weapon 12 times. He hit the teenager with 10 rounds, an autopsy showed ‚Äì eight of them in the back. Rodr√≠guez died about 30ft from the bluff on which the fence stands. The border patrol initially suggested that Rodr√≠guez was among those throwing rocks. Witnesses said the teen was only walking home from playing basketball. The federal government quickly announced it would investigate whether Swartz had used excessive force. An investigation continues and was cited in the government‚Äôs choice not to comment for this story. When Rodr√≠guez‚Äôs mother sued, the Justice Department recused itself from defending Swartz, saying he could still face criminal charges. Swartz‚Äôs attorney, Sean Chapman, also declined to comment on pending litigation. But he argued in court that although the shooting was ‚Äúhorrible and tragic‚Äù, his client could not be held liable. He urged the judge to dismiss the case outright, arguing the US constitution did not apply to foreign citizens on foreign soil, at least until the supreme court explicitly stated otherwise. Cross-border impunity ‚ÄúThe attorney is saying that the day the agent shot Jos√© Antonio he was protected, because from a constitutional perspective there was no clearly established law,‚Äù said Lu√≠s Parra, a lawyer for the Rodr√≠guez family. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre of the opinion that that‚Äôs absurd. The agent would be acting with total impunity, and we reject that. The family rejects that. They want justice. They want the Department of Homeland Security to start being transparent about what their officers are doing.‚Äù The Rodr√≠guez legal team alleges that Swartz violated both the fourth and fifth amendments of the constitution, because he shot Rodr√≠guez without justification, and say that in the right circumstances, the US constitution protects foreigners abroad.
Lee Gelernt, a senior attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union and a professor at Fordham University, argued the case in court this week. ‚ÄúThe constitution applies because the border patrol agent was on US soil,‚Äù Gelernt told the Guardian. ‚ÄúThe only thing that happened in Mexico was the bullet hitting the young man. The test the supreme court has set for determining when the constitution applies to an action across the border is a very practical test.‚Äù Gelernt asked the judge to weigh the facts of the case, and not to set a ‚Äúbright line rule‚Äù saying the constitution does not apply ‚Äúbecause Jos√© Antonio was a Mexican citizen on Mexican soil and that that‚Äôs the heart of it‚Äù. ‚ÄúA bright line rule would have enormous ramifications,‚Äù Gelernt said, before laying out Chapman‚Äôs argument. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs saying an agent can shoot on the US side but can‚Äôt be hit with constitutional liability ‚Äì even though the actions may have been criminal, even on US soil, with the gun up to the fence, and shots through the fence that killed a civilian Mexican teenager for no reason.‚Äù In the 2008 case Boumediene v Bush, the supreme court ruled that the constitution extends beyond US territory except in ‚Äúimpractical or anomalous‚Äù circumstances. Gelernt contrasted that case, which dealt with Guant√°namo Bay, and this one: ‚ÄúThis was not a military case. Jos√© Antonio was not accused of a crime, he was not sneaking over the border, and he had the right not to be arbitrarily killed.‚Äù In court, Chapman brought up a more recent case: that of a 15-year-old boy, Sergio Adrian Hern√°ndez, who was shot dead in an altercation with the border patrol in 2010. In April a federal appeals court ruled that the teen‚Äôs family could not sue because the fourth amendment could not be asserted by a Mexican citizen on Mexican soil. On the fifth amendment, the five judges of the fifth circuit ruled: ‚ÄúNo case law in 2010, when this episode occurred, reasonably warned [the agent] that his conduct violated the fifth amendment.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe may not like it, but the law is the law,‚Äù Chapman said. The ambiguity in the law may yet come before the supreme court again, however, since the losing side in the Rodr√≠guez case will likely appeal, raising the case to a higher court. Should the ninth circuit appeals court eventually rule in that the constitution applied to Rodr√≠guez, contradicting the fifth circuit ruling, the case could force the supreme court to resolve questions of impunity and the constitutional rights of non-Americans abroad. Overlooked killings Recent reports and investigations into the use of force by the border patrol have produced damning conclusions. In 2013 a Customs and Border Protection review found that between 67 reported abuses, including 19 that resulted in deaths, the border patrol showed a ‚Äúlack of diligence‚Äù and that agents often shot at suspects in cars, endangering bystanders, passengers and each other. An investigation by the Arizona Republic found that between 2005 and 2013 at least 42 people were killed by border patrol and customs officers, including 13 Americans. Officials said at the time that agents who used excessive force were disciplined, but the investigation noted that ‚Äúin none of the 42 deaths is any agent or officer publicly known to have faced consequences‚Äù. The Mexican government has lodged complaints about several of the shootings, and in January backed the Hern√°ndez family in court. Border patrol officials say their use-of-force policy mandates that agents not fire their weapons absent a ‚Äúreasonable belief‚Äù of ‚Äúimminent danger‚Äù. As in the cases of police officers accused of abuses, agents have cited this controversial grey area in the rule when explaining their actions in deadly incidents. Lu√≠s Parra drew comparisons between the federal agency and police departments, noting that with more than 21,000 agents, the border patrol amounts to one of the largest police forces in the nation, second only to the NYPD and nearly twice as large as the Chicago PD. ‚ÄúYou look at the cases out of Missouri, New York and Baltimore, and the set of facts that occurred here, and you would believe that there would be a huge uproar about Jos√© Antonio,‚Äù Parra said, referring to recent, high-profile deaths of African American men at the hands of police. ‚ÄúAnd in those cases there are at least answers, if not justice. It‚Äôs been a real frustration to the family not having an answers as to why this 16-year-old boy was shot 10 times, eight times in the back.‚Äù Araceli Rodr√≠guez vented that frustration at length, posing rhetorical questions that the US courts are taking literally. ‚ÄúWhat I want to ask the American authorities is: ‚ÄòWhat is your law, then? What does justice mean to you? What could be more important than justice?‚Äô ‚ÄúThey know they have murderers working for them and they still pay and protect them.‚Äù She said she still felt hope, despite the long road through the courts ahead. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want my son to be forgotten,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI want people to keep talking.‚Äù

column4: Facelift for little-known Paris pagoda that houses 10-metre Mir√≥ Buddha
column5:
Hidden in a wood on the outskirts of Paris is an African pavilion-turned-pagoda that houses the largest Buddha in Europe, made in the Paris atelier of the Spanish artist Joan Mir√≥. The Grande Pagode is an eclectic cultural, religious and artistic treasure, but most of those strolling and jogging around the Lac Daumesnil in the Bois de Vincennes, do not even know it is there. Now France‚Äôs Buddhist community, which celebrated the reopening of the pagoda this weekend after a ‚Ç¨1m (¬£720,000) facelift, is hoping to attract new visitors. Unveiling the renovated listed building, Liliane Lefait, administrator of the French Buddhist Union ‚Äì an umbrella group for several Buddhist organisations set up following the waves of immigration from Vietnam and south Asia in the 1960s ‚Äì said: ‚ÄúThis place is open for everyone and anyone to visit. It‚Äôs a very calming, peaceful place. I feel calm just coming here, even without praying.‚Äù Despite it being 28 metres (92ft) high, you cannot see the pagoda for the trees. It was originally built in 1931 as the Cameroon pavilion for the international colonial exhibition and was constructed to resemble a traditional African home ‚Äì but three times the size ‚Äì using long-established materials and decorations.
When the exhibition closed, most of the buildings were torn down, but the Cameroon pavilion and neighbouring Togo building, both constructed of wood, were left standing. The pavilion briefly became the Museum of Wood, before the site was acquired by France‚Äôs International Buddhist Institute and transformed into the Grande Pagode, home to the 10-metre-high (33ft) golden buddha statue, which was created in six parts in Mir√≥‚Äôs atelier and reassembled in situ.
Lost among the foliage, the building fell slowly into disrepair over the past four decades until the Paris city authorities acquired the site and came up with the funds to renovate it. ‚ÄúThe Asian members of the Buddhist community were quite zen about it even though it really is an important place for them to meet and share occasions. But when holy people came from Asia, where they have wonderful pagodas that are well-kept and decorated, they were shocked at the state of ours,‚Äù Lefait told the Guardian. ‚ÄúNow we are absolutely delighted with it.‚Äù The pagoda is open intermittently from April to October on holiday weekends.

column4: Stonewall chief: 'It‚Äôs a better time to be gay than it was. But not for all'
column5:
Stonewall has its offices on the 13th floor of a condemned block by Waterloo station, but its chief executive has a particular reason to be fond of the crumbling edifice that houses the LGBT rights organisation. ‚ÄúThis building used to be occupied by the Department of Education,‚Äù explains Ruth Hunt. ‚ÄúSection 28 was devised in the place that Stonewall now works out of ‚Äì there‚Äôs something satisfying about that.‚Äù Even more so with the organisation rolling out a groundbreaking anti-homophobia campaign in schools, including faith schools, funded by the DoE, nearly 30 years after the passing of the Conservatives‚Äô controversial law to prevent what they saw as the promotion of homosexuality. Almost half a million pounds will go towards training local groups to become ‚Äúeducation champions‚Äù and deliver training on LGBT equality in schools, where, says Hunt, ‚Äúwe have a very big problem‚Äù. According to Stonewall research, 75,000 young people were bullied last year for being gay; 90% of secondary school teachers have witnessed homophobic bullying in schools, but only 17% have received training to tackle it.
‚ÄúSo many young lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans people have an awful time at school,‚Äù Hunt says. ‚ÄúTeachers don‚Äôt necessarily feel equipped to deal with this bullying either. It‚Äôs essential that teachers get the right training so they can stop and prevent homophobic, biphobic and transphobic bullying. We need to teach young people about diversity ‚Äì including different families ‚Äì so they can live, work, and socialise in 21st-century Britain.‚Äù It has been a frenetic first six months for the head of the UK‚Äôs largest LGBT-rights organisation. In that time, Stonewall has begun to represent trans people after years of dispute and resentment ‚Äì a move Hunt describes as ‚Äúa real joy‚Äù. In its dealings with the transgender community in the past, Stonewall, as she bluntly puts it, ‚Äúcocked up‚Äù. Originally, the organisation was wary of dwarfing smaller trans groups, but worked alongside Press For Change, a gender identity organisation. ‚ÄúIt was about doing what we could to empower the trans community by not doing T,‚Äù she says. But she is clear that ‚Äì whatever the original intentions ‚Äì Stonewall let the trans community down. ‚ÄúWe made a series of cockups, so it didn‚Äôt look like we were trying to support people, it looked like we were a bit crap,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWe invited speakers with a transphobic history, we nominated them for awards, we made a film for secondary schools which included the word ‚Äútranny‚Äù unhelpfully [...] we were often in positions of privilege and opportunity with ministers where we could have talked about trans issues. By not doing, we were doing more harm.‚Äù Winning back that trust has been ‚Äúbloody hard‚Äù. In an initial meeting with about 50 of Stonewall‚Äôs fiercest critics, she told them the organisation was weaker for their absence. ‚ÄúIt was never about, ‚Äòdon‚Äôt worry Stonewall is here and we can help you‚Äô, it was about ‚Äòwe are all weakened by this and actually we all have something to gain‚Äô.‚Äù Hunt worked for Stonewall for nine years before becoming chief executive, taking over from Ben Summerskill, who was in the role for a decade. Since taking up the top job, she has had to rapidly develop a thick skin. She‚Äôs been criticised for being too timid ‚Äì for example for not joining a boycott of the Dorchester hotel, owned by the Sultan of Brunei, who gave approval to Brunei‚Äôs new penal code, which urges death by stoning for same-sex sexual activity. Sometimes, doing the right thing for campaigners on the ground and being seen to do the right thing by her own UK base can clash. ‚ÄúWe have now bred a generation of campaigners who think hashtag bring back our girls, hashtag boycott, is in some way contributing to that social movement internationally, but it isn‚Äôt always the most helpful way of going about things,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a constant stretch internally when I‚Äôm going, ‚Äòcome on, let‚Äôs get out there and say stuff‚Äô and our team is saying ‚Äòwell, actually that‚Äôs not helpful‚Äô.‚Äù Hunt is only 35 (‚ÄúI lack gravitas. But I‚Äôm all right with that,‚Äù she says) and, of course, she‚Äôs a woman. Does that bring its own challenges? ‚ÄúYes. But I think that it is generally a different experience for women in leadership,‚Äù she offers. ‚ÄúI get accused of running a dyke mafia ‚Äì by virtue of me being a lesbian. I have to work harder to demonstrate that I get it ‚Äì people expect me not to be as effective as I am sometimes. But we have a very traditional support base. They love Stonewall and they worked with Ben for 10 years and it is going to take time to gain their trust.‚Äù She‚Äôs also had comments on her style and hair and has been told she is ‚Äútoo designer‚Äù. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think Ben ever got such observations about his style or his glasses, his hair, and it‚Äôs new to me,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not something I‚Äôm comfortable with, or used to, and I am toughening up fast.‚Äù Hunt has also been criticised for her faith. She is a Catholic who still goes to church, but was ‚Äúnaive‚Äù enough to imagine it wouldn‚Äôt come under scrutiny. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been harder for me to come out as a Catholic than it was to come out as a lesbian ‚Äì easily,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAt least I had the backing of a community when I came out as a lesbian.‚Äù Faith can still be a real barrier to gay people being able to exercise their rights, despite historic legislation that enabled gay couples to marry last year. ‚ÄúIt is doing significant damage to people‚Äôs mental health ‚Äì we have to do something about it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThere are also many faith leaders who are gay and many faith leaders who are distressed by the constant exclusion of LGBT people from their communities and parishes.‚Äù As for the pope, Hunt says he needs to decide on his message and exactly what he wants to achieve. ‚ÄúI think he oscillates wildly between different positions,‚Äù she says ‚Äì though she is realistic about the chances of her getting his attention. ‚ÄúI think there is more Stonewall can do, but then I don‚Äôt think Pope Francis is going to be tweeting me directly anytime soon for top tips on how to run the Vatican,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúStill ... we‚Äôre happy to help them set up their LGBT network as soon as they say the word.‚Äù With the passing of major legislative landmarks in the UK ‚Äì the gay marriage bill, equal parenting rights, rights in the workplace ‚Äì one of the major challenges facing Stonewall today is not the establishment, but apathy. ‚ÄúWe are a movement that has been motivated by individual interest in our own rights and we have a challenge now to shift to a place where we are interested in other people‚Äôs rights ‚Äì and that‚Äôs hard,‚Äù she says. Although one of Stonewall‚Äôs aim should be ‚Äúto stop functioning one day‚Äù, Hunt thinks there is still much to fight for. Hate crimes against LGBT people remain stubbornly high ‚Äì one in six LGBT people have experienced a hate crime but three quarters did not report to police, according to Stonewall research. ‚ÄúReporting rates are still as low as ever, conviction rate is still as low as ever ‚Äì it‚Äôs the one area where we have made no impact.‚Äù Hate is a long way from being obliterated, she says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a better time to be gay than it was. But only for some, not for all,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThere is still so much going on that we don‚Äôt know the half of, so we‚Äôre not stopping yet by any means, even if it doesn‚Äôt lend itself to the side of a bus like it once did.‚Äù

column4: Schools reopen in earthquake-devastated Nepal
column5:
Hundreds of thousands of Nepalese children have returned to school in Nepal for the first time since two earthquakes last month killed more than 8,700 people and injured 23,000. Schools have been shut in the poverty-stricken south Asian state since the tremors, which left thousands of classrooms badly damaged. At the Adarsha Saula Yubak Higher secondary school in the small village of Khokana, about 10 miles south of Kathmandu, red stickers indicated the cracked buildings were unsafe. As children filed into wooden huts constructed in the school grounds by parents and volunteers, the school‚Äôs principal, Saroj Bhakta Acharya, addressed the students, telling them not to be afraid. ‚ÄúWe will resume our school in this bamboo made hut so do not worry about the earthquake,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe will spend a week, playing and talking about good things.‚Äù
Acharya told students that school uniform was not compulsory for those who had lost their possessions and called for a minute‚Äôs silence for student Rupa Maharjan, 15, who was killed in the earthquake. Of the school‚Äôs 1,300 students, only half were present. ‚ÄúWe can understand their mood,‚Äù said Acharya. ‚ÄúOut of our 56 teachers, 16 of them have lost their houses completely and are still living outside.‚Äù Though aid agencies and local authorities have tried to find alternatives, almost a million children across Nepal are still without classrooms. Hari Prasad Aryal, the district education officer of Gorkha district, the epicentre of the 25 April quake, said almost 80% of the area‚Äôs schools resumed classes on Sunday though few students attended. Almost all the schools in the district had been severely damaged. ‚ÄúIn those areas where people are living away from their villages in camps, we have asked school administrations to run temporary schools at the area where people have been staying,‚Äù he said. The task of rebuilding tens of thousands of schools is a huge burden for Nepal. Officials have said total reconstruction costs for the country will be $7bn (¬£4.6bn), a third of the annual GDP. Some estimates are as high as $20bn. Millions have been left homeless. In Dolakha district, which was badly hit in the second earthquake, about half of the 450 schools reopened on Sunday, with around half their students attending on average, said the district education chief, Lok Bahadur Lopchan. ‚ÄúWe are running schools from a temporary shelters,‚Äù Lopchan said. ‚ÄúWe are hoping more students will come to school in coming days.‚Äù In Khokana, parents described children who were still frightened of being inside. Gita Shahi, 35, said her seven-year-old daughter was afraid. ‚ÄúWe are still living in the field under the tarpaulins, ‚Äù she said. However, Sabina Shahi, 11, said she was pleased to see her friends again. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs better to be in the school though I am scared of another earthquake,‚Äù she said. Unicef has warned the disaster could reverse the progress Nepal has made in education over the last 25 years, during which primary school enrolment has risen from 64% to more than 95%. ‚ÄúThe longer children stay home, the more difficult it will be for them to return to school,‚Äù Tomoo Hozumi, Unicef‚Äôs Nepal representative, told AFP. Chhori Laxmi Maharjan, a clinical psychologist at the Ankur counselling centre, Kathmandu, said going to school would help children. ‚ÄúWhat they were doing before the earthquake was going to school, playing with friends and having a certain routine,‚Äù Maharjan said. ‚ÄúThis will help them them heal.‚Äù

column4: Canadian law professors challenge 'colonial' law on royal succession
column5: A law enacted in Canada to ensure the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge‚Äôs first-born child could become head of state regardless of gender was unconstitutional and smacked of colonialism, a Canadian court will hear. Almost two years after the birth of Prince George, two law professors from Quebec‚Äôs Laval university are to challenge a law enacted to ensure that, had the duchess given birth to daughter, the child could become Queen. The case, which starts on Monday in a court in Quebec, will examine the constitutional history of Canada and its legal relationship with the UK. Genevi√®ve Motard and Patrick Taillon, both professors of constitutional law, will argue that, although the British monarch is Canada‚Äôs head of state, the UK is a foreign country, and the Canadian parliament merely ‚Äúassented‚Äù to the changes made by the British parliament and did not properly amend Canadian law. ‚ÄúThe position seems to be that, still, British law applies automatically in Canada, which we consider to be a colonial position, and it‚Äôs a throwback to ancient times,‚Äù said Andr√© Binette, one of the legal team representing Motard and Taillon. The case stems from 2011, when the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were newly married and expected to start a family. The 15 member countries of the Commonwealth where the Queen is head of state hastily agreed to modernise succession laws. The changes allowed a first-born child, regardless of gender, to succeed to the throne and for a sovereign to marry a Catholic. Those 15 countries then introduced laws to reflect the changes and, in 2013, the Canadian parliament adopted an act ‚Äúassenting‚Äù to the alteration of the British royal succession. But, the professors will claim, it did so without consulting with the 10 provinces that make up Canada. The plaintiffs are not arguing whether an older daughter should have precedence over her younger brother in the line of succession. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not really about the content of the legal change. Of course, everybody agrees with gender equality,‚Äù Binette said. Rather, the object of the case was to determine to what extent the federal parliament could amend the constitution without the participation of the provinces, he said. Motard and Taillon, supported by the Quebec government, and Canadian Royal Heritage Trust, a monarchist organisation, contend that, because Canada is a sovereign state with its own constitution, its parliament must alter Canadian law to implement the royal succession reform. They will argue there is a Canadian law regarding succession, which determines who can become Canada‚Äôs head of state. In 1931, the statute of Westminster gave legal recognition to an independent Canada, but the British parliament had retained, at Canada‚Äôs request, the power to alter royal succession law. In 1982, however, the Canada Act severed any residual jurisdiction that the British parliament had over Canadian law, including Canadian royal succession, the plaintiffs will claim. ‚ÄúWhile Australia, New Zealand and the other Commonwealth members involved have made changes in their own laws in parallel to the British law, Canada has chosen simply to assent to the British law,‚Äù Binette said. ‚ÄúWe believe that the 1982 Canada Act has severed all remaining legal ties with the UK and that includes the monarchy.‚Äù The hearing, before Justice Claude Bouchard, of the superior court of Quebec, is expected to last 10 days. If the case succeeds, it could take three years for Canada to obtain the consent of all 10 provinces to enable it to change its royal succession law. ‚ÄúBut now there is no urgency because Princess Catherine had a boy,‚Äù Binette said.

column4: Yanis Varoufakis dismisses rumours he intends to resign as 'grossly premature'
column5:
Greece‚Äôs finance minister has denied he is on the brink of resigning, as his country prepares to enter a crucial month that could determine its future in the eurozone. Yanis Varoufakis rebuffed speculation that he could soon throw in the towel, less than five months after the leftwing Syriza party was voted in. Such talk is ‚Äúgrossly premature‚Äù, tweeted the economics professor-turned -politician.
He channelled the spirit of John Maynard Keynes, telling a follower ‚Äúin the long run we are all dead‚Äù ‚Äì but that in the medium term he is going nowhere.
Varoufakis‚Äôs position has looked less secure since the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, shaped his Brussels negotiating team, seemingly sidelining his finance minister. The finance ministry was also embroiled in a row after selecting economist Elena Panaritis to be Greece‚Äôs new representative at the International Monetary Fund. Some Syriza MPs had criticised the choice of Panaritis, who is a former MP for the leftwing Pasok party, which agreed Greece‚Äôs first bailout. Officials from Greece have been locked in talks with creditors over the weekend in an attempt to agree a package of economic reforms. Outstanding issues include pensions, labour market reform, VAT rates and Greece‚Äôs budget targets. Athens had hoped to reach a deal by Sunday, but insiders were suggesting a breakthrough could come within the next 48 hours. Jos√© Manuel Barroso, the former European commission president, warned on Sunday that it was vital to find a solution quickly. He told the BBC‚Äôs Andrew Marr show: ‚ÄúSometimes I get the impression that people are waiting for an accident so that they can really focus [on] avoiding a bigger disaster. It‚Äôs too long, this time that has been taken to find a solution. I believe it‚Äôs important now to find that solution.‚Äù The consequences of a Greek default, or its exit from the eurozone, would be negative for both Greece and Europe, Barroso added. Greece‚Äôs final tranche of bailout funds will remain frozen until agreement is reached, leaving it perilously short of money to pay a series of financial demands in June. Tsipras was understood to be planning a telephone call with the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, and French president, Fran√ßois Hollande, in the next couple of days. He is pushing for a political intervention to break the deadlock. Greece is scheduled to pay back ‚Ç¨1.6bn (¬£1.2bn) to the IMF in June, starting with a ‚Ç¨305m (¬£219m) payment on Friday, and analysts fear it will struggle to find the money. The possibility of Greece defaulting on its obligations to the IMF is causing ripples in the financial markets. Shares fell on Friday as the German finance minister, Wolfgang Sch√§uble, warned that the positive comments from Athens officials were ‚Äúnot fully reflected‚Äù in the talks with its creditors. Greece could hold all of its June IMF payments until the end of the month, which is also the date when its current bailout programme with the eurozone expires. It then faces making two repayments to the European Central Bank over the summer, totalling ‚Ç¨6.7bn (¬£4.8bn), which could be particularly challenging. ‚ÄúWe believe meeting the ‚Ç¨1.6bn in payments to the IMF by the end of June will be difficult. Payments of ‚Ç¨3.5bn on bonds held by the ECB on 20 July appear even more unlikely,‚Äù said Michael Gapen, an economist at Barclays.

column4: Russian entry ban on politicians shows EU sanctions are working, says Rifkind
column5:
Russia‚Äôs entry ban on 89 European politicians and military leaders shows sanctions against the country are working, Sir Malcolm Rifkind has said. The former foreign secretary and former deputy prime minister Nick Clegg are among the list of figures barred from entering the country. ‚ÄúIt shows we are making an impact because they wouldn‚Äôt have reacted unless they felt very sore at what had happened,‚Äù Rifkind told BBC Radio 5 Live. ‚ÄúOnce sanctions were extended, it‚Äôs had a major impact on the Russian economy. ‚ÄúThis has happened at a time when the oil price has collapsed and therefore a main source of revenue for Mr Putin has disappeared. That‚Äôs pretty important when it comes to his attempts to build up his military might and to force his neighbours to do what they‚Äôre told. ‚ÄúIf there had to be such a ban, I am rather proud to be on it ‚Äì I‚Äôd be rather miffed if I wasn‚Äôt,‚Äù he added. Rifkind‚Äôs comments came as the European Union responded with anger to Russia‚Äôs ban on politicians, calling it ‚Äútotally arbitrary and unjustified‚Äù. It said no explanation had been provided for the list, which was shared this week after several requests by diplomats for transparency. ‚ÄúThe list with 89 names has now been shared by the Russian authorities. We don‚Äôt have any other information on legal basis, criteria and process of this decision,‚Äù an EU spokesman said on Saturday. ‚ÄúWe consider this measure as totally arbitrary and unjustified, especially in the absence of any further clarification.‚Äù Many of the figures reportedly included on the list have previously spoken out against the Kremlin. Clegg urged his Liberal Democrat ministers to avoid attending last year‚Äôs Winter Olympics in Sochi because of Russia‚Äôs anti-gay laws. He also argued that the country should lose the right to host the 2018 World Cup after Russian troops allegedly downed the civilian airliner Flight MH17 in eastern Ukraine last July. Others reportedly barred include the general secretary of the EU council, Uwe Corsepius, the former EU enlargement chief, Stefan F√ºle, as well as British intelligence and military chiefs, including the MI5 director general, Andrew Parker, former MI6 chief Sir John Sawers and the chief of the defence staff, Gen Sir Nicholas Houghton. ‚ÄúI understand that they would like the sanctions removed; I want them removed and want to see good relations with Russia,‚Äù Rifkind said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very important that Russia, Britain and western Europe as a whole work amicably together, but we can‚Äôt ignore the fact that for the first time since the end of the second world war, part of the borders of a European territory has been violated by a military attack, and that is unacceptable.‚Äù Russia invaded Hungary and Czechoslovakia during uprisings in 1956 and 1968 respectively. A Russian foreign ministry official confirmed that the ban was a result of EU sanctions against Russia. ‚ÄúAn answer to some European countries demanding to explain why these names have been put on the lists of persons banned from entering Russia is quite simple ‚Äì this was done as a response to a sanctions campaign unleashed against Russia by some Germany-led countries of the European Union,‚Äù the unnamed official told Russian news agency Tass. The official said Russia had previously recommended that envoys of countries that have imposed sanctions on Russia should apply to Russian consular offices before their trips to check whether they are barred from entering the country. ‚ÄúHowever, our partners preferred not to do so and asked to notify them through diplomatic channels,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúJust one thing remains unclear: did our European co-workers want these lists to minimise inconveniences for potential ‚Äòdenied persons‚Äô or to stage a political show?‚Äù The UK foreign office said Russia‚Äôs action would not cause the EU to change its position on sanctions. ‚ÄúThe way for Russia to get the sanctions lifted is to remove its troops from Ukraine and comply with its obligations under the Minsk agreements,‚Äù a spokesperson said. ‚ÄúThe EU and member states are urgently seeking more transparency from the Russian authorities for this move.‚Äù The Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, said on Friday the Netherlands would not abide by the ban as it was ‚Äúnot based on international law, was not transparent and could not be challenged in a court of law‚Äù. The German foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, said the list would hamper peace efforts. ‚ÄúAt a time in which we are trying to defuse a persistent and dangerous conflict, this does not contribute towards that,‚Äù he said.
Swedish MEP Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, who was among the list of barred names, tweeted: ‚ÄúBeing on this list does not change my commitment to the people of Ukraine,‚Äù while the former Czech foreign minister Karel Schwarzenberg welcomed his inclusion, stating: ‚ÄúWhen I saw the other names, I found out I was in a very decent club. I consider this a reward.‚Äù Sanctions were imposed on Russia after the country annexed Ukraine‚Äôs Crimea region in March 2014. More than 6,200 people have been killed in fighting between Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian separatists. But Russia has repeatedly dismissed accusations from Ukraine, Nato and western powers that it is supporting the separatists with arms and troops. This article was amended on 1 June 2015. Rifkind said Russia‚Äôs role in the Ukraine crisis was the first time since the end of the second world war that the borders of a European territory had been violated by a military attack. In fact, Russian troops entered Hungary and Czechoslovakia during uprisings in 1956 and 1968 respectively. This has been clarified.

column4: Whether Greece does a deal or defaults, the prospects seem equally grim
column5:
As Greek prime minister Alexis Tsipras and his finance minister Yanis Varoufakis have discovered the hard way, international financial deal-making is a world away from the thrill of a barnstorming election campaign. But with Varoufakis sidelined after a series of less-than-helpful public interventions, Tsipras and his colleagues appear to be in the final stages of agreeing a deal with the country‚Äôs eurozone creditors and the International Monetary Fund ‚Äì renamed the ‚ÄúBrussels Group‚Äù to assuage the Greek public‚Äôs hatred of the ‚Äútroika‚Äù. Every day last week saw a fog of claims and counterclaims about how much progress was being made by officials in Brussels and their political bosses, who discussed the issue on the sidelines of the G7 summit in Dresden. But there is at last a feeling that both sides are making progress. If Tsipras pulls off a deal and skirts default, it will be a political and personal triumph, in the face of extraordinary odds. And if he can persuade Greek voters to back him in the messy compromises he will inevitably have to make to win over the lenders ‚Äì especially the IMF, which is reportedly taking a particularly tough line ‚Äì it will be close to miraculous. As Gabriel Sterne of Oxford Economics pointed out last week, while two-thirds of the Greek public believe Syriza should be willing to compromise, almost 60% thought that should not include pension reform ‚Äì likely to be a red line for creditors. Sterne believes there is now almost a 50/50 chance that the country could be forced out of the single currency.
The sad truth for the Greek people is that none of the roads ahead of them looks anything but grindingly hard. This is a country where GDP collapsed by a quarter in the aftermath of the crisis; where unemployment remains above 25%; and where average wages fell by almost 18% in real terms between 2008 and 2013. The latest reports suggest that Angela Merkel and Fran√ßois Hollande will discuss the issue with European commission president Jean-Claude Juncker on Monday. But with every day of fruitless talks that passes, bank deposits drain out of Greece as nervous savers squirrel their money abroad, investors postpone spending plans and holidaymakers opt for Ibiza instead of Crete, for fear of being caught out by a summer Greccident. Bank deposits have hit a 10-year low, according to the latest data. And the political turmoil has strangled the tentative economic recovery that got under way last year. Separate figures released last week confirmed that Greece has slipped back into recession. If a deal is done, the country is likely to face another bout of painful structural reforms and stringent spending cuts, to satisfy the Brussels Group that it‚Äôs not throwing good money after bad ‚Äì and there appears little hope that the debt forgiveness Tsipras and Varoufakis once so stirringly advocated will be part of the package. That means Greece will still face hefty repayments, and the scrutiny of its paymasters, for years to come. And if no deal is forthcoming by the 30 June deadline both sides appear to have set (though Athens must cobble together the money for several debt repayments before then), then Greece faces the risky and uncertain prospect of defaulting on its debts and crashing out of the euro. Euro-exit would at least come with the benefits of a drastic devaluation in the currency ‚Äì a New Drachma, perhaps. Hordes of holidaymakers would presumably follow, keen to take advantage of the cut-price ouzo, and over time Greece might be able to attract inward investment as a cheap location for manufacturing for the European market. But in the short-term, Grexit would mean capital controls, financial market chaos, and soaring inflation. The Greek people have already endured extraordinary hardship. But as another debt deadline looms, it‚Äôs hard to foresee an outcome that will bring anything but more tough times ahead. Amazon tax battle goes on There has been outrage that Amazon, by routing transactions through a Luxembourg-based company called Amazon EU Sarl, has diverted sales worth billions of pounds and euros out of major markets such as Germany, France and the UK ‚Äî thus ensuring that resulting profits are beyond the reach of tax authorities in those countries. Last week, in the face of a tax crackdown by George Osborne ‚Äì and probable similar moves across Europe ‚Äì it emerged that Amazon has caved in. It has begun opening Amazon EU Sarl branches in all its major European markets, and sales are now flowing through these branches, where any profits will be taxed. It is an important victory. But make no mistake: Amazon has not given up the fight. There are fierce battles to come before the retailer pays much corporation tax in Europe. Round two has already begun. This second struggle concerns the tax affairs of Amazon EU Sarl itself. Given that this is where most of Amazon‚Äôs European revenues are pooled, you might expect it to have large taxable profits. You would be wrong. Amazon EU Sarl ‚Äì which has little in the way of conventional running costs ‚Äî has paid little or no tax for much of its life. The reason for this lies with the royalties Amazon EU Sarl pays to a controversial partnership called Amazon Europe Holding Technologies SCS, which are tax deductible. AEHT is also based in Luxembourg, but has its partners back in the US. Thanks to a Luxembourg tax ruling, these royalties wash straight through AEHT, untaxed. In the US these payments go untaxed again, lost in a mismatch of tax rules between America and Luxembourg. The European commission is fighting to unravel this tax arrangement, but Amazon will resist fiercely. Without a breakthrough on this second front, the first victory ‚Äì getting Amazon to recognise UK transactions in a taxable UK entity ‚Äì is hollow. Those boycotting the company over its tax affairs should be under no illusion: the battle is not won. Master of universe out of touch with real world Dick Fuld ‚Äì the man once known on Wall Street as ‚Äúthe gorilla‚Äù ‚Äì has had more than six years to ponder what went wrong at Lehman Brothers, the once-mighty American investment bank that he used to run. So when he made his first public remarks since the 2008 crisis last week, his audience was eager to hear the fruits of his reflections. His answer? An unforeseeable perfect storm of forces swept away the Wall Street institution. But, ultimately, the fault could be traced back to politicians in Washington, for promoting the ‚ÄúAmerican dream‚Äù of home ownership for low earners, leaving them exposed when interest rates rose. The gorilla himself, evidently, was entirely innocent. Fuld may be an extreme example of the dangerous beasts that once roamed the financial jungle. But his unrepentant performance was a stark reminder of the gulf that still remains between Wall Street and the real world.

column4: Anna Erelle: ‚ÄòIn front of me was this man who had killed women and children‚Äô
column5: Anna Erelle is the pseudonym of a French journalist who spent a month undercover investigating the secretive world of jihadi brides for a Paris magazine. Last year, she created a fake Facebook profile under the name of M√©lodie, a 20-year-old recent convert to Islam. During the course of her investigations, she made contact with Abou Bilel, a notorious Islamic State fighter, who asked her to travel to Syria to be his wife. Her subsequent article led to Isis issuing a fatwa against her. Today, she lives under police protection and cannot reveal her true identity. Her book, In the Skin of a Jihadist, is published next month. One of the things that surprised me about Abou Bilel is that he used emoticons in his interactions with you‚Ä¶ Like a teenager! But he was twice the age of M√©lodie and he was talking like he was as young as she was. Was it stressful leading a double life? At the time, everything moved so quickly I didn‚Äôt have time to think about me. I had always to think about M√©lodie and her next step, the next lie‚Ä¶ Since the book, I realised maybe I was more affected than I thought. It‚Äôs like the aftermath of an earthquake. Did you ever feel guilty about lying? No. For a few minutes at the beginning, maybe, just before taking on the identity of M√©lodie. At first, I felt I was a journalist, I didn‚Äôt want to lie about my job, but then in front of me was this killer who had killed women and children and so many people. A few months after, when I heard that he had died [there are conflicting reports about whether Abou Bilel is alive or dead], I thought for a few minutes ‚Äì and they were long, hard minutes ‚Äì whether it was my fault he died because he‚Äôd told me too much and the organisation had killed him for that. I cried, actually, because I don‚Äôt want to be involved in the death of anybody, even the worst person in the world. Was there anything you liked about Abou Bilel the more you got to know him? Nothing. I think I always try to find a little bit of good in a person, I look for it. But I tried to search for it in him for one month and I didn‚Äôt find it. He is someone without humanity. What is the attraction for young women who fly out to Syria and Iraq to join Isis forces? Multiple reasons. First, these are girls who are maybe too naive. They really think they will help the population, so they go for that. But now, for one year or so, we have seen a lot of girls going to Syria or Iraq because they think they will make a good marriage and become somebody very important when they are married to a powerful man. The scary stuff is that the girls are now as drunk on power as the men. I was thinking about the three girls in your country [Kadiza Sultana, Shamima Begum and Amira Abase, who flew to Syria from east London in February] who went and it was so sad because they went to join one of their best friends [Sharmeena Begum] and I thought: ‚ÄúMy God. They saw how this girl‚Äôs family had been destroyed and they still went.‚Äù And they went, smiling like nothing was wrong! Do you think part of the allure is that they believe they will become famous? Probably yes, for some of them. For some, it‚Äôs not a game, it‚Äôs a goal ‚Äì they want to help. For others, it‚Äôs a little bit‚Ä¶ not fashion‚Ä¶ but yeah, all these people want a little bit of success, they want to be famous. They want to put their name in the story of Isis so when they arrive, they are happy to go on Twitter to show how powerful they are. Do you think the rise of social networking has helped Isis? Yes, but it‚Äôs not just social networking, it‚Äôs the way they use it. They are very intelligent in the way they communicate. Before, terrorism was not like this ‚Äì it was secret and insidious. But then they went on Twitter and Facebook and said: ‚ÄúYes, we are murderers. You can be like us. Do you want to come?‚Äù And lots of people said yes! It appeals to a generation that feels lost, doesn‚Äôt see any future. They think in Syria, everything is possible. When have you been most scared throughout this process? The day I discovered there was a fatwa against me on the internet. I wasn‚Äôt scared of Abou Bilel but the first time I Skyped him and saw him in a car with high technology [the back of his car contained a bulletproof vest and an Uzi submachine gun], it was really intense. Do you have any regrets? No. Not a single thing because I did my job. I don‚Äôt know if I did it well, but I did it with a lot of precautions. Today, I don‚Äôt regret it because I learned a lot about Isis and I learned a lot about me too: where are the lines, the boundaries, which I will not cross. Since the Charlie Hebdo atrocity, you‚Äôve been under police protection. What has that been like? To begin with, I had police at my place and every time I went for a meeting, they would come with me. Now I‚Äôm just under surveillance. I‚Äôm not afraid of yesterday. I‚Äôm not afraid today. But I‚Äôm very concerned about the future. In the way of thinking of these people, they never let go. When they call for revenge, they actually want to do it and they will try to do it even if they have to die to achieve it. I‚Äôm scared for the future because at the moment there‚Äôs lots of publicity around the book and so now I have the cops and many people around me but when that dies down in a few weeks, I will be anonymous and it will be easier for them. Is it true that the police made you give up your dog for your own safety? Yeah, but only for two months. It‚Äôs funny actually because I have a really big dog with a face like a teddy bear and the cops said: ‚ÄúYou can recognise her really easily on the streets.‚Äù It was the period of Charlie Hebdo and everyone was really paranoid. Two months after, I phoned the police and said ‚ÄúPlease can I have my dog back? I miss her so much!‚Äù and they said OK. What advice would you give to a teenage girl thinking of flying out to join Isis? If she wants to help people, she can help people here instead. She can be useful around her neighbourhood. To the teenagers who want to go for marriage, I would say: ‚ÄúOK, go but you will never come back. Your child will never know your parents or your family and never see where you grew up. It‚Äôs hell and when you enter hell, you can never get out.‚Äù Do you feel lonely? Sometimes, yes. For me, there is a before and after this story because my life changed, not only with the cops and security but also because many people came into my life and many others left it because they were worried about being seen with me. I‚Äôve grown up a lot. In the Skin of a Jihadist is published by HarperCollins (¬£12.99). To buy it for ¬£9.99 go to bookshop.theguardian.com or call 0330 333 6846

column4: 'No Diet Coke for you': Islamophobia claim prompts United Airlines boycott
column5:
What happens when you ask for an unopened can of Diet Coke on an airplane? If you‚Äôre a Muslim woman, according to one report, you don‚Äôt get served. And the man sitting next to you gets an unopened can of beer just fine. Tahera Ahmad, a Muslim chaplain at Chicago‚Äôs Northwestern University, documented these allegations from onboard a United Airlines flight this weekend in an episode that almost immediately went viral ‚Äì and led to pledges to boycott the airline. On her Facebook page, Ahmad claimed a flight attendant was ‚Äúclearly discriminating against me‚Äù after she asked for an unopened of soda for hygiene reasons and says was told, ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôm sorry. I just can‚Äôt give you an unopened can, so no Diet Coke for you.‚Äù
When the man next to her allegedly got an unopened beer can from the in-flight service, Ahmad said she was told something even more inflammatory: ‚ÄúWe are unauthorized to give unopened cans to people, because they may use it as a WEAPON on the plane.‚Äù Ahmad said her fellow passengers were of no help: ‚Äúyou Moslem, you need to shut the F** up,‚Äù Ahmad said, in the Facebook post, that she was told by another male passenger across the aisle. ‚Äú[y]es you know you would use it as a WEAPON, so shut the F** up.‚Äù Ahmad did not respond to multiple requests for comment, but Muslim activists took to social media to call the alleged incident an ‚Äúinexcusable‚Äù act of bigotry as other social media users said they would boycott United Airlines based on what they interpreted as open discrimination.
United Airlines spokesman Charles Hobart told the Guardian that the airline was attempting to contact Ahmad in order to ‚Äúget a better understanding of what occurred during the flight‚Äù. Hobart also said United was discussing the alleged incident with Shuttle America, United‚Äôs regional partner that operated the flight. Republic Airways, which owns Shuttle America, did not respond to a request for comment on its beverage policy. Federal Aviation Administration policy forbids carrying on unopened alcoholic beverages but does not appear to have a specific ‚Äúunopened can‚Äù regulation. Ahmad told the Chicago Sun-Times that she received an apology from the flight attendant on behalf of herself and the other passenger, saying that the United employee had ‚Äúacknowledged it was unethical and said he never should have said anything‚Äù. The story of Islamophobia at 30,000 feet went viral just hours after an anti-Islam protest in Phoenix drew global attention following a lethal incident in Texas earlier this month. The standfirst on this article was amended on 1 June 2015 to more accurately reflect the story.

column4: The heat and the death toll are rising in India. Is this a glimpse of Earth‚Äôs future?
column5:
Roads have twisted in the heat. Hospitals are overwhelmed by thousands of dehydrated people, the poor, the elderly and children among the worst hit. Urgent instructions to wear wide-brimmed hats and light-coloured cotton clothes, use umbrellas and drink lots of fluid have been issued by the government. India is struggling to cope with one of the deadliest heatwaves to hit the subcontinent. And its attempt to do so is raising a question for the whole planet ‚Äì how can humans cope with the kinds of temperatures that scientists fear may become ever more common? In only 10 days, the death toll is reported to have reached around 1,800, a 20-year high. The brunt of the burden has fallen on the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, where 1,300 people have died, the highest loss of life due to heat the state has known, according to officials. By comparison, 447 people in the state died from the heat last year. The blistering temperatures may, mercifully, be about to break, as there are signs that the longed-for monsoon may be arriving in the form of showers and thunderstorms in the south. But as temperatures neared 50C in recent weeks, leave for doctors has been cancelled and the government has issued warnings for people to stay indoors and stay hydrated. For many, though, that isn‚Äôt an option. The greatest loss of life has been among the elderly and the poor, in particular day labourers who have little alternative but to risk their lives in the heat for fear of losing their livelihoods.
‚ÄúPeople are dying and suffering, and I think it shows us the vulnerability that exists even in an area that is used to very hot weather,‚Äù said Peter Stott at the Met Office in Exeter. ‚ÄúIt can still have a major impact.‚Äù It is hard to say for sure whether any single extreme weather event is a result of manmade climate change, but this is a scenario we should get used to seeing more of, scientists say. As the effects of climate change take hold and global temperatures creep up, extreme heat events will become more common. ‚ÄúRecent research shows that heatwaves are currently five times more frequent than they would be in the absence of human-caused warming, and the chance of any particular heatwave being caused by climate change is 80%,‚Äù a spokesperson for Greenpeace said, adding that unless efforts are made to cut carbon emissions, heatwaves are forecast to be 12 times more likely by 2040. These trends will push the capabilities of the human body beyond the limits of the cooling systems it has evolved and raise serious questions about the future of food production and farming. Globally, more than half of all working hours outside the home are spent outdoors, mainly in agriculture. As the heatwave in India shows, those who have to work outside in hot conditions are at the greatest risk of heat exhaustion and heatstroke. There are reports that construction workers in the Indian city of Gurgaon had no choice but to continue working all last week in temperatures higher than 43C, in order to earn their wage of 200 rupees a day (about ¬£2). ‚ÄúIf everybody had the same lifestyle as Europeans and Americans, it wouldn‚Äôt be so much of an issue, but most of the food that is generated and grown in south-east Asia, Latin America and parts of Africa comes from small landholders,‚Äù said Mark Maslin, professor of climatology at University College London (UCL). ‚ÄúIn the south of the US people in air-conditioned tractors are farming vast areas in an industrial way, but most of the world works on smallholders producing enough food to feed themselves and enough surplus to provide food for the local towns and cities.‚Äù This problem is exacerbated by the fact that humidity in the areas most affected by climate change poses an insurmountable challenge to the way the human body deals with heat. ‚ÄúHumans can survive for short periods in environments hot enough to cook a steak, as long as the air is dry,‚Äù said Matthew Huber of the Department of Earth Sciences at the University of New Hampshire, who has studied the extent to which humans might adapt to heat stress as a result of global warming. Those same temperatures in more humid climates would kill us. ‚ÄúHumans have a vast and nearly unique capacity to cool themselves by sweating ‚Äì but this only works when the air is relatively dry,‚Äù he added. In very dry conditions, people can work outside in temperatures of up to 40C. But the safety cutoff drops below 30C when you have very high humidity. To calculate the limits in which it is safe for people to work in extreme heat, scientists rely on a measure of temperature that takes into account both the heat and the humidity. This is known as the wet-bulb globe temperature. At wet-bulb temperatures higher than 35C, human skin can no longer itself cool down through evaporation. The US military suspends training and physical exercise when this temperature exceeds 32C. Peak wet-bulb temperatures measured in the heatwave in India are around 30-31C. ‚ÄúWhile this value is less than the 35C threshold, that threshold is the value for a healthy, fully hydrated person in the shade who is not engaged in labour,‚Äù said Huber, explaining why the heatwave in India has been so lethal. ‚ÄúOn the other hand, for poor workers in India, not working can also carry serious consequences.‚Äù
In recent years, several groups have used this measure to make predictions about what rising temperatures will mean for workers worldwide, and to paint a picture of what global productivity will look like as average temperatures creep up. A recent study published in Nature Climate Change estimates that heat stress has already reduced global labour to 90% of capacity during the hottest months of the year. Under the most dire climate change projections, this could fall as low as 40% by 2200. The regions predicted to be worst affected include India, northern Australia and the south-east of the US. But countries that cannot afford technological adaptations such as air conditioning will be affected the most. ‚ÄúAs climate change starts to bite and these heatwaves come, people in poor countries are very vulnerable because they don‚Äôt have another source of income,‚Äù said Maslin. ‚ÄúSo if their crops fail and they are not able to work outside, they don‚Äôt have the money to buy food so they starve.‚Äù The effects of crop failure are also likely to have global repercussions in terms of food security. In 2009, Maslin was involved in a report published by UCL and medical journal The Lancet on how to manage the health effects of climate change. It said that the biggest threat from climate change was to food and water security. ‚ÄúYou have a double whammy: your populations are increasing and the heatwaves are increasing. So the amount of food you can produce is going to decrease and there you have a major crisis,‚Äù Maslin said. He pointed to a Russian heatwave in 2010 that affected global wheat prices. Although numbers are hard to pin down, it is forecast that many people will be forced to leave their homes, making climate migration an international issue. About 17 million people were displaced by natural hazards in 2009, and 42 million in 2010, according to a British government report. People who work outside, in extreme cases of climate change, may become seasonal migrant workers, Huber said. In the short term, policies that could help include instituting international work standards for heat conditions, or even switching to night-time working to reduce exposure. ‚ÄúI predict that access to air conditioning ‚Äì or an equivalent technology ‚Äì will become a fundamental right enshrined in international law,‚Äù Huber said. Nevertheless, such technological solutions come with their own problems. Relying on air conditioning for survival means that power cuts ‚Äì which are common during heatwaves ‚Äì would become life threatening. Much better, scientists say, would be to reduce global warming. The next Lancet commission, a follow-up to the 2009 report, is due next month. ‚ÄúIt focuses on cutting emissions and why this is so important for global health,‚Äù Maslin said.‚ÄúThe reason is that, as far as economists can see, there is no way of ensuring those people have enough money to be protected from the problem of not being able to grow food.‚Äù Stott agreed. Bleak as the picture is, he said: ‚ÄúThe key thing is where emissions go. When we think about the future, it‚Äôs a very different world depending on what happens to carbon emissions ‚Äì and there‚Äôs still plenty of opportunity to avoid those worst effects. The next few years are crucial. It‚Äôs all to play for.‚Äù HOW THE BODY REACTS TO HEAT Cooling The body works hard to keep its core temperature at around 37C. As it heats up, blood vessels expand, sending blood to the surface of the skin to cool it down. Sweating increases in an attempt to cool the surface of the skin through evaporation, though high humidity can make this impossible. Heat exhaustion After several days of heat exposure, the body‚Äôs attempts to cool itself down begin to take their toll. Lost fluids and salts cause muscles to stop working, leading to cramps and weakness. Reduced blood flow to the brain causes headaches and dizziness. The elderly and people with high blood pressure are most at risk. Heatstroke The body‚Äôs cooling system becomes overwhelmed and shuts down, and body temperature can rocket to 41C or more in 10 minutes. Organs can no longer function, and if heatstroke isn‚Äôt treated fast, the brain overheats, sometimes leading to death. Sunstroke This is the most common type of heatstroke, caused by the sun shining directly on the head and neck for long periods. ‚Ä¢ The article was amended on 6 June 2015 to correct the affiliation of academic Matthew Huber.

column4: Manuela Carmena set to lead Spain‚Äôs ‚Äòindignados‚Äô to power in Madrid
column5:
The candidate enters the stadium, fist pumping the air and shaking as many hands possible en route to the podium, as thousands of supporters cheer wildly. For most politicians, scenes like that are an invaluable part of the campaign, a chance to flaunt their supporters in the face of the opposition: but not so for the woman poised to become Madrid‚Äôs mayor. ‚ÄúRallies are one person going blah, blah, blah and then leaving,‚Äù Manuela Carmena tells the Observer. ‚ÄúI refuse to do them.‚Äù To her, rallies simply reinforce the chasm between people and their politicians. ‚ÄúWe said no to rallies. Instead we held meetings in neighbourhoods and said, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre your candidates, tell us if what we‚Äôre doing is good or bad, ask us questions.‚Äô We gave the word to people ‚Äì we didn‚Äôt want to speak.‚Äù Months ago, the 71-year-old retired judge was a little-known figure in Spain. But at the helm of Ahora Madrid, a leftist coalition that ran in Madrid‚Äôs recent municipal elections, the former Communist activist has become a prominent voice of the political and social transformation sweeping Spain. The electoral campaign saw artists come together to back her campaign, flooding social networks with artwork that cast her as a symbol of change, while street artists spread her message across the city. One week before the election, polls said the 10-point gap between the conservative People‚Äôs party (PP) ‚Äì which has ruled Madrid for some 20 years ‚Äì and Ahora Madrid had narrowed to a virtual tie. Last Sunday, as Spaniards cast their ballots in municipal and regional elections, the PP squeaked out a win in Madrid, but failed to secure a majority. The result means Carmena and Ahora Madrid could join forces with the Socialists, wresting power from the PP and into the hands of a group with roots in Spain‚Äôs indignado movement.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been really exciting,‚Äù says Carmena in an interview at the barebones offices donated to Ahora Madrid for the campaign, one street from the Madrid plaza where the indignados launched their movement in 2011. ‚ÄúYou wonder, what just happened? Truthfully, we were unknown candidates, we didn‚Äôt have any money for the campaign. I like to say we ran on the currency of hope.‚Äù Ahora Madrid is not a political party, she explains, but rather a coalition of leftist groups, which includes Podemos and thousands of citizens. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a platform of people who have come together to change things.‚Äù The changes they envision for the city are straightforward, ranging from doing away with home evictions when possible and providing alternative accommodations when not, to guaranteed electricity and water for households that cannot afford utilities, and developing a plan to create jobs for young people and the long-term unemployed. The priority is to tackle the inequality that colours Madrid, says Carmena, citing neighbourhoods where nearly one in three are unemployed, compared with others where unemployment sits at 6%. As mayor, Carmena has also promised to slash her salary by more than half. Those are the concrete aims. But starting with her first day in office, Carmena is promising a radical overhaul in how politics is carried out in the city. ‚ÄúI think for a long time politics established itself in very violent ways ‚Äì rigid, reactive attitudes with authoritarian structures.‚Äù The time has come, she says, to usher in ‚Äúa feminine way of doing politics‚Äù, turning Madrid into an incubator of policies centred around the values of coexistence, caring and non-aggression. ‚ÄúTo govern is to listen,‚Äù says Carmena, repeating her oft-used phrase from the campaign. It comes as little surprise to Carmena that two of the most prominent voices leading the push for democratic regeneration in Spain belong to women ‚Äì her own and that of Ada Colau, whose Barcelona En Com√∫ movement is likely to govern Barcelona. ‚ÄúI think the world is increasingly realising the need to abandon vertical attitudes and move towards a deepening of democracy,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThose are values of the new feminine culture that will likely be the culture of the 22nd century.‚Äù Her views echo the frustrations that emanated from Spain‚Äôs plazas four years ago, when hundreds of thousands of indignados rallied against a political class whose priorities were seen to be out of step with those of the people. It is a movement primarily spawned and supported by young Spaniards, yet in Madrid its leaders include a septuagenarian, laughs Carmena, pointing to the nearly 50-year difference that exists between her and the youngest member of her team. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs curious. It was like all of a sudden they looked at me and said, this generation did things that were very interesting. And in me they saw ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know ‚Äì maybe a caring grandmother.‚Äù She sees parallels between the indignado generation and her own.
